editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: A PLAIN INTRODUCTION TO THE Art of Phy≈øick. CONTAINING The Fundamentals, And Nece≈ø≈øary Preliminaries to Practice.
Whereby the Reading of Practical Authors will be render'd ea≈øie and intelligible to the Young Student.
To which is added, The Materia Medica contracted.
And Alphabetical Tables of the Vertues of Roots, Barks, Woods, Herbs, Flowers, Seeds, Fruits, Juices and Gums, of Animals and things taken from them, of Minerals, &c.
Al≈øo a Collection of choice Medicines Chymical and Galenical.
Together with A different way of making the mo≈øt celebrated Compo≈øitions in the Apothecaries Shops.
By J. PECHEY of the Col. of Phy≈øicians in London.
LONDON: Printed for Henry Bonwicke, at the Red Lion in St. Paul's Church-yard, 1697.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p:
THE following Treati≈øe, being an Introduction to the Art of Phy≈øick, I have, in the fir≈øt Part, collected from the be≈øt In≈øtitutions, the Fundamentals of Phy≈øick, and have ≈øpoken briefly of Elements, Temperaments, Qualities, Sexes, Ages, and the various Temperaments of them, and of native Heat, and of Humours, viz. Blood, Flegm, Choler, Melancholy, Chyle: Al≈øo of natural excrementitious Humours, as Milk, Seed, men≈øtruous Blood, yellow Choler, Serum, the Humour of the Stomach, Spittle, pancreatic Juice, Lympha, and Slime of the Guts; al≈øo of Parts in general, of a Faculty in general, of Action in general, of the internal and external Sen≈øes, of animal Motion, of the Pul≈øe, Circulation of the Blood, Re≈øpiration,
Chylification, Sanguification, the peri≈øtaltick Motion of the Guts, Generation, Nutrition, of things non-natural in general, as of Air, and the like. But I have treated more largely of Meat and Drink, becau≈øe they are of great Importance with re≈øpect to the Pre≈øervation of Health. I have al≈øo treated briefly of Sleep and Watching, of Motion and Re≈øt, and of the Non-naturals, and of things contrary to Nature, of Signs, a Cri≈øis, and of Urine. And to conclude this Part, I have treated of Gli≈øters, Vomits, Purges, Bleeding, Leeches, Baths, Frictions, Ligatures, actual and potential Cauteries, Cupping-Gla≈ø≈øes, and I≈ø≈øues; of Phy≈øical Weights and Mea≈øures, and the way of compo≈øing the various Forms of Medicines.
The ≈øecond Part, which I call, Materia Medica contracted, was chiefly collected from Etmuller and Marggravius.
La≈øtly, I have added, Marggrav's Shop-Compo≈øitions, and a Collection of ≈øuch Chymical Medicines as I judg mo≈øt u≈øeful.

div.head: A Plain and Short INTRODUCTION TO THE Art of Phy≈øick. CONTAINING The Fundamentals, And Nece≈ø≈øary Preliminaries to Practice.
CHAP. I. Of Medicine in general.
div.p: PHy≈øick, both upon the account of its object, and the nece≈ø≈øity of it, is a mo≈øt Noble Art.

It wholly con≈øi≈øts of Practice; for all the parts of it are directed to Healing: And therefore it is an Art, and not a Science; the end whereof is Contemplation: And con≈øequently, Treati≈øes that are made up of Hypothe≈øes, or Suppo≈øitions, belong rather to Phylo≈øophy than Phy≈øick.

But it mu≈øt be acknowledged, that there are ≈øome Di≈øea≈øes incurable, therefore out of the reach of Phy≈øick; yet it is nece≈ø≈øary to treat of them, that they may be known as ≈øuch, and foretold, that the Art may not be di≈øgraced.

It's ≈øaid to be Conjectural only, by rea≈øon of him that exerci≈øeth it, who can only gue≈øs at Di≈øea≈øes and their Cau≈øes, the Quantity and Virtue of Medicines, and the particular Proprieties of the Body; for it has as much certainty in it as many other Arts; and to ≈øpeak the Truth, what Certainty is there, be≈øides the fir≈øt Truths, and Matters of Faith.

It is commonly divided into five parts, viz. Phy≈øiology, that Treats of Natural Things: Hygiene, that Treats of Things non-natural, or Things nece≈ø≈øary for the pre≈øervation of Health; but yet ≈øometimes hurting it: Pathology, that Treats of Things contrary to Nature: Semeiotice, that ≈øhews the Signs of Things contrary to Nature: Therapeutice, that Treats of the general way of Cure, by Chyrurgery, Pharmacy, and Diet.
But Phy≈øiology does not properly belong to Phy≈øick, and therefore ought not to be accounted a part of it; yet becau≈øe it is u≈øually propo≈øed in Treati≈øes of this kind, I will briefly do ≈øo.

Things that are called Natural are ≈øeven, viz. Elements, Temperaments, Humours, Spirits, Parts, Faculties, Actions; and among the≈øe, are to be reckoned ≈øome other things which are treated of in Phy≈øiology, as Age, Sex, and the like.

Elements are the mo≈øt Simple Bodies, of which all other Bodies are fir≈øt compo≈øed, and at la≈øt di≈ø≈øolved. The union or conjunction of the Elements in the Body is called mixture; and a Body made up of the Elements, is called mixed.

The Elements are Four, viz. Earth, Water, Air and Fire. The Chymi≈øts add Salt, Sulphur, and
Mercury, tho' improperly; for in ≈øome Bodies, for in≈øtance, Gold, burnt Talc, Gla≈øs, you cannot find either of the three; and in other mixt Bodies you may find more, as in the Humane Blood, Flegm, Salt, Oyl, Spirit and Earth; and if we ≈øhould allow that Salt, Sulphur and Mercury may be drawn from ≈øome Bodies by the force of the Fire, it does not therefore follow, that they were in them before as fir≈øt Principles; for perhaps they were produced in them by the Fire: Moreover, they are not perfectly Simple Bodies.
Temperament in general, is a convenient proportion of the Elements among them≈øelves, or is a ≈øymetrical proportion of the Qualities.

A Quality is a certain di≈øpo≈øition of in≈øen≈øible Particles, con≈øtituting ≈øen≈øible Parts; it is divided into Fir≈øt and Second. The≈øe Four are called the fir≈øt, Heat, Cold, Moi≈øture, Dryne≈øs; and that which exceeds the re≈øt, denominates the Temperament.

The fir≈øt Quality among Phy≈øicians is termed Actual and Potential; Actual, which is perceived immediately by touching, as Heat in Fire, Coldne≈øs in Water, and the like. It's ≈øaid Potential, when it is not immediately perceived by touching, as Heat in Pepper, Coldne≈øs in Lettice.
The ≈øecond Qualities are Colours, Sounds, Smells, Ta≈øts, Gravity, Levity, Hardne≈øs, Softne≈øs, Smoothne≈øs, Roughne≈øs, Rarity, Den≈øity, and the like.

An equal Temperament with re≈øpect to weight, con≈øi≈øts in an exact mixture of all the fir≈øt Qualities. An equal Temperament with re≈øpect to Ju≈øtice, as they term it, is improperly called equal; for it's ≈øuch a proportion of the fir≈øt Qualities as the Nature of the Mixture requires, whether they are in an equal degree or not.

Temperament is divided into Partial and Total. A Partial Temperament is that which is allotted to
every part; as the temperament of the Brain, Heart, or the like. A Temperament that is called Total is a≈øcribed to the whole Mixture, and is made up of ≈øuch as are partial, as the Temperament of this or that Man.

Temperament is al≈øo divided into innate and acquired. The innate Temperament is that which naturally belongs to a Man; the acquired is that which comes in the cour≈øe of years, by rea≈øon of things non-natural, or contrary to Nature.

All the Parts of the Body, according to them≈øelves are hot and moi≈øt; yet with re≈øpect one to another, ≈øome are ≈øaid to be hot, cold, moi≈øt and dry. The Heart, Blood, Spirits, Arteries, Veins, Lungs, Spleen, Liver, are counted hot; but the Heart is reckoned the hotte≈øt.
Parts that are counted Cold, are the Bones, Cartilages, Tendons, Membranes, Ligaments, Spinal Marrow, and the like.
The moi≈øt parts, are the Blood and other Humours, the Brain, and Spinal Marrow.
The dry parts are the Bones, the Cartilages, Tendons, Ligaments, Heart, Lungs, Nails, Hair.

The ≈øigns of a hot and dry Temperament of the whole, are a quick and hard Pul≈øe, a dry habit of the Body, a brown Complexion, cri≈øped Hair, of a brown or black Colour; for Heat feeds on the moi≈øture of the Body, melts the Fat, and drys up the Humours. The Appetite and Dige≈øtion are ≈ømall, there is a pronene≈øs to Anger, the Sleep is ≈øhort and di≈øturbed by rea≈øon of the heat of the Spirits; Venery is exce≈ø≈øive, by rea≈øon of the Acrimony of the Seed; the Wit is Sharp, and the Body Active, becau≈øe the Spirits are pure. The Italians and Spaniards are ≈øo Con≈øtituted.

The ≈øigns of an hot and moi≈øt Temperament, are a large Pul≈øe, but not frequent nor hard; a Fat habit
of the Body, but not very Fat; becau≈øe that proceeds from Frigidity and Moi≈øture. The Complexion is florid and clear; the Hairs are ≈øometimes curled, and ≈øometimes not, and not very Black; the Appetite and Dige≈øtion are pretty good; the Sleep moderate and quiet, the Mind chearful; and Venery moderate.

The ≈øigns of a Cold and Moi≈øt Temperament are, a ≈ømall and ≈øoft Pul≈øe, a white and ≈ømooth Skin, a ≈øoft and fat habit of Body, the Hair Yellow, and mo≈øt commonly ≈øtrait, the Appetite great, and the Dige≈øtion good; the Sleep very much, a drow≈øie Di≈øpo≈øition, Wit ≈ømall, an unfitne≈øs for Motion, Venery ≈ømall. And this is the Temperament of mo≈øt of the Northern People.

The ≈øigns of a Cold and Dry Temperament are, a ≈ømall Pul≈øe, and ≈øomewhat hard; the Skin ≈øomewhat rough, the habit of the Body dry, the Hair thin, Appetite and Dige≈øtion ≈ømall, Sleep ≈øhorter than in the Cold and Moi≈øt Temperament, little or no inclination to Venery.

But it is to be noted, that you mu≈øt not expect all the≈øe ≈øigns preci≈øely in the≈øe four Temperaments, yet there ought to be mo≈øt of them; and according to the number of them, you mu≈øt judge of the exce≈øs in this or that Quality.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Sexes, Ages, and the various Temperaments of them.
div.p: ACcording to the diver≈øity of Sex and Age, the Temperament is al≈øo divers.
Sexes differ according to the different Conformation and Temper of the Genital Parts.

Sex is twofold, Ma≈øculine and Feminine. The former is mo≈øt commonly hotter than the latter; which appears caeteris paribus, by the Pul≈øe, that are larger and more frequent, by the habit of the Body, which is dryer, by the greater firmne≈øs of the Parts, by the Actions that are ≈øtronger and more perfect, by a greater di≈øpo≈øition to a Fever, and a le≈øs quantity of Crudities; all which, as they proceed from a greater heat, ≈øo they vindicate it. Nor does Womens growing ≈øooner, contradict what has bin ≈øaid, becau≈øe this is rather to be a≈øcribed to the ≈øoftne≈øs and ductility of the Parts, than to Heat: Nor would it make any thing again≈øt us, if we ≈øhould grant they have more Blood than Men; for if it ≈øhould be ≈øo, it would not follow that they generate more Blood; but that they do not con≈øume ≈øo much. They being more ≈øalacious, and more prone to Anger, proves nothing; for one may come from their Pride, and the other from the weakne≈øs of their Minds; tho' we confe≈øs that ≈øome Viragoes may be hotter than Men.

Age is the various ≈øea≈øons of Humane Life, wherein ≈øome notable change is ob≈øerved. They are eight: Infancy, which continues to the third year. Childhood, from the third to the tenth. Puberty, from the tenth to the eighteenth year. Adole≈øcency, from the eightteenth to the twenty fifth. Juvenility, from the twenty fifth to the thirty fifth. Virility, from the thirty fifth to the fiftieth. Old Age, from the fiftieth to the ≈øixty fifth: Decrepid Age takes up all the re≈øt of the time of Life.

The Cau≈øes of Ages is the divers proportion of the Native Heat, at this or that time of Life, by rea≈øon of natural things, or things preternatural; ≈øo that the Ages in all are not circum≈øcribed within the ≈øaid terms of years; but they happen in ≈øome ≈øooner, in ≈øome later; and ≈øome grow Old ≈øooner than others.

Infancy is the mo≈øt Moi≈øt of all, which appears plainly from the flexibility and ≈øoftne≈øs of the Members; all other Ages, the farther they recede from Infancy, the dryer they are. But it is not the hote≈øt of all; for the greate≈øt heat would not ≈øuit with moi≈øture; for it would either di≈ø≈øipate it, or extingui≈øh it. Heat therefore increa≈øes till Virility, and then it is at its height; for the habit of the Body, by continual action of the Heat, is dryed, and pre≈ø≈øes the mouths of the Arteries, and makes them narrower; ≈øo that on this account the thicker part of the Blood is kept from the Parts which it ought to moi≈øten; the Sero≈øities are not purged off, but are daily kept up more and more in the Ve≈ø≈øels, they ≈øuppre≈øs the Fire of the Heart, and at la≈øt extingui≈øh it. The abundance of this unconcocted Humidity is the cau≈øe of Hoarine≈øs in Old Men; and their Baldne≈øs ari≈øes from the defect of the matter of Hairs; which is a fat Vapour, or at lea≈øt, becau≈øe ≈øuch a Vapour does not come to the Hairs, by rea≈øon of a con≈øtriction of the Pores. But in the mean while, we mu≈øt not infer, that Old Men are moi≈øte≈øt; for their Blood does not penetrate and moi≈øten the parts of the Body, tho upon the account of the Excrements that are put off upon certain parts of the Body, as the No≈øtrils, Eyes, and the like, they may ≈øeem mo≈øt moi≈øt.

From what has bin ≈øaid it appears, that the next cau≈øe of Death in Old Men, is too great a Sero≈øity of the Blood; but the dryne≈øs of the Body is the remoter Cau≈øe, and want of Heat the mo≈øt remote; and therefore Old Men are be≈øt pre≈øerved by hot and dry things, as with Wine, and the Spirits of it, and the like; which revive the languid Heat, and dry up the Sero≈øities.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Native Heat.
div.p: IT may not be incongruous to add ≈øomething concerning the Natural Heat to the Temperaments; according to the variation whereof, the Temperament varies much.

The Natural Heat is nothing el≈øe but a quick and confu≈øed Motion of a ≈øubtile Matter, or certain Fire that is not Lucid, ≈øuch as we perceive in Lime when it is ≈øprinkled with Water, in ≈øeveral Chymical Fermentations, in Hor≈øe-dung, and in Herbs heapt up together and putrifying; yet is it hot, and differs only from our common Fire in degree. This motion ari≈øes hence, viz. becau≈øe a ≈øubtile Matter in≈øinuating it ≈øelf into the Blood, cannot move freely in it, and therefore is forced to exert its power upon the Particles of the Blood, and to agitate them confu≈øedly; ≈øo that it has the ≈øame Cau≈øes with Fermentation, and therefore we may well think it proceeds from it.

Fermentation is an inte≈øtine Motion among the heterogeneous Parts of any Body, whereby that in ≈øome ≈øort, is rarified and fired. It is effected in this manner, viz. A ≈øubtile Matter pa≈ø≈øing through ≈øome humid and fluid Bodies, meets with rigid Particles which are not very flexible, which ≈øwim in them, and becau≈øe they cannot accommodate them≈øelves to the Pores, occa≈øion a Confu≈øion; ≈øo that then the ≈øubtile Matter in≈øinuates it ≈øelf in a large quantity to fill the Pores, and ≈øo it rarifies the ≈øaid Bodies; as more Men, for in≈øtance, can be contained in a Room, when they are quiet and lie ≈øtill, than when they move di≈øorderly; this is every where ≈øeen in humid Bodies,
as Wine that is quiet all the Winter, will Ferment ≈øo much in the Spring, as to break the Ve≈ø≈øel if there be no Vent, the ≈øubtile Matter being put into a motion by the approach of the Sun. But all Rarefaction of a Liquor is not properly Fermentation, but only that which is from an inte≈øtine Principle, or an Heterogeneity of Parts, and a diver≈øity of the Pores, by rea≈øon whereof the pa≈ø≈øage for the ≈øubtile Matter is rendered more difficult, and con≈øequently there is no Fermentation in Water, or in another Liquor more homogeneous, rarifying over a Fire; for it boils up only by being forced by a great quantity of ≈øubtile Matter from abroad, and not from any internal Cau≈øe.

The Natural Heat, or ≈øubtile Matter, re≈øides in the Ventricles of the Heart, e≈øpecially in the Left, and rarifies the Blood as it pa≈ø≈øes by. It is kept up by a ≈øubtile Matter, which is continually brought to the Heart, from the Nouri≈øhment, Chyle, and Blood.

We are hotter in Summer than in Winter; for our Pul≈øe are then quicker and ≈øtronger; our Thir≈øt is greater, and we then more de≈øire Cold Things, and Dige≈øt them without offence, and are injured by Hot Things, and are prone to Fevers; and we perceive no ≈øhaking or ≈øhivering after Meals, as in the Winter. We are Colder in the Winter, becau≈øe a ≈øerous Humour abounds then in the Blood, by rea≈øon Tran≈øpiration is le≈øs, and the Fire of the Heart is le≈ø≈øen'd by the Cold Air that is breathed in; but the Dige≈øtion is be≈øt in Winter, and we grow fatter then, by rea≈øon of the moderate Heat; for great Heat di≈ø≈øolves Fat, and di≈ø≈øipates the Ferment of the Stomach; and therefore in Fevers, and in Summer, we grow Lean, and have but ≈ømall Appetites.

Moreover, in Sleep our inner-parts are not hotter than when we are awake, yea they are not ≈øo hot, as appears by the Pul≈øe, that are then more languid
and le≈øs, and by the palene≈øs; and this is agreeable to Rea≈øon; for the Blood does not then pa≈øs ≈øo frequently through the Heart, and con≈øequently does not heat ≈øo much; and our Sweating a Nights does not contradict what has bin ≈øaid, for that proceeds chiefly from Vapours retain'd by the Coverings, and conden≈øed upon the Body.

The Natural Heat is ≈øometimes ≈øuddainly rai≈øed, as by Anger, or Joy, the Animal Spirits on this account flowing oftner into the Fibres of the Heart, move the Blood oftner, and increa≈øe the Fire of the Heart: This Heat is al≈øo increa≈øed by the motion of the Body, and by the u≈øe of Spices and Wind.

It is de≈øtroy'd chiefly three ways, viz. by ≈øuffocation, di≈ø≈øipation, and want of repair; it is ≈øuffocated by too much Blood; as a ≈ømall Fire by too much Wood, or by the Vi≈øco≈øity of the Blood, or the Coagulation of it by Cold or Poi≈øon. It is di≈ø≈øipated by too great Labour, or violent Sweats. It cannot be repair'd when there is want of Meat and Drink, or when the Aliment is weak, or by rea≈øon of a compre≈ø≈øion of the Ve≈ø≈øels, or the thickne≈øs or vi≈øcidity of the Blood. In Old Men the Natural Heat dies, partly becau≈øe it is oppre≈øs'd with Serum, and partly becau≈øe in a long tract of Time it is di≈ø≈øipated.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of an Humour.
div.p: AN Humour is a liquid Sub≈øtance in the Body of an Animal, bred according to Nature, by Meat and Drink; it is twofold, Nutritious and Excrementitious.

Nutritious Humours, are Humours apt to be turned into our Sub≈øtance. They are innumerable; but the chief of them are the≈øe four, viz. Blood ≈øtrictly taken, Flegmatick Blood, or Flegm; Choleric Blood, or Choler; Melancholy Blood, or Melancholy.
Blood ≈øtrictly taken, is the redder and more temperate Portion of the Ma≈øs of Blood; they that have abundance of it are chearful, and comely.
Flegm is the whiter and cruder Portion of the Ma≈øs of Blood, of a Cold and Moi≈øt Temperament. Tho≈øe that abound with it, are Slow, Sleepy, Pale and Fat.
Choler is the thinner Portion of the Ma≈øs of Blood, of an hot and dry Temperament: They that have it in abundance, are Angry, Agile, Witty and Lean.
Melancholy is the earthy and gro≈øs Portion of the Ma≈øs of Blood, of a cold and dry Temperament. They that abound with this Humour, are Sad, Fearful, and Black.

Chyle is a liquid Ma≈øs bred in the Stomach and Guts from Meat and Drink; I ≈øay in the Stomach and Bowels, becau≈øe ≈øome Chylification is made in the≈øe, tho' chiefly in the Stomach; but we ≈øhall ≈øpeak more particularly of Chylification among Natural Actions.

The Chyle is expelled from the Stomach partly by the Mu≈øcles that contract the Belly, and partly by the impul≈øe of the Liver; and partly by the Peri≈øtaltic motion of the annular Fibres of the Stomach, ≈øucce≈ø≈øively contracted from the upper Orifice to the lower. The Chyle being thru≈øt from the Stomach into the Guts, is further elaborated there, by the ferment of the Stomach which it brings with it, and by the Bile and pancreatic Juice, which entring into the Duodenum, and mixt with the Chyle, are fermented together; and together with the Chyle, pa≈øs into the lacteal Veins, which are innumerable ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels,

≈øo very ≈ømall that they can't be ≈øeen, unle≈øs they are full of Chyle; they come out of every part of the Inte≈øtines and Me≈øentery. Ca≈øpar A≈øellius found them out in the year 1622. in di≈ø≈øecting a live Dog well fed. Pre≈øently after their ri≈øe, they aim at the neare≈øt part of the Me≈øentery, whereunto the inte≈øtine from which they ari≈øe is knit; then they go the readie≈øt way to ≈øuch glandules of the Me≈øentery as are neare≈øt to them; but in their pa≈ø≈øage ≈øometimes, many little Branches meeting, grow into one great Trunk, viz. before they in≈øinuate them≈øelves into the gland, to which we ≈øaid they were going; but in their very entrance into the glands, or a little before, this Trunk ≈øeparates again into new Branches, more, and ≈ømaller than the other, which are obliterated in the very ≈øub≈øtance of the gland: Out of the gland there ≈øpring again new capillary Veins, which by and by meeting together, make one Trunk again as before; which being carried towards the beginning of the Me≈øentery, in their march join to them≈øelves, others of the ≈øame kind meeting them, and ≈øo grow larger and larger, and at la≈øt very many enter into the great or middle gland of the Me≈øentery, in the ≈øame manner they entred the ≈ømaller, and ≈øome pa≈øs over its Superficies, and by and by they all empty them≈øelves into the common receptacle of the Chyle, that lies under the ≈øaid gland. This receptacle is ≈øeated under the Celiac Artery, and emulgents at the Vertebrae of the Loins, whence there ≈øprings a Duct, that pre≈øently enters the Diaphragm, with the Arteria magna, where it begins to be call'd Ductus Thoracicus. This Duct having pa≈øs'd the Midriff, it marches further up under the great Artery, till about the fifth or ≈øixth Vertebra of the Thorax, where it turns a little a≈øide from the great Artery to the Left Hand, and ≈øo below the interco≈øtal Arteries and Veins, under the pleura and gland thymus, it a≈øcends to the
left ≈øubclavian Vein, into who≈øe lower ≈øide it opens, ju≈øt there where the left jugular Vein enters into it on the upper ≈øide, ≈øo that their Mouths face one another; but it opens not into this Vein with any large Orifice, but by ≈øix or ≈øeven little ones, being all covered together in the interior Cavity of the Subclavia, with one broad Valve looking towards the Cava from the Shoulder, whereby here is granted to the Chyle and Lympha a free pa≈ø≈øage out of the Ductus Chyliferus into the Subclavia; but their return, or of Blood with them out of the Vein into the Duct is prevented. This Duct ending thus in the ≈øubclavian Vein, the Chyle that it conveys into it, pa≈ø≈øes with the Blood, returning by the Cava into the right Ventricle of the Heart.

The Chyle in the Stomach and Guts keeps in ≈øome ≈øort, the Colour of what is eaten: So Cows and Sheep, becau≈øe they feed on Gra≈øs, have a greeni≈øh Chyle. The Chyle of a Man is mo≈øt commonly of an A≈øh Colour; but in the lacteal Veins, and the Thoraic Duct, 'tis quite White.
An excrementitious Humour, is an Humour that is not fit to be converted into our ≈øub≈øtance: 'Tis divided into Natural and Preternatural; the Preternatural belongs to Pathology.
The Natural excrementitious Humour, is that which has not an inimical quality.

Excrementitious Humours are partly generated in the Blood, becau≈øe our Nouri≈øhment has ≈øome Particles which are apt to become Excrementitious, but partly becau≈øe the Blood lo≈øes much of its ≈øubtile Parts, by being often rarified in the Heart, and by nouri≈øhing our Vital Fire; and on this account, many of its Parts are render'd unfit for u≈øe, and do hurt, unle≈øs they are eliminated from the Ma≈øs of Blood, for the Flegm ≈øtops the pa≈ø≈øages: The Earth, or the Caput mortuum, coagulates; the Water hinders the
inflammability of the Blood; and the Sulphur by adu≈øtion, becomes bitter and acrid.

Moreover, divers excrementitious Humours are evacuated in divers places; and meerly according to their diver≈øity, as to magnitude or figure, in this or that emunctory, and in the particles of this or that Humour, without the help of any fictitious Faculty: And this will not ≈øeem ≈øtrange to any one, who ≈øees that meerly by a diver≈øity of the Pores and Parts, a whole≈øom and unwhol≈øome Herb grow near together in the ≈øame Ground; and one ≈øort of Juice ≈ølows in the Tree, another in the Bark, and another in the Leaves and Fruits.

A Natural excrementitious Humour, is divided into u≈øeful and unu≈øeful; a Natural excrementitious Humour is u≈øeful, when of it ≈øelf it is ≈øome way ≈øerviceable to the Body, as Milk, Seed, Men≈øtruous Blood, the Mothers Blood, yellow Choler, Melancholy, Serum, the Humour of the Pericardium, the acid Humour of the Stomach, Spittle, Pancreatic Juice, Lympha, and the ≈ølime of the Guts.

The Natural excrementitious Humour is unu≈øeful, when of it ≈øelf it is no way ≈øerviceable to the Body wherein it is bred; as Urine, Sweat, Tears, Snot, the Blood of a Woman in Labour, the Blood of the Hemorrhoids, and the Wax of the Ears.
Milk is a portion of the Chyle, ≈øeparated by the glands, into the milky Tubes, for the nouri≈øhment of the Infant.

The milky Tubes are Ve≈ø≈øels properly belonging to the Brea≈øts, and they come from their innumerable Glands, and terminate in the Paps with many holes; they are incompa≈ø≈øed here and there with Nervous Fibres from the ≈ømall rope of the Arm-pit, that the≈øe being in≈ølated, they may be contracted to pre≈øs out the Milk.

The Matter of Milk is Chyle, and not Blood, as many heretofore have thought, and that it was turn'd White in the Brea≈øts; but it does not ≈øtay there long enough to be elaborated; and be≈øide, the Parts are not formed for ≈øuch an u≈øe. Moreover, a piece of Succory eaten before, has bin drawn out with it, and al≈øo the Bran of Bread eaten before: A Purging Medicine taken by the Nur≈øe, is pre≈øently mixt with the Milk, and Purges the Child; and ≈øometimes when it does not the Nur≈øe, Saffron and Burnt Wine, and other things taken by the Nur≈øe, communicate the ta≈øt and ≈ømell to the Milk in the ≈øpace of half an hour, or le≈øs; and the Nur≈øe pre≈øently after drinking a large draught, finds a chillne≈øs and fullne≈øs in her Brea≈øts; which could not be if Blood were the Matter of Milk: Be≈øides, a Woman would con≈øume away if Blood were the Matter of Milk; con≈øidering, that a Woman in Health affords daily a Quart of Milk. Moreover, Fat Women have more Milk than Lean, and yet the Lean Women have mo≈øt Blood, and their ≈øanguiferous Ve≈ø≈øels are larger: But you will ≈øay, that Blood is ≈øometimes ≈øucked out of the Brea≈øts, and that in Women that give Suck, the Veins of the Brea≈øts are more Turgid than at other times; and therefore Blood is the Matter of Milk. To the fir≈øt I an≈øwer, That Blood is not ≈øucked without Violence; and therefore this does not prove that it is the Matter of Milk. Secondly, The greater di≈øten≈øion of the Veins of the Brea≈øt prove nothing al≈øo, becau≈øe this is to be imputed to the greater motion of the Blood upwards, by rea≈øon of the compre≈ø≈øion of the lower Arteries by the Womb.
I ≈øuppo≈øe the Thoracic Duct is the pa≈ø≈øage of the Chyle to the Brea≈øts, from whence ≈øome ≈ømall branches are reflected about the Calvicles, towards the Brea≈øts.

Women with Child have Milk in their Brea≈øts, and e≈øpecially in a few days before Delivery, not becau≈øe the men≈øtruous Blood regurgitates from the Womb through the Epiga≈øtric Ve≈ø≈øels to the Brea≈øts, for the≈øe do not at all communicate one with another; and Circulation refutes this: Be≈øides, ≈øome Virgins have Milk, yea Men and Children; and many Animals which have not the Cour≈øes; but the rea≈øon is, for that in Women with Child, the Child growing big, the Womb is wonderfully expanded, and ≈øo the ≈øanguiferous Ve≈ø≈øels of the lower Belly are pre≈øs'd; and therefore the Blood regurgitates upwards, and thereby its quantity and heat, opens the Pores of the Glands of the Brea≈øts, and cau≈øes the lacteal Tubes to expand more; and for the ≈øame rea≈øon, the receptacles of the Chyle are more pre≈ø≈øed, and the Chyle is more forceably driven upwards, and ≈øo opens more the glands and pa≈ø≈øages of the Brea≈øts, and the lacteal Tubes.

The Milk after Delivery flows more freely; for the Chyle that u≈øed to be carried to the Womb for the Nouri≈øhment of the Child, regurgitates upwards, the pa≈ø≈øages of the Womb being ≈øtopt: Be≈øides, the Infant ≈øucks; and how much that conduces to the production of Milk, none will wonder that reads in Hi≈øtory, that Milk has bin drawn to the Brea≈øts of Virgins, by continual Suction alone.

The Milk at length cea≈øes, either becau≈øe the Child is wean'd, or becau≈øe the Nur≈øe is with Child, and then the Chyle begins to return to the Womb, for nouri≈øhment of the Foetus; and continues this cour≈øe till the Womb being more di≈øtended, towards the end of gravidation, pre≈ø≈øes the Ve≈ø≈øels of the Chyle.
The cau≈øe that Children newly born, Old Women, and Men, have Milk in their Brea≈øts, are the largene≈øs of the pa≈ø≈øages of the Brea≈øts, the laxity of the Glands, and the abundance of Chyle.

Seed is a whiti≈øh Humour turgid with Spirits, bred in the Stones, and Pro≈øtatae, and further elaborated for Generation in the carrying Ve≈ø≈øels, and the ≈ømall Seminal Bladders. The Matter of it is Blood carried on both Sides, from the Trunk of the Aorta, in a ≈øtrait Pa≈ø≈øage by the Arteries to the Stones, and there put off thro the ≈ømall Glands that are only vi≈øible by a Micro≈øcope upon the tubulous Sub≈øtance of the Stones; this is confirm'd by the artificial Divi≈øion and Di≈øper≈øion of the Arteries in the Stones, and Pro≈øtata, and by the Straitne≈øs of them, together with the Wreathing of the corre≈øponding Veins, and the Multitude of Valves, for the≈øe are ≈øo framed, that the Blood may pa≈øs quicker to the Stones, than from them, and that the nobler Part of the Blood may the ea≈øier ≈øweat throught to the tubulous Sub≈øtance of the Stones from the ≈ømall Glands and Arteries every where join'd to it, for the making of Seed. Moreover, it appears hence, viz. becau≈øe tho≈øe that are of a Sanguine Complexion abound mo≈øt with Seed,

But ≈øome will have the nervous Juice to be the Matter of it, for the≈øe Rea≈øons, becau≈øe they perceive many Nerves in the Te≈øticles, and that the taking away of a great Quantity of Blood, does not ≈øo much weaken a Man, as the Lo≈øs of a little Seed, and that after Coition, the Head akes, and that ≈øuch as are given to Venery, are ≈øubject to Di≈øtillations from the Brain on the Spinal Marrow. And la≈øtly, becau≈øe the Te≈øticles are white, not red‚ñ™ To the fir≈øt I an≈øwer, that the nervous Juice is either Animal Spirit conden≈øated, or another Humour: But the Nature of a Spirit which hath Particles that quickly fly away, cannot conden≈øate into a Seminal Humour, and the nervous Juice can be no other Humour, for if it were, it wou'd ≈øtop the Pa≈ø≈øage of the Nerves. To the ≈øecond I an≈øwer, this is manife≈øt to Sen≈øe, and they convey a great many Spirits, which ought to be in the Seed, without which
the Blood could not pa≈øs through tho≈øe innumerable and narrow Tubes which are in the Te≈øticles, nor be changed into prolific Seed, which ought to be made by the various Motion of the Spirits, and the Particles of it, and the working of them among them≈øelves. To the third, fourth, and fifth, I an≈øwer, that it may be ea≈øily under≈øtood that this happens only by the Lo≈øs of Animal Spirits; for the Te≈øticles being emptied, the Nerves proportionably, at lea≈øt tho≈øe which are near, are al≈øo emptied, and then by Rea≈øon of the greater Facility of the Motion towards them, Spirits flow more abundantly into them, and ≈øo the other Parts, and al≈øo the Brain are robb'd, and upon this Account the Fibres are di≈øordered, and the Brain becoming cold, conden≈øes the Vapours, and puts them off on the Spine. To the ≈øixth I an≈øwer, that all the Parts and the Te≈øticles al≈øo are nouri≈øhed with Blood, and yet all are ≈øomewhat white.

Seed begins to be generated about Puberty, becau≈øe the Heat of the Glands of the Te≈øticles being then greater, opens more the Arteries and ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels, and drives the Blood better through them, and the Nerves are readier to carry Spirits.

The Seed is of an A≈øhy Colour in the Tubes of the Te≈øticles, but whiter in the Head of the Epydidimidis, it is made in the Te≈øticles and Pro≈øtatae, and is conveyed by the carrying Ve≈ø≈øels by a very ≈ømall and winding Duct to the Seminal Bladders, wherein it is kept, and further elaborated, till by Titillation the Nerves and Fibres about the Sides of them, being much inflated, pre≈øs out the Seed, which is then very turgid with Spirit, into the Urethra, through the Holes of the Gland that ≈øtops the Seminal Bladders.

The Stones are the Shop of the Seed, and therefore Eunuchs have not Seed, but ≈øome Titillation they have, by rea≈øon of a certain Humour that drops from the Pro≈øtatae into the Urethra, but this is not true
Seed. And yet Eunuchs may have Seed in the Seminal Ve≈ø≈øels ≈øufficient for Copulation once or twice, and may impregnate a Woman.

Tho≈øe which do not indulge them≈øelves in Venery, and live cha≈øtely, do not generate much Seed, for the Pa≈ø≈øages are narrowed by degrees, and the Seminal Matter turns back, and nouri≈øhes and makes fat the Loins and other Parts.

Women have prolifick Seed, if by that you under≈øtand the Eggs whereof their Te≈øticles are full, which being made fruitful, and expanded by the Man's Seminal Air, break out of the Cups wherein they are chiefly contain'd, into the Fallopian Tubes, and from thence into the Cavity of the Womb.

That Humour which Women emit in Copulation, is not true Seed, becau≈øe that is ejected without, about the Clytoris and Orifice of the Privities, and never into the Womb; this is manife≈øt in big-bellied Women, the Orifice of who≈øe Womb is always clo≈øe ≈øhut, and cover'd with a yellow Mucilage. And be≈øides, many Women conceive, and yet, as they ≈øay, have not emitted that Humour: Moreover, it has ≈øeldom the Con≈øi≈øtence of Seed, nor is it Spirituous, becau≈øe Whores copulating often in a Day, are not weakened by the Excretion of it, nor is it elaborated as Seed, for it is not generated in the Organs of it, but in the Glands.

The Furrows of the Womb emit this Humour, or certain Ducts opening into the Sheath from the Pro≈øtatae or other Glands of the Womb, by Rea≈øon of Titillation, and the Con≈øtriction of the Fibres of the Womb, which happens in Coition.

And yet this Humour is profitable, becau≈øe it perpetually moi≈øtens the Sheath, and perhaps it conduces to the Elevation of the Man's Seminal Spirit or Air from the Sheath to the Cavity of the Womb, and from thence to the Eggs to make them fruitful.
Men≈øtruous Blood, is Blood abounding in the Body, which is evacuated by the Womb Monthly.

The chief Cau≈øe is the abounding of the Blood at a certain Time, Heat and the ea≈øie Dilatation of the Womb al≈øo help. That a Plenitude is the Cau≈øe may be proved, for that they that have mo≈øt Blood, evacuate mo≈øt this way, and then ru≈øtic Women, that con≈øume much Blood by Labour, have little or no men≈øtruous Flux, and tho≈øe who have lo≈øt much Blood by Venefaction, have few or no Cour≈øes at all: Men al≈øo who do not abound with Blood, by Rea≈øon of Labour and more Heat, have no ≈øuch Flux. But there are ≈øome Women who Monthly evacuate Blood by the No≈øtrils, Hemorrhoids, or other Parts. Tho≈øe Women that are hot have the Cour≈øes ≈øooner, but in a le≈øs Quantity, and not ≈øo long as tho≈øe that are cold.

Some ≈øay the Cau≈øe of the Cour≈øes is a certain Saline Ferment of the Womb, being gradually depo≈øited on the Sub≈øtance of it, whereby the Womb collecting much Fire in it ≈øelf, is turgid, rarefied, and dilated, grows hot, and evacuates the more fluid Blood, until that Ferment is carried off, and this Ferment they ≈øay is manife≈øt from tho≈øe things which move the Cour≈øes, for they con≈øi≈øt of much volatile Salt.

According to the≈øe Cau≈øes the Cour≈øes begin to ≈ølow about the fourteenth Year, becau≈øe the Body then having in a manner its due Magnitude, the Blood begins to abound, and to be luxuriant in the Womb and other Parts, and hence the Brea≈øts grow big, the Womb is le≈øs wrinkled, and does not pre≈øs its Arteries ≈øo much, and a greater Heat exagitates the Blood more violently, dilates the Arteries, and opens them.
The Cour≈øes ordinarily ≈øtop about the fiftieth Year, partly by the Defect of Blood and Heat, and partly upon the Account of the Narrowne≈øs and Drine≈øs of its Pa≈ø≈øages.

The men≈øtruous Blood is brought fir≈øt to the Sheath of the Womb, and not to the Bottom of it, for it ≈øometimes flows in Women with Child, and if it ≈øhou'd drop from the Bottom, it wou'd putrifie, and injure the Child and its Nouri≈øhment, and ≈øo occa≈øion Abortion.

The men≈øtruous Blood does not ≈øtagnate in the Ve≈ø≈øels of the Womb, but circulates as the other Bood does, for otherwi≈øe it wou'd become venomous, but it is thinner and hotter than the other Blood, and therefore being taken inwardly it forces the Cour≈øes.

About the Time of the coming of the Cour≈øes, Pain and Ten≈øion and Heat are felt about the Spine and Hypoga≈øter, becau≈øe the Blood can't at fir≈øt break through the Arteries. This men≈øtruous Blood is Arterial, for only Arteries lead to the Womb; when it can't be expell'd by the Womb, it is ≈øometimes ejected by the Lungs, Gums, No≈øtrils, or the like. It ≈øeldom ≈ølows in a Woman with Child, becau≈øe it does not abound in them, partly becau≈øe it is ≈øpent for the Increa≈øe of the Womb, and partly becau≈øe Part of the Mothers Chyle goes to the Child.

Yellow or natural excrementitious Choler is a yellow and bitter Humour, ≈øecreted from the Ma≈øs of Blood into the Gaul Bladder, or Porus Bilarius, it is ≈øeparated by the Impul≈øe of the Blood of the Vena porta, into the Glands of the Liver, which it pa≈ø≈øes through, by rea≈øon of the ≈øpecial Conformity of them, with its Particles, as to Magnitude and Figure, and it enters the Branches of the Gaul Bladder, and of the Porus bilarius, di≈øper≈øed among the Branches of the Vena porta, which ab≈øorb the Choler from the Extremities and Pores of the ≈øaid Gland. But I wou'd not be ≈øo under≈øtood, as that I wou'd wholly reject particular Pa≈ø≈øages, for that there are ≈øuch is very plau≈øible, and I hope they will be found out at one time or another, by the Indu≈øtry of the modern Anatomi≈øts.

The Urine falling continually from the Reins through the Ureters to the Bladder, is retain'd in it, until by the Quantity or Quality, it ≈øtimulates to Excretion. It is evacuated by a Contraction of the Mu≈øcles of the Belly, and of the Fibres of the Bladder, whil≈øt they being irritated, the Spirits flow more plentifully into them; and how great the Contraction of the Bladder is, may be ≈øeen in the Di≈ø≈øection of a Bea≈øt; which, when it is va≈øtly expanded, after Evacuation of the Urine, ≈øinks into a very ≈ømall Compa≈øs: Le≈øt the Urine ≈øhou'd flow out when we are ≈øleeping, or involuntarily, a great round Mu≈øcle is placed before the Neck of the Bladder, call'd Sphincter; ≈øuch an one a is at the End of the right Gut, for retaining the Excrement; and therefore to make Water, we contract the Belly and Bladder ≈øo much, as to ≈øomewhat overcome the Action of the Sphincter, which is perpetua Contraction.
The Urine cannot return again from the Bladder to the Ureters, becau≈øe they are obliquely in≈øerted within the Membranes of the Bladder, and ≈øo when it lyes up on them it ≈øhuts their Pa≈ø≈øages.

In a Calf, and the like, all the time they are in the Womb, the Urine is evacuated through the upper Part of the Bladder, but not ≈øo in an Humane Foetus, which either voids it into the Womb, or it is kept it the Bladder all the time the Child is in the Womb.

We make more Water in the Winter than in the Summer, and ≈øo being placed in cold Water, becau≈øe by the Stoppage of the Pores in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration is hindred, and the Serum is diverted to the inner Parts.

Tears are a ≈øerous Humour, flowing from the Eye of tho≈øe that weep: The Matter of them is a Vapour; and ≈øalt Serum, continually brought through the Arteries with the Blood, to the weeping Glands, to lubricate and moi≈øten the Eye, and through them ≈øeque≈øtered
into the weeping Ducts, which are very numerous in the Eye-lids.

Serum flowing in too great a Quantity to the Eye: Al≈øo Collyria ≈øometimes running through the No≈øtrils and Palate, through the weeping Gland, placed in the greater Angle of the Eye, that is very ≈øpongy, and through three or four Holes of the Bone of the No≈øe, are ta≈øted in the Mouth; through the≈øe Holes the Rayes of the Sun enter partly the No≈øtils, when looking on the Sun we ≈øneeze.

Our Eyes water upon the account of a Moat, A≈øh, Smoak, Onions, Garlic, and the like; becau≈øe by rea≈øon of the≈øe, Pain being occa≈øion'd in the Eye, there is a greater Flux of Blood than is u≈øual, and a proportionable Separation of Serum; or becau≈øe, by reiterated Contractions of the Belly, then intervening, the Bowels pre≈øs more the Aorta, and the Blood, with its Serum, is more moved upwards, and for the ≈øame rea≈øon in other Pains; in Trumpeting, Coughing, ≈øneezing, drinking, and the like, our Eyes water.

In Sorrow Tears flow, partly becau≈øe by rea≈øon of a le≈ø≈øer Influx of the Spirits, the Pores of the Eye fall down, and the Vapours gather together; partly, becau≈øe now and then, by rea≈øon of interluding Love or Joy, without which there is no Sorrow, the Blood being driven generou≈øly through the Body, puts off its Serum more largely on the weeping Ducts.

Snot is a clammy and vi≈øcid Humour ≈øticking to the No≈øtrils; the Matter of it comes from the internal Arteries of the No≈øtrils; or it may be a flegmatic Humour pour'd out of the Arteries upon the Brain, and may pa≈øs from thence through the Os Cribro≈øum into the No≈øtrils, and grow thick there by the Cold, or by alternate Expiration and In≈øpiration of the Air, whereby its thin Particles are dry'd up; for the Mamillary Proce≈ø≈øes are hollow to the Ventricles that are
before: And part of it may be al≈øo a Vapour conden≈øed in the No≈øtrils; but it does not come, as is ≈øaid, through the Hole of the Bone of the Skull to the Palate, for here are no Pa≈ø≈øages for it, but all the Humour coming from the Ventricles to the Infundibulum, and pituitary Gland, is refunded through the Membrane under the Gland that is pervious with many ≈ømall Holes, into the jugular Veins that are placed on each ≈øide of the Cella turcica.
If we expire, or in≈øpire ≈øtrongly, the Mouth being ≈øhut, the Snot is carried with the Air to the No≈øtrils from the Palate; and ≈øo on the contrary.
The Blood of a Woman in Child-bed, is Blood whereby the Woman is purged in her lying in. Childbed is the Time from Delivery, to the Purification of the Woman.

The Water of a Woman in Delivery, is that which flows from the Womb at the Time of Delivery: The Matter of it is the Urine, Sweat, and ≈øuperfluous Chyle of the Child contain'd in the Amnion, it flows out when the Child, by kicking, breaks the Membranes, and ≈øometimes a long while before the Child is born; but it is better not to break ≈øo, for by lubricating the Pa≈ø≈øages, it facilitates the Birth.
The hemorrhoidal Blood is a Portion of Blood abounding, which is carried off by the hemorrhoidal Arteries, and it ≈øerves in Men as the Cour≈øes in Women.

A Spirit is the thinne≈øt and mo≈øt agile Part of the Body; the Matter of it is the fine≈øt, that is, the mo≈øt ≈øulphureous Part of the Blood: That there is ≈øuch a thing as Spirit, may be proved; becau≈øe, if you bind or cut off the Nerve of any Part, ≈øo as that the Spirit can't come to it, the Motion and Sen≈øe of it pre≈øently peri≈øh.

Spirit is commonly divided into animal, vital, and natural; but I ≈øuppo≈øe there is but one Spirit; which,
becau≈øe it performs animal Actions, is animal; which moves when it flows into the medullary Part of the Nerve, which ≈øerves for Motion; it gives Sen≈øe when it flows upon the Membrane which ≈øerves for Sen≈øe, and it is vital as it performs vital Actions, and natural as it performs natural Actions; and ≈øo the re≈øt without any ≈øpecific Di≈øtinction. Animal Spirit is generated in the Head only, by Separation from the Blood when it forces thro the Branches of the carotid Arteries, upon the external Sub≈øtance of the Brain and Cerebellum, that is more lax than the re≈øt; pre≈øently the fine≈øt Particles recede from it into the Pores of the Brain and Cerebellum.

The Spirit makes its Excur≈øions from the Brain three ways: Fir≈øt, By the Command of the Mind. Secondly, 'tis expell'd by the Contraction of the Heart, that forces the Blood upon the Brain and Cerebellum; and new Spirits being pre≈øently ≈øeparated from it, force by the wole Dia≈øtole of the Brain, and partly by the Sy≈øtole, the animal Spirits previou≈øly exi≈øting in the Brain, into the Beginning of the Nerves; and this Motion of the Spirits is moderate and ≈ølow, and thereby the Ten≈øion of all the Mu≈øcles is equal; and hence it is manife≈øt, why by every Pul≈øe there is a Concu≈ø≈øion of the whole Body, tho this may al≈øo proceed from the Blood continually thru≈øt into the Arteries. 'Tis manife≈øt al≈øo, why one Arm being cut off, the other grows ≈øtrong thereupon, and why to one of two antagoni≈øt Mu≈øcles the other is convul≈øively drawn, and which way it is drawn, it carries the Part with it: viz. becau≈øe then the ≈øaid Parts are puffed up and extended with a greater Quantity of Spirits. Thirdly, The Spirit flows from the Brain when any Part is irritated; for then, by the Motion of the ≈ømall Fibres of the Nerves, the Pores in the Brain are opened; and ≈øo in Re≈øpiration, in the Motion of the Heart, in the peri≈øtaltic Motion, and the like; wherein
there is a certain natural Irritation, and ≈øo it flows when ≈øome Member being tickled or irritated, is ≈øometimes otherwi≈øe drawn, but then the Irritation is preternatural. But by rea≈øon of ≈øuch an Apertion of the Pores of the Brain, this Efflux of Spirits is ≈øuch, that it does not only fall upon the Nerves of the Part irritated, but al≈øo upon the neighbouring Nerves; and this is the chief Cau≈øe of Sympathy, which is ob≈øerved in divers Parts; for In≈øtance, betwixt the Reins and Stomach, by rea≈øon whereof, tho≈øe being irritated, vomiting is occa≈øion'd; and ≈øo betwixt the Colon and the Stomach, as when that is affected the Patient vomits.

The Spirits ≈øerving involuntary Actions, come chiefly from the Cerebellum, and the medullary Furrows from the Cerebellum, to the Nerves of the wandring Pair, ≈øhew this; and this is the Rea≈øon why, in an Apoplexy, the Pul≈øe and Re≈øpiration do not quite cea≈øe, which is partly performed by tho≈øe Nerves.

The Spirits, in their natural State, being about to cau≈øe Motion, are not fired like Gun-powder in the Brain, or exploded thence: For if ≈øo, Motion cou'd not be re≈øtrain'd at any Time when we wou'd.
The Spirit conduces ≈øomewhat to the Nutrition of the Parts, by ≈øeparating their Fibres, and the Sides of the Pores from one another, and ≈øo by making way for the Blood.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of Parts in general.
div.p:
A Part is a Body cohering to the Whole, fitted for the Function and U≈øe of it; I do not add, joined by the common Life, as ≈øome do, that they may
exclude the Hair, Nails, Humours, and Spirits, which are all truly Parts; for as to the Hairs and Nails, they ≈øhew Life as other Parts do which are nouri≈øhed, and they grow with all Dimen≈øions, according as other Parts do, by receiving Nouri≈øhment inwardly, and by applying it to Parts that are deficient, and not only by placing it at the Root, for the Nails have ≈ømall Arteries, and the Hairs are hollow, and for the mo≈øt part triangular, as the Micro≈øcope ≈øhews, and in the plica polonica they ≈øweat out Blood: It matters not that the Hairs grow upon tabid People, and on ≈øuch as are dead, for in them there is a Di≈ø≈øolution or Colliquation of the Body, which makes the Hairs grow mo≈øt, by yielding an agreeable Nouri≈øhment, viz. a ≈øat Vapour exhaling from the Body, as appears from the Inflammability, the fat Fume, and Odor of them; al≈øo from that oyly and clammy Matter that ≈øticks to the Hairs, if they are not frequently cleans'd. La≈øtly, They are profitable; for, by keeping the Pores of the Skin open, they conduce to the Expul≈øion of a ≈øooty Excrement, as when a Stick is fixt in the Earth, the Earth about it is dryer. On the Eye-lids, they defend the Eyes, and tho≈øe on the Head defend it, and the like. The Nails are to ≈øtrengthen the Fingers, and render them capable to apprehend ≈ømall things.

But the Humours and Spirits do not grow, do not live, nor increa≈øe vitally, but only by the Appo≈øition of new Matter, as Rain-water is increa≈øed in a Tub, and yet notwith≈øtanding the Humours are Parts; and indeed, the mo≈øt noble and mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary, as well as the watry Humour of the Eye, which almo≈øt all allow to be a Part, tho it is not nouri≈øhed and grows.
All the ≈øolid Parts are of them≈øelves white, as appears by the wa≈øhing and Maceration of them in Water, whereby they put off the Tincture of the Blood, with which they are all nouri≈øhed.
Fir≈øt, Parts are divided into fluid and ≈øolid; the fluid are the Blood and Spirits, the ≈øolid all that are di≈øtinct from them.
Secondly, They are divided into organic, and inorganic.
An organic Part is a Part which requires a ≈øpecial Conformation, for performing the Action it is peculiarly de≈øign'd, as the Eye, Ear, No≈øe, and the like.

An inorganic Part is a Part which does not require a ≈øpecial Conformation for performing the Action it is peculiarly de≈øigned, as ≈øimple Fle≈øh, a Membrane. I ≈øay, the Action for which it is peculiarly de≈øign'd, becau≈øe, as to the common Actions, in all the Parts, for in≈øtance Nutrition, no determinate Conformation is required.

Thirdly, A Part is divided into Principal and Mini≈øtring: The principal Part is that which be≈øtows ≈øomething on the whole Body, that is ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary to Life. The mini≈øtring Part is that which does not be≈øtow any thing on the whole Body that is ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary to Life.

The principal Parts (at lea≈øt among the Solids, for among the Fluids, Blood and Spirits are ≈øuch) are the Brain, which be≈øtows Spirits on the whole Body, and the Heart, which be≈øtows Blood on the whole Body; for if the Heart ≈øhould not give Blood, the Brain would pre≈øently ≈øuffer an Eclip≈øe of all its Actions, and other Parts could not live without this; and if the Brain ≈øhould not ≈øupply the Heart with Spirits, whereby it is ≈øucce≈ø≈øively con≈øtringed, Death would ≈øoon follow. The other Parts mini≈øter, e≈øpecially tho≈øe which carry, for in≈øtance, the Veins, Arteries, and Nerves: The Stomach, Liver, Lungs, and Stones, are fal≈øly accounted by ≈øome, principal Parts, for they do not ≈øupply any thing that is ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary to Life; for we live many Days fa≈øting, or only with nouri≈øhing Gly≈øters, and divers know how
to ≈øtop their Breath a great while, and the Liver ≈øupplies no more than other Parts, and the Te≈øticles, tho they make Life more perfect, yet are not ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary to Life, as is evident in Eunuchs and Geldings.

Fourthly, A Part is wont to be divided by the Schools, into ≈øimilar and di≈ø≈øimilar. A ≈øimilar is ≈øuch an one whereof all the Parts appear, at fir≈øt View, of the ≈øame Sub≈øtance. A di≈ø≈øimilar is ≈øuch an one whereof all the Parts do not appear, at fir≈øt View, of the ≈øame Sub≈øtance. I ≈øay, at fir≈øt View, becau≈øe otherwi≈øe, many that are wont to be reckon'd ≈øimilar, are not ≈øuch, for there are very few wherein you ≈øhall not ob≈øerve a diver≈øe Sub≈øtance.

A Bone, a Cartilage, a Fibre, a Membrane, the Cuticle, Skin, Hair, Fle≈øh, a Tendon, a Gland, Fat, a Nerve, an Artery, a Vein, lymphatic Ve≈ø≈øels, the lacteal Veins, and the like, are counted ≈øimilar Parts.

Fifthly, a Part is divided into ≈øpermatic, ≈øanguine, and mixt; a ≈øpermatic Part is wont to be defined a Part, who≈øe Matter is wholly, in its fir≈øt Formation, Seed. A ≈øanguineous Part is a Part, who≈øe Matter is wholly, in its fir≈øt Formation, Blood. A mixt Part is a Part, which is made, in its fir≈øt Formation, of an equal Portion of Blood and Seed. I ≈øay, in its fir≈øt Formation, becau≈øe it is certain, that in the adult they chiefly con≈øi≈øt of Blood, wherewith they are all nouri≈øhed.

A Bone, a Cartilage, a Nerve, a Fibre, a Tendon, a Membrane, an Artery, a Vein, the Marrow of the Brain, the Hairs, Nails, and the like, are counted ≈øpermatic: Al≈øo the fourfold Fle≈øh, viz. the Fle≈øh of the Mu≈øcles, which is generated of Blood, lightly concreted, and is red and fibrous: The Fle≈øh, or Parenchyma of the Vi≈øcera, which is the proper Sub≈øtance of each of them, as of the Reins, Spleen, Liver, and Lungs; the Ve≈ø≈øels whereof it ≈øtrengthens, and fills up
their void Spaces, the particular Fle≈øh of every membranous Part, as that of the Stomach, Inte≈øtines, Womb, Bladder, and the like. La≈øtly, the glandulous Fle≈øh, which con≈øtitutes the Glands. The Fle≈øh is counted mixt, but whether all the Parts of it are ≈øuch, ≈øo as that ≈øome of them are only compounded of Seed, and others only of Blood, and others of equal Parts of both, I much doubt.

Sixthly, A Part is wont to be divided, from its Office, into animal, vital, and natural: An animal Part is a Part that is principally de≈øign'd for the performing animal Functions, ≈øuch are the animal Spirit, the Brain, ≈øpinal Marrow, Nerves, Eye, Ear, No≈øe, Tongue, with the Palate, the membranous, and nervous Parts, and the like, which conduce to animal Actions.
A vital Part is a Part principally contrived for vital Functions; ≈øuch are the Heart and Lungs.
A natural Part is a Part principally contrived for natural Functions; Such are the Stomach, Guts, Liver, Spleen, Pancreas, Genital Parts, and the like.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of a Faculty in general, and of the Species of it.
div.p: A Faculty in general, is an internal Principle that formally produces Actions.

Three more general are commonly allowed, viz. The animal Faculty, the vital Faculty, and the natural Faculty; but I allow only two of them, viz. the animal Faculty, and the natural, as every Action that is not animal, is truly natural.

An animal Faculty is a Faculty producing animal Actions: This is wont to be ≈øubdivided, as the animal
Action, into the ≈øen≈øitive, appetitive, and motive Faculty; and the ≈øen≈øitive again into external and internal: But all the≈øe do not differ really among them≈øelves, and a parte rei, are the very Soul, con≈øidered as the Efficient of this or that Operation.

The natural Faculty is a Faculty producing natural Actions: It is as various as natural Actions are, and is a parte rei, Blood and Spirits, and other Di≈øpo≈øitions of the Parts, as to Magnitude, Figure, and the like, as they produce natural Actions.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of Action in general, and its Species, but e≈øpecially of the internal and external Sen≈øes.
div.p: ACtion in general is a certain Operation, which is produced in us, either by the Mind or Body: It is divided into animal and natural. An animal Action is an Action that is produced by the Soul, and is fivefold, viz. the Under≈øtanding, the Will, Sen≈øe, ≈øen≈øitive Appetite, and animal Motion.
Sen≈øe is twofold, external and internal. Internal is threefold, viz. common Sen≈øe, Fancy, and Memory. External is fivefold, viz. Sight, Hearing, Ta≈øting, Smelling, and Touching.

All the≈øe animal Actions are not really di≈øtingui≈øhed from the Soul, nor con≈øequently among them≈øelves; for the Under≈øtanding is the Soul, as it independently, from the Body, produces certain Thoughts; and the Will is the Soul, as without Dependence on the Body, it exerci≈øes tho≈øe Affections, which we call the Operations of Will; and the Sen≈øe is the Soul, as it knows ≈øome things by means of a corporeal Organ; and it is internal, if the Organ of it is the Brain, and external
if any other Part be the Organ: It is Sight, if the Organ of it be the Eye; and Hearing, if the Organ of it be the Ear: It is the common Sen≈øe, as in the Brain, but e≈øpecially in the middle Part of the Medulla oblongata, it perceives whatever moves the Organs of the external Sen≈øes; this is only conver≈øant about things pre≈øent. It is Fancy or Imagination, as it perceives ≈øen≈øible Objects at a Time wherein they are not perceived by the external Sen≈øes, and forms Images and Repre≈øentations of them, otherwi≈øe called Phanta≈øms. It is Memory, as by the Foot≈øteps of the Spirits impre≈ø≈øed upon the Brain, it is determined for Remembrance. La≈øtly, The ≈øen≈øitive Appetite is the Soul, as upon occa≈øion of a certain Motion of the animal Spirits in the Brain, it is di≈øpo≈øed to have the≈øe Affections we call Pa≈ø≈øions, for in≈øtance, Love, De≈øire, Hope, Fear, Hatred, and the like: The Action al≈øo, whereby the Soul moves the Spirits, is really the Soul it ≈øelf.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of animal Motion, and of the Species of natural Action.
div.p: ANimal motion is a motion performed by the Will, whereby the animal Spirits which always run about the Brain are in readine≈øs for an influx, and pre≈øently flow into the beginnings of the Nerves, and there protrude the Spirits previou≈øly exi≈øting to the Mu≈øcle, which blow up the Fibres of it, and ≈øo make it ≈øhorter and more compact; and ≈øo the Member into which it is in≈øerted is moved.

Natural Actions are various: The chief are the motion of the Heart, the Pul≈øe, the Circulation of the Blood, Re≈øpiration, Hunger, and Thir≈øt, Chylification, Sanguification,
the peri≈øtaltic Motion, Nutrition, Accretion, and Generation.

The motion of the Heart is Mu≈øcular; for it is con≈øtringed on every part by the duct of the Fibres, it is le≈ø≈øened and grows hard in its motion, in the ≈øame manner other Mu≈øcles do. It is two-fold, viz. Dilatation or Dia≈øtole, in re≈øpect of which the Heart is meerly pa≈ø≈øive; and Contraction or Sy≈øtole, which is the action of the Heart.

Both the Auricles of the Heart together, as the Ventricles of it, have their Sy≈øtole and Dia≈øtole; but the Sy≈øtole of them is the Dia≈øtole of the Ventricles; and ≈øo on the contrary. The Dia≈øtole of the Auricles does not ≈øo much depend on the rarefaction of the Blood, as the quantity of it; for the Blood is forced into them by great Veins. The Dia≈øtole was before the Sy≈øtole, or otherwi≈øe there would have been no Sy≈øtole; and it partly depends upon the quantity of the Blood, and partly upon the fermentation and rarefaction of it by ≈øome ≈øubtile matter in the Heart, whereby the ≈øides of the Heart are expanded. The Sy≈øtole of the Heart is made by the influx of the Animal Spirits.

The Pul≈øe is an alternate dilatation and con≈øtriction of the Artery, by rea≈øon of the Bloods being forced into the Arteries. There are at lea≈øt two Thou≈øand Pul≈øes in an hours time, in every healthy Man, as any one may find by numbering them; but they are much altered by the Pa≈ø≈øions of the Mind: They are quick in People that are angry, and in tho≈øe that are chearful; and when we are labouring and running: They are ≈ølower in ≈øuch as are ≈øorrowful fearful, and the like. In Children the Pul≈øe is quick, becau≈øe the Heart is tender, and ≈øoon irritated, and their Arteries are ea≈øily dilated, and their Blood is thin, and ≈øoon rarifies.

The Circulation of the Blood is a motion whereby the Blood continually flows thro' the Arteries from the Heart, and returns to it again by the Veins. This
Circulation of the Blood is ≈øo obvious, that none needs doubt of it; for in bleeding in the Arm, a Quart of Blood, yea, the whole Ma≈øs may be drawn away, and it cannot be ≈øuppo≈øed that ≈øo much Blood was contained in the Arm. Circulation al≈øo is manife≈øt from the Valves of the Veins, which are ≈øo di≈øpo≈øed as to remit the Blood to the Heart, but not on the contrary.

The manner of Circulation is as follows; the Blood is carried from the Vena cava, a≈øcending and de≈øcending, to the right Auricle of the Heart, and thence to the right Ventricle of the Heart, and after it has been rarified in this Ventricle, it is conveyed into the Artery of the Lungs, and from thence into the Vein of the Lungs, and the left Auricle of the Heart, and ≈øo into the left Ventricle of the Heart, and then, after another Rarefaction of it there, it is driven into the Arteria Aorta a≈øcending, and de≈øcending, and di≈øper≈øed thro' the whole Body; and from thence again it is carried as before, thro' the corre≈øponding Branches of the Vena cava, into the right Auricle of the Heart immediately, by Ino≈øculation of the Branches, and Tran≈øudation from the Artery, into the adjoyning Vein, or mediately thro the middle Fle≈øh, betwixt the veiny and arterial Branches, and thro' the Sinus's and their Branches in the Brain, where the Blood is ab≈øorbed from the Carotide and vertebral Arteries; and from the≈øe it is carried to the Juguiars.

It is manife≈øt that the Blood circulates thro' the Fle≈øh, becau≈øe, when it is pre≈ø≈øed, it grows white, the Blood then flying away; but when that returns, it looks red as before. Moreover, in blu≈øhing, the Face looks red, the Blood flying to it. The Blood enters the Fle≈øh by the fine ≈øimple and porous Tunics of the capillary Arteries, or thro' the Extremities of them.

In a Foetus the Blood is otherwi≈øe circulated; namely, in part, from the Vena cava, thro' the foramen
ovale, it pa≈ø≈øes into the Vein of the Lungs, nor does all pa≈øs thro' the right Ventricle of the Heart, but enters from the Artery of the Lungs into the Aorta, a membranaceous Tube being ≈øtretched from that to this, and ≈øo it does not pa≈øs again thro' the left Ventricle of the Heart. Another part goes the ordinary way. This other Motion of the Blood is rather in a Foetus than tho≈øe that are born; in whom, after ≈øome Days, the ≈øaid Pa≈ø≈øages are ≈øhut.
The End of Circulation is the Nutrition of the Parts, the heating of the Body, and the Generation of the vital and animal Spirits, and to pre≈øerve the Blood from Coagulation.

A certain Time cannot be ≈øet for the Circulation of the Blood, for it is le≈øs in hot People than in cold; becau≈øe in the≈øe, by rea≈øon of a quicker Rarefaction of the Blood, the Heart is ≈øooner irritated to con≈øtriction, whereby the Blood is driven out. The Time is al≈øo le≈øs in ≈øuch as are in Motion, than in tho≈øe that are quiet; becau≈øe in ≈øuch, by a Contraction of the Mu≈øcles, the Ve≈ø≈øels are, by turns, more ≈øtraitned, and the Blood flows quicker. Lower thinks the Blood circulates in an Hour. The Quickne≈øs of the Circulation of the Blood appears hence, viz. if one of the Carotide Arteries be only cut, all the Blood will flow out in the 12th. Part of an Hour, and if ≈øo, how ≈øoon would it run out if the Aorta were cut?

Re≈øpiration is a Motion, whereby the Air is alternately drawn into the Lungs, and expelled out: It con≈øi≈øts of In≈øpiration and Expiration. In≈øpiration is partly made by the Dilatation of the Brea≈øt, and partly by the ela≈øtick Force of the Air, and partly by the Pre≈ø≈øure which it has from the Weight of the incumbent Atmo≈øphere. The Brea≈øt is dilated chiefly by the internal and external interco≈øtal Mu≈øcles. Expiration is made by the Con≈øtriction of the Brea≈øt and Lungs, al≈øo by the Heat and Rarefaction of the Air in the Lungs.
Re≈øpiration is a ≈øpontaneous Action, becau≈øe it is perform'd when we know nothing of it, but it is it ≈øome ≈øort voluntary, becau≈øe we can quicken or retard it as we will.

The chief End of Re≈øpiration is Voice; to perform which there is need of Air: Be≈øides, by this means ≈øome fuliginous and adu≈øt Particles are carried off. Tho≈øe who≈øe Lungs do not move freely, as crooked People, and the like, are ≈øubject to Con≈øumptions; becau≈øe their Lungs not being ≈øufficiently dilated and contracted, cannot well free them≈øelves from the fuliginous Vapours of the Blood, and other acrid and gro≈øs Particles, upon which account they are ≈øubject to Ob≈øtructions, and at length to Corruption.

Divers can continue under Water a notable while without breathing, becau≈øe they know how to fill them≈øelves with Air before, and becau≈øe they are le≈øs hot; but ≈øome ≈øay that they have a way of putting their Hands to their Mouth, and ≈øo to ≈øeparate the Air from the Water.

Hy≈øteric Women are ≈øaid to live a long while without breathing, yet I ≈øuppo≈øe they do breath, tho the Standers by do not perceive it, or at lea≈øt, the Air pa≈ø≈øes of its own accord, into their Lungs, and out again, and this perhaps may ≈øuffice for them.
The Motion of the Brain is the con≈øtant Motion of it made alternately by the Sy≈øtole and Dia≈øtole, according to its Sub≈øtance, and independent from the Meninges.
Hunger is a trouble≈øome Sen≈øe of Vellication in the Stomach, whereby we are di≈øpo≈øed to crave for ≈øome ≈øolid thing to take it off. This Vellication proceeds from an Acid in the Stomach.
We are more hungry in the Winter than in the Summer; becau≈øe then the Ferment of the Stomach is more acrid, and, by rea≈øon of le≈øs Tran≈øpiration, more plentiful.

That an Acid is the Cau≈øe of Hunger is proved, becau≈øe Acids increa≈øe it, and re≈øtore it when it is lo≈øt, and tho≈øe things take it away, which de≈øtroy or attemperate an Acid; for in≈øtance, Crabs-eyes, Hartshorn calcined, Pear's, fat things, Spirit of Wine, and the like: If Hunger be continued long, it at length le≈ø≈øens of its own accord, becau≈øe the Acid is dried up, or overwhelmed by other Humours drawn from the Stomach.

Some think that Hunger is occa≈øioned by Suction, whereby the Veins ≈øuck from the Liver, the Liver from the Guts, the Guts from the Stomach; but this is ≈øo vain, that it is ≈øcarce worth refuting, for there is no Suction in the Parts, much le≈øs ≈øuch a continual one.
Thir≈øt is a trouble≈øome Sen≈øe of Vellication in the Mouth and Jaws, whereby we are di≈øpo≈øed to crave for ≈øome liquid thing to take it off; the Cau≈øe is Siccity, or a ≈øalt Humour or Vapour.

We ≈øometimes put off Thir≈øt by holding in our Mouths a leaden Bullet, or the like, not becau≈øe Humidity flows from the≈øe, but becau≈øe, by the Motion of them and the Tongue, the ≈øalivary Ducts are more opened, and the Spittle flows out.
Liquid things take off Thir≈øt, by moi≈øtening and diluting the ≈øaline Particles.
Spirit of Wine quenches the Thir≈øt of Travellers at the Beginning, by opening the ≈øalivary Ducts, and by helping the Propul≈øion of Moi≈øture, but it afterwards increa≈øes it.
Chilification is the Conver≈øion of Meat and Drink into Chile; it is chiefly made in the Stomach and Guts, but it begins in the Mouth.

The efficient Cau≈øe of Chilification is partly Spittle, but e≈øpecially ≈øome acid Humour. It is made in the following manner: Hard Meat is fir≈øt chewed by the Teeth, and often turned about in the Mouth by the Motion of the Tongue, and by the Jaws and Lips,
and is moi≈øtened with Spittle, and then is conveyed to the Stomach, partly by the Weight of it, and partly by the Contraction of the annular Fibres of the Oefophagus. If the Meat is ≈øolid, it is ≈ølowly di≈ø≈øolved in the Stomach; but if it is liquid, it is ≈øoon dige≈øted. The Stomach pre≈øently embraces the Meat on every ≈øide with its Fibres, and both its Orifices, at lea≈øt the upper, is ≈øomewhat contracted, but both of them are ≈øomewhat ≈øhut, even when the Stomach is empty, le≈øt any thing ≈øhould regurgitate from the Guts to the Mouth, or the indige≈øted Meat ≈øhould fall into the Guts. This Clo≈øure is made by many carnous and nervous Fibres, wherewith both Orifices are compo≈øed in the manner of a nervous and carnous Ring, the Meat being included in the Stomach, is impregnated with Spittle, and the acid Humour that ≈øweats out of the Sides of the Stomach, and ≈øometime after it is bedewed with the Spittle and an acid Humour, it becomes ≈øpongy and porous in the Stomach, becau≈øe now its Parts are fermented by ≈øubtle Matter; afterwards it appears torn into ≈ømall Pieces, and at length the whole is reduced to the Con≈øi≈øtence of Cream, and then Chylification is fini≈øhed in the Stomach: But all Meat, and every Part of it does not turn to Chyle in the Stomach altogether: but the ≈øofter and finer, a little and well chewed is turned to Chyle ≈øoone≈øt, Caeteris paribus; and therefore that which is eaten fir≈øt may not be fir≈øt dige≈øted, becau≈øe it may be gro≈ø≈øer and more vi≈øcid. Things boyled, Caeteris paribus, are ≈øooner dige≈øted than ro≈øted things, and ≈øuch things as are not ≈ømoaked, ≈øooner than ≈øuch as are: Milk or Broath is dige≈øted in the Space of an Hour, and in a great mea≈øure di≈øtributed: Bread is pretty ≈øoon di≈ø≈øolved, ≈øo are Pot-herbs and Pul≈øe; but Fi≈øh and Fle≈øh require longer Time: That Meat which is di≈ø≈øolved, does not ≈øtay in the Stomach till all be ≈øo, but that which is fir≈øt di≈ø≈øolved is fir≈øt conveyed to the lower Orifice, and tran≈ømitted thro'
it. That this is ≈øo, the opening of many Dogs after eating, makes appear, and we judge that it is ≈øo in Men; but ≈øeeing Chylification is ≈øo various it cannot be limited to a certain Time, for ≈øome Peoples Stomachs are ≈øo ≈øtrong, that the Chyle is perfected in in three, four, or five Hours at mo≈øt; whereas on the contrary, the Stomach of ≈øome is ≈øo weak, that eight, ten, or thirteen Hours are required to perfect Chylification: But generally ≈øpeaking, ≈øeven Hours are ≈øufficient: But the certain Sign of Chylification is the craving after more Meat.

A further Chylification and Fermentation are made in the Guts; for fir≈øt, the Chyle carries to the Guts from the Stomach, the dige≈øtive Humour well mixed with it, and new Spittle, and an acid Humour, continually ≈ølow to the Stomach, and ≈øo a new ferment of it is continually generated, and pa≈ø≈øes from the Stomach to the Chyle expelled; yea, it is probable, that ≈øome acid Humour continually flows from the Me≈øeraick Arteries, as in the Stomach, upon all the Guts that are near it.

Dige≈øtion is better made in the Night when we ≈øleep than in the Day when we are awake, at lea≈øt the A≈ø≈øumption being equal, and other things alike; for in Sleep, the Blood and Spirits, being not ≈øo much carried to the external Parts of the Body, the Stomach receives more Acid and Heat, and is the more nearly contracted, and ≈øo the better embraces the Meat; and con≈øequently the Supper, which is contrary to Cu≈øtom now adays, ought to be a fuller Meal than the Dinner; and tho' the Time betwixt Dinner and Supper, is le≈øs than betwixt the Supper and the next Days Dinner, yet you mu≈øt know, that that which is eaten at a large Dinner, is often not fully dige≈øted before Supper, and ≈øo the Stomach has a double Task.

Chylification is al≈øo better in Winter than in Summer, and therefore we are ≈øooner hungry in Winter,
we eat more, and grow fat; and this Rea≈øon confirms, becau≈øe in Winter the Acid of the Stomach being le≈øs re≈øolved, abounds more.

Sanguification is the Conver≈øion of Chyle into Blood; this is done in the whole Body, but e≈øpecially in the Heart, and in the left Ventricle of it, wherein the Particles of Chyle are much rarified and agitated with the Particles of the Blood.

The Cau≈øe of Sanguification is our Heat or natural Fire, which remaining after the foregoing Fermentation of the Blood in the Heart, in≈øinuates it ≈øelf pre≈øently into the Pores of the other Blood coming into the Heart, mixed with the Chyle, in the Pa≈ø≈øage whereof, when it meets with ≈øome Particles that di≈øagree with it, Fermentation ari≈øes among the Particles of the Chyle, and with the Blood in the Heart and Arteries, whereby they are le≈ø≈øened by degrees, rendred flexible, and di≈øpo≈øed to Redne≈øs.

That Heat is the Cau≈øe of Redne≈øs, and con≈øequently, the Author of Sanguification, none will deny, who ≈øees Quinces, that before were white, Beer, and other things, to grow red by boyling, and that ≈øome chymical Liquors poured upon one another ferment and become red.

But there are ≈øome, notwith≈øtanding, will not have Sanguification to be made by any Fermentation in the Heart, denying that the Blood is ≈øo rarified and agitated in the Heart by a ≈øubtle Matter, for the≈øe Rea≈øons; Fir≈øt, becau≈øe in this ca≈øe ≈øo great a Quantity of Blood would fall upon the Ventricles of the Heart, as would endanger the breaking of them. Secondly, Becau≈øe the Blood does not ≈øtay a ≈øufficient Time in the Heart for ≈øuch a Rarefaction, and if it were put upon a Fire, it would not rarifie ≈øo ≈øoon. Thirdly, that the Heart being pricked, the Blood comes out frothy. To the fir≈øt I an≈øwer, that ≈øo much Blood does not enter into the Ventricles, as to fill them with its Quantity; for the Auricles, which
are as it were the Mea≈øures of the Ventricles, are not ≈øo great; be≈øides, the fle≈øhy Walls of them have their Expan≈øibility, to which, when they are extended, the Heart is irritated, and pre≈øently contracts, and ≈øo there is no Danger of a Rupture. To the ≈øecond I an≈øwer, that it ought not to continue long, becau≈øe the Blood is in a manner previou≈øly endued with ≈øufficient Heat, as we ≈øee Milk rarified, being removed from the Fire, ≈øub≈øides a little, and being put on again, pre≈øently rarifies more; and the rea≈øon why Blood does not rarifie ≈øo ≈øoon on the Fire as in the Heart, is becau≈øe the ≈øubtle Matter, whereby it is very apt to rarifie, is lo≈øt, when the Blood is drawn out. To the third I an≈øwer, that this may be, becau≈øe ≈øo ≈øoon as it comes out of the Heart, much of the ≈øubtle Matter flies away; and therefore, upon the whole, we ≈øuppo≈øe, that Sanguification is perfected in us by Fermentation.

The peri≈øtaltick Motion of the Guts is a Motion whereby the Stomach and Guts are continually and ≈øucce≈ø≈øively ≈øtraightened from the Beginning to the End, and creep among≈øt them≈øelves like Worms. This is proved by our con≈øtantly ≈øeeing it in the Di≈ø≈øection of living Animals. Perhaps ≈øome will ≈øay, that this is a Convul≈øion and preternatural, but I think this ought not to be ≈øu≈øpected, becau≈øe it al≈øo appears in a Dog, a very ≈ømall Apertion of the Belly being only made, which may be done by le≈øs Pain than will cau≈øe a Convul≈øion, e≈øpecially if the Dog be young. Be≈øides, tho≈øe annular and carnous Fibres in the Tunicks of the Inte≈øtines, that have ≈øo many Nerves, ≈øhew the ≈øame; al≈øo the Protru≈øion of the Chyle and Faeces thro' the Guts, which would be otherwi≈øe very difficult, by rea≈øon of ≈øo many Turnings and Windings, and ≈øo be the Cau≈øe of Putrefaction, and ≈ølow Nutrition.
This Motion is made by a ≈øucce≈ø≈øive Inflation, and Contraction of the annular Fibres, by the animal Spirits, and al≈øo by the Retraction of the right Fibres.

Nutrition is the Conver≈øion of the Aliment into the Sub≈øtance of the living Body, whereby the living Body, according to all its integral Parts, keeps proportionably the ≈øame Quantity; and therefore the Re≈øtauration ought to be preci≈øely as much, as the Diminution is.

Nutrition is nece≈ø≈øary to all Animals, not only in re≈øpect of the Augmentation of their Parts, while they are little Embryo's, but al≈øo in re≈øpect of their Con≈øervation after, during Life; becau≈øe their Bodies being in a natural Con≈øumption, or Exhau≈øtion, would inevitably be ≈øoon re≈øolved into their fir≈øt Elements, unle≈øs the Providence of Nature had ordained a continual Renovation or Reparation of Parts, by Sub≈øtitution, and A≈ø≈øimulation of fre≈øh Matter in the room of tho≈øe Particles di≈øper≈øed and con≈øumed.

The efficient Cau≈øe of the perpetual Con≈øumption of our Bodies, ≈øeems to be what all Philo≈øophers unanimou≈øly hold it to be, the vital Heat of the Blood, therein fir≈øt kindled, by the pla≈øtick Spirit continually renewed by the vital Spirit, and by the Arteries diffu≈øed to all Parts of the Body, that they may thereby be warmed, cheri≈øhed, and enlivened.
