This vital Heat continually glowing within us, and principally in the Ventricles of the Heart, con≈øi≈øting in a certain Motion of the various Particles of the Blood, and in ≈øome Degree, analogous to Fire or Flame, I cannot conceive how it is po≈ø≈øible for it to ≈øub≈øi≈øt or continue, for ≈øo much as one Moment of Time, unle≈øs it be maintained by convenient Fuel, which is thereby unce≈ø≈øantly fed upon, and by degrees con≈øumed, for it is of the Nature of all Fire, how gentle, or mild ≈øoever, to generate and con≈øerve it ≈øelf, only by preying upon, and de≈øtroying the Matter wherein it is generated.
This vital Heat therefore, without Intermi≈ø≈øion, agitating, di≈ø≈øolving, and con≈øuming the minute and mo≈øt ea≈øily ex≈øoluble Particles of the Body, mu≈øt be the efficient Cau≈øe of the perpetual Con≈øumption of our Bodies; ≈øo that in truth we have one and the ≈øame Cau≈øe both of our Life, and of our Death; and to ≈øpeak more properly, our very Life is nothing but a continual Death, and we live becau≈øe we die; for we live ≈øo long, as while this internal ve≈øtal Heat is kept glowing in the Blood, and when it cea≈øes to glow, either for want of convenient Su≈øtenance, or by violent Suffocation, the Life is in≈øtantly extingui≈øhed.

The Matter con≈øumed, I humbly conceive to be, for the greate≈øt part, the fluid Parts of the Body, chiefly the Blood and Spirits which are mo≈øt ea≈øily ex≈øoluble, and ≈øomewhat, tho' but little of the Sub≈øtance al≈øo of the ≈øolid Parts; for Experience teaches, that divers Animals, Bears, Dormice, Swallows, and the like, ≈øleep the whole Winter, without receiving any Supply of Aliment, and yet have all the ≈øolid Parts of their Bodies as large and firm, when they awake again in the Spring, as when they fir≈øt betook them≈øelves to their Dens and Dormitories, and the rea≈øon hereof ≈øeems to be this, that their vital Heat being all that time calm and gentle, con≈øumes their Blood and Spirits but ≈ølowly, and very little of their ≈øolid Parts, as a Lamp burns long, when the Oyl that ≈øeeds it is much, and the Flame but little and calm. We have Examples al≈øo of Leucophlegmatic Virgins; who, from a gradual Decay of Appetite, have fallen at length into an ab≈øolute Aver≈øion from all Food, and endured long Ab≈øtinence without either Miracle or Impo≈øture, and yet notwith≈øtanding, have not been emaciated in Proportion to the Time of their fa≈øting; whence it is probable, that in our Bodies there is not ≈øo rapid and profu≈øe an Expence, or Exhau≈øtion of the Sub≈øtance of the ≈øolid Parts, as heretofore many learned
Phy≈øicians have imagined to be made by the Activity of the vital Heat.

It is difficult, if not impo≈ø≈øible, to make an accurate Computation of the dayly Expences of this vital Heat; for ≈øo great is the Difference among Men, in re≈øpect of Temperament, Diet, Age, Exerci≈øe, the Sea≈øon of the Year, and various other Circum≈øtances, that a definite Calculation cannot be made of this Di≈øpen≈øe, no not in tho≈øe who keep to the ≈øtricte≈øt Rules of an a≈øcetic Life, weighing them≈øelves and their Meat and Drink, as Cornaro is repored to have done dayly. We may indeed conjecture, from the ≈øtatic Experiments of Sanctorius, that the Expence is great, for in≈øtance, if fourty Pounds of Meat and Drink be ≈øuppo≈øed ≈øufficient to maintain a Man of middle Stature, ≈øober and of good Health, for ten Days, and about twenty Pounds be a≈ø≈øigned to the Excrements voided by Stool and Urine in that Time, the other twenty Pounds may be rea≈øonably a≈øcribed to in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration; but ≈øtill this is meer Conjecture.

As to the Re≈øtauration, the efficient Principle is certainly the very ≈øame with the generant or formative; becau≈øe Generation cannot be effected without Augmentation, and Augmentation is Nutrition: And I conceive, that Life con≈øi≈øts in, and depends upon a continual Generation of the vital Spirits out of the mo≈øt ≈øubtle, active, and volatile Parts of the Blood, and that Nutrition con≈øi≈øts in Reparation of what is con≈øumed by Appo≈øition and A≈ø≈øimulation of con≈øimular and congenerous Matter. The material or con≈øtituent Principle I take to be a certain mild, ≈øweet, and bal≈øamic Liquor, analogous to the White of an Egg, and they are mi≈øtaken, who think that the Parts of the Body, being in Sub≈øtance diver≈øe, the Parts of the Aliment al≈øo ought to be equally diver≈øe, as if Nutrition were really nothing but Selection, and ≈øimular Attraction of convenient Aliment, and that there were not
required in every ≈øingle Part, a Concoction, A≈ø≈øimulation, Appo≈øition, and Tran≈ømutation of one Matter common to all; for fir≈øt, it is a difficult Que≈øtion, whether there be in Nature any ≈øuch thing as Attraction or not, and to prove ≈øimular Attraction is yet more difficult, ≈øo that the very Foundation of this Opinion is meerly precarious. Moreover, it is evident, that the Aliment common to all the Parts, is ≈øimular, not heterogeneous, it being the proper Work of the pla≈øtic Power ≈øtill remaining in every Animal, as to form all the various Parts out of the ≈øame homogeneous Matter at fir≈øt, ≈øo to augment and repair them all during Life, out of like Matter, by transforming that into the Sub≈øtance of every Part, which is indeed potentially all Parts, but actually none, as out of the ≈øame Rain-Water all ≈øorts of Plants receive their Nouri≈øhment.

As to the manner how this homogeneous Matter is by the pla≈øtic Power accommodated to the Refection of all the various Parts of the Body; mo≈øt probable it is, that this admirable Work is gradually done by Di≈øtribution, Appo≈øition, Affixion, or Agglutination, and A≈ø≈øimulation, or Tran≈ømutation; all which Acts mu≈øt be ≈øucce≈ø≈øively performed, before the Operation can be compleat; for the Succus nutritius being prepared fir≈øt in the Stomach and Guts, and then in other Parts, to that end ordained, mu≈øt be di≈øtributed, brought home, and apponed to all Parts, that need Refection; then from Contiguity by Appo≈øition, it mu≈øt be advanced to Continuity by Affiction or Agglutination, and in fine, made of the ≈øame Sub≈øtance with each Part by A≈ø≈øimulation or Tran≈ømutation, which is the Perfection, or ultimate Term of Nutrition.
Generation is a Production of Nature, whereby one living Creature is formed in the Similitude of another.

Generation is performed in the following manner, the virile Seed is injected into the Sheath of the Womb,
and from thence is elevated a certain ≈øeminal Air or Spirit, which flies thro' the inner Mouth of the Womb, to the Bottom of it, and thence to the Fallopian Tubes, and ≈øo to the Te≈øticles or Ovaria of the Woman. Some think that the mo≈øt ≈øpirituous Portion of the Seed is imbibed by the Sub≈øtance of the Womb, and ≈øo conveyed with the Blood, to the Ovaria, to fecundate them: But our way is the ea≈øier and ≈øhorter, at the ≈øame time the Woman, by rea≈øon of Plea≈øure and Titulation, is wont to emit a certain ≈øerous Humour, which may conduce to Conception, tho' it be not Seed, by diluting and rarifying the virile Seed, and by rendring the Separation of the ≈øeminal Spirit more ea≈øie, and by elevating it to the Ovaria, and ≈øo the ≈øeminal Air being rai≈øed from the virile Seed, that which is gro≈øs remains in the Sheath, is di≈ø≈øipated and ≈ølides out; and that we are generated by this ≈øeminal Air, and not by gro≈øs Seed, may be proved by Superfoetation, or new Conception in tho≈øe that are with Child; for in ≈øuch the Mouth of the Womb is clo≈øe ≈øhut, ≈øo that nothing but a Spirit can pa≈øs. Moreover, this may be proved by ≈øome that generate, tho by rea≈øon of the Brevity and Debility of the Penis, never ca≈øt their Seed into the Bottom of the Womb, which certainly cou'd not be, if the Air alone of it were not ≈øufficient for Generation; and do we not ≈øee that a Cock generates without the Ejection of Seed, and meerly, as I may ≈øay, by touching the Fundament of the Hen with a moi≈øtened Penis, and yet this Place is far di≈øtant from the Ovaria in a Hen; what therefore can conduce to the breeding of Eggs, may con≈øequentto the Generation of Men? This ≈øeminal Air therefore being conveyed from the Bottom of the Womb thro' the Fallopian Tubes, into the Ovaria, there in≈øinuates it ≈øelf into one Egg or more, as they are nearer to its Entrance, or more di≈øpo≈øed to receive and nouri≈øh it; and hence it is, why all the Eggs are not fecundated
at once, and ordinarily but a few; and why not always at the fir≈øt Congre≈øs. The Eggs are be≈øt fecundated, when a Woman is neare≈øt the Time of her Cour≈øes, by rea≈øon of the greater Poro≈øity of her Womb and Te≈øticles, whereby the ≈øeminal Air is the ea≈øier received into the Eggs. The Eggs are contained in membranous Cups like Acorns, and indeed very loo≈øly, ≈øo that they may be expelled out of them by the Breath only. The fecundated Egg being turgid and rarified by the ≈øeminal Spirit, can no longer contain it ≈øelf in its Cup, but falls from it of its own accord into the Fallopian Tube, and from thence, by a ≈øucce≈ø≈øive Con≈øtriction of all the Fibres, it is forced into the Bottom of the Womb.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of things nonnatural in general.
div.p: THings nonnatural are things nece≈ø≈øary for the Pre≈øervation of Health, but hurt it when ill applyed; ≈øuch are the ambient Air, Meat and Drink, Sleep and Watching, Motion and Re≈øt, things to be evacuated and retained. The≈øe things indifferently do good or Hurt, as they are well or ill applyed: But we mu≈øt under≈øtand, that what is good for one, may be hurtful for another, according to the Nature and Cu≈øtom in divers People, whereunto much is to be attributed in the U≈øe of nonnatural things; yea, the ≈øame thing may do good at one time, and hurt at another.

We do not con≈øider Air here ≈øimply and by it ≈øelf, but as it encompa≈ø≈øes us, that is, as it has various Corpu≈øcles mixed with it, and as it can affect us with them: But it generally affects our Bodies, either extrin≈øically, that is, by in≈øinuating it ≈øelf into the Pores
of the Skin, or intrin≈øically being breathed in; and either way variou≈øly, as it is by it ≈øelf diver≈øe, or by being mixed with other things, ≈øo if there is much Water mixed with it, it may moi≈øten us much, and if it be very ≈øubtle, it may heat us much, and if it be mixed with narcotic things, as in ≈øome places it is, it may make us drow≈øy, yea, induce a deadly Sleep: If it be infected with a pe≈øtilential Contagion, or with any other ill thing, it may occa≈øion the Plague, or ≈øome other Di≈øea≈øe.

It is di≈øputed by ≈øome, whether Air or Aliment affects us mo≈øt; but becau≈øe the manner of both is diver≈øe, it cannot be ≈øo exactly judged of, yet it is certain, we are much affected by both, and indeed more contitinually by the Air, than Aliment; for we can ≈øcarce continue a Moment without Air, for unle≈øs it attemperate the Heat of the Blood, it will be ≈øoon choaked; but we are more ≈øen≈øibly and vehemently affected with Aliment, by rea≈øon of the Gro≈ø≈øne≈øs and Den≈øity of it.

If you ask what Air is mo≈øt proper for the Pre≈øervation of Health, I ≈øay, a pure and limpid Air, that is ventilated with whole≈øome Winds, and free from na≈øty Exhalations, from Carca≈øes. and Sinks, and the like; and ≈øuch an one I judge proper for any healthy Man: But when any Quality exceeds its contrary, it requires an Air that is exce≈ø≈øive in the contrary, ≈øo a hot Air is proper for a Man that is very cold, and cold Air for one that is very hot, and for Diver≈øity of Ages, Diver≈øity of Air is proper, for with them the Temperament is changed, and therefore with the virile Age, which is mo≈øt temperate and perfect, a temperate Air be≈øt agrees.

To the Air are to be reduced Winds, Regions, and Stats, for by the≈øe the State of the Air is much changed. The Wind is nothing el≈øe than the Air, togegether with Exhalations and Vapours adhering to it, agitated about the Earth, the Wind is u≈øeful in moving
the Air about, and thereby pre≈øerving it from Putrefaction, and it di≈ø≈øipates Filth that is mixed with the Air. Sailers reckon twenty four Winds, ≈øome twelve, others 16; but the chief of them are tho≈øe four which are called Cardinal, namely, the North, which is cold and dry, the South, which is hot and moi≈øt, the Ea≈øt, which is hot and dry, the We≈øt, which is cold and moi≈øt. The South Wind is the mo≈øt unwhole≈øome, becau≈øe it occa≈øions a Dullne≈øs of the Sen≈øes, and burthens all the Actions and Parts. The North is al≈øo bad, next to that the We≈øt, but the be≈øt of all is the Ea≈øt, e≈øpecially breathing in a Morning, for then it is purer, becau≈øe it breaths from a Place where the Sun is. The We≈øt is al≈øo good, if it blow in the Evening.

A Region is a Part of Earth, where there is a great Difference in the fir≈øt Qualities, by rea≈øon of a more right or oblique Motion of the Sun-beams. Regions are chiefly five, viz. the Aequinoctial placed under the Zodiack, the North lying in a Space betwixt the Circle of Cancer and the Arctick Pole, the Meridian in the Space betwixt Capricorn and the Antarctick Pole, the Oriental and the Occidental.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of Meat and Drink.
div.p: MEat is a ≈øolid and gro≈øs Aliment, that chiefly takes off Hunger; it is ≈øaid chiefly, becau≈øe the thinner Part of it may quench Thir≈øt, as thick Drink may appea≈øe Hunger. How great the Nece≈ø≈øity of both is, and how ea≈øily we are hurt by them, every one knows.

All Aliment is either taken from Plants or Animals, but that nouri≈øhes le≈øs than this, becau≈øe this has a Matter more agreeable to ours; namely, of almo≈øt the ≈øame Aliment and Chyle, and more agreeable to our Parts and Pores; and therefore ea≈øier adheres to them. Minerals do not nouri≈øh, becau≈øe they have Parts too much di≈øagreeable to ours, and cannot adhere to them, by rea≈øon of their Rigidity; but indeed, Chymi≈øts ≈øay, that aurum potabile protracts Life; but if this be true, it does it upon another account, and not by nonri≈øhing; namely, by ≈øtrengthening the Blood, and di≈øcu≈ø≈øing its ≈øuperfluous Humidity, and by rai≈øing the languid Heat in old Men.

Some Meat is of good Juice, that is, nouri≈øhes much; ≈øome of ill Juice; ≈øome is ea≈øily dige≈øted, ≈øome more difficultly; and ≈øome is ea≈øily corrupted in the Stomach, other not, and of tho≈øe which are ea≈øily dige≈øted, and of tho≈øe which are not ea≈øily dige≈øted, ≈øome are of good Juice, ≈øome not: All Meat that ≈øoon di≈ø≈øolves, ≈øoon nouri≈øhes; but all of it does not nouri≈øh much, becau≈øe it may be of an improper Juice; for ≈øuch things as nouri≈øh much, ought to participate of Gro≈øne≈øs and Vi≈øco≈øity, which, Caeteris paribus, are ≈ølower di≈ø≈øolved.
Meat of the be≈øt Juice, of ea≈øie Dige≈øtion, and of the fewe≈øt Excrements, is be≈øt, and the contrary wor≈øt.

Bread is made of various Corn, but the be≈øt of good Wheat well fermented before, whereof the fine≈øt is called White-bread, made of the fine≈øt Meal, the pure≈øt, ≈øofte≈øt, and lighte≈øt, and freed from all the Bran, and this is mo≈øt nouri≈øhing. The next Degree is not free from all the Bran, but only from the gro≈ø≈øer. Hou≈øhold Bread has all the Bran and Flower mixed together confu≈øedly. There is al≈øo a ≈øort of Bread that is cour≈øer, which con≈øi≈øts more of Bran than of Flower, and this nouri≈øhes lae≈øt. Among all the≈øe Kinds,
the Hou≈øhold-bread is the mo≈øt whole≈øome; becau≈øe, by rea≈øon of the Bran joined with it, it does not ob≈øtruct ≈øo much, and loo≈øens the Belly, and moderately nouri≈øhes; but the fine≈øt, and the next Sort, cau≈øe Ob≈øtructions by their Vi≈øcidity, the cour≈øe≈øt nouri≈øhes lea≈øt, but more or le≈øs, according to the Bran: This is mo≈øt u≈øed by poor People, and ≈øo is Rye-bread, which is harder, black, and offends the Stomach.

Of the Fle≈øh of four-footed Bea≈øts, Veal is the be≈øt, next to that Mutton and Kid; of Fowl, Chicken, Capons, Pidgeons, Patridges; of Sea Fi≈øh, Cod-fi≈øh; of River Fi≈øh, a Pearch, a Gudgeon, a Pike. Of tho≈øe things that come from Animals, Eggs and Milk are the be≈øt; of Fruits, Rai≈øins and Figs: But the≈øe that are ≈øaid to be the be≈øt and mo≈øt healthful, are not good for every body, nor does any agree with every body; but every one mu≈øt find out what be≈øt agrees with him: For tho≈øe that have a good Stomach, or labour much, as Country-men, Soldiers, and Sailers, Beef and Pork is be≈øt, becau≈øe they want a ≈øolid and gro≈øs Blood, which nouri≈øhes much, and does not ≈øo ≈øoon wa≈øt.
Fi≈øh are ≈øu≈øpected by many, but unde≈øervedly; for they make good Blood of a moderate Con≈øi≈øtence, and are ea≈øily dige≈øted.

The manner in eating ought to be ≈øuch, that the gro≈øs ought to be eat fir≈øt; for though I ≈øuppo≈øe that there is a Confu≈øion of all things taken into the Stomach, and that the Order of A≈ø≈øumption does not continue long, yet the gro≈ø≈øer being taken fir≈øt, may be ≈øooner worked upon by the Acid of the Stomach. We ought to eat when we are hungry, and when the Stomach is empty; but ≈øome are hungry when their Stomachs are full, by rea≈øon of too great Quantity of the Acid, and in this Ca≈øe the Hunger mu≈øt not be taken off by Meats, becau≈øe it is not natural.

I cannot ≈øay in general how often we ought to eat in a Day, for ≈øuch as are cholerick may eat three or
four times a Day moderately; ≈øuch as are phlegmatic may eat once a Day, becau≈øe they bear Hunger better, and do not con≈øume ≈øo much Blood. Such as are melancholy may eat twice or thrice a Day. We ought to eat ≈øo much at a time as will take off Hunger without burthening the Stomach, or ≈øo much as the Stomach can concoct without leaving Crudities behind it; the Quantity of the Meat is to be varied according to the Con≈øtitution, Strength, and Age; ≈øo one Quantity is proper for Youth, another for Age, another for a weak Man, another for a ≈øtrong Man, another for a healthy Man, another for a ≈øick Man, another for a cholerick Man, another for a flegmatic Man, and ≈øuch a Quantity for one that exerci≈øes his Body, and le≈øs for one that exerci≈øes his Mind: But it is better to eat ≈øomewhat too much than too little; and therefore it is better to indulge the Appetite ≈øomewhat, for ≈øo the Stomach will be accu≈øtomed to bear ≈øometimes ≈ømall Exce≈ø≈øes, and to concoct ≈øomething more.

And as the Quantity of Meats ought to be adapted to the Con≈øtitutions, ≈øo the Quality ought to be ≈øo too, according to the Diver≈øity of Tempers, Age, Time, and Cu≈øtom; ≈øo tho≈øe that are hot and dry ought to u≈øe cooling and moi≈øtening Diet, ≈øo Children require more tender Diet than Youths or Men, and a cooler Diet ought to be u≈øed in Summer than in Winter. Meats boyled ≈øooner turn to Chyle than ro≈øted Meat; but ro≈øted Meat nouri≈øhes more, becau≈øe it more abounds with nutritive Juice, as may be ≈øeen by cutting it with a Knife; for the hard Cru≈øt without keeps in the Gravey, which is di≈øper≈øed in the Broath of boyled Meat; therefore ro≈øted Meat is mo≈øt proper for Labourers, and boyled Meat for tho≈øe that live a ≈øedentary Life.

Drink is a thin and liquid Aliment, chiefly u≈øed to quench Thir≈øt. The chiefe≈øt kind of Drinks are Water, Wine, and Beer. It is di≈øputed concerning Water,
whether it nouri≈øhes; but I ≈øay it nouri≈øhes; for it is not a ≈øimple Element, and many Men live pretty well that drink only Water, and ≈øeem to be refre≈øhed by it; and we ≈øee that Water alone nouri≈øhes a long while, and that Fi≈øh increa≈øe, being kept in Troughs; and ≈øo Plants and Fruits are nouri≈øhed by Water. There are many Species of Water, there is Rain-water, Well-water, Fountain-water, Lake-water, Snow-water, and Ice-water. The be≈øt Water is that which is limpid and Sweet, or rather without any Ta≈øte or Colour, ≈øo that the Goodne≈øs of Water is to be judged of by the Ab≈øence of Colour, Ta≈øte, and Smell. Some think that the lighte≈øt Water is be≈øt, but this is not to be judged of by the Scale; for often ill Water weighs le≈øs than good; but the meaning is, it ≈øits lighter upon the Stomach and Bowels. Fountain-water is the be≈øt, if it be ≈øtrained thro' good Earth; next to it Rain-water, which is lighter, thinner, and clearer, but is wor≈øe, by rea≈øon of diver≈øe Vapours and Exhalations, which are mixed with it. Well-water is very unwhole≈øome, becau≈øe it is counted to ≈øtagnate, and is not agitated by the Rayes of the Sun, and if the Well be covered, it is much wor≈øe That which is taken out of the mid≈øt of a River is better, if it be clear, and if the Stream be rapid. The Water of a Lake is very ill, by rea≈øon of the Stagnation. Wor≈øt of all is Ice or Snow-Water; for it is very impure and crude. In ≈øhort, the be≈øt is the pure, clear, and ≈øubtle Water; which being ≈øet on the Fire, ≈øoon heats, and taken thence, is ≈øoon cool. Let the Fountain be ≈øituate towards the Ea≈øt, and run to the North. The Water which runs on pure Earth is better than ≈øuch as runs upon Stones.

It is good for hot, fat, and fle≈øhy Men, and mixed with Wine for ≈øuch as u≈øe much Labour and Exerci≈øe: And tho' it does not nouri≈øh much, yet it refre≈øhes, and is a Vehicle for the Food; it excites Appetite, and
opportunely given in burning Fevers, it does good; for it is very contrary to the Nature of a Fever, for it refre≈øhes and moi≈øtens the Body; but it is bad for ≈øuch as have weak Stomachs, and that are troubled with Convul≈øions. Ill Water is corrected by beaten Pepper, or with Ani≈øe-≈øeeds, and for ≈øick Men boyl therewith Cinnamon, and the like. Honey-Water or Metheglin has great Vertues, it takes away Thir≈øt, cures cold Infirmities of the Brain, Nerves, and Joints. It is good again≈øt Coughs, cuts and expells gro≈øs Flegm, moves the Body, and purges the Pa≈ø≈øages of the Urine.

Wine is expre≈ø≈øed from the Grape. There are various Differences of it according to the Colour, Smell, Gro≈ø≈øne≈øs, Tenuity, and Age. Wine is hot and dry; the be≈øt Wine is that which ta≈øtes rough, and ≈øweeti≈øh. Sweet Wine nouri≈øhes much, is a Friend to the Brea≈øt, but ≈øoon increa≈øes Choler: Rough Wine, on the contrary, is injurious to the Brea≈øt, and binds much: Fragrant Wine refre≈øhes the Spirits much, but afterwards it di≈øorders the Head. Yellow Wine is hotter than white; it is aperitive, and forces Urine. Red Wine ≈øtrengthens the Stomach, and other Parts, and makes laudable Blood; but if it be gro≈øs, it breeds gro≈øs Blood, nouri≈øhes more, and cau≈øes Ob≈øtructions. That which is thin is more aperitive than that which is gro≈øs, it ≈øooner pa≈ø≈øes, and does not nouri≈øh ≈øo much. New Wine is not ≈øo hot as old, but generates Wind, unle≈øs it loo≈øen the Belly. Old Wine di≈øturbs the Head: Rheni≈øh Wine, by rea≈øon of its great Tenuity and Crudity, ≈øtirs up the Humours into a Flux, and ≈øeparates them from the Ma≈øs, and occa≈øions the Gout.

Of all the Liquors we drink, Wine may ju≈øtly claim the Superiority; for it is more whole≈øome, and by rea≈øon of its ≈øubtle and penetrating Sub≈øtance, it mixes better with the Ma≈øs than Water and other Drinks: Be≈øides, it is very plea≈øant and grateful to the Pallate, it re≈øtores the radical Moi≈øture, and chears the Heart, and is
the mo≈øt certain Prop and Maintainance of our Life; and therefore our Fore-fathers called the Vine Vitis, qua≈øi vita, as if it were the Tree of Life: But the U≈øe thereof is to be regulated by the≈øe 12 following In≈øtructions; 1≈øt. When the Wine is ≈øtrong and full of Spirit, we mu≈øt always mix Water therewith; 2dly. Never drink Wine after Dinner nor Supper, till the Concoction of the Food be ended; for then it helps Nouri≈øhment, penetrating more ea≈øily the Body; whereas at fir≈øt it will hinder Dige≈øtion. 3dly. You mu≈øt have a care that you do not drink Wine cooled with Snow or Ice-Water, for it is very pernicious to the Brain, Sinews, Brea≈øt, Stomach, Kidneys, and Bladder. 4thly. You mu≈øt avoid drinking Wine fa≈øting, becau≈øe it troubles the Under≈øtanding, occa≈øions the Cramp, and is exceeding hurtful to the Brain and Nerves. 5thly. It is not convenient to drink a large Quantity of thin Wine after moi≈øt Fruit. 6thly. If at the ≈øame Table both ≈øtrong and ≈ømall Wine are u≈øed, begin with the ≈ømall, re≈øerving the ≈øtrong for the la≈øt, which comforts the Mouth of the Stomach, and helps Dige≈øtion. 7thly. By how much the Food is more cold and gro≈øs, by ≈øo much the more need is there of ≈øtrong Wine: But when the Food is more ≈øubtle, hot, and dige≈øtable, let the Wine be weak; and therefore ≈øuch as feed on Beef and Fi≈øh are to drink ≈øtronger Wine than ≈øuch as feed on Pullets, and the like. 8thly. Such as u≈øe much Wine, ought not to eat much, for Wine ≈øerves in≈øtead of Meat and Drink; and therefore Nature cannot ea≈øily dige≈øt them both. 9thly. Wine that is weaken'd with Water is whole≈øomer than that which is naturally weak; for the later more ea≈øily putrifies. 10thly. Such as have a weak Brain and hot Stomach, and dwell in ≈øultry Countries, ought to drink a little Wine, mixing Water therewith: But if cold, more Wine and le≈øs Water will not be ami≈øs. 11thly. You mu≈øt ob≈øerve the Sea≈øon
of the Year, for in Winter drink very ≈øparingly, but ≈øtrong Wine; in Summer more largely, but ≈ømall and mixed with Water. 12thly. You mu≈øt con≈øider the Age, for as Wine is very bad for Children, ≈øo it is mo≈øt proper for old Men, ≈øeeing that it qualifies and allays their cold Complexion; and therefore Plato denies Wine to Children, gives young Men leave to drink it moderately, and allows old Men a more plentiful U≈øe thereof, ≈øaying, that young Men, before they are twenty two Years old ought not to drink any Wine, becau≈øe that will add Fire to their Fire.

Good Wine ought to be clean, pure, and clear; it mu≈øt be of an excellent Odour, for ≈øuch Wines increa≈øe the ≈øubtle Spirits, nouri≈øh excellently, and breed good Blood; it mu≈øt ta≈øte plea≈øantly, but mo≈øt not be ≈øharp nor ≈øweet; for if ≈øweet, it inflames, ob≈øtructs, and fills the Head; if ≈øharp or ≈øowre, it hurts the Nerves and Stomach, and begets Crudities.

Wine, if u≈øed di≈øcreetly and moderately, does communicate innumerable Benefits, both to Body and Mind; for as to the Mind, it is rendered more ≈øecure and calm, the Spirits are ≈øtrengthened, and dilate them≈øelves, Joy and Gladne≈øs are augmented, ≈øad and unplea≈øant Thoughts are bani≈øhed; it clears the Under≈øtanding, excites the Wit, takes away Melancholy, incourages the Spirits, and enlivens them; it is very nouri≈øhing, re≈øi≈øts Putrefaction, helps Dige≈øtion, and breeds good Blood, cuts Flegm, expels Wind, provokes Sleep, excites Appetite, fattens healthy Men, opens Ob≈øtructions, concocts crude Humours, and is the Theriaca magna of the Ancients.
New Wine is of difficult Dige≈øtion, offends the Bowels, cau≈øes Wind and the Bloody Flux.

Old Wine is hot and dry, and the older it is, the more Heat it acquires. The be≈øt is odoriferous and full of Spirits: It is naught for Copulation, becau≈øe it dries up the Seed. It is naught for young Men and
cholerick Per≈øons; but good for old Men, e≈øpecially in the Winter.

Beer and Ale are common and familiar Drinks in England, and no doubt it is profitable and whole≈øome, as Experience ≈øhews: But the different Preparations, or Brewing thereof, make no ≈ømall Difference in the Drink. The Difference of Waters al≈øo, whereof it is made, is greatly to be con≈øidered; therefore, according to their Natures, you mu≈øt judge of the Drink; al≈øo the Difference of the Corn or Grain is to be con≈øidered; as Drinks made of Wheat-malt nouri≈øh mo≈øt. Some People mix Wheat and Barly together: Others mix ≈øome Oats with Barly for Malt: Generally in Ale are u≈øed no Hops, or le≈øs Hops than in Beer; therefore Ale is more nouri≈øhing, and loo≈øens the Belly.

Cider is a cold Liquor, it is very plea≈øant indeed, but is windy; it is ≈øaid to be good for the Scurvy. Becau≈øe Meat and Drink are of ≈øo great Importance with re≈øpect to the Pre≈øervation of Health, and Cure of Di≈øea≈øes, as well as for Su≈øtenance, I ≈øhall here particularly, tho briefly, di≈øcour≈øe of the various Sorts of Meats, Fruits, and Herbs, which are generally u≈øed for Diet.
Beans Clean≈øe and fatten, but are windy, therefore occa≈øion Cholick Pains, and di≈øturb the Head. The French is the be≈øt and lea≈øt windy.
Pea≈øe are not ≈øo windy as Beans, Green Pea≈øe are very plea≈øant to the Ta≈øt, provoke Appetite, are good for Coughs and an A≈øthma; but they are injurious to many, by rea≈øon of their Windine≈øs.
Rice binds the Body, cures Fluxes, Pains in the Stomach, and Griping in the Guts, but being u≈øed too long, cau≈øes Ob≈øtructions and Wind.
A≈øparagus is quickly boyled, nouri≈øhes more than all other Herbs, is good for the Stomach, purges the Brea≈øt, provokes Urine, and clean≈øes the Kidneys from Gravel.
Capers excite Appetite, remove Ob≈øtructions of the Liver and Spleen, kill Worms, and are good for phlegmatic and melancholy People.
Artichokes are plea≈øant to the Ta≈øte, provoke Urine, and make it ≈øtink, as A≈øparagus does; but they are windy, and injure the Head and Stomach.
Cabbage loo≈øens the Belly, is good for Stoppage of Urine and other Ob≈øtructions: but it is windy, and cau≈øes a ≈øtinking Breath, and increa≈øes Melancholy.
Sampier beink pickled, pre≈øerves the Stomach, and is good for the Reins.
Lettice is ea≈øily dige≈øted, breeds Milk, and provokes Sleep.
Par≈øly provokes Urine, the Cour≈øes, clean≈øes the Reins, and removes Ob≈øtructions and Wind, but is bad for the Head and Eye-≈øight.
Garlick is good again≈øt Poi≈øon, the Worms, provokes Urine, and is good for a Drop≈øie and Shortne≈øs of Breath; but is injurious to the Head and Eye≈øight.
Carrots breed Milk, provoke the Cour≈øes and Urine, and open Ob≈øtructions; but they are windy.
Onions increa≈øe Appetite, attenuate the Humours, make a good Colour, and increa≈øe Seed; but they are bad for the Head and Eyes.
Par≈ønips provoke the Cour≈øes and Urine, and remove Ob≈øtructions; but they are windy, provoke Venery, occa≈øion the Itch, and breed bad Blood.
Leeks provoke Urine and the Cour≈øes, and expel Wind, they are good for the Lungs and Stomach, but they offend the Head.
Radi≈øhes provoke Urine, expel Gravel, and increa≈øe Milk; but they cau≈øe ≈øtinking Bel≈øhes and Wind.
Quinces help Dige≈øtion, ≈øtop Fluxes and vomiting, and ≈øtrengthen the Stomach.
Apples comfort the Heart, open the Brea≈øt, and are pectoral.
Pears provoke Appetite, and ≈øtrengthen the Stomach, and loo≈øen the Belly: But Bergamots are the mo≈øt whole≈øome, but being eaten before Meals they breed Wind and occa≈øion the Cholick.

Oranges that are ≈øweet, eaten before Meals, are good for the Stomach. Sowre Oranges quench the Thir≈øt, and excite Appetite; but ≈øowre, or Sevil Oranges bind the Body, cool the Stomach, and contract the Brea≈øt, and the ≈øweet increa≈øe Choler.

Lemons excite Appetite, ≈øtop vomiting, cut gro≈øs Humours, are good in malignant Fevers, and kill Worms. An Ounce of the Juice drank in Wine expells Gravel: But they cool the Stomach, occa≈øion the Cholick, and cau≈øe Leanne≈øs, and breed melancholy Humours.
Filberts eaten at the Beginning of Dinner are good again≈øt Gravel; but they are hardly dige≈øted, cau≈øe Wind, and Pains in the Head.

Walnuts fa≈øten loo≈øe Teeth, they pre≈øerve again≈øt Poi≈øon and the Plague; but they mu≈øt be eaten at Break-fa≈øt, and are good after Fi≈øh; they kill Worms, and being pre≈øerved, they loo≈øen the Belly, and are pectoral: But they hurt the Throat, cau≈øe Coughs, when they are dry, and cau≈øe the Head-ach. The Shade of a Nut-Tree is very injurious; for it ≈øends out ill Vapours that offend the Head.

Apricocks quench Thir≈øt, excite Appetite, and provoke Urine; the Kernels kill Worms, and are excellent for the Heart-burning; but they cau≈øe Fluxes of the Belly, and putrifie quickly, and breed gro≈øs and vi≈øcous Flegm.

Peaches are good for the Stomach, and loo≈øen the Belly. The be≈øt are tho≈øe that are odoriferous, wellcoloured, and fully ripe, ≈øo that they come clear from the Stone; they mu≈øt be eaten before Dinner, and good Wine mu≈øt be drank after them; but they ≈øoon corrupt, occa≈øion Wind and ill Humours.
Olives clean≈øe the Stomach from Flegm, and excite Appetite, and ≈øtop vomiting, the Pickle is good to wa≈øh the Mouth; for it fa≈øtens loo≈øe Teeth, and ≈øtrengthens the Gums.
Plums purge Choler, extingui≈øh Heat, take away Thir≈øt in ≈øeveri≈øh People, but they injure a cold and weak Stomach, are bad for flegmatick Per≈øons, and ≈øuch as are troubled with the Cholick.

Cucumbers are very cooling and refre≈øhing in the Summer, they provoke Urine, and are good for the Reins and Bladder, and a hot Stomach; but they are apt to corrupt, and to breed ill Humours, if they are not quickly concocted by the Stomach.

Strawberries extingui≈øh Heat, take away Thir≈øt, provoke Urine and the Appetite: But they ≈øoon corrupt in the Stomach, and are very injurious to paralytic People, to ≈øuch as are troubled with Convul≈øions, and tho≈øe that eat many of them are often ≈øeized with malignant Fevers.

Melons are very refre≈øhing, they clean≈øe the Body, provoke Urine, quench Thir≈øt, and excite Appetite, and are excellent for the Gravel and Stone: But they occa≈øion Wind and Gripes, and being corrupted, malignant Fevers.

Fle≈øh is more nouri≈øhing than all other Food, for it is ea≈øily turned into Blood, and affords great Nouri≈øhment. You mu≈øt always take notice, that Fle≈øh, Herbs, Fruits and Corn are to be cho≈øen in high Places, ≈øuch as are refre≈øhed with whole≈øome Winds, and recreated with the warm Beams of the Sun, where there are no Ponds, Lakes, and ≈øtanding Waters; for in ≈øuch Places they are quickly corrupted. The Fle≈øh of all tho≈øe Creatures which live in Fens and ≈øtanding Pools are to be avoided, as Ducks and Gee≈øe. The Fle≈øh of Creatures too old are naught, hard, dry, ≈øinewy, and of ≈ømall Nouri≈øhment, and hard to be dige≈øted; and on the contrary, ≈øuch as are too young
overabound with Moi≈øture, and are full of Superfluities, tho' ea≈øily concocted in the Stomach.

Salted Fle≈øh occa≈øions gro≈øs and melancholy Humours, and bad Juice; for it dries much, and nouri≈øhes little. Fat Meat is ea≈øily dige≈øted, but breeds many Superfluities, and therefore is of ≈ømall Nouri≈øhment; it takes away the Appetite, and hinders Dige≈øtion. The leaner nouri≈øhes better, and generates fewer Superfluities; and therefore the midling betwixt both is mo≈øt whole≈øome.

The Fle≈øh of Birds is lighter, dryer, and ea≈øier dige≈øted than that of four-footed Bea≈øts, and therefore more agreeable to tho≈øe that exerci≈øe the Mind more than the Body, for they are dige≈øted more ea≈øily, and breed Blood that is clear, clean, and full of Spirits, and fit for the Exerci≈øe of the Mind.

The Fle≈øh of wild Creatures, and ≈øuch as frequent the Woods is better than that of tame, and the Blood which is bred by eating them, will have fewer Superfluities, by rea≈øon of much running and Exerci≈øe, which they are accu≈øtomed to; and becau≈øe they live in a more dry Air, e≈øpecially ≈øuch as frequent the Mountains, and their Fle≈øh will keep longer uncorrupted; for they have le≈øs Fat; and therefore generate fewer Superfluities, nouri≈øh better, and breed a more ≈øound Blood; but tame Creatures are more moi≈øt than wild, by rea≈øon of their little Motion, and the Moi≈øtne≈øs of the Air they live in.
In moi≈øt Times and Complexions, the Fle≈øh that inclines to Dryne≈øs is mo≈øt proper; and ≈øo on the contrary.
The Fle≈øh of gelded Creatures is be≈øt, becau≈øe it is mo≈øt temperate; for it is more hot than the Female, and colder than the Male.
The Fle≈øh of black Creatures is lighter and ≈øweeter than that of white.

The Fle≈øh that ≈øticks to the Bone is of be≈øt Nouri≈øhment; and Fle≈øh of the right Side is better than that of the left, and the fore Part is to be preferred to the hinder; becau≈øe the fore Part is hotter and of ea≈øier Dige≈øtion, but the hinder Part is more cold and more gro≈øs; the Fle≈øh near the Heart is better than that which is farther off; for being ≈øtrengthened by the Heat of the Heart, it is more fit to nouri≈øh.
That Fle≈øh which is dry mu≈øt be boyled, the moi≈øt roa≈øted.

The Fle≈øh which is roa≈øted is fatter, of greater Nouri≈øhment, tho' more hard of Dige≈øtion than boyled, which tho' of le≈øs, yet is of better Nouri≈øhment; and therefore more whole≈øome. At Dinner boyled Meats are be≈øt, at Supper roa≈øted. Fryed and broyled Meats generate nau≈øeous Humours and Crudities in the Stomach, and are of difficult Dige≈øtion, tho very nouri≈øhing.
Lamb breeds good Nouri≈øhment, is ea≈øie to be dige≈øted, and is good again≈øt melancholy Humours, and is proper in hot weather and in hot Countries.
Beef affords great Nouri≈øhment to tho≈øe that labour much, and breeds much Blood.
Veal nouri≈øhes much, and generates good Blood, and is ea≈øily dige≈øted.
Kid is an excellent Nouri≈øhment, and very ea≈øie to be dige≈øted.
Deer are of great and good Nouri≈øhment, and are good again≈øt the Pal≈øie and Cholick, and make ≈øuch lean as are too fat.
Mutton breeds good Blood, makes good Nouri≈øhment, and is ea≈øily dige≈øted.
Brawn made of the Fle≈øh of tame young Bores is a delicate Meat, having not ≈øo much excrementitious Moi≈øture, as Bacon or Pork, but the hard or horny Part is difficultly concocted.

Rabits are a good Nouri≈øhment, they con≈øume the ≈øuperfluous Moi≈øture, and Flegm in the Stomach. The Fle≈øh is whiter, and not ≈øo dry as that of a Hare; and therefore nouri≈øhes better, and is ea≈øier dige≈øted.

Young Hares are very ≈øweet and plea≈øant to the Stomach, they are good for ≈øuch as are too fat, and cau≈øe a good Colour and Beauty in the Face. The Blood of a Hare fryed and eaten is good again≈øt the Bloodyflux, inward Impo≈øthumes, and the Gravel in the Kidneys. The Brains of a roa≈øted Hare cures the trembling of the Members, and facilitates the Breeding of Teeth in Children.

Bacon and Pork yield a good Nouri≈øhment, but is injurious to ≈øuch as live ea≈øie; they cau≈øe the Gout, e≈øpecially the Fle≈øh of a ≈øucking Pig, and it cau≈øes the Cholick, and the Stone in the Kidneys.

Among≈øt the Parts of Birds and Bea≈øts, ≈øome are better than others; for all the Extremities, as the Head, the Neck, the Feet, the Tail, in re≈øpect of the re≈øt, are hard, of little and gro≈øs Nouri≈øhment, and hard to be dige≈øted: But better and more ≈øavory are the Parts about the Wings, Back, and Brea≈øt.
Butter is good for the Lungs, and nouri≈øhes well.

Chee≈øe that is new, fattens, ta≈øtes plea≈øantly, and is not injurious to the Stomach. Cream Chee≈øe is mo≈øt whole≈øome; but it mu≈øt be eaten the ≈øame Day it is made in. Chee≈øe is only to be eaten to ≈øhut up and clo≈øe the Mouth of the Stomach, and we mu≈øt beware we eat not too much of it, e≈øpecially of old Chee≈øe; for it occa≈øions Thir≈øt, inflames the Blood, and cau≈øes the Stone.
Milk is good for the hectic Fever, takes off the Heat of Urine, cures Coughs, and opens the Brea≈øt, but it is naught for tho≈øe that are troubled with the Cholick, and the Stone.
Whey is good for ≈øuch as are of a hot Con≈øtitution, it quenches Thir≈øt, and provokes Sleep.

The different Nature of Birds is di≈øcerned by the Time, the Age, the Food, the Place, and the Air; becau≈øe at ≈øuch Time as Birds couple, as well dome≈øtick as wild Fowl, they thereby grow lean, and feed little. Some Birds are be≈øt in the Summer, at which time they eat Corn; others in Autumn, becau≈øe they eat Grapes, Figs, Apples, Berries, and the like. Other Birds are be≈øt in the Winter, as Thru≈øhes, Blackbirds, wild Gee≈øe, Cranes, and all water Fowl.

Some live on VVorms; but mo≈øt eat Corn, as Pidgeons, Doves, and the like: In ≈øhort, ≈øome are nouri≈øhed on Land, others in Rivers, ≈øome in Lakes, and others in Sea, and a great many Birds feed on Herbs; and it is ob≈øervable, that the Fle≈øh of wild Fowl has always the Ta≈øte of ≈øuch things as the Birds feed on, as of Ants, VVorms, Fi≈øh, Slime, and Mud.
Mountain Fowl are always to be preferred before the re≈øt; be≈øides gelding or cutting a Fowl makes it fat and ≈øweet, as appears in the Fle≈øh of Capons.
The Fle≈øh of young Birds is always better than that of old.
A Duck is the hotte≈øt of all tame Fowl; the VVings and Liver are the be≈øt; but of hard Dige≈øtion and gro≈øs Nouri≈øhment; but is good in cold weather for hot Stomachs, and ≈øuch as labour much.
Capon nouri≈øhes better than all other Fowl, and generates good Blood.
Pidgeons afford good Nouri≈øhment, breed excellent Blood, and are good for old and flegmatic Men. They ≈øtrengthen the Legs, and cure the Pal≈øy; but they are not good for hot Con≈øtitutions.
Phea≈øants are very agreeable to humane Nature, comfort and ≈øtrengthen the Stomach, yield great Nouri≈øhment, and fatten exceedingly.
Hens nouri≈øh the Body wonderfully, are ea≈øily dige≈øted, and breed good Blood: But old Hens are of hard Dige≈øtion. The Fle≈øh of a Cock is dryer, hot, and ≈øulphureous.
Turky is a good Nouri≈øhment, the Fle≈øh is white≈øt and be≈øt, and excells all others in VVhole≈øomne≈øs; for it is ea≈øily dige≈øted, and breeds good Blood.
I arks, if they are fat, nouri≈øh well, and are ea≈øily dige≈øted, they are be≈øt in Autumn, and in VVinter.
Blackbirds nouri≈øh ≈øufficiently, when they are fat and young; but they are of hard Dige≈øtion.

Gee≈øe; the be≈øt Parts of them are the VVings and Liver; the Fle≈øh of young Gee≈øe affordeth good Nouri≈øhment, and fattens tho≈øe that are lean. If you feed Gee≈øe with Milk, their Liver is much more plea≈øant, and dige≈øts and nouri≈øhes well enough; but their Fle≈øh is of hard Dige≈øtion.
Plovers are an excellent and whole≈øome Food, and afford good Nouri≈øhment; only they are of a melancholy Juice.

Eggs of a fat Hen fed with Corn, and trod by the Cock, and fre≈øh laid, are the be≈øt; next to the≈øe is a Phea≈øants Egg; but tho≈øe of a Goo≈øe or Duck are naught, becau≈øe they have a ≈øtrong Smell, and are of hard Dige≈øtion; and therefore a young Hens Egg is beyond all. Let it be ≈ømall, long, and fre≈øh. Eggs are of a copious Nouri≈øhment, they are good for old Men, excite Venery, and open the Brea≈øt. Potched are be≈øt.

Young Sparrows afford good Nouri≈øhment, excite Venery. Mountain Sparrows have a wonderful Vertue again≈øt the Stone in the Kidneys and Bladder; but are of difficult Dige≈øtion, and cau≈øe Melancholy.
Peacocks; the be≈øt are bred in good Air, young and tender, they nouri≈øh enough, but are of hard and ≈ølow Dige≈øtion, and breed melancholy Blood.

Partridges breed good and ≈ølender Nouri≈øhment, and ea≈øily dige≈øt, they fatten and dry up the Moi≈øture of the Stomach, and contribute much to the Pre≈øervation of the Health, and the Fle≈øh is better than that of a Hen. It is ≈øaid, they cure the Pox and the Falling
Sickne≈øs, being eaten a whole Year together; but old Partridges are of a very hard Sub≈øtance, and of a very bad Ta≈øte, and injure Melancholy People, and bind the Body.
Stares nouri≈øh well, and as they ≈øay, cure the Pox, continuing to eat every Day throughout the Year, one Stare and no more. But old Stares are of hard Dige≈øtion.
Quails are good for melancholy Men, are very nouri≈øhing and plea≈øaing to the Ta≈øte: But ≈øome ≈øay, they cau≈øe Fevers, the Cramp, and Falling Sickne≈øs, wherewith they ≈øay this Bird is troubled.
Thru≈øhes nouri≈øh very well, and are ea≈øily dige≈øted, the Mountain Thru≈øhes are the be≈øt.

Turtles nouri≈øh excellently, and are ea≈øily dige≈øted; they ≈øtrengthen the Stomach, and quicken the VVit; roa≈øted with Cloves and Juice of Oranges are very good in the Bloody Flux, and for all other Fluxes.

Fi≈øh, in re≈øpect of Fle≈øh, are of le≈øs Nouri≈øhment, are gro≈øs, flegmatic, cold, and full of Superfluities. The old nouri≈øh more than the young, and tho≈øe that live among≈øt Stones and Rocks are the be≈øt. Fi≈øh are of hard Dige≈øtion, and the ≈øign of their Indige≈øtion is Thir≈øt; ≈øeeing they all cau≈øe Thir≈øt if they remain long in the Stomach; nay, ≈øometimes they corrupt. Concerning Fi≈øh, you may ob≈øerve the≈øe following Rules: 1≈øt. That all Fi≈øh ≈øhould be eaten hot. 2dly. You mu≈øt eat le≈øs of Fi≈øh than of Fle≈øh. 3dly. You mu≈øt not eat them too often. 4thly. You mu≈øt not eat Fi≈øh after great Labour and Exerci≈øe; for then they ea≈øily corrupt; nor mu≈øt they be eaten after other other Food. 5thly. Fi≈øh and Milk are not proper together, nor are Eggs to be u≈øed with it. 6thly. Great and ≈ølimy Fi≈øh pickled are better than fre≈øh. 7thly. You mu≈øt ob≈øerve, that the clearer and deeper the VVater is, the better are the Fi≈øh that are nouri≈øhed therein. 8thly. Sea Fi≈øh are whole≈øomer than fre≈øhwater
Fi≈øh, hotter, and not ≈øo moi≈øt, and their Nouri≈øhment comes near that of Fle≈øh. 9thly. Among≈øt the Sea and River Fi≈øh, tho≈øe are be≈øt which live in rocky Places, next to the≈øe in ≈øandy Places, in ≈øweet, clear, and running VVater, where there is no Filth: But tho≈øe Fi≈øh are naught which live in Pools, Lakes, Mar≈øhes, and in any ≈øtill and muddy Water. 10thly. Among≈øt all the Fi≈øh both in Sea and Rivers, tho≈øe which are not too big are the be≈øt, and which have not a hard and dry Fle≈øh, that ta≈øte and ≈ømell well, are cri≈øp and tender, and have many Fins and Scales. 11thly. Fi≈øh are cold and moi≈øt; and therefore naught for cold Con≈øtitutions, but good for cholerick Men. 12thly. The be≈øt way of dre≈ø≈øing Fi≈øh is to broyl it, to boyl it is the next way, to fry it is the wor≈øt.

Eels are of a delicate Ta≈øte and good Nouri≈øhment, but offend the Stomach, and are of hard Dige≈øtion, and being u≈øed too often, breed the Stone in the Kidnies and Bladder, and occa≈øion the Gout and Convul≈øions. In ≈øhort, whoever eats much of them indangers his Life.
Carps are the mo≈øt noble of all Fi≈øh, and of a very plea≈øant and grateful Ta≈øte, and nouri≈øh well, in what manner ≈øoever they are eaten.
Crabs are good for con≈øumptive People, they nouri≈øh very much, provoke Urine, and clean≈øe the Kidneys; but they are of hard Dige≈øtion.
Lampreys are of excellent Nouri≈øhment, excite Venery, and are of a mo≈øt delicious Ta≈øte; but they are of hard Dige≈øtion, bad for gouty People, and for ≈øuch as are troubled with Convul≈øions.
Pikes nouri≈øh very much; but are of hard Dige≈øtion.
Oy≈øters provoke Appetite, and they are a very proper Diet in many Ca≈øes.

Sturgeon nouri≈øhes well, and excites Venery; but is of hard Dige≈øtion. Of the Spawn or Row of this Fi≈øh Salted
is made Cavyare, which provokes Appetite, and makes the Drink reli≈øh.
Lob≈øters fatten and nouri≈øh much, and their Broth cures Shortne≈øs of Breath; but they are cold and flegmatic, and of a hard Dige≈øtion.
Sprats being boyled as ≈øoon as they are taken, yield good Nouri≈øhment and ta≈øte plea≈øantly; but they occa≈øion VVind.
Tench are very nouri≈øhing, but of hard Dige≈øtion.
Salmon is plea≈øant to the Palate, ea≈øily dige≈øted, and affords good Juice.
Soles, Plaice, and Turbet are highly commended among≈øt Sea Fi≈øh; for they have a delicate Fle≈øh, they yield good Nouri≈øhment, are not ea≈øily corrupted, and are ea≈øily dige≈øted.
Gudgeons are the be≈øt of all ≈ømall Fi≈øh, whole≈øome Aliment, ea≈øily dige≈øted, and may be ≈øafely given to ≈øick Per≈øons.
Pearch have ≈øoft, moi≈øt, and tender Fle≈øh, but they nouri≈øh little, and are full of excrementitious Juice.
Cod-fi≈øh, if fre≈øh, is of good Juice, and ea≈øily concocted; but when it is dry, it is of hard Dige≈øtion, and of gro≈øs Nouri≈øhment.

Barbels: The little ones are better than the great, and ≈øuch as are caught in ≈øtony Places, and not in muddy Ponds; they are very plea≈øant to the Palate; but their Fle≈øh is hard and not ea≈øily dige≈øted.
Trouts: The bigge≈øt are be≈øt, and ≈øuch as are bred in ≈øweet VVaters. The River Trout nouri≈øhes well, good for young and cholerick, but naught for decrepid and flegmatick Men.

Vinegar: The be≈øt is that which is made of the be≈øt VVine. It is cutting, dige≈øtive, and openining. It is very good to extingui≈øh the Heat of Choler and Thir≈øt. It ≈øtrengthens the Gums, excites the Appetite, removes Ob≈øtructions, helps Dige≈øtion, and is good for
hot and moi≈øt Stomachs, and re≈øi≈øts Putrefaction; therefore is good in the Plague time: But it breeds melancholy Humours, injures the Nerves, makes lean, offends the Brea≈øt, and being u≈øed too much, makes Men look old and withered.

Honey is ab≈øter≈øive and opening, provokes Urine, and clean≈øes its Pa≈ø≈øages. It is good for old and flegmatick Men of a cold Con≈øtitution, and is pectoral. Democritus being asked how a Man might keep him≈øelf in Health; An≈øwered, by Oyl without, and Honey within. It heats the Stomach, moves the Body, re≈øi≈øts Corruption, and turns to good Blood; but it occa≈øions VVind and the Gripes.
Oyl of Olives is very ≈øweet, and agreeable to Nature. VVhen it is two Years old it is be≈øt, it ought to be made of ripe Olives.
Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds is next to it in Goodne≈øs. Oyl fattens, and a good Quantity of it is excellent to bring up Poy≈øon by Vomit; but if it be eaten too often, it le≈ø≈øens the Appetite.

Salt, of all Sawces, is be≈øt; without which no Food is good. It is put into Victuals for three Rea≈øons: 1≈øt. That thereby the Food may de≈øcend ea≈øier into the Stomach. 2dly. To make it more ≈øavoury. 3dly. Becau≈øe it re≈øi≈øts Putrefaction; con≈øuming, by its Dryne≈øs, that Moi≈øture, whereby Putrefaction might have been occa≈øioned. It excites the Appetite, and dige≈øtive Faculty, and prevents nau≈øeating. It di≈ø≈øolves, attenuates, and dries up the ≈øuperfluous Moi≈øture, provokes the Bowels to evacuate the Excrements, and is therefore u≈øed in Gli≈øters and Suppo≈øitories; but things too much ≈øalted generate Melancholy and Vapours, breed ill Nouri≈øhment, dry up the Blood, cau≈øe Scabbine≈øs and Itch, Ring-worms, and other ≈øuch Humours and Breakings out in the Face and Body, and ≈øtops the Pa≈ø≈øages of the Urine.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of Sleep and Watching.
div.p: SLeep is the Ce≈ø≈øation of the external Sen≈øes from Operation; the Cau≈øe of Sleep is the Remi≈ø≈øion and Sub≈øidence of the Fibres, wherewith the Brain is chiefly formed, ≈øo that the Motions imprinted upon the Organs of the five external Sen≈øes cannot be duly propagated to the Seat of the Soul, and be known there, as we ≈øee that a Motion upon a ≈ølack String of a Violin is not ≈øo readily promoted, as when it is wond up hard. The ≈øaid Remi≈ø≈øion of the Fibres in the Brain ari≈øes from a Defect or Dullne≈øs, ≈øo that the animal Spirits do not ≈øufficiently expand tho≈øe Tubes; and ≈øo after Labour we are inclined to Sleep, by rea≈øon of a Defect of the Spirits. In like manner, after the taking of Opium or other Narcoticks, we are di≈øpo≈øed to ≈øleep, becau≈øe they ≈øeize the Spirits by their volatile Oleo≈øity. La≈øtly, we are inclined to ≈øleep after eating or drinking; becau≈øe then the Humidity of the Brain relaxes the Fibres, and perhaps, becau≈øe the Vapours ≈øomewhat hinder the Spirits: But ≈øome, when they drink much, cannot ≈øleep; becau≈øe the Spirits are thereby heated and inraged.

All Creatures, by long Fatigues and VVatchings, wa≈øte and con≈øume them≈øelves; and therefore ≈øtand in need of Re≈øt and Sleep, the Advantage and Good whereof is, that it reheats and corroborates the Members, concocts the Humours, augments the natural Heat, fattens the Body, heals the Infirmities of the Mind, and mitigates and allays Troubles and Sorrows: For whil≈øt we ≈øleep, the Faculties of the Mind repo≈øe them≈øelves. Sleep al≈øo facilitates the Dige≈øtion of the Food which lies in the Stomach, and not only
concocts it there, but al≈øo di≈øtributes it thro' the Parts of the Body; for the natural Heat concenters in the inward Parts, whereby the Food is better concocted. La≈øtly, Sleep removes all La≈ø≈øitude and VVearine≈øs, cau≈øed by overmuch watching; and therefore it is called a Re≈øt from all Labour.

But we mu≈øt avoid long and ≈øuperfluous Sleep, which is no le≈øs pernicious than the other is good; for it chills the Body, weakens the natural Heat, and breeds flegmatic Humours, whence afterwards proceeds much Sloath and Lazine≈øs, and ≈øends many Vapours to the Head, which are oftentimes the immediate Cau≈øe of Rheums and Catarrhs, and is very de≈øtructive to gro≈øs and fat Bodies. In brief, it is neither good for the Body nor the Mind, nor for Bu≈øine≈øs. He who ≈øleeps too much is but half a Man, Sleep rendring him in all Points like a dead Man except his Dige≈øtion of the Food; for he neither ≈øees, hears, ≈øpeaks, or under≈øtands, and is ab≈øolutely deprived of all Rea≈øon; which, for the Time, is a perfect Death. Superfluous Sleep moreover, both in ≈øound and firm Bodies generates Shortne≈øs of Breath, and is a con≈øtant Forerunner, and Preparative to an Apoplexy, Lethargy, Pal≈øy, and Numne≈øs, and it hinders the ≈øea≈øonable Evacuation of the Excrements, cau≈øing them to remain longer in the Ve≈ø≈øels and Guts. Sleep ought to be taken at ≈øuch a Time as the Stomach is free from all ≈ømoaky Food, the Vapours whereof arriving at the Brain, are congealed and made heavy, and then falling down, they ob≈øtruct the Members.

But on the contrary, too much watching, and want of Sleep generate over much Heat in the Brain, cau≈øe Angui≈øh of Mind, and a bad Dige≈øtion; for by watching, the natural Heat is weakened, which occa≈øions Crudities.

Sleep is good for flegmatic Per≈øons; becau≈øe it concocts the crude Humours, whence afterwards is generated
good Blood, whereby a Man becomes more warm, the natural Heat being increa≈øed by the Plenty of Blood. Sleep moreover is very u≈øeful in choleric Per≈øons, both to quiet the Mind, and to correct the Con≈øtitution of the Body: But it is mo≈øt of all requi≈øite in melancholy Men; for by Sleep they acquire a competent Stock of Heat and Moi≈øture, things very contrary to their Con≈øtitution.

Sleep, in the Day time, and after Dinner, is not to be allow'd, unle≈øs a Man has accu≈øtomed him≈øelf to it, or has not re≈øted well the Night before, or perceives a kind of La≈ø≈øitude or VVearine≈øs thro' all his Limbs; in the≈øe Ca≈øes he may ≈øleep after Dinner, e≈øpecially if his Stomach be weak and cannot dige≈øt the Food: But po≈øt-meridian Sleep ought to be taken in a Chair, and not to be above an Hour long.

In long Days Sleep may be taken in a Chair, if the Strength be decayed. Some indeed forbid ≈øleeping adays, e≈øpecially after Dinner: But I think it is not injurious; for ≈øo the Spirits, weakened by Labour and Cares, are refre≈øhed; and I cannot indeed ≈øee why it is wor≈øe than nocturnal Sleep, only it hinders Sleep anights, and makes the Nights ≈øeem long and tedious. The ordinary Time for Sleep is ≈øeven Hours; for that Time ≈øeems ≈øufficient for perfecting Dige≈øtion, and refre≈øhing the Spirits: But ≈øome require more Sleep, ≈øome le≈øs; ≈øo Children require more, and old People, choleric, and dry; becau≈øe it moi≈øtens and re≈øtores the Spirits: But fat and flegmatic People ≈øhould not ≈øleep much. Such as labour much ought to ≈øleep long. It ≈øignifies little on what ≈øide you lye at fir≈øt going to ≈øleep. It is injurious to ≈øleep with an empty Stomach. Sleeping on the Back hurts the Reins, and hinders Breathing, and furthers Di≈øea≈øes of the Nerves.

The Signs of ≈øufficient Sleep are a Lightne≈øs and Agility, which ≈øpreads its ≈øelf over all the Body, and chiefly the Brain, whereas Heavine≈øs of the Body, and
un≈øavoury Belchings, ≈øignifie that more Sleep is required. To conclude, moderate Sleep re≈øtores the animal Faculties, helps concoction of the Victuals, and crude Humours, cau≈øes a Forgetfulne≈øs of Labour, and of all ≈øorrowful Thoughts, mitigates the Grief of the Mind, moi≈øtens all the Members of the Body, re≈øtores all the wa≈øted Faculties, augments the natural Heat, increa≈øes radical Moi≈øture, clari≈øies and ≈øtrengthens the Sight, takes away Wearine≈øs, refre≈øhing the tired Body, and ≈øtops Fluxes and Rheums: But if immoderate, it makes the Head heavy, troubles the Mind, weakens the Memory, and all the animal Faculties, makes the Body cold, multiplies Flegm, extingui≈øhes the natural Heat, induces a nau≈øeating, makes the Face pale, and is hurtful to all ≈ølegmatic Di≈øea≈øes.

Waking is an Inten≈øion, or rather an Exten≈øion of the Soul and Faculties thereof, to all the Parts of the Body; which, when it is moderate, ≈øtirs up and excites all the Sen≈øes, di≈øpo≈øes and orders the vital Faculties to their Operations, expelling and driving forth all the ≈øuperfluous Humours from the Body; but if immoderate and exce≈ø≈øive, it generates Di≈øea≈øes of the Head, corrupts the Temperature of the Brain, cau≈øes Madne≈øs, kindles the Humours, excites ≈øharp and acrimonious Infirmities, makes Men look pale and lean, and weakens the concoctive Faculty, di≈ø≈øolves the Spirits, fills the Head with Vapours, makes the Eyes hollow, increa≈øes Heat, cau≈øes Crudities in the Stomach; therefore let Sleep and Waking be always moderate, and if a Man cannot ≈øleep, let him take at lea≈øt ≈øome Repo≈øe with his Eyes ≈øhut, which in ≈øome ≈øort may ≈øupply the place of Sleep.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of Motion and Re≈øt.
div.p: MOtion is here Labour and Exerci≈øe, as walking, playing at Ball, running, riding; they excite natural Heat, and con≈øume all the Crudities of the Body.

Some Exerci≈øes are ≈øtrong and weari≈øome, and others moderate and gentle; the temperate Exerci≈øe is that which contributes much to the Health; for it corroborates the natural Health, wa≈øtes the Superfluities, enlivens Youth, chears old Age, and hinders Fullne≈øs, fortifies the Sen≈øes, renders the Body light and agile, ≈øtrengthens the Nerves and all the Joints; for by Exerci≈øe all the Parts become more robu≈øt; it con≈øolidates the Members, helps Dige≈øtion, keeps the Pa≈ø≈øages of the Body clear and open, ≈øo that the ≈ømoaky Vapours of the Spirits may find a better and more free I≈ø≈øue.

The gentle Exerci≈øes are fi≈øhing, fowling, and ≈øuch like Diverti≈øements, which clear the Mind: And, as moderate and temperate Exerci≈øe does wonderfully contribute to Health, ≈øo overmuch Idlene≈øs is very pernicious.

Frictions are al≈øo exceeding u≈øeful; for they hinder the Humours from falling into the Joints, and being u≈øed in the right Time, that is, when the Superfluities ≈øhall be evaporated from the inward Parts, they help Dige≈øtion, recreate the Body, and open the Pores, whereby the moi≈øt Humours, and Vapours of the Body obtain an ea≈øier Pa≈ø≈øage; al≈øo draw the Blood to the outward Parts, and confirm the natural Heat.

Exerci≈øe is to be u≈øed ≈øo long as the Body can bear it, without growing too weary, that is, till you wax hot,
having a fre≈øh Colour, and begin to ≈øweat, which, as ≈øoon as you perceive, change your Cloaths, and dry well all the Members, and put on other Cloaths, and if it be nece≈ø≈øary, lye a little in Bed and re≈øt your ≈øelf, till you ≈øhall be refre≈øhed, and recover new Strength.
Shooting with a Bow is counted a proper Exerci≈øe for the Brea≈øt and Lungs; bowling for the Back and Reins: But riding on Horeback is the be≈øt Exerci≈øe of all, and may ≈øerve in≈øtead of all.

The Time for Exerci≈øe is before Meals, having fir≈øt evacuated the Excrements of the Belly and Bladder; for it is u≈øually very bad and de≈øtructive to exerci≈øe the Body pre≈øently after Meals, and this is the Source of divers Infirmities; but Labourers and Country People, by continual Cu≈øtom, labour without Injury, as ≈øoon as the Meat is out of their Mouths.

After violent Exerci≈øe, one ought to beware of catching cold; for the Motion and Exerci≈øe having opened the Pores of the Body, the cold ea≈øily enters therein, bringing along with it Catarrhs, and diver≈øe other Infirmities.

Friction or rubbing is to be u≈øed in the Morning, after having been at Stool, which mu≈øt be performed on the extream Parts of the Body; begin at the Knees, and proceed to the Feet, then the Thighs, then from upper Ribs to the lower, then from the Shoulders down the Back, and la≈øtly, from the Arms to the Hands. You mu≈øt u≈øe a Napkin or Towel, gently rubbing your Body, till the Skin wax ≈øomething red. In old Men the Motion of the ≈øuperiour Members, as the Arms and the Shoulders, is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary, becau≈øe it diverts and prohibits the Humours from falling into the lower Parts.

It is proper for every Per≈øon to pull off his Shoes and Stockings him≈øelf, without the Help of a Servant; for this is ≈øome ≈øort of Exerci≈øe, and ≈øtirs up the Heat and Spirits. By the by, the binding the Stockings
hard with Garters cau≈øes ≈øeveral Pains, and hinders the Heat, Blood, and Spirits from circulating and de≈øcending into the Joints, upon which account they are weakened, and apt to receive divers Di≈øtempers.

In the Morning, as ≈øoon as you are up, rub well your Head, and comb it with an Ivory Comb, from the Forehead upwards to the Crown, then with a rough Cloath or Sponge rub your Head,; for hereby the Superfluities which are lodg'd there will be expelled, and the Spirits rarified, and the Pa≈ø≈øages of the Head opened, and the Memory and other Faculties of the Mind corroborated, and the Sight ≈øtrengthened. It is al≈øo good to ≈øhave the Beard often, becau≈øe it chears the Man; ≈øo does the wa≈øhing of the Face and Hands; the Eyes are al≈øo to be wa≈øhed with fre≈øh Water, and the putting the Eyes into cool fre≈øh Water, open, wonderfully clears and purifies the Sight; afterwards dry them very well with a clean Towel. Take care al≈øo that your Teeth be very clean, which for want of well rubbing and clean≈øing, cau≈øes a naughty and ≈øtinking Breath, and the Filth of the Teeth mixed with the Food, breeds Corruption, and renders it putrified: Be≈øides, rotten Teeth ≈øend to the Brain an infectious Vapour. It is good ≈øometimes to wa≈øh the Mouth with Wine.

No Exerci≈øe is proper after Dinner, but a quiet Compo≈øure and Stillne≈øs of the Body is mo≈øt requi≈øite, e≈øpecially for an Hour after Dinner, after which a little walking is not ami≈øs to dige≈øt and jog down the Victuals to the Bottom of the Stomach. La≈øtly, Tho≈øe Exerci≈øes are be≈øt which are performed in the open Air, rather than in Hou≈øes, in the Sun rather than in the Shade.

Tho≈øe that by ≈øome Accident or other cannot walk, let them ride, or be carried in a Hor≈øe-litter, ≈øo that they may in ≈øome manner exerci≈øe them≈øelves before Meals; for by Idlene≈øs, and over much Re≈øt, all the
Faculties of Body and Mind are enervated, and Crudities, Ob≈øtructions, and infinite Numbers of Di≈øea≈øes are occa≈øioned; and Idlene≈øs is reckoned the chief Cau≈øe of cold Di≈øea≈øes, it makes Men negligent, ≈øloathful, ignorant, and makes the Body fat, lazy, weak, and cau≈øes a pale Complexion, extingui≈øhes the natural Heat, increa≈øes Flegm, and fills the Body with Superfluities; it occa≈øions the Gout, Catarrhs, Ob≈øtructions, and the falling Sickne≈øs; therefore when at any time you are nece≈ø≈øitated to be in Idlene≈øs, or by ≈øome Bu≈øine≈øs or Incumbrance are forced to ab≈øtain from all manner of Exerci≈øe, you mu≈øt, in≈øtead thereof, ob≈øerve a ≈ølender Diet, and u≈øe that Food which is of mo≈øt ea≈øie Dige≈øtion, and Broaths, which, without any Trouble or Difficulty, are dige≈øted and di≈øtributed thro' all the Body, and cau≈øe a Slipperyne≈øs of the Belly.

Superfluous Re≈øt being therefore ≈øo very injurious, and Sloath and Lazine≈øs the Cau≈øe of ≈øo many grievous Di≈øea≈øes, as we ≈øee tho≈øe in Pri≈øons always fall into Di≈øea≈øes, it behoves us to u≈øe moderate Exerci≈øe, whereby Superfluities may be removed, the Cau≈øes of ≈øo many Di≈øea≈øes. Moreover, we ought not to neglect the Exerci≈øe of the Mind, for as the Body with Exerci≈øe is rendred ≈øtrong and robu≈øt, ≈øo the Mind is nouri≈øhed by Studies, and acquires fre≈øh Vigour; and many, by a continual Exerci≈øe of the Mind, have freed their Bodies from great Di≈øea≈øes. The Exerci≈øes of the Mind are Speculation, ≈øinging with mu≈øical In≈øtruments, the Study of Hi≈øtory, Divinity, and the like; for the≈øe things delighting the Mind, feed it in ≈øuch ≈øort that all the Virtues become more ≈øtrong, and better enabled to re≈øi≈øt and overcome Infirmities; and the≈øe Exerci≈øes performed at due Times, that is, after a perfect Concoction of your Victuals, both nouri≈øh and corroborate the Mind, and render the Memory quick and la≈øting. But if the≈øe Exerci≈øes of the Mind are
u≈øed out of ≈øea≈øon, they hinder Dige≈øtion, and heap up and contract many Superfluities, and occa≈øion various Ob≈øtructions, and putrid Fevers.

To conclude, Hippocrates affirms, that moderate Exerci≈øe is above all things mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary for flegmatick People, and for ≈øuch as are of a cold and moi≈øt Con≈øtitution, and that for hot and cholerick Per≈øons, Re≈øt is very fit and commodious. Moreover, all learned Phy≈øicians agree, that both Exerci≈øe and Re≈øt, if moderate, are a ≈øpecial means to pre≈øerve Health, and prolong Life.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of things to be evacuated.
div.p: THings to be evacuated and retained are the Excrements of the Belly, Urine, in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration, the Cour≈øes, and the Seed; for the≈øe evacuated in due Time, and in due Quantity, conduce much to the Pre≈øervation of Health, otherwi≈øe they injure the Health. The Excrements of the Belly not evacuated in due Time, occa≈øion cholic Pains, and cau≈øe ≈øtinking Vapours in the Stomach and Mouth. The≈øe Excrements, in their natural E≈øtate, are ≈øomewhat ≈øoft, and ≈øtick together, the Colour is browni≈øh, and they do not ≈øtink very much.

The Urine, when it is right, is of a yellow Colour, of a moderate Thickne≈øs, with or without a Sediment. When there is a Sediment it is white, light, and equal, and the Quantity is equal to the Liquors taken in. When it is retained too long, either by the Fault of the Reins, or of the Bladder, or becau≈øe the Matter of it is not ≈øufficiently ≈øeparated, it occa≈øions a Drop≈øy, Fainting, ≈øleepy Di≈øea≈øes, a Pal≈øy, and the like.

If in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration be hindred, the Skin becomes filthy, the Itch is occa≈øioned, a Drop≈øie, a Fe
‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ er, and the like. In≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration is made thro' the Pores of the Skin and Mouth. It is manife≈øt by the in≈øpection of the Breath in Winter-time, when it conden≈øes, when it comes out, that very much is emitted by in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration. It al≈øo appears by the many drops it makes; al≈øo if we touch with the Finger any poli≈øhed Metal, it will pre≈øently be con≈øiderably moi≈øtened; and if ≈øo much be done by ≈øo little a part, and in ≈øo ≈øhort a time, how much do we think is evaporated by the whole Body in the ≈øpace of one day? Yet it does not ≈øeem ≈øo great, as Sanctorius affirms he has found by the Static Art; for he would make us believe, that in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration alone is greater than all Evacuations taken together; for if the Meat and Drink of one day weigh eight pound, he ≈øays, that about five of them flies away in≈øen≈øibly. He ≈øays al≈øo, that the Urine of one Night is wont to be half a Pint, and the Excrements of the Belly four Ounces; and that forty Ounces at lea≈øt, are evacuated by in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration; ≈øo that as much is evacuated by in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration in one day, as is carried off by Stool in fifteen.

The Cour≈øes ought to flow in Women at Fourteen Years of Age, and in ≈øuch as are not pa≈øt Fifty, unle≈øs they are with Child, or give Suck; in which ca≈øes the cau≈øe of the Cour≈øes cea≈øe; and they ought to flow every Month; and the quantity of them ought to be proportioned to the quantity and heat of the Blood: For a certain quantity generally ≈øpeaking, cannot be limited; for ≈øome have a great many, and ≈øome but a few, nor do they continue upon all alike; for ≈øome have them two days, ≈øome three, ≈øome four, ≈øome ≈øix or eight days. They that have them too much are weakened, are ≈øubject to Faintings, and wa≈øte. Tho≈øe in whom they are ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed become Hy≈øterick, breath
difficultly, look Pale, and lo≈øe their Appetites

Venery, if it be duly u≈øed, conduces to Health, but when it is immoderate, it emaciates, and weakens the Nerves, Head, and whole Body, di≈ø≈øipates the Spirits, and wonderfully ≈øhortens the Life. It is mo≈øt conveniently u≈øed by ≈øuch as are ≈øanguine, and of a full Habit of Body, in the Morning after Sleep; for then the Seed is more elaborated, and abounds more, Dige≈øtion being perfected, and a Di≈øtribution being made.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of the Pa≈ø≈øions of the Mind.
div.p: THE chief Pa≈ø≈øions of the Mind are Mirth, Sadne≈øs, Anger, Love, Hatred, Shame, Hope, De≈øpair.

Mirth is a Delight ari≈øing from ≈øome Good, we ≈øuppo≈øe we have obtained. This above all the re≈øt conduces to Health, at lea≈øt if it be moderate; for in it the Spirits pa≈øs plea≈øantly in the Brain, and in all the Nerves: But immoderate Mirth is injurious, and ≈øometimes deadly.

Sorrow is a Pain ari≈øing from the Apprehen≈øion of Ill befalling us. In it the Spirits in the Brain and Nerves move very weakly, and ≈øometimes a Weight in the Brea≈øt, Suffocation, and Death it ≈øelf are occa≈øioned by it.
Anger is the De≈øire of Revenge, upon the Apprehen≈øion of ≈øome Injury offered us. In Anger the Spirits are wont to be violently moved in the Brain.

Love is the De≈øire of an Object which we apprehend to be good and convenient. In Love both the Blood
and Spirits, within and without the Brain are moved plea≈øantly.
Hatred is the Apprehen≈øion of an Object, which we judge hurtful or inconvenient. Hatred is Sorrow for the Good, and Mirth for the Ill of another.
Fear is a ≈øinking of the Mind by rea≈øon of the Apprehen≈øion of ≈øome imminent Ill.
Shame is a great Opinion, or Apprehen≈øion of Scandal.
Hope is a De≈øire of ≈øome future Good that ≈øeems difficult to be obtained; but yet po≈ø≈øible.
De≈øpair is an Affection of the Mind ari≈øing from the Apprehen≈øion of Good, which we judge impo≈ø≈øible to be obtained.

The Pa≈ø≈øions of the Mind have great Power, and do much contribute to the changing of the Body; becau≈øe they make a Stirring and Motion in the Humours, and in the Spirits. And the≈øe immoderate and ≈øudden Motions are rai≈øed from the Center of the Body to the Circumference, as Anger, Joy, and the like, or from the Circumference to the Center, as Fear, and the like, from whence proceed great Motions of the Spirits; and therefore we ought carefully to avoid ≈øuch Pa≈ø≈øions, ≈øeeing they dry the Body, and alter it too much, troubling it and changing it from its natural Con≈øtitution; and therefore Plato called the≈øe the Infirmities of the Mind, viz. Anger, Joy, Sorrow, Melancholy, Anxiety, or Angui≈øh, Exclamation, Fury, Violence, Brawling, Contention, Hatred, Envy, Perplexity, Fear, Shame, unplea≈øant Thoughts, unbridled De≈øires, Boldne≈øs, Incontinence, Importunity, Ambition, Di≈øtru≈øt, Hope, De≈øpair, and the like; all which Pa≈ø≈øions, be≈øides the great Hurt they do to the Body, do al≈øo very much offend the Mind; for Anger and overmuch Sorrow afflict the Spirits, dry the Bones, extenuate the Fle≈øh, inflame and burn the Body, putting it into Confu≈øion, out of its natural E≈øtate,
whence afterwards proceed many Evils, as Catarrhs and Fluxes in the Joints, and the like: But the≈øe Pa≈ø≈øions, when they are moderate, are ≈øometimes good for Men, and do not a little contribute to their Health: For Example, Anger excites and increa≈øes the natural Heat, and oftentimes it is good to be angry, to repair that natural Heat, and therefore, in cold Di≈øea≈øes, it is to be ≈øtirred up: as on the contrary, in hot, it is to be avoided. Joy and Gladne≈øs ≈øtrengthens the Dige≈øtion, and this is the chief and true≈øt rea≈øon why Men, more than all other Creatures, are expo≈øed to Crudities: Becau≈øe the Bea≈øts, and irrational Animals, tho' they eat to Satiety, neverthele≈øs do not hinder the natural Virtue which concocts the Food. But Men, by diver≈øe Thoughts, and Perturbations of Mind, divert the Virtue of its Operation, and tho' they eat moderately, yet they fall into Crudities, whence proceed many Di≈øea≈øes; and therefore a Man, by all po≈ø≈øible means, ought to avoid ≈øad Thoughts, and dolorous Subjects, and all other things which may any ways di≈øturb the Mind; for to have a chearful Mind is good in all Di≈øea≈øes. You mu≈øt keep your ≈øelf al≈øo from frequent weeping, from great Fury, and from an Appetite or De≈øire of Revenge; for the≈øe things weaken the Brain, and hinder the Dige≈øtion, and alter the natural State of the Body; for Fear withdraws the Spirits and the Blood, attracting them inwardly to the Heart, whence the Members grow cold, the Body pale, cau≈øing Tremblings, the Voice is interrupted, and the whole Force of the Body is deficient. Many have peri≈øhed by overmuch Fear and Sorrow.

Rutilius being denyed the Con≈øul≈øhip, which he earne≈øtly ≈øought after, ≈øuddenly expired. Marcus Lepidus al≈øo died for Grief, and many have died by Exce≈øs of Joy; but none of Anger, and ≈øome have died of Shame. For which Cau≈øe the≈øe Pa≈ø≈øions of the Mind ought always to be u≈øed with Moderation, and chiefly
Joy. In ≈øhort, nothing is more nece≈ø≈øary for the Pre≈øervation of Health, than to live merrily, nor to trouble ones ≈øelf, or be angry. That Man therefore that loves Health, let him delight in Gardens, frequent green and plea≈øant Places, let him conver≈øe with merry and jocund Friends, with Mu≈øick and Songs; for by the≈øe things the Spirits are re≈øtored, and as the Strength of a Man is increa≈øed by good Victuals, Wine, ≈øweet Smells, ≈øo by Tranquility, by avoiding of Cares and trouble≈øome Affairs, which render a Man ≈øad, and by frequenting merry Companions the Man is refre≈øhed. Likewi≈øe it is good to hear and read plea≈øant Di≈øcour≈øes and delightful Subjects. No le≈øs plea≈øant and whole≈øome it is to enjoy a ≈øweet and clear Air, to walk ≈øometimes in the Fields, to ri≈øe betimes in the Morning, than which there is nothing in the World that chears and glads the Heart of Man more, and does al≈øo wonderfully contribute to Health. To conclude, in Trouble and Adver≈øity, let a Man defend him≈øelf from Dejection of Mind, and in Pro≈øperity from extream Joy.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Of things contrary to Nature.
div.p: THings contrary to Nature, or preternatural, are things oppo≈øite to the natural Con≈øtitution of a living Body. They are three, a Di≈øea≈øe, the Cau≈øe of a Di≈øea≈øe, and the Symptom; under which every thing contrary to Nature is comprehended.

A Di≈øea≈øe is a Con≈øtitution contrary to the nature of a living Body, whereby all the actions are not rightly performed. This Con≈øtitution proceeds from an undue temper, conformation or union of the Parts,
whereby ≈øome action is performed ill, or at lea≈øt not rightly modified, and hereby we are rendred incapable to perform all the actions aright. It is ≈øaid, whereby all the Actions are not perform'd aright; becau≈øe an ob≈øtruction of all the actions is not required to a Di≈øea≈øe; but it is ≈øaid to be a Di≈øea≈øe, if any one of them be hurt.

When we ≈øay a Di≈øea≈øe is a Con≈øtitution contrary to Nature, it does not include the Con≈øtitution of old Men and Children, tho in it the actions are not rightly performed; becau≈øe ≈øuch Ages are agreeable to the cour≈øe of Nature.
The living Body, and the ≈øolid and fluid parts of it are the ≈øubjects of a Di≈øea≈øe.

A Di≈øea≈øe is divided e≈ø≈øentially into three ≈øpecies; into a Di≈øea≈øe from an undue temper, or ≈øimilar; into a Di≈øea≈øe from an ill formation, or organick; and into a Di≈øea≈øe occa≈øioned from the ≈øolution of the Continuum. It is al≈øo otherwi≈øe variou≈øly divided according to its accidental differences, into univer≈øal, particular, contagious, not contagious, epidemic, endemic, long, ≈øhort, acute, not acute, benign, malignant, great, ≈ømall, ≈øimple, compound, primary, ≈øecundary, ≈øymptomatic, hereditary.

A Similar Di≈øea≈øe, or a Di≈øea≈øe proceeding from an undue temper, ari≈øes from an inconvenient temper of the fir≈øt qualities, as a Di≈øea≈øe from a hot or cold intemperies of the Brain or Stomach, or the like.
An Organick Di≈øea≈øe is a Di≈øea≈øe ari≈øing from an ill Formation of the Part. It is fourfold, ari≈øing from an undue Figure, magnitude, number, and Situation of the Part.
A Di≈øea≈øe proceeding from a ≈øolution of the Continuum is a hurt of the Function of a Similar, or Organick Part. It is fourfold, viz. a Contu≈øion, a Wound, a Fracture, and an Ulcer.
An univer≈øal Di≈øea≈øe is that which affects the whole Body, as Cachexy, Ana≈øarca, and the like.
A particular Di≈øea≈øe is that which affects only part of the Body, as a Pleurifie, and the like.
A contagious Di≈øea≈øe is that which is conveyed to another by ≈øome Effluvia.
Di≈øea≈øes called Pandemij, are Di≈øea≈øes of the ≈øame Species, which invade many at the ≈øame time, and in the ≈øame Region.
An Epidemic or Popular Di≈øea≈øe, is a Di≈øea≈øe ari≈øing from ≈øome common Cau≈øe, and ≈øeizes many at one time and place, but is not re≈øtrained to one Region, as the Plague, Quin≈øie, Pleuri≈øie.

An Endemic Di≈øea≈øe is a Di≈øea≈øe ari≈øing from ≈øome common cau≈øe, that is proper to ≈øome Region or Regions, as the Scurvy to Holland, Denmark, Swedeland, Norway; the French Pox to India, the Bronchochele to the Alpes, the Plicae Poloniae, and the like.
Sporadic Di≈øea≈øes are Di≈øea≈øes of different kinds, which invade many at the ≈øame time, and in the ≈øame Region, as a Pleuri≈øie, and Ophthalmia.

From the Time Di≈øea≈øes are ≈øhort or long. A Di≈øea≈øe is ≈øhort that ≈øoon comes to its end; as a Diary, a burning Fever, and the like. A Di≈øea≈øe is long, when it does not come to its end in a ≈øhort time, as a Drop≈øie, Pal≈øie, and the like.

A Di≈øea≈øe is Acute, when it comes to its end in a ≈øhort time with danger. An extream Acute Di≈øea≈øe ends in three or four days at farthe≈øt; as a Pe≈øtilential Fever, or the like. It is ≈øaid to be peracute, when it la≈øts ≈øeven days.

From Magnitude a Di≈øea≈øe is ≈øaid to be great or ≈ømall. The Magnitude of a Di≈øea≈øe may be two ways con≈øidered. Fir≈øt, with compari≈øon to the Per≈øon affected; and ≈øo a Di≈øea≈øe ≈ømall in it ≈øelf may be accounted great, in a weak Man or a Child. Secondly, Di≈øea≈øe is called great which ≈øoon dejects the ≈øtrength, and kills; and the greatne≈øs of it may ari≈øe from the noblene≈øs, or great u≈øe of the part afflicted.

A ≈øimple Di≈øea≈øe is an Ob≈øtruction of ≈øome Vein or Wound, or a cold Intemperies of the Stomach, or the like. Organic with common; for in≈øtance, the Magnitude of the Foot increa≈øed with a Wound. Similar with organic and common, as a Wound of the Hand with a great and hot ≈øwelling.
A Primary Di≈øea≈øe is a Di≈øea≈øe produced by ≈øome Cau≈øe, which is not a Di≈øea≈øe in the ≈øame Body.
