An hereditary Di≈øea≈øe is a Di≈øea≈øe imparted to the Child by the Parents, obnoxious to ≈øuch a kind of Di≈øea≈øe, upon account of the Fault of the Seed, or of the Nutriment of the Child. I ≈øay obnoxious, for it is not nece≈ø≈øary the Parents ≈øhould actually have the Di≈øea≈øe, or that they ≈øhould ever have it. Perhaps it is prevented by a contrary Cour≈øe of Diet, or the like, it is enough if there be ≈øuch a Di≈øpo≈øition.

The Time of the Di≈øea≈øe is the Time wherein ≈øome notable Change of the Di≈øea≈øe is ob≈øerved. The univer≈øal Time is that which di≈øtingui≈øhes the Cour≈øe of the whole Di≈øea≈øe. It is fourfold, the Beginning, Increa≈øe, State, and Declination; the≈øe four Times are
ab≈øolutely accounted in every Di≈øea≈øe, whether it tends to Life or Death, whether it be cured by Medicines, or not: But the≈øe Times are went to be very unequal; becau≈øe one Di≈øea≈øe runs its Cour≈øe much ≈øooner than another, and con≈øequently pa≈ø≈øes all the Sea≈øons ≈øooner.

No one dies in the univer≈øal Declination of a Di≈øea≈øe, at lea≈øt of that Di≈øea≈øe, whereof that is the Declination; for the Cau≈øe of the Di≈øea≈øe is expelled and overcome, yet he may die in the Declination by ≈øome other Di≈øea≈øe joined with it, or coming upon it, or by Defect, or Want of things requi≈øite to Life.

The particular Time of the Di≈øea≈øe is that which di≈øtingui≈øhes the Cour≈øe of the Paroxy≈øm. The Paroxy≈øm is the Exacerbation coming by turns in Di≈øea≈øes. The Period is the Time of Exacerbation and Remi≈ø≈øion in ≈øome Di≈øea≈øes. The Type is the Order of Inten≈øion and Remi≈ø≈øion: But every Di≈øea≈øe has not a Type or Period, as an Atrophy, Pal≈øy, Eliphantia≈øis, and the like; for they continually afflict.

The Cau≈øe of a Di≈øea≈øe with Phy≈øicians, is a thing contrary to Nature, effecting a Di≈øea≈øe. It is divided into procatarctic, antecedent, and continent. The procatarctic Cau≈øe is the Cau≈øe that is evident to any one. It is twofold, internal and external. The internal are all the Pa≈ø≈øions of the Mind, Anger, Sorrow, Mirth, Pain, and the like. The external are a Stone, a Sword, a Knife, a Stick, Air, Meat and Drink, and the like.

The antecedent Cau≈øe is a Cau≈øe not evident to every one, which being taken off, the Di≈øea≈øe does not pre≈øently cea≈øe, ≈øuch is the Abundance of Blood, which cau≈øes an Inflammation in ≈øome Part; being removed by bleeding, the Inflammation does not pre≈øently cea≈øe.
The containing Cau≈øe is that which being taken of the Di≈øea≈øe pre≈øently cea≈øes.

A Symptom is an Effect of a Di≈øea≈øe, as Thir≈øt of a Fever: A Symptom ought to follow a Di≈øea≈øe as its Cau≈øe; either nearly or remotely. A Di≈øea≈øe may be al≈øo a Symptom, ≈øo is a Fever following an Inflammation.
A Symptom is divided into three general Species, viz. The Action Hurt, the Fault of things evacuated and retained, and the Quality of the Blood changed.

The Action is hurt when it is not as it ≈øhould be. There are three Kinds of Action hurt, viz. aboli≈øhed, dimini≈øhed, and depraved. div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of the Signs in general, and of ≈øome of the Species of them.
div.p: ASign, among Phy≈øicians, is a manife≈øt thing that leads us to the Knowledge of ≈øomething that is hidden. It is divided into diagno≈øtic, progno≈øtic, and commemorative; and the≈øe are ≈øubdivided into healthy and unhealthy. I do not add neutral; becau≈øe I think there is no ≈øuch thing as a neutral Con≈øtitution; becau≈øe every one is either ≈øick or well.

A diagno≈øtic Sign is moreover in≈øeparable and proper, and al≈øo in≈øeparable and proper together. The diagno≈øtic is that which ≈øignifies ≈øomething pre≈øent. The progno≈øtic is that which ≈øignifies ≈øomething that is future. The commemorative Sign is that which ≈øignifies ≈øomething that is pa≈øt. The healthy Sign is that which ≈øignifies Health pre≈øent, future, or pa≈øt. An unhealthy Sign is that which ≈øignifies a Di≈øea≈øe pre≈øent, pa≈øt, or to come. An in≈øeparable diagno≈øtic Sign is that which ≈øignifies ≈øome Con≈øtitution, and cannot be ≈øeparated from it. A proper diagno≈øtic Sign is that which agrees only to one. This Sign is truly pathognomonic; for it ≈øignifies the proper Nature and E≈ø≈øence of the Di≈øea≈øe from whence it flows: But it is ordinarily not one ≈øimple Sign, but a Heap of many together; for in≈øtance, a pricking Pain in the Side, with a Cough, and Difficulty of Breathing, a Fever, and a a ≈øtrong Pul≈øe, of a Pleuri≈øie.

An healthy diagno≈øtic Sign is a natural Pul≈øe, and a natural Urine. An healthy Progno≈øtic is the Concoction of the Excrements in Di≈øea≈øes. An healthy Commemorative Progno≈øtic is a Firmne≈øs of all the Actions; for that ≈øignifies pre≈øent Health. An unhealthy Diagno≈øtic is an Hurt of the Action, as a Swelling with Redne≈øs, and a beating Pain, of an In≈ølammation. An unhealthy Progno≈øtic is ≈øpontaneous La≈ø≈øitude. An unhealthy commemorative Sign is a Cicatrix; al≈øo the Weakne≈øs of tho≈øe that recover.

Signs are generally taken from the Cau≈øes, as the Fountain, or from the Effects; that is, from all tho≈øe things which any way follow Health, the Di≈øea≈øe, or the Cau≈øes of it. Some will have the E≈ø≈øence of a thing to be added here, and ≈øo they ≈øay that a Piece of the Lungs being ca≈øt up, an Ulcer of them is bred, or Part of the thick Guts being ca≈øt out by Stool in a Di≈øentery, they ≈øay they know the gro≈øs Guts are affected: But in the Ca≈øes mentioned, the Sign is not taken
from the very E≈ø≈øence of the thing, as di≈øtinct from the Cau≈øes and Effects, but meerly from the Effects.

The progno≈øtic Sign, both healthy and unhealthy, ≈øerves much for the Honour of the Phy≈øician; for a ≈øucce≈øsful Progno≈øtication gives him great Authority, and makes the ≈øick better tru≈øt him: But he mu≈øt be careful that he be not too free or ra≈øh in his Progno≈øtication, le≈øt he get Di≈øgrace.

A Di≈øea≈øe may be known by four Signs: Fir≈øt, By the Species of what is excreted, ≈øo a Di≈øentery is known by the ≈ømall Parts of the Inte≈øtines evacuated by Stool, a ≈øtony Con≈øtitution by a ≈øandy Urine. Secondly, By the Nature of the Place, ≈øo a Di≈øea≈øe or ill Con≈øtitution from Worms is known by Pains torturing the Belly. Thirdly, from the Propriety of the Pain, ≈øo an Inflammation is known by a beating Pain. Fourthly, By proper Accidents, ≈øo a burning Fever is known by a violent Heat of the whole Body, and by the Blackne≈øs of the Tongue, and a great Thir≈øt; a Pleuri≈øie by difficult breathing, with a Cough and Fever. There are al≈øo be≈øides three more Signs that are le≈øs principal, viz. a Proclivity of the ≈øick to a certain Di≈øea≈øe; ≈øo an hy≈øteric Pa≈ø≈øion is known in ≈øome Women by their Di≈øpo≈øition that way. The evident Cau≈øe foregoing the Di≈øea≈øe, ≈øo a hot Di≈øea≈øe is known in tho≈øe that u≈øe a hot Diet, tho≈øe things that do Good or Hurt; ≈øo a hot Di≈øea≈øe is known, by being exa≈øperated by hot Medicines, and mitigated by cold.

The Cau≈øe of the Di≈øea≈øe is known chiefly by ≈øeven Signs: Fir≈øt, By the Temperament, and ≈øo by a hot Temperament we may know the Cau≈øe of the Di≈øea≈øe is hot. Secondly, By the Colour of the Skin, ≈øo by the yellow Colour of the Skin, you may know that Bile is the Cau≈øe. Thirdly, By the Age, ≈øo by Old Age you may know the Cau≈øe is cold; by Youth you
may know it is hot. Fourthly, By the Species of the Pain; ≈øo Bile is known by a burning Pain. Fifthly, By the evident Cau≈øe, ≈øo by high and plentiful feeding, and a ≈øedentary Life, you may know that too great a Quantity of Blood is the Cau≈øe, ≈øo by a cooling Remedy doing good, you may know that the Cau≈øe is hot.

The Signs of a Plethora are, a tumid Habit of the Body, an Expan≈øion and Ten≈øion of the Veins, a red Colour of the whole Body, e≈øpecially of the Face, a full Pul≈øe, an Unfitne≈øs for Motion, a ≈øpontaneous and ten≈øive La≈ø≈øitude in the whole Body, a voluptuous Life, Suppre≈ø≈øion of u≈øual Evacuations, and the like.

The Signs of Cacochymy are diver≈øe, as the Species of it are diver≈øe, the chief whereof are choleric, melancholy, flegmatic, ≈øanguine, and ≈øerous, and they are in the whole Body, or only in Part of it. The Signs of a bilious Cacochymy, are a yellow Colour of the Skin, e≈øpecially of the Face, an high colour'd Urine, quick Pal≈øe, choleric Excrements, choleric Pu≈øtles, a Pricking in the Habit of the Body, an hot and dry Diet, Relief by cold and moi≈øt things, and the like. The Signs of a flegmatick Cacochymy are, a white Colour of the Skin, a ≈øoft and tumid Habit of the Body, flegmatic Excretions, a pale Urine, much Sleep, Relief by hot and dry things, a cold and moi≈øt Diet.
The Signs of Wind are, a Ten≈øion and Tumour without Gravity, which does not pit upon pre≈ø≈øing with the Finger, a wandering Pain, an Eruption, or bel≈øhing of Wind, a flatulent Diet, and the like.

The Part affected is known by five Signs. Fir≈øt, By the Action hurt, ≈øo a Di≈øorder of the Ear is known by Dea≈øne≈øs. Secondly, By the Situation of the Di≈øea≈øe, ≈øo you may know the Spleen is affected by a hard ≈øwe ‚Ä¢
ling on the left Side. Thirdly, by the Propriety of the Pain, ≈øo you may know a Membrane is affected by
a pungent Pain; you may know a Parenchyma is affected by a heavy Pain. Fourthly, By proper Accidents, ≈øo by Anxiety you may know the Stomach is affected, and by fainting you may know the Heart is affected. Fifthly, by things that are evacuated, as you may know the Lungs are affected by ≈ømall Particles of the ≈øpongy Fle≈øh ca≈øt up by coughing; you may al≈øo know the Bowels are affected by the Excrements coming out of a Wound of the Belly, ≈øo that things evacuated are not here to be under≈øtood only of tho≈øe things which come from the Sub≈øtance of the Part affected, but al≈øo things contained in it. Moreover, as to things evacuated, three things are further to be con≈øidered, which do mo≈øt di≈øtinctly ≈øhew the affected Part, viz. the Propriety of the Sub≈øtance excreted, and ≈øo by Froth ca≈øt up, we may know the Lungs are affected. 2dly. By the Magnitude of the Sub≈øtance excreted, ≈øo a gro≈ø≈øer Tunic of the Guts being voided by Stool, we may know a gro≈øs Gut is affected. La≈øtly, By the Manner of Evacuation, ≈øo an Artery hurt is known by the impetuous Efflux of the Blood.

A Symptom that is manife≈øt is known by it ≈øelf, but that which is ob≈øcure is be≈øt known by ≈øome more manife≈øt Symptom of the ≈øame Di≈øea≈øe; and remotely and ob≈øcurely by the Di≈øea≈øe, and the Cau≈øe of it, ≈øo by the wa≈øting of the Body, as by the mo≈øt remarkable Symptom, we know that Nutrition is le≈ø≈øened, and ≈øo a Fault of Sanguification by an ill Colour of the Body, and a weak Con≈øtriction of the Heart, by a weak Pul≈øe.

By four Signs e≈øpecially you may know whether the Di≈øea≈øe will be cured, or will kill, viz. By the Species of it, the Magnitude of it, with a re≈øpect to the Strength of the ≈øick, by the Motion of it, and the Manner of it, ≈øo for in≈øtance, a Di≈øea≈øe that is known to be deadly by its Species, is a Con≈øumption, a Wound of the Heart, the Plague, a Cancer, and the
like: A Di≈øea≈øe on the contrary, which is known by its Species to be curable, is an Ephemeral Fever, and the like: A Di≈øea≈øe which is known to be deadly by its Magnitude, is either great in its ≈øelf, or comparatively ≈øo; becau≈øe it is to la≈øt long, e≈øpecially if it be al≈øo malignant. A Di≈øea≈øe is known to be deadly by the wor≈øt and mo≈øt grievous Symptoms. La≈øtly, a deadly Di≈øea≈øe is known by its Motion, for in≈øtance, if it be long, tho' only moderate, it is dangerous and great; for ≈øuch an one wa≈øtes the Strength by degrees, and at length kills.

As to the Length and Shortne≈øs of a Di≈øea≈øe, they may be known chiefly by three things. Fir≈øt, By the Species of the Di≈øea≈øe, ≈øo an Apoplexy, Plague, an ephemeral Fever, are known to be ≈øhort; a quartan Ague, Pal≈øy, and the like, are known to be long. Secondly, By the Magnitude of the Di≈øea≈øe, ≈øo you know a Di≈øea≈øe in it ≈øelf great, or comparatively ≈øo, does not la≈øt long. Thirdly, From the manner of the Di≈øea≈øe, ≈øo you may know a Di≈øea≈øe will not la≈øt long, that has unu≈øual and violent Symptoms. The Progno≈øtics taken from the≈øe Signs are not a little confirmed by the Sea≈øon of the Year, ≈øo Di≈øea≈øes in the Autumn and Winter are wont to be longer than Di≈øea≈øes in the Spring and Summer, by rea≈øon of the Tenuity of the Matter, and the greater Apertion of the Body.
A critical Sign is that which ≈øignifies a Cri≈øis. It is wont to be reckoned threefold, demon≈øtrative, progno≈øtic, and commemorative.

A critical demon≈øtrative Sign is a great Loo≈øene≈øs, or a large Hemorrhage at the No≈øe, as they make ≈øome Change in the Di≈øea≈øe. A critical progno≈øtic Sign is a great Pain of the Head, Redne≈øs of the Face, as they ≈øignifie a Hemorrhage of the No≈øe. A commemorative critical Sign is the better Di≈øpo≈øition of the ≈øick, after the Cri≈øis is made.

A Cri≈øis is the ≈øudden Change of a Di≈øea≈øe, either for Life or Death, it is divided into good and bad, al≈øo into perfect and imperfect. A good Cri≈øis is for Life, a bad Cri≈øis for Death. A Cri≈øis that is perfect, perfectly carries off the Di≈øea≈øe.

A Cri≈øis is not perfect in our Country, becau≈øe our Region is cold, and the Humours are cold, but the chief rea≈øon is, becau≈øe the Practice in the≈øe Parts is ≈øuch, as does not commit much to Nature; but we do at the Beginning carry off, or at lea≈øt le≈ø≈øen the Cau≈øe of the Di≈øea≈øe, by bleeding, or gentle purging, or by Medicines that move Urine or Sweat, or the like. Yet, notwith≈øtanding, a Cri≈øis does ≈øometimes happen here; for ≈øometimes we ≈øee, that Fevers are ≈øometime carried off by Sweat, a Loo≈øene≈øs, or bleeding at the No≈øe.

The Cau≈øe of a Cri≈øis is a violent Influx of the animal Spirits into the Fibres of ≈øome Part, whereby the Part contracting it ≈øelf, expels the Cau≈øe of the Di≈øea≈øe, or our Heat, or the Motion of the Blood, whereof the Cau≈øe of the Di≈øea≈øe con≈øi≈øts, is detruded to certain Parts; and if this or that Protru≈øion of the morbi≈øic Matter be ≈øuch, that thereby it be wholly eliminated from the Body, the Cri≈øis is perfect. The Ancients a≈ø≈øigned certain Days for a good and perfect Cri≈øis, and ≈øo much depended on them, that they did not fear a Relap≈øe, when the Cri≈øis happened on any of the≈øe Days; and ≈øome of the≈øe Days they called Indices, or Contemplabiles, becau≈øe then they were to ≈øee whether the Signs of Concoction did appear in the Excrements, and ≈øo promi≈øe a good Cri≈øis: Others they called Interdicentes, in which no Cri≈øis was made; but there was a Provocation of Nature to a Cri≈øis. La≈øtly, Of the≈øe they called ≈øome void Days, wherein no Cri≈øis was made, nor was there any Provocation of Nature to it. The≈øe they al≈øo called medicinal, becau≈øe they counted it lawful to give Medicines at this Time.
But ≈øeeing it appears from their Writings, that a good Cri≈øis has been made of any Day, and becau≈øe there is no rea≈øon why tho≈øe Days ≈øhould be only critical, we attribute no more to them, than we do to climateric Years, that ≈øo much terrifie rich and covetous Men, and to bi≈ø≈øextile Years, that frighten Women with Child.

There are ≈øuch great Differences of the Pul≈øe among Authors, that it is impo≈ø≈øible to di≈øtingui≈øh them; wherefore I ≈øhall only ≈øet down tho≈øe that are u≈øeful in Practice, and the≈øe Differences are four, great and ≈ømall, ≈øtrong and weak, equal and unequal, frequent and rare. A great Pul≈øe is when the Artery beats much, long, broad, and deep, a ≈ømall Pul≈øe is, when the Artery does not beat much, nor long, broad, and deep; you mu≈øt always under≈øtand proportionable to the Body; for the Pul≈øe of the Body may be great with re≈øpect to it, tho' it be really le≈øs than in a Man. The Cau≈øe of a great Pul≈øe is a great Quantity of Blood, or a great Rarefaction of it in the Arteries. A great Pul≈øe, as to it ≈øelf, fignifies Strength, and is a good Sign, and on the contrary, a ≈ømall Pul≈øe ≈øignifies Weakne≈øs, Death, or at lea≈øt a long Continuance of the Di≈øea≈øe: But you mu≈øt not think that a great Pul≈øe is always be≈øt; for it is to be ≈øu≈øpected ≈øometimes, as in tho≈øe that are plethoric; for the great Con≈øtriction of the Heart oftner proceeds from too great an Irritation of it, than from the Strength of the Faculty; wherefore a moderate Pul≈øe is be≈øt.

The Pul≈øe is ≈øtrong when the Artery ≈øtrikes the Finger hard upon touching. The Pul≈øe is weak, when the Artery ≈øtrikes the Finger weakly. A ≈øtrong Pul≈øe proceeds from a ≈øtrong Con≈øtriction of the Heart, and from a ≈øtrong Cour≈øe of the Blood into the Arteries; and therefore is a good Sign; namely, it ≈øhews Strength, and a brisk Influx of the animal Spirits into the Heart, it ≈øhews al≈øo the Shortne≈øs of the Di≈øea≈øe;
for where ≈øuch a Pul≈øe is, the Body the ea≈øier clean≈øes it ≈øelf from the morbific Matter. An equal Pul≈øe is when the Pul≈øe equally ≈øtrikes the Finger touching it. A frequent Pul≈øe is when it frequently ≈øtrikes the Finger touching it. The Cau≈øes of a frequent Pul≈øe are a Di≈øpo≈øition of the Blood to rarifie pre≈øently in the Heart, the Tenuity of it, and the previous Rarity. A rare Pul≈øe flows from contrary Cau≈øes, it is ill in Youth, common in Age, but wor≈øt, when it is weak as well as rare.

A Pul≈øe proper to a hot Temperament, is wont to be great and frequent, and often ≈øtrong. A Pul≈øe proper to a cold Temperament is ≈ømall, ≈ølow, and weak: A Pul≈øe proper to a dry Temperament is rate and ≈øomewhat hard. A Pul≈øe proper to a moi≈øt Temperament is ≈øomewhat great, rare, and ≈øoft. From what has been ≈øaid, it is ea≈øie to judge of Pul≈øes proper to compounded Temperaments, as hot and dry, hot and moi≈øt, cold and dry, cold and moi≈øt.

Childrens Pul≈øe are very quick, and ≈øomewhat ≈øoft; for their Blood is very thin, and their Heart is very tender. In Youths and Men, the Pul≈øe is very great, and very ≈øtrong, in Women the Pul≈øe is quick and ≈øoft, ≈øometimes great, but mo≈øt commonly ≈ømall, for their Heat is weak. Old People have a rare and weak Pul≈øe, by rea≈øon their Heat is languid. In the Spring the Pul≈øe is wont to be ≈øtrong, great, and moderately quick, for the Blood abounds by rea≈øon of the foregoing Winter, and the Heat is moderate. In the Summer the Pul≈øe is quick, ≈øomewhat great, and ≈øtrong, becau≈øe the Blood rarifies better, and the Heat is more. In Autumn the Pul≈øe is incon≈øtant and weak, becau≈øe the Heat is le≈ø≈øened, and by rea≈øon of the frequent Variation of the State of the Air. In the Winter the Pul≈øe is ≈ømall, weak, and rare, for in Winter the Heat langui≈øhes by rea≈øon of Sero≈øity, and is le≈ø≈øened by the Air. In Sleep the Pul≈øe is languid, rare, and ≈ømall, for the Heat is then ≈ømall: But when any one awakes, the Pul≈øe is increa≈øed,
and is very unequal, becau≈øe the Spirits ru≈øh from the Brain into the Nerves of the Heart. In Anger the Pul≈øe is great, ≈øtrong, and frequent; becau≈øe the Spirits are carried plentifully and violently into the Heart. In Sorrow the Pul≈øe is ≈ømall, weak, and rare, becau≈øe the Spirits langui≈øh in the Brain. In Mirth the Pul≈øe is moderately great, ≈øtrong, and equal. The Pul≈øe proper for Love is more difficultly known; for it is compounded of ≈øeveral Pul≈øes, of diver≈øe Affections of the Mind; yet any one may know Love by the Pul≈øe, if Signs of Di≈øea≈øes being ab≈øent, the Pul≈øe is very unequal and inordinate; for the Spirits are wont to move very irregularly both in the Brain and out of it; for ≈øometimes they are merry, and ≈øometimes ≈øad, ≈øometimes they fear, and ≈øometimes they hope well.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Of the ∆≤rine as a Sign, of the Indication, the Indicant, and the thing indicated.
div.p: WE treat only here of the Urine, as an Effect, ≈øhewing its Cau≈øe in the Body, and ≈øo taken, it ≈øhews the Temper of the Body, or ≈øomething particular about the Parts of it, thro' which the Serum continually flows; for by them it is varied in Sub≈øtance or Quality; but the In≈øpection of the Urine is be≈øt after Chylification is perfectly made, and therefore it is be≈øt to ≈øee it after Sleep in a Morning. You mu≈øt put it into a clear and thin Gla≈øs, that is round at Bottom; but it mu≈øt not be viewed after Coition, Watching, Purging, or after U≈øe of Medicines that affect the Urine, and it mu≈øt not be viewed as ≈øoon as voided, nor too long after; but as ≈øoon as it is cold, and has a Sediment. You ought to view it in a clear Air.
If any one ≈øhall bring to a Phy≈øician, with De≈øign to deceive him, the Urine of a Brute, or any thing el≈øe, in≈øtead of Man's Water, the Cheat is be≈øt di≈øcovered by the Smell.

Every Di≈øea≈øe cannot be known by the Urine, tho' Pi≈øs-prophets pretend they are able to know all by it; for a Giddine≈øs of the Head, a Wound of a certain Part, a Pal≈øy, Luxation, and many other Di≈øea≈øes cannot be known by it, tho' ≈øomething may be brought to the Reins and Bladder from every Part: But the Con≈øtitutions, Good or Ill of tho≈øe Parts, wherein the Urine is perfected, generated, or ≈øomewhat altered, are chiefly known by the Urine, as of the Vi≈øcera ≈øerving for Concoction of the Blood, Heart, Ureters, and Reins; therefore I ≈øay that Urine is a very general diagno≈øtic Sign, and more general than the Pul≈øe, becau≈øe it often di≈øcovers the Di≈øea≈øe, the Cau≈øe of it, and the Part affected; but the Pul≈øe does not ≈øo; for by the Urine we know Di≈øea≈øes, as Ulcers, Wounds, Ob≈øtructions, and the Intemperies of the inner Parts; by the Urine we know the Cau≈øes, as Vi≈øcidity, Crudity, Choler, Stones, Sand, Clods of Blood, and the like. By the Urine we know the Part affected, as the Bladder affected by Scales or fetid Pus mixed with the Urine. We know the Reins are affected by Caruncles, Blood and Pus coming away with the Urine. We know that the Bladder of the Gaul is affected by the Urine being pale for a long while: But none of the≈øe are found by the Pul≈øe, yet the Pul≈øe is a more certain Sign of Life or Death, for it ≈øhews the primary Cau≈øes of Life, whether they are well or ill, as the Influx of the animal Spirits from the Brain to the Heart, the Temper of the Heart, Blood, and the Concomitants of them.

Urine al≈øo often ≈øhews Death, as an I≈øchury by the Defect of it in a Leucophlegmatia, by the Aquo≈øity of it; in an Ulcer of the Bladder, by Pus mixed with it, in
the Plague, by the Blackne≈øs of it, and its variegated Colour, and the like: But we mu≈øt not progno≈øticate any thing ra≈øhly by the In≈øpection of the Urine: For ≈øometimes, in the mo≈øt dangerous Di≈øea≈øes, and when the Pul≈øe are ill, the Urine appears good, and yet the Patient dyes notwith≈øtanding; wherefore it is very fallacious.

The chief Colours which are ob≈øerved in Urine, are the≈øe four, white, red, yellow, black. The general Cau≈øes of Colours in Urine are the Heat continually boyling, and working upon the Aliment, the Stomach, and Guts, and upon the Chyle mixed with the Blood. That Heat is the Cau≈øe of the Colour in Urine is very manife≈øt from Fevers, the Heat of the Air, Labour, long Retention of it in the Body, and the like; and we ≈øee that by Heat Beer grows redder, and that Rheni≈øh Wine carried into Spain looks more yellow, and Urine boyled over the Fire grows very red.

White Urine is twofold, one thin, called watery, the other thick, called milky. The Cau≈øe of a watry Urine is weak Heat, as in ≈øuch as are cachectical, and hydropical, large Drinking, too ≈øhort a Continuance of it in the Body by rea≈øon of the Laxity of the Pa≈øages; for ≈øo ≈øuch a due Chylification and Sanguification cannot be made, as to tincture the Urine. An Ob≈øtruction of the Pa≈ø≈øages, as we ≈øee in a Stone of the Kidnies. La≈øtly, Choler, by rea≈øon it is carried to the Head by being thin and light, as we ≈øee it is ≈øometimes very ≈øuddenly in Fevers, and then it betokens a Delirium. The Cau≈øe of a milky Urine is the Mixture of ≈øome white Humour with it, as Flegm, Seed, Pus, and the like.

A yellow Urine is cau≈øed by a due Concoction of the Chyle with the Blood. A red Urine is made by the Mixture of Blood with it, or by a greater Coction. Blood is mixed with the Urine, either upon the account
of the Tenuity of it, or by rea≈øon of a Rupture of a Ve≈ø≈øel in the Reins, or Bladder, or the like. A black Urine, and other Species of it, ≈øignifie the Adu≈ø≈øe on or Corruption of the Humours in the Body. The Urine often changes Colour, and ≈øo when 'tis voided red, being expo≈øed to the Air, it ≈øometimes, a little after, turns brown or yellow, and this comes to pa≈øs by the divers Reflection of the Light.

The Urine never ≈ømells plea≈øantly unle≈øs ≈øome odoriferous thing be taken in, as Musk or the like, yet the natural Smell is not very ≈øtinking tho ≈øtrong and ≈øulphureous, and if it be without, it argues Debility of Heat, or that the Urine has not continued long enough in the Body. If the Urine ≈øtink much (unle≈øs ≈øtinking things have been taken in, as putrid Chee≈øe, Garlic, or the like) it ≈øignifies the Corruption of ≈øome Humour, or the Ulceration of ≈øome Part, e≈øpecially if Pus be mixt with it. But Urine that has Pus mixt with it, does not nece≈ø≈øarily ≈øtink, for often Pus it ≈øelf, coming from an Impo≈øtume, ≈øcarce ≈ømells, and much le≈øs when it is mixt with Urine. But it is manife≈øt from Experience, that Matter made in the Reins or Bladder, ≈øtinks much, and is gro≈øs and vi≈øcid.

The Ta≈øte of the Urine is ≈øalt and nitrous, as is the Serum whereof it is chiefly con≈øtituted, if it has any other Ta≈øt, it proceeds from the Mixture of another Humour, and ≈øignifies that ≈øuch an Humour abounds in the Body. But you will ≈øay, it is below a Phy≈øician to ta≈øte: Urine I an≈øwer, the Phy≈øician need not ta≈øte the Urine, for the Patient him≈øelf may do it.

The Quantity of the Urine is either the Abundance or Paucity of it. The Quantity in the natural State, is proportionable to the liquid Matter taken in, yet ≈øomewhat le≈øs, perhaps about a third, for ≈øome Part of it continually pa≈ø≈øes into Nouri≈øhment, and ≈øome Part is evacuated in≈øen≈øibly, or by Sweat, or by Spittle, and ≈øome ought to remain in the Blood to dilute it, or to be a Vehicle for it.

a great Quantity of Urine, unle≈øs it be occa≈øioned by Cold ob≈øtructing in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration, or by rea≈øon of taking Diureticks, Drop≈øie, Rheumati≈øm, or by the Cri≈øis of a Fever, whereby the Cau≈øe of the Di≈øea≈øe is carried off, ≈øignifies a Debility of the urinary Pa≈ø≈øages, and the Laxity of them, and as the Effect, the future wa≈øting of the Body, as in a Diabetes. A ≈ømall Quantity of Urine, unle≈øs it proceeds from a Defect of liquid things taken in, ≈øignifies great Heat di≈ø≈øipating the Serum, by in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration, Sweat, or the like, and is often ≈øeen in Fevers; or it ≈øignifies an Ob≈øtruction of the urinary Pa≈ø≈øages, a Drop≈øie of ≈øome Part, a Rheumati≈øm, Catarrh, or the like.
The natural Con≈øi≈øtence of Urine is like that of Beer, moderately and duely boyl'd and fermented.
A gro≈øs Urine ari≈øes from a Defect of Sero≈øity, or by ≈øome thick thing mixed with it, as it happens ≈øometimes at the Beginning of Fevers, and in Children that eat too much.
A thin Urine proceeds from an Ob≈øtruction of the Urinary Pa≈ø≈øages, and ≈øo by rea≈øon of the Stone in the Kidneys it is thin, or by rea≈øon of the Weakne≈øs of the natural Heat.

That which is contained in the Urine is that Body which is ob≈øervable in the Sub≈øtance of the Urine. It is univer≈øally threefold, the Hypo≈øta≈øis, which ≈øub≈øides to the Bottom; the Eneorema which is ≈øu≈øpended in the Middle, and the Nubecula which is on the Top: Of the≈øe none ought to be in the Urine of a well Per≈øon, but the Hypo≈øta≈øis, which ≈øignifies that Concoction is made, and if it be of a whiti≈øh, and of a round Figure, and equal, it is be≈øt.

That which is particularly contained in the Urine is either a Stone, Sand, Matter, Blood, Caruncles, Fat, or a brawny Sediment; and mo≈øt of the≈øe ≈øignifie a Di≈øpo≈øition to the Stone in the Kidnies, or in the Bladder.
Fat ≈øignifies a wa≈øting of the Body, and is often ≈øeen upon the Top of the Urine of con≈øumptive People. As to the Sand, it is not as ≈øome think always Fragments of a greater Stone, but a certain Concrete of Salt in the Urine.

Becau≈øe the ordinary People, and ≈øome of the better Sort have been a long while, and are ≈øtill much abu≈øed by Quacks, Empericks, and ≈øome methodical Phi≈øicians, who pretend to the Knowledge of all Di≈øea≈øes, by the In≈øpection of the Urine, I ≈øhall here make appear, that there is no certain Knowledge of many Di≈øea≈øes to be gathered from the Urine alone, and that it is better for the Phy≈øician to ≈øee his Patient once, than to view his Urine twenty times: And ≈øeveral learned Phy≈øicians have likewi≈øe written diver≈øe Tracts therein, di≈øcovering the Dangers of taking Phy≈øick pre≈øcribed only by the Sight of the Urine, to the end that they might di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs Men of that fond Opinion of a Phy≈øician's di≈øcerning Di≈øea≈øes by it, wherewith they have been ≈øo long time deluded; and one of the≈øe, in ≈øhewing the Fal≈øhood and uncertain Judgment of Di≈øea≈øes by the Urine, hath ≈øet down the ingenious Confe≈ø≈øion of a dying Phy≈øician, made to him, being then pre≈øent with him ≈øome three or four Days before his Departure, who being reque≈øted to leave to Po≈øterity that Skill whereby he had been ≈øo much admired and e≈øteemed for judging Women to be with Child by their Urine, made this An≈øwer; I have, ≈øaid he, with great Applau≈øe, exerci≈øed it, and found, by much Experience, that it is a great Cheat; and therefore not worthy to be counted an Art, and unfit to be communicated to Po≈øterity. Another of them makes al≈øo this fair Confe≈ø≈øion. Says he, I have been ≈øo fortunate herein, that I have ≈øeldom failed in my Predictions of determining a Woman to be with Child by the Urine, as I have made them believe, when the Me≈ø≈øenger has been able to certifie me of the State of the Woman's Body, and could
an≈øwer me to certain other Que≈øtions touching other Signs of Conception. Above all the re≈øt, I was once magnified by a Coun≈øellours Wife, for this cunning Cheat; ≈øhe meeting with two other Doctors, ≈øhe told them to their Faces, that I was the cunninge≈øt Doctor in all the Town; for I had told her, by her Water, that ≈øhe was with Child, and ju≈øt how long it was ≈øince ≈øhe conceived of it: But had the Woman that brought the Urine, ≈øhewed me no more than the Urine did, I ≈øhould ≈øcarce have ventured to have pronounced her to have been with Child: But I, ≈øaid he, am more to be blamed for my jugling, than ≈øhe for her Credulity.

Notwith≈øtanding what has been ≈øaid, the vulgar Sort are ≈øo ≈øtrongly prepo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by rea≈øon of their Ignorance, that Phy≈øicians can di≈øcern, by the Urine, the Di≈øea≈øe, the Conception, the Sex, the Parties Age, with many other ≈øuch Ab≈øurdities, that I fear it will be a hard Matter to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs them of that Opinion; and Phy≈øicians, the more to blame they, have intimated and pretended ≈øo much to this Knowledge, that they will hardly acknowledge their Errors, and relinqui≈øh this Cheat: But when it ≈øhall appear that the Urine is deceitful, and the Phy≈øician that pretends Knowledge of Di≈øea≈øes thereby, and gives his Judgment by ≈øuch Fallacies and Jugling, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed in the en≈øuing Di≈øcour≈øe, let the ignorant chu≈øe whether he will believe his lying Oracle or no, and let the Phy≈øician chu≈øe whether he will be hone≈øter than to u≈øe ≈øuch Deceit. Yet I hope the one will blu≈øh to have been ≈øo deluded, and the other to have his conjecturing di≈øcovered, the Urine giving no certain Knowledge of mo≈øt Di≈øea≈øes.

Di≈øea≈øes are either acute or chronical,; acute are a Pleuri≈øy, Peripneumonia, Frenzy, Iliac Pa≈ø≈øion, Fever, Small Pox, Pe≈øtilence, and the like. Chronical Di≈øea≈øes are ≈øuch as proceed from the ill Temperature of the Humours, and Di≈øpo≈øition of the Con≈øtitution
of the Body, ≈øuch are a Con≈øumption, Drop≈øie, Melancholy, Gout, Pal≈øy, Falling Sickne≈øs, Cachexy, and the like; but for the mo≈øt part, the common fort of People come or ≈øend their Water to Phy≈øicians for acute Di≈øea≈øes, and acute Di≈øea≈øes have always a hot and burning Fever joined with them, and the Urine, for the mo≈øt part, in a burning Fever, is of a high red Colour, and ≈øuch an Urine being brought to the Phy≈øician to ca≈øt, as they call it, and being of a red high Colour, he pre≈øently conceives it to be a ≈øharp and violent Di≈øea≈øe, and then knows for certain that there is a Fever joined with it, and ≈øo he is quickly prepared to give his Judgment of it, and needs now do no more but give a De≈øcription of a Fever to make the Me≈ø≈øenger believe that he perceives a Di≈øea≈øe in the Water, ye he comes to the true Knowledge of the Di≈øea≈øe by ≈øome ≈øuch Parly and Expo≈øtulation with the Me≈ø≈øenger, as ≈øhews the Symptoms and Affects of the ≈øick Party. Now the De≈øcription of a Fever, and indeed one De≈øcription will ≈øerve for any Fever, and for all ≈øharp and violent Di≈øea≈øes, is to reckon up the Symptoms and Signs of a Fever, which he knows before he looks upon the Water: They are the≈øe, Oppre≈ø≈øion of the Stomach, Want of Appetite, a great Pain in the Head and Back, and the like. Now the ≈øaying ≈øo makes the Me≈ø≈øenger think that the Doctor perceives by the Urine that the Party is ≈øo affected, yet it is no ≈øuch Matter; for a high colour'd Urine is not always the infallible Sign of a Fever; but ≈øuppo≈øe it were, yet the Symptoms and Companions of a Fever, as Heat, Thir≈øt, Pain in the Head, and Want of Sleep, Oppre≈ø≈øion of the Stomach, Want of Appetite, and the like, are not to be ≈øeen in the Water.

The≈øe things being premi≈øed, I hope thou wilt be the better able to judge of that which follows, and perceive how ea≈øie a thing it is to give Judgment of Di≈øea≈øes by the Urine, tho' it be not there to be ≈øeen, and
will perceive the Fallacies that uphold this Cu≈øtom, and ≈øo learn to di≈øtingui≈øh betwixt an hone≈øt, learned, plain-dealing Phy≈øician, and a chearing Ca≈øter of Water.

The Me≈ø≈øenger, whether Man or Woman, you mu≈øt note, is one who is as it were made out of Wax, and the Phy≈øician can mould him into any Form that ≈øhall fit his Purpo≈øe be≈øt, and make him, by impertinent Que≈øtions, as he thinks, to tell him any thing concerning the ≈øick Party, that he ≈øhall de≈øire to know.

The Urine, if brought out of the Country, is for the mo≈øt part in a Gla≈øs Bottle: But if ones in the City, it is brought in an Urinal or Viol, it is red and high coloured; and therefore the Pi≈øs-prophet rips up all the Symptoms of a Fever, as before, and the Me≈ø≈øenger pre≈øently an≈øwers that the Party is ju≈øt ≈øo affected, as I ≈øaid: But as yet he has not named the Di≈øea≈øe, and perhaps omitted ≈øomething, which is expected he ≈øhould have named, and the Me≈ø≈øenger is ready then to ask him, if he perceived nothing el≈øe in the Water; to whom he an≈øwers, yes, if you'll give me leave to tell you; and perhaps the Me≈ø≈øenger asks if he do not perceive a Stitch, then the Pi≈øs-pot Lecturer an≈øwers, looking upon the Water, as if it were there to be perceived, yes, I well perceive the Stitch, and ≈øome Cough too, and he ≈øays, when the Cough take; the Party, the Party is much pained in the Side; and becau≈øe he did not fir≈øt name the Stitch, he tells the Me≈ø≈øenger, that we fir≈øt u≈øe to declare the Cau≈øe of the Di≈øea≈øe, before we come to every Pa≈ø≈øion, or Effect of the Di≈øea≈øe, or before we name it. He further adds, that he was not come to ≈øpeak of the Stitch, becau≈øe he had named the Oppre≈ø≈øion of the Stomach, and the Ob≈øtruction of the Spleen and Me≈øentery, and that the Stitch was nothing el≈øe, but a ≈ølatulous and windy Humour proceeding thence to the Part affected. And now having been ≈øo happy in his Predictions of
the Di≈øea≈øe, and rightly determined it to be a Pleuri≈øie, ≈øo now he proceeds to the Pre≈øcription of ≈øuch Remedies as may cure this Pleuri≈øie, and yet here he is as far to ≈øeek, tho' he know the Di≈øea≈øe to be a Pleuri≈øie, as if he knew not the Di≈øea≈øe at all, nor had ≈øeen the Urine, becau≈øe he does not therein perceive the Scope and Grounds of pre≈øcribing fit Remedies, in every Re≈øpect, proper to the Di≈øea≈øe, according to the Rules of Art, the which Scope and Grounds are the≈øe, namely, the Parties Age, the Sex, the Con≈øtitution of the Body, and the Strength of it at this Time, with divers other Accidents, as whether the Party be bound in his Body, or have a Flux, or the like; all which, nor any one of them can be di≈øcerned by the Urine, and ≈øo he mu≈øt needs err in his Pre≈øcription, if the Me≈ø≈øenger refu≈øe, or be unable to give him a full account of the Ca≈øe; for if not knowing the Age of the Party, he ≈øhould order ≈øuch a Quantity of Blood to be taken away from a Youth, ≈øuppo≈øe Ten or Twelve Ounces, in a Pleuri≈øie, the Di≈øea≈øe in Hand, as ≈øhould be taken from a Man in his full Strength, the Party might peri≈øh thereby: Or if he ≈øhould take but four or five Ounces of Blood from a lu≈øty young Man in this Di≈øea≈øe, he would do him no good, and ≈øo he might peri≈øh on the other hand. He may likewi≈øe err in the Do≈øe, by pro≈øcribing more or le≈øs than is proportionable to the Party's Age. He may likewi≈øe err as much by not knowing the Sex, if he ≈øhould in the forenamed Di≈øea≈øe pre≈øcribe Blood-letting to a Woman, when ≈øhe has her natural Cour≈øes upon her; for thereby there may be a Solution of the Di≈øea≈øe without bleeding. div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of Gli≈øters, Vomits, Purges, Bleeding, Leeches, Baths, Frictions, Ligatures, actual and potential Cauteries, Cupping-gla≈ø≈øes, and I≈ø≈øues.
div.p: A Gli≈øter is of good U≈øe in Phy≈øick, and it ≈øerves to mollifie the Excrements, to di≈øcu≈øs Wind, and to clean≈øe the Bowels from vi≈øcid Humours, tho' their Vertue, as mo≈øt ≈øuppo≈øe, reaches no farther than the Guts, yet a Woman has been di≈øordered in her Head by a Gli≈øter of Wine injected. Some ≈øay, that Opium in Gli≈øters procures Sleep, and Sennertus advi≈øes, in his Chapter of a Frenzy, when the Patient is very weak, to mix Opiates with Gli≈øters. The Quantity of the Gli≈øter is commonly pre≈øcribed to fifteen or eighteen Ounces, which is often too much, when the Guts are filled with Excrements or Wind, or when the Patient is ≈øhort of Stature.

Gli≈øters, according to Galen, may be ≈øub≈øtituted for purging Medicines. When Purges do not their Office,
Phy≈øicians commonly inject a Gli≈øter; but ≈øome think that a Suppo≈øitory made of Honey and half a Dram of Salt is better in this Ca≈øe.

Gli≈øters made of Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds are counted very effectual in the Cholick. A Gli≈øter of Tabacco is very proper to empty the Bowels. Let two Pipes be filled with Tabacco after the u≈øual Manner, then light them, and turn the Mouths of their Heads one upon the other, then put the ≈ømaller End of one up the Fundament, and holding the ≈ømall End of the other in your Mouth, you may blow the Smoak up into the Guts.

A Vomit works by moving inordinately the Fibres of the Nerves of the Stomach. A Vomit does not only evacuate from the Stomach, but al≈øo from the ≈ømall Guts, the Ductus Cholidochus, and from the pancreatic Duct. But all do not equally bear Vomits; tho≈øe who are narrow brea≈øted, that are ≈øubject to an A≈øthma, ≈øpitting of Blood, vomit with great Danger: But they are of excellent U≈øe when the Appetite is languid, and when the Stomach nau≈øeates and when the antecedent Cau≈øe lurks in the Stomach; nor is vomiting ≈øo very dangerous a Remedy, as is commonly thought; for Rea≈øon and daily Experience ≈øhews the contrary. But frequent and difficult vomiting loo≈øens the Tone of the Stomach, weakens the Bowels, and hurts the Head.

No purging Medicine purges electively, or is de≈øtined for evacuating ≈øome particular Humour, but works upon all the Humours, and therefore it is vain to think that Cholagogs purge only Choler, Phlegmagogs only Flegm, Melanagogs only Melancholy, Hydragogs only Water. It is al≈øo vain to think that a Purge is appropriated to the Head only, or to the Liver or Spleen only, or the like; for every Purge circulates with the Blood, and is carried to every Part, and works upon it.

Purging is proper for a Cacochymy, to carry off the ill Humous. The Strength ought to be good, which may be known by the Pul≈øe; the Age, the Sex, the Temperament, the Habit of Body, the Cu≈øtom, and the like; the middle Age bears purging be≈øt. Infants and Old Age are purged difficulty. If Children are to be purged, the Cathartic mu≈øt be given to the Nur≈øe, for ≈øo it is ≈øuckt in with the Milk, and works more kindly. Men bear purging better than Women: But ≈øome Women, e≈øpecially ≈øuch as have a Stoppage of their Cour≈øes, bear ≈øtrong Purges. In the purging of Women you mu≈øt take notice, that they mu≈øt not be purged when they have their Cour≈øes upon them, and big bellied Women are not to be purged ra≈øhly; for there is Danger of Abortion. The ≈øafe≈øt Time of purging them is from the fourth Month to the ≈øeventh; but now a-days big bellied Women are purged at any Time with gentle Purges.
An hot and moi≈øt Temperament, and a fle≈øhy Habit of Body bear Purges be≈øt.
We mu≈øt take notice in pre≈øcribing a Purge, whether the Body be much bound, and if ≈øo, it is be≈øt to give a Gli≈øter fir≈øt.

Some ≈øay that the Humours mu≈øt not be purged till they are concocted or prepared by previous Medicines: But our modern Practice is contrary to this. The Do≈øe of a purging Medicine is to be found out by Experience, for the Propriety and Condition of Bodies are various; we mu≈øt therefore ask the Patient whether he has taken a Purge at any Time when he was ≈øick, and whether it wrought enough, and according to De≈øire or not; if you under≈øtand that the Patient is ea≈øie to work upon, then u≈øe the more gentle means, or a ≈ømaller Do≈øe.

Some add Narcotics with Cathartics, and it has been found by Experience, that after a gentle Sleep, a mo≈øt ≈øucce≈øsful Exclu≈øion of Humours has followed.
For a Pain in the Stomach, or the Cholic, the following Pills are very proper.
div.q: Take of the be≈øt Aloes one Dram, of Laudanum opiatum four Grains, of Diagrydium ≈øix Grains, mix them, and make Pills to be given at a convenient Time.
div.p: They allay the Pain in an Hour, and afterwards evacuate the Humours.
Pills are the longe≈øt in working, Powders next, then Electuaries; but the quicke≈øt of all are Potions.
Melancholy and mad People require ≈øtrong Purges.
It is ill to feed freely after a Purge hath done working, and it was u≈øual with the Ancients to omit their Dinner on the Day they took a Purge.

If a Purge work not in four or five Hours, advi≈øe ≈øtirring about, and if there be no Fever, give two or three Pills of Aloes, hot Broath, half an Ounce of white Tartar finely powdered in Broath, or a common Gli≈øter.

Tho≈øe who have been ≈øubject to the Falling-≈øickne≈øs, Pal≈øy, Stone, Hypochondriac Melancholy, ≈øuch as have had the French-pox, inveterate Itch, Scabs, Lepro≈øie, or Scurvy, and tho≈øe that have ≈øome u≈øual Evacuation ≈øtopt, as the Terms, Hemorrhoids, an old Ulcer, or a wonted Flux, or have a con≈øiderable Member cut off; the≈øe and ≈øuch like, if they will con≈øult for their own Safety and Life, ought to purge while they are in Health, to prevent Di≈øea≈øes.
It is very proper after Purges, e≈øpecially in hy≈øteric and hypochondriac Ca≈øes, in the Cholic and the like, to give an Anodyne at Bed-time.

Bleeding is a very ancient Remedy, u≈øed by all Nations, and there are few Di≈øea≈øes wherein it is not indicated, if the Strength be ≈øufficient; but e≈øpecially when the Quantity of it is too great, or when it is extrava≈øated upon ≈øome Part, or coagulated. The Ancients
were wont to reckon three Sorts of bleeding, one for Evacuation, another for Revul≈øion, and the third for Derivation: But I admit but of one, and that is of Evacuation, and that does all; for when Part of it is evacuated, the re≈øt is better contained in the Ve≈ø≈øels, and circulates better, ≈øo that Fluxion is prevented, and an Inflammation, and the Veins being emptied, that Blood which is extrava≈øated is the ea≈øier recalled, as in a Quin≈øy, Peripneumonia, Pleuri≈øy, and other Inflammations.

Some reckon there is a great Difference about the Veins that are to be opened; for they think that ≈øome above others do evacuate a certain Part, and therefore they have called ≈øome Veins Cephalic, ≈øome Hepatic, ≈øome I≈øchiadiac, and the like: But one would think the≈øe neither under≈øtand Anatomy nor Circulation; for otherwi≈øe they would know that the Veins communicate with the Arteries, and like ≈øo many Rivulets, take their Ri≈øe from the ≈øame Fountain; and therefore it is no matter of which ≈øide the Vein is opened, or which it is, only that which is large≈øt and the mo≈øt commodiou≈øly opened is to be cho≈øen: But in an Ob≈øtruction of the Cour≈øes, a Vein of the Foot mu≈øt be opened; becau≈øe thereby the Flux of them is promoted, and ≈øuch Ob≈øtructions are often turned this way.

The Veins which are wont to be opened in the Head are the Jugular, the Temporal, the Vein of the Forehead, and that under the Tongue; in the Arm, the Cephalic, Middle, and Ba≈øilic; in the Hand, the Salvatella and Cephalic; in the Foot, the I≈øchiadiac.

In opening the≈øe Veins, Care mu≈øt be taken that the Nerve or Tendon lying under be not hurt, le≈øt Convul≈øions, and other grievous Accidents, or Death ≈øhould follow. Care ≈øhould be al≈øo taken that the Artery lying under be not hurt, for ≈øo an Aneuri≈øm will be occa≈øioned, and in clo≈øing the Wound you mu≈øt not
leave any Blood in the Lips of it, le≈øt an Inflammation ≈øhould ari≈øe; but you mu≈øt wa≈øh it well out, and bind it up. Care mu≈øt be al≈øo taken that a Vein be not opened ra≈øhly in the Plague, Small-pox, Petechial, and Malignant Fevers, le≈øt the Malignity ≈øhould ≈øtrike in and kill the Patient, nor in the State of Fevers, nor in the cold Fit of Agues, nor in great bellied Women, e≈øpecially at the Beginning or End of their going with Child. Moreover, Women with Child mu≈øt not be blooded in the Foot, in the Arm there is le≈øs Danger; and now many Women are wont to bleed when they are with Child, thinking that it is good for the Child's Health, and indeed it often ≈øucceeds very well.

Too much Blood mu≈øt not be taken away at a time. You never ought to take away above a Pound at one time, nor ≈øo much but in extraordinary Ca≈øes. The common Quantities are ≈øeven, eight, nine or ten Ounces, and it is better to repeat bleeding, than to take away too much at a time.

You ought not to bleed till the Blood turns to a better Colour, as the Cu≈øtom of ≈øome is; for ≈øometimes that which come out fir≈øt is red, and that which follows is of another Colour, and if you would continue bleeding till the Colour change better, the Patient's Life will be endangered; and you ought never to bleed till the Patient faints, as is the Cu≈øtom of ≈øome. It is be≈øt to receive the Blood in Porringers, that the exact Quantity of it may be known.
Old Men and Children do not bear bleeding well, yet ≈øometimes they mu≈øt be blooded in a Quin≈øey, Pleuri≈øie, or the like.
More Blood may be taken away from fle≈øhy People than from fat; al≈øo from ≈øuch as are thin, if they have not been rendred ≈øo by a ≈øpare Diet and much Labour, for ≈øuch have mo≈øt Blood.

Many will not bleed in the Dog-days, as if there were ≈øomething ≈øpecial then that oppo≈øed it: But the Heat of that Time, and the Di≈ø≈øipation of the Strength thereby are the only things to be minded, for if the Weather be then temperate, or if Nece≈ø≈øity urge, you may bleed.

If an Infant being troubled with the Falling-≈øickne≈øs, for in≈øtance, an I≈ø≈øue be made in the Nape of the Neck, and a regular Diet withall be pre≈øcribed the Nur≈øe, and fitting Medicines given, whereby the Fuel of the Di≈øea≈øe may be ≈øub≈øtracted, and the Head ≈øtrengthened, ≈øo that there be no Su≈øpicion of the Return of the Malady for a Year together, the I≈ø≈øue may be ≈øafely clo≈øed up; for if it ≈øhould be continued any longer, the good Juices may flow out as well as the bad, and the Part may be debilitated. In a Man of middle Age, his pre≈øent State is to be compared with the former, which if it be become better, and while the I≈ø≈øue has ran he has not ≈øuffered a Relap≈øe, it may by little and little be obliterated in the Nape of the Neck, or in
the fore Part of the Head, by le≈ø≈øening the Pea by degrees, and a new one may be made in the Arm for Security, which al≈øo for a while may be dryed up. But let old Men wear them to the la≈øt, namely, tho≈øe who≈øe natural Heat is weak, and in whom there flows out Plenty of Matter. VVe mu≈øt con≈øider al≈øo in VVomen with Child, whether the innate Heat be ≈øo brisk, as altogether to con≈øume the morbific Matter, or whether the offending Matter find ≈øome other VVay. From all which we may infer that there is no definite Time of wearing an I≈ø≈øue, and that Death does not always follow clo≈øing them up.

The Ancients practi≈øed Scarification far more confidently and frequently than we now a-days, who u≈øe it in no other Ca≈øes than in the Application of Cupping-gla≈ø≈øes, and in the Cure of Gangreens: But it is of wonderful Efficacy to ea≈øe all Pains that invade the outward Part of the Body: One being afflicted Night and Day for many Months together with venereal Pains in his Leg, and could be ea≈øed by no Medicines, was cured by the Help of Scarification.
The Aegyptians u≈øe to ≈øcarifie the Skin in very many Places.

Baths, as they are very profitable u≈øed aright, ≈øo they are dangerous u≈øed ami≈øs: For ≈øome are to be bathed gently, ≈øome more ≈øtrongly. The Ancients were wont in Baths to u≈øe hard Scrapers made of Stone, or of ≈øome Metal, or of the harde≈øt Woods, to clean≈øe off the Filth from the Skin: But tho≈øe who are to be u≈øed more gently, mu≈øt dry their Bodies only with wiping them with Sponges or linnen Cloaths.

Bathing wears off La≈ø≈øitudes, for it ≈øupples the Joints, and loo≈øens the Skin; wherefore whether a Man be troubled with ≈øpontaneous or non≈øpontaneous La≈ø≈øitudes, he can u≈øe nothing better than a Bath, unle≈øs there be either ≈øuch a Fullne≈øs or Badne≈øs of Humours, that it is fitting to bleed or purge fir≈øt.
Bathing after a long Journey takes off Wearine≈øs.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of Alexipharmics, Cordials, Diaphoretics, Diuretics, and Anodynes.
div.p: THo≈øe are reckoned for Cordials that a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Heart labouring in any kind; wherefore one is ≈øaid by Authors notably to ≈øtrengthen the Heart, another to keep it unhurt by any Putrefaction, others to relieve a weak oppre≈ø≈øed Heart, to cure its Tremor or Fainting, and to pre≈øerve it from Corruption. Moreover, becau≈øe in the Plague, Small-pox, and malignant Fevers, the Heart is believed to be ≈øeized or be≈øet with Poy≈øon or Malignity; therefore the Remedies that are wont to help in the≈øe Di≈øea≈øes are not called ≈øimply Cordials, but Alexiteries, and Alexipharmics. This Opinion concerning both Cordial and Alexiterial Medicines ≈øeems to ri≈øe from hence, in as much as the Heart is commonly believed to be the Beginning of all Life and Heat, and that therefore our Health and Death depend on its immediate Affection, hence what things ≈øoever recreate the Soul are ≈øuppo≈øed to do it, as they are benign and friendly to the Heart.

As to Cordials, by which the too ≈øtrait Frame of the efferve≈øcing Blood is loo≈øened and opened for the ≈øetting at Liberty the febrile Matter, and other Recrements, tho≈øe are of Affinity with ≈øome Diuretics and Diaphoretics, yea, ≈øometimes they are of common or reciprocal U≈øe, in as much as the vitiated Cra≈øis of the Blood ≈øometimes cannot be relieved, unle≈øs its Frame being fir≈øt unlocked, there lye open an Exit for di≈øcharging the Serum by the Reins, or the Pores of
the Skin. Saline Medicines do chiefly execute all the≈øe Intentions of Cure; for the opening of any Body, whether liquid or ≈øolid, is hardly performed but by a ≈øaline Key; for commonly all Concretion or Compaction is from a Salt of one Sort, and the Di≈ø≈øolution from ≈øome of another Sort that ≈ønatches into its Embraces the fir≈øt Salt; therefore we reckon Salines among Cordials, no le≈øs than among Diuretics and Diaphoretics; becau≈øe there is the ≈øame Rea≈øon in all. In the fir≈øt Rank Cordials indued with a volatile Salt offer them≈øelves, and are ju≈øtly preferrable to all the re≈øt, as Spirit of Harts-horn, of Blood, of Sal-armoniac, the Spirit of Sculls, the Salt of Vipers, and the Powder of Toads; ≈øuch Remedies as the≈øe have recalled many from the very Jaws of Death.

The ≈øecond Place among Saline Cordials is of Right owing to Remedies indued with an Alcalizat Salt; for the≈øe are commonly reputed notable Cordials; of this Sort are the Bezoar Stone, Pearls, Corals, the Bone of a Stag's Heart, the Horn of the ≈øame, the Powder of Ivory, the Eyes and Claws of Crabs, and other Powders of Stones and Shells, which common Experience witne≈ø≈øes to be often given with Benefit. To this Cla≈ø≈øis of Cordials are Bole-armenic, Lemnian, and ≈øealed Earths, and other chalky Medicines de≈øervedly referred, but not upon the Account that they ≈øuccour the labouring Heart, but becau≈øe they de≈øtroy the predominancies of an acid or fixed Salt, either in the Bowels or in the Ma≈øs of Blood, and correct the Enormities produced thereby.

Acid Medicines, or ≈øuch as are indued with a fluid Salt are to be reckoned in the Li≈øt of Cordials, for the≈øe are e≈øteemed by mo≈øt to be notable Alexiteries again≈øt the Pe≈øtilence, wherefore in the Cure of malignant Fevers, Treacle and Bezoartic Vinegars are highly cryed up, yea, Vinegar or acid things are u≈øual Ingredients in Waters di≈øtilled for the ≈øame U≈øe:
For the ≈øame Rea≈øon Spirit of Vitriol, the Juice of Citron, Sorrel, Pomgranates, and the like, are reckoned for Cordials, and Alexiteries, and that indeed ju≈øtly; becau≈øe the≈øe do excellently di≈ø≈øolve the Combinations of fixed Salts with adu≈øt Sulphur; and therefore, by ≈øuch Remedies as the≈øe, the Coagulations and Extrava≈øations of the Blood that u≈øe to happen in malignant Fevers are often prevented or cured. For the ≈øame Rea≈øons for which the fore≈øaid ≈øaline Medicines are reckoned for Cordials, others al≈øo, who≈øe Ba≈øis is a fixt Salt, are reputed ≈øuch, or are put into their Compo≈øitions; for ≈øeeing Salts of divers Sorts are bred in our Body, and they commonly pa≈øs from one State to another, hence not one Kind of Salt, but Salts of different Kinds ought to be given according as the Intention is. A nitrous Salt is al≈øo ju≈øtly numbred among≈øt Cordials, and is accounted a famous Antipuretic, in that it takes away Thir≈øt, and bridles the febrile Heat.

Moreover, ≈øome Medicines have the Name of Cordials, becau≈øe they exert their Virtues upon the Spirits, and more immediately than upon the Blood. The≈øe Medicines are fitly enough reduced to two Heads, and as they are gentle or rugged, attain the ≈øame Scope, namely, they either erect and confirm the animal Spirits by cheri≈øhing, and as it were, gently and ≈øoftly ≈øtroaking of them, or el≈øe by vexing, and as it were, ≈øpurring of them, they drive them into quicker, and ≈øometimes more regular Motions. The Cordials of the fir≈øt Sort, as ≈øoon as they are ≈øwallowed, nay ≈øometimes, being but ta≈øted, exert their Virtue, and by a grateful Appul≈øe, recruit the Spirits that re≈øide in the fir≈øt Ways; then by the Continuity of the≈øe, the ≈øame Ovation being communicated ≈øucce≈ø≈øively to the other Spirits, ≈øhortly undulates through the whole Frame of the ≈øen≈øitive Soul, ≈øo that both the Brain, and al≈øo the Praecordia being irritated with a
fuller influx of the Spirits, exulting as it were, they perform their Functions more briskly and chearfully. For this purpo≈øe ≈øerve the Waters commonly called Cordial; al≈øo the preparations of Musk and Amber, and the Aromatic Powders that are mixed with them. Such things as have a grateful Savour or Smell, or are plea≈øant to look upon, ina≈ømuch as they recreate the Animal Spirits, are reckoned al≈øo among Cordials. In the mean time, other Cordials of this Cla≈ø≈øis, the fir≈øt ways and ma≈øs of Blood being almo≈øt untouched, ≈øeem to operate fir≈øt of all in the Brain; of which ≈øort are ≈øome Cephalics, as Sage, Betony, Ro≈øemary, Vervain, and the like. There are another ≈øort of Cordials that operate in a different manner, and help wholly on another Account: The≈øe do not gently cheri≈øh the Animal Spirits, and cau≈øe them to be expanded equally, but rather irritate them, and make them run and be carried this way and that way; and being thereby rouzed, they leave their former Di≈øorders, and of their own accord return into regular Order. Thus it is u≈øual in Swooning, Fainting, Oppre≈ø≈øion, or Spa≈øm of the Heart; and in almo≈øt any other failings, languors, or irregularities of the Spirits, to give inwardly Spirits of Harts-horn, of Soot, of Sal Armoniac, or Tincture of Ca≈øtor, or A≈ø≈øa Fatida, with other Liquors: Or to hold to the No≈øe the≈øe and the like, as e≈øpecially Volatile Salts, and Empyreumatical Chymical Oyls. Be≈øides, it may be ≈øometimes good in ≈øuddain defections of the Soul, to ≈øprinkle Cold Water on the Face, to pinch the No≈øe, to ≈øhake the Body very much, and ≈øometimes to ≈øtrike a Box on the Ear: Such Admini≈øtrations as the≈øe give help, ina≈ømuch as they Rouze up the Animal Spirits, being oppre≈ø≈øed or di≈øtracted, or imployed other ways than they ≈øhould, and Command them to their former Offices.

Great Caution is needful, that Men indulge not them≈øelves too much in the u≈øe of Cordials; for many
eminent Men and Women, from the more frequent u≈øe of the≈øe, fall into this ≈øad Cu≈øtom, that it has become nece≈ø≈øary to take a Draught often in a Day, either of ≈øome generous Wine or Spirit, or ≈øome ≈øtrong Water; yea moreover, Nature being a little accu≈øtomed to extraordinaries, remains not long content with the ≈øame, and therefore they increa≈øe them daily, and repeat them oftener; ≈øo that at length the Stomach can bear, or dige≈øt nothing moderate, but ≈øtill de≈øires ≈øtronger and hotter; and the other Vi≈øcera, e≈øpecially the Liver, are ≈øo dryed and parched thereby, that the Blood being le≈ø≈øened as to its quantity, and depraved as to its Cra≈øis, Di≈øea≈øes and Death ≈øupervene. There are ≈øundry occa≈øions that bring Men into this bad Cu≈øtom of ≈øipping Cordial Liquors; as ≈øudden Faintings, which are perhaps occa≈øioned by Grief, toil≈øome Labour, va≈øt Sweats, or acute Pain; al≈øo when one has eaten ≈øomething that agrees not with his Stomach, and cau≈øes a weight and nau≈øeou≈øne≈øs, or when a Swooning, or Stupor, ≈øeems to be impendent through a ≈øpa≈ømodic di≈øpo≈øition, yea for many other cau≈øes it is u≈øual to guzzle vinous Spirits; and then after that, ≈øuch Cordials being taken ≈øometime, begin to be agreeable, and delight, the Ma≈øs of Blood being a little more freely expanded, and kindled by every ta≈øte of them, the whole Hypo≈øta≈øis of the Soul is thereby amplified, and excited into a kind of Ovation; which ≈øub≈øiding again, the Soul remembring that Complacence, and being not content with her pre≈øent State, affects the ≈øame again, and craves after more; wherefore upon every trouble of Body and Mind, as ≈øoon as the Spirits ≈øink a little, a Cordial Draught is pre≈øently de≈øired to rai≈øe them again; and ≈øo the Fabrick of the Body is ≈øhattered: Nor does this evil Cu≈øtom prevail only among Drunken Companions, but ≈øometimes learned Men, and fine and ingenious Women, that they may the more improve and exhilerate their
Genius, ≈øip often hot Spirits and Waters, or Aqua Vita, tho' it is improperly called ≈øo, and thereby undermine their Health.

When the Stomach langui≈øhes, thick Alexipharmics are more commended than Liquid, that they may ≈øtay there the longer. When the Heart is affected, Liquid are better, becau≈øe they penetrate more ≈øpeedily.
In Hypochondriac Ca≈øes, Cordials are ≈øometimes to be u≈øed.

The Ancients u≈øed Leaf Gold with many Medicines, but to what purpo≈øe, unle≈øs to plea≈øe the Eye, I know not; for its ≈øub≈øtance is too ≈øolid and compact to be re≈øolved and brought to act by our Heat.

No great tru≈øt is to be had to Bezoar Stone; for if the Faculties that are a≈øcribed to it, are granted to be true, yet becau≈øe its dearne≈øs makes many that ≈øell it endeavour to counterfeit it, we can hardly have any but what is adulterated; for the Writers of Indian Affairs ≈øay that it is very rare, and dearer among the Indians, than with us.

Harts-horn is not much wor≈øe than the Bezoar Stone, or Unicorns Horn, again≈øt Poi≈øons, and poi≈øonous Di≈øea≈øes; for it defends the Heart from malignant Vapours, it cuts the toughne≈øs of Humours, it opens ob≈øtructions of the inward Vi≈øcera; and by its penetrating quality re≈øi≈øts the putrefaction of the Humours.
Treacle is al≈øo a great Cordial, and very proper again≈øt Poi≈øon. Many that have been ≈øubject to Swoonings, without evident cau≈øe, have bin cured by it.
Many doubt whether precious Stones have any Cordial Vertue.
Among Alexipharmics, Tormentil and Bole are wor≈øt for tho≈øe that have a dry Belly; for they cau≈øe Ob≈øtructions.

Sulphureous Spirits kindle the Sulphur of the Blood; Volatile Urinous ones rarifie it, and acid Spirits tame, dull, or blunt it. All the≈øe u≈øed inwardly, re≈øtore
the heat and motion of the Blood, increa≈øe and invigorate its Bal≈øamic Oleous Parts, whence Apoplectic, Hy≈øteric, Cordial Spirits, and the like, revive the Spirits, remove Fainting, and recall the langui≈øhing Faculties: But ≈øeeing both the≈øe, and the re≈øt, are very active, they are all of them to be given warily; for being given un≈øea≈øonably, they fill the Head, and intoxicate, they deject the Appetite, and make Men Pthy≈øical and Hydropical.

Diaphoretics, as to the way of their working and operations, have great Affinity with mo≈øt Cardiacs, commonly ≈øo called, in≈øomuch that many of both kinds are of a common or reciprocal u≈øe; and ≈øeeing they differ chiefly, only as to their greater or le≈ø≈øer efficacy, when we are bound to pa≈øs from one Genus to the other, generally we need only increa≈øe or le≈ø≈øen the Do≈øe, and chu≈øe the fitte≈øt time for admini≈øtring them.

As to the various kinds, and preparations of the Matter, whereof Sudorific Medicines are made, they are generally either the integral, or elementary Parts of ≈øome mixed Body, viz. Either natural Concretes are given in their whole Sub≈øtance, either ≈øimple or extracted, as when the Leaves, Roots, or Seeds of Carduus, Contrayerva, Angelica, or the like, are taken in Powder, Decoction, Con≈øerve or Magi≈øtery; or Diaphoretics con≈øi≈øt of the Particles of this or that Element, viz. ≈øpirituous, ≈øulphureous, or ≈øaline, either ≈øimple, or ≈øome prevailing over other: As if a Salt, Spirit, or Oyl be extracted from Carduus, or other vegetable, mineral, or animal Body, and be reduced into the Form of a Medicine, either by it ≈øelf, or with other Preparations.

We will briefly run over all, or at lea≈øt the chief Species of them. Fir≈øt, Diaphoretics, who≈øe Vertue con≈øi≈øts in the Integral Particles of the whole Concrete, being unequally mixt, ≈øeem to be indued with ≈øome
one Element more eminent than the re≈øt, viz. a Saline, and to owe their Vertue chiefly to it. Now that Salt upon which the hydrotic Vertue depends, comes under a double State; for in ≈øome Concretes it is volatile and acrimonious, or bitter; in others alcalizate and fixt in a ≈øort; fir≈øt, in the former Rank are mo≈øt Vegetables e≈øteem'd Antidotes by the Ancients, ≈øuch are the Leaves of Scordium, Carduus, Scabious, Perwinkle, the Flowers of Marygold, Camomile, the Roots of Burdock, Zedoary, Galingal, and the like; al≈øo the Confections of Mithridate, Treacle, Dia≈øcordium, the Decoctions of Guiacum, Box, and the like, are reckoned among the≈øe. Secondly, The other ≈øort of Diaphoretics which, while they con≈øi≈øt of the integral Parts, of the mixt, have an alcali Salt predominant, as Stones, and the bony or ≈øhelly Parts of Animals and Vegetables, as Bezoar, Pearls, the Eyes and Claws of Crabs, and the like, who≈øe Diaphoretic Vertue proceeds chiefly from an alcali Salt. Hydrotic Medicines al≈øo, which after a ≈øpagyrical Analy≈øis, owe their Vertue to this or that ≈øort of elementary Particles, being framed out of divers Subjects, and with a different Preparation, are chiefly either ≈øpirituous or ≈øaline, or both together combined one with another, or with ≈øome ≈øulphureous Particles; for ≈øuch as are wholly, or for the greate≈øt Part ≈øulphureous, are le≈øs proper for this Intention. To the ≈øpirituous we refer hot Waters, and all ≈øorts of Liquors indued with a vinous Spirit, ≈øuch as are commonly di≈øtilled by Chimi≈øtry out of the Fruits or Juices of Vegetables, or ripened by Fermentation, or re≈øolved by Putrefaction, as the Spirits of Wine, of the Berries of Juniper and Elder, of black Cherries, and the like. Such vinous Liquors as the≈øe being taken inwardly, procure Sweat.
Saline Preparations al≈øo of divers kinds, and different States are pre≈øcribed ≈øucce≈øsfully for the procuring Sweat.

To Diaphoretics, who≈øe Ba≈øis are Spirits, with the other elementary Particles combined (as for example, a Dram of Mixtura Simplex in a convenient Vehicle) are referred tho≈øe which con≈øi≈øt of a Spirit; a fixt Salt or Sulphur combined; of which ≈øort are the Tincture of Salt of Tartar and Antimony, the Do≈øe whereof is from one Scruple to two in ≈øome Liquor. Moreover, di≈øtilled Waters, wherein the ≈øpirituous Particles are diluted with the watry, u≈øe to be given with Succe≈øs for provoking Sweat; the Do≈øes of the fore≈øaid Waters may be actuated by the Addition of chymical Liquors or Salts. Medicines of this ≈øort being endued with a vinous Spirit are chiefly, and almo≈øt ≈øolely profitable for old Men, and for ≈øuch as are endued with a cold Temperament, or are ≈øubject to the Pal≈øy or Drop≈øy. But in a hot Con≈øtitution, and where there is a Heat of the Vi≈øcera, or a febrile Efferve≈øcence of the Blood, they u≈øe to do more Hurt than Good, in as much as they rarifie the former, and accend the latter too much. The Diaphoretics which have a ≈øaline Ba≈øis, as they are of a various Nature, viz. accordingly, as it is a volatile, fixed, acetous, or nitrous Salt, ≈øo they are of a different U≈øe and Operation, whence in ≈øome Ca≈øes one ≈øort is better, and in others another, or another. A fixt and volatile Salt are be≈øt for tho≈øe who≈øe Blood is very full of a ≈øerous Humour: Be≈øides, if the Liquor that waters the Vi≈øcera and Genus Nervo≈øum do at any time wax eager, as it u≈øes to do in Drop≈øies and Cacochymies, and in tho≈øe who are ≈øubject to ≈øpa≈ømodic Di≈øea≈øes; the≈øe Medicines are more profitably admini≈øtred for procuring Sweat. Diaphoretics al≈øo which have a nitrous Salt for their Ba≈øis, ≈øeem to help in the ≈øame Ca≈øes, almo≈øt as the former, con≈øi≈øting of a fixt and volatile Salt. Diaphoretics, who≈øe Ba≈øis is an acid Salt, are chiefly profitable again≈øt the Predominancies of a fixt Salt or Sulphur.

Some Medicines that are wholly, or for the greate≈øt part ≈øulphureous, are commonly reckoned in the Number of Diaphoretics, as ≈øome natural Bal≈øoms, and ≈øome factitious ones, al≈øo chymical Oyls, e≈øpecially tho≈øe of Guiacum, Box, Camphor, Harts-horn, and Soot; likewi≈øe the re≈øinous Extracts of heavy Woods, with many others, which tho of them≈øelves they conduce little towards the provoking of Sweat, yet being joined with other ≈øaline things, they are not altogether unprofitable, in as much as in a colder and too phlegmatic Con≈øtitution, ≈øulphureous ≈øaline Remedies do rarifie the over-watry Blood, and di≈øpo≈øe it to a freer Evaporation, no le≈øs than ≈øpirtuous things.

The Ba≈øis of a ≈øudorific Diet-drink are the Decoctions of Liquors for the curing of the Pox, and ≈øome other chronical Di≈øea≈øes deeply rooted in the Blood and Humours; for very inten≈øe and frequent ≈øweating, daily for a long time, is requi≈øite for the Cure of ≈øome Di≈øea≈øes, viz. not only that the Impurities and Corruptions of the Vi≈øcera and Humours may be carried off, but al≈øo, that the morbific Tinctures that are deeply imprinted thereupon may be wholly de≈øtroyed: For this purpo≈øe it will not be enough to give ≈øome ≈øudorific Powder or Bolus now and then, but an entire Diet ought to be ordered for this Intention; wherefore let all the Drink be a ≈øudorific Decoction, after one Do≈øe whereof taken in the Morning, let plentiful ≈øweating be provoked, making u≈øe be≈øides of the Heat of a Bath or Hot-hou≈øe. Moreover, ≈øeeing by this means both the Pores of the Skin are unlockt, and Nature al≈øo is inclined to ≈øweating all the Day after, the Recrements of the Blood and nervous Juice will evaporate by Per≈øpiration continued all along by the U≈øe of the ≈øame Drink. By this Method, not only the French Pox is ≈øafely, and for the mo≈øt part very certainly cured, but al≈øo ≈øome other ≈øtubborn herculean Di≈øea≈øes are ≈øometimes happily remedied.

All Humours are not profitably le≈ø≈øened and evacuated by Sweat, but only ≈øome; not Blood nor Choler, but all ≈øorts of Flegm, and all Serum, as well the watry as the ≈øalt Muriatic, the acid and ≈øowr. But glutinous Flegm, ≈øeeing it is not ≈øo fit for Motion, ought fir≈øt, or at the ≈øame time, to be incided, attenuated, and made fluid, that it may the more ea≈øily be driven forth by or with Sweat. An acid ≈øowr Humour ought al≈øo to be prepared for its Expul≈øion by Sweat. That the mentioned Humours are driven and expelled by the Pores of the Skin, and ≈øo by Sweat, appears by the Sweat it ≈øelf, which ≈øometimes comes forth glutinous, often watry and in≈øipid, ≈øometimes muriatic or brine-like, ≈øometimes al≈øo ≈øomewhat acid or ≈øowr.

There are but few true ≈øudorific Medicines, and among the≈øe Opium is the chief; for the rea≈øon why Treacle or Mithridate cau≈øe Sweat, is wholly from the Opium that is mixed with them: For the≈øe two Electuaries prepared without Opium do not provoke Sweat at all.

The mo≈øt convenient Time for ≈øweating is the Morning, and that on an empty Stomach; for then the Sweat comes out more ea≈øily and plentifully. Note, that after ≈øweating Decoctions, purging is nece≈ø≈øary to carry off the gro≈øs Excrements.

The Origins of many Di≈øea≈øes happen for want of a due Separation of the Serum; but as to this Separation, ≈øeeing there are Faults of divers Kinds, the Offence is for the mo≈øt part either in Defect or in Exce≈øs; for ≈øometimes the Serum does too pertinaciou≈øly adhere to the Blood, and on the contrary, ≈øometimes it parts too ≈øoon from it, and in this regard the Blood being not able to contain the Serum, doth ≈øpue it out of the Mouths of the Arteries in many Places, and almo≈øt every where, and ≈øo depo≈øiting it in the Vi≈øcera or Habit of the Body, occa≈øions an A≈øcites or Ana≈øarca; and ≈øometimes, ≈øending it off immoderately to the

When the Blood, through an Incorporation, and mutual Combination of the fixt Salt with the Sulphur and Earth becomes ≈øo thick and tenacious, that the Watry Particles do not ea≈øily part from the re≈øt, the Diuretics, which may loo≈øen its Frame, and fu≈øe the Serum, mu≈øt be of ≈øuch a Sort as are endued with a volatile or acid Salt; for ≈øuch Particles do chiefly di≈ø≈øolve the Combination that the fixt Salt has entred into. Sometimes the Blood keeps not its Serum long enough within its Compages, but being ≈øubject to Fluxions, or rather Coagulations, it depo≈øites the Serum here and there in great Plenty: It rai≈øes Catarrhs or Humours in divers Places, or the Blood being habitually weak, and inclining to Sowrne≈øs, is apt to coagulate as to its thicker Particles, ≈øo that in the Circulation, the thinner being thrown off every where, and falling upon the weaker Parts, cau≈øe ≈øometimes cephalic or thoracic Di≈øtempers; ≈øometimes an A≈øcites, or Ana≈øarca, and from a like Cau≈øe we think a Diabetes al≈øo ≈øprings; for many dangerous Di≈øea≈øes, which are erroneou≈øly a≈øcribed to the Di≈øcra≈øies of the Vi≈øcera, ari≈øe from this Cau≈øe; namely, in as much as the Blood, being of an evil Temper, and liable to Coagulation, cannot continue the Thred of the Circulation entire, but in divers Places depo≈øites the Serum that is too apt to depart from it. Among the Diuretics endued with an acid Salt, are the Spirits of Salt or Nitre, al≈øo the Juice of Lemons and Sorrel; white Rheni≈øh Wine and Cider are of greate≈øt Note with the Vulgar, for the≈øe alone fu≈øe the Blood, and precipitate it into its Sero≈øities, as when an Acid is poured into boyling Milk: But this happens not alike to all. Concerning the right U≈øe of opiate Medicines, the≈øe four things following are to be ob≈øerved, viz. before we give a narcotic Medicine, we mu≈øt fir≈øt con≈øider the Con≈øtitution of the Patient. The Do≈øe of Opium is ordinary or extraordinary, the ordinary Do≈øe is threefold, low, middle, and high, and it varies much according to the Preparation of the Opium; for the Do≈øe is to be con≈øidered as the Opium is mixed and compounded with other things, or as it is ≈øimple; for if it be given alone, the Do≈øe mu≈øt be le≈øs; for in≈øtance, in grown People, the lowe≈øt Do≈øe is ordinarily a quarter or half a Grain, or one Grain, the middle two Grains, or three, the highe≈øt is four or five Grains.
