div.p: The Heads and Seeds of white Poppies, whereof Diacodium, al≈øo Decoctions, Emul≈øions, and other hypnotic Preparations are made, are far le≈øs indued with a narcotic Sulphur, than the concrete Juice of Opium, and what thereof is in the≈øe, is far more pure and harmle≈øs; wherefore we do oftener, and more ≈øecurely give Remedies made up of the≈øe; for it is not good to a≈øcend to Laudanum, unle≈øs, when through the Vehemence of Symptoms, Diacodiats will not do.

The Ancients, who thought that Opium hurt by its exce≈ø≈øive Coldne≈øs, u≈øed altogether hot Medicines to correct it, ≈øuch as Pepper, Pyrethrum, Saffron, Ca≈øtor, Euphorbium, and the like. But they were induced to correct Opium in that manner, by a fal≈øe Hypothe≈øis, and they made no good Preparation of their Medicines, to ≈øpeak only of Philonjum Romanum, heretofore
a ≈øufficiently frequent Medicine: Experience has taught, that by the Mixture of ≈øo many hot Ingredients, it can hardly be ≈øwallowed, but it will burn the Throat, and cau≈øe an Heat therein; and being mixed in Gli≈øters, but even to half a Dram, it has, in ≈øome, cau≈øed a great Heat in the lower Belly and ≈øtrait Gut.

Opiates, tho they are divine Medicines, and tho they do a great deal of good in many Di≈øea≈øes, yet an imprudent and un≈øea≈øonable U≈øe of them has been the Death of ≈øome. It is commonly known that the principal Functions of the Soul are much hurt by Narcotics; ≈øome have been made dull and ≈øtupid, and others mad, and the rea≈øon why Opium is devoured by the Turks in great Quantity, without any Harm, or however without any Danger of Life, is, becau≈øe its Particles, by frequent U≈øe, become agreeable and familiar; as we ob≈øerve concerning the Smoak of Tabaco taken in a Pipe; for whereas at the fir≈øt it u≈øes to cau≈øe Giddine≈øs, and often vomiting or purging, cold Sweats, trembling, and often fainting; yet after a while, we take it without Di≈øturbance, yea, with great Delight; and the rea≈øon why a large Do≈øe of Opium adds Courage, and notable Boldne≈øs to them, ≈øo that they can enter upon a Fight without Fear, I ≈øay, the rea≈øon ≈øeems to be, becau≈øe this Medicine, by ≈øomewhat ≈øtupifying the Spirits, makes them amazed, ≈øo that they can undauntedly endure the Approaches of ≈øen≈øible things how≈øoever terrible they are.

When Narcotics are given with Purgers, the Quantity of the Purgers is to be increa≈øed, becau≈øe the narcotic Vertue blunts them, as if half a Dram of Pil. Coch. minor is enough otherwi≈øe, let two Scruples, or two and an half be given with a Narcotic, and let Narcotics be given with Purges, that have Digridium or Coloquintida in them, whereby Nature may be ≈øollicited to Expurgation: And if the Purge ≈øtop, let it be called out by an acrimonious
and provoking Gli≈øter. Ob≈øerve this carefully, when you give Narcotics with Cathartics.

Let Narcotics be never taken on the Day before purging or bleeding, becau≈øe they dull the Spirits, and hinder the Blood from flowing freely; and if they are taken by the Mouth, or injected by Gli≈øters, they hinder the Operation of the Purge.
To conclude, note, that Narcotics do mo≈øt Good, when Evacuations have went before. Note likewi≈øe, that it is be≈øt to begin with a ≈ømall Do≈øe, and to increa≈øe it as there is occa≈øion.
Children do not bear Narcotics ≈øo well as the adult.

div.head: CHAP. XX. Of Weights and Mea≈øures u≈øed in Phy≈øick.
div.p: DRY things are generally weighed. A Grain is the Foundation of Weight. A Scruple contains twenty Grains; a Dram three Scruples; an Ounce eight Drams. A Pound is twelve Ounces. Liquid things are mea≈øured.

The Quantity of Medicines in Magnitude is pre≈øcribed by Handfulls, Armfulls, or Pugils. A Handfull is that Quantity which may be held in the Hand, an≈øwerable to half an Ounce. A Pugil is either greater or le≈øs. The greater is as much as may be taken in all the five Fingers: The le≈ø≈øer as much as may be taken in three Fingers. The greater is in Weight a whole Dram, the le≈ø≈øer half a Dram.
In Number al≈øo the Quantity of Medicines is con≈øidered, and that either equally or unequally; for in≈øtance, three or four Lupins.

Roots, Barks, and Woods are weighed: Leaves are mea≈øured by Handfulls; if they are pre≈øcribed for
Baths, by Armfulls. The Do≈øes of Seeds are for the mo≈øt part expre≈ø≈øed; yet Barly and Rice are mea≈øured by the Pugil. Flowers are mea≈øured by the Pugil. Small Fruits are weighed, great are numbred. Aromatics, Gums, and Ro≈øins are weighed. Precious Liquors and di≈øtilled Oyls are pre≈øcribed by Drops.

list.head: The Notes of Weights u≈øed by Phy≈øicians.

div.p: The five greater opening Roots, Par≈øly, Fennel, A≈ø≈øparagus, Par≈øly, Butchers Broom.
The five emollient Herbs, Mar≈øh-mallows, Beets, Mallows, Mercury, Violets.
The five capillary Herbs, black Maiden-hair, white Maiden-hair, Ceterach, Harts-tongue, Polytrichum.
The four cordial Flowers, Borrage, Buglo≈øs, Ro≈øes, Violets.
The four greater carminative Seeds, Caraways, Ani≈øe, Cummin, Fennel.
The four le≈ø≈øer hot Seeds, Bi≈øhops Weed, Amomum, Smallage, Daucus.
The four greater cold Seeds, Citruls, Cucumbers, Melons, Gourds.
The four le≈ø≈øer cold Seeds, Succory, Endive, Lettice, Pur≈ølain.
The Fragments of the five precious Stones, Granates, Hyacinth, Sapphyr, Sardus, Smaragd.

An Apozem or Decoction is a liquid Form of a Medicine, made of divers Ingredients, and ≈øweetened with Honey or Sugar, and prepared in ≈øufficient Quantity for four or five Do≈øes, to purge or alter: That is called an altering Apozem which hath a Vertue to alter the Body, and things contained in it, e≈øpecially the Humours, without that vi≈øible Evacuation, which is u≈øually called purging.

In the Compo≈øition of it ≈øix things are diligently to be con≈øidered; fir≈øt, The Matter out of which the Vertues are to be drawn; ≈øecondly, The Liquor into which it is to be conveyed; thirdly, The Decoction; fourthly, What things are to di≈ø≈øolved in it; fifthly, The clarifying of it; ≈øixthly, The aromatizing it. In the Matter the≈øe three things are to be regarded, the Quantity, the Quality, and the Order of Pre≈øcription. Concerning the Quality, the Ingredients are chiefly Roots, Barks, Woods, Leaves, Seeds, Fruits, Flowers, Spices. The Quantity or Do≈øe is as follows. Roots are not to exceed four Ounces, or ≈øix at the mo≈øt. Barks one Ounce, or two Ounces at mo≈øt, Woods in the ≈øame Quantity. Leaves not above eight large Handfulls. Seeds to one Ounce, or an Ounce and an half. Fruits are either the le≈ø≈øer Sort, and they are pre≈øcribed from one Ounce to two Ounces; or in Number, and that u≈øually by Pairs.

If they are large Fruits they are pre≈øcribed only in Number, either even or odd: If they be of the greate≈øt Sort, as Apples, and the like, they are pre≈øcribed by one, two, three, or the like; but if they are le≈øs, as Figs, by Pairs. Flowers from four Pugils to ≈øix.
Spices are be≈øt added in the ≈øea≈øoning. Concerning the Order of the Pre≈øcription, they are to be prepared by the Apothecary, as they are pre≈øcribed by the Phy≈øician, viz. fir≈øt Roots, then Barks and Woods, if any be added; ≈øecondly, Leaves; thirdly, Seeds; fourthly, Fruits; fifthly, Flowers, and with them the Spices la≈øt of all. The Quality of the Liquor is to be varyed, according to the Intention of the Phy≈øician; but generally Fountain-Water; the Quantity is ≈øeldom pre≈øcribed any other way than by Q. S. and is ordered to be boyled to one Pint and an half for Apozems, I u≈øually intend it for four Do≈øes. You mu≈øt not pre≈øcribe above twenty Ounces; for they are apt to corrupt. The Quantity of things to be di≈ø≈øolved differs according to the Nature of them. Sweetners are u≈øually di≈ø≈øolved from four Ounces to ≈øix at mo≈øt, ≈øo that every Do≈øe of the Apozem may have between an Ounce, and an Ounce and an half in every Do≈øe: But where Syrup and Sugar are mixed together, the Quantity of the Syrup is mo≈øt commonly about three Ounces, and the Sugar pre≈øcribed only with a Q. S. Juices and other ≈øtrong Liquors, as Vinegar, Aqua Vitae, and the like, are pre≈øcribed from one Ounce to two Ounces at the mo≈øt. In the aromatizing, or ≈øpicing, two things are to be con≈øidered, the Quality and the Quantity of the Spices: As to the Quality, it is either Spice, yellow or red Sanders, Cinnamon, Ginger, or Saffron: As to the Quantity, one Dram, or a Dram and an half is ≈øufficient.

In a purging Apozem three things are to be con≈øidered, the Compo≈øition, the U≈øe, and Profit In the Compo≈øition two things are to be regarded, fir≈øt, The Ingredients; ≈øecondly, tho≈øe things that are to be di≈ø≈øolved in it: The Ingredients are ≈øimple Purgers with their Correctives: In the≈øe, three things are to be regarded, the Quantity, Quality, and Order of Pre≈øcription. In relation to the Quantity, note, that
tho≈øe purging Simples which are only boyled are the≈øe; Sena, Polypody, Carthamus, Turbith, Hermodactils, Agarick, Epithymum, Hellebore, Spurge, and the Seeds of Dwarf Elder. Tho≈øe which are to be infu≈øed or but very little boyled, are Rhubarb, Myrobolans, Tamarinds, and ≈øometimes Ca≈ø≈øia. As to the Quantity, it ought to be double to the Quantity they are given in Sub≈øtance, if they are the ≈øtronger Sort; or treble, or quadruple, if they are of the milder Sort, more e≈øpecially, the three following are to be cho≈øen, for the Fundamentals of almo≈øt every purging Apozem.
div.q: Take of the Leaves of oriental Sena, the Pith of the Seed of Carthamus, Polypody of the Oak new gathered, each two Ounces and an half; you may add, upon occa≈øion, half an Ounce of Gummy Turbith, or half an Ounce of Hermodactyls, or half an Ounce of Agaric trochi≈øcated, or half an Ounce of Rhubarb tyed up in a Rag, or ≈øix Drams of Epithymum, or two Drams of the Roots of black Hellebore, or an Ounce and an half of Tamarinds, or half an Ounce of the Bark of Citron, Myrobalans, or an Ounce of common Orris Roots.
div.p: Things to be di≈ø≈øolved in the ≈øtrained Decoction are Syrups or Electuaries, viz. Syrups to four Ounces or ≈øix Ounces, Electuaries to two or three Drams, and ≈øo let an Apozem be made for four Do≈øes.

A Julep is a fluid Medicine compo≈øed of an appropriate Liquor, and Syrup, or Sugar mixed together without boyling, for four or five Do≈øes, either to prepare, or alter the Humours, or to ≈øtrengthen the Body. In the compo≈øition two things are to be minded, fir≈øt a proper Liquor, of which it is to be made; Secondly, what things are to be di≈ø≈øolved in it. In the Liquor two things are to be regarded, the quality and quantity: As to the quality, either there is pre≈øcribed a ≈øingle di≈øtilled Water, re≈øpecting the Di≈øea≈øe, and the
di≈øea≈øed Part, or el≈øe a di≈øtilled Water, and a Juice together, or el≈øe a Decoction: The quantity ought to be about eight Ounces.

Things to be di≈ø≈øolved are con≈øidered with re≈øpect to their quantity or quality: As to the quality, either Sugar, ≈øome proper Syrup, or Cordial Confection, Pearl, Ivory, or Coral is mixed with it: As to the quantity of Sweetne≈øs, one Ounce, or an Ounce and an half. Confections and Powders are pre≈øcribed from one Scruple to two.

A Potion is a liquid form of Medicine, made of things proper for Purging, or Cordials; but now a days by a Potion is meant a Purging Potion. The difference of Purging Potions are taken from the difference of Humours they Purge; hence ≈øome are Cholagogues, ≈øome Phlegmagogues, others Hydragogues, others Melanagogues; and others, compo≈øed of all the≈øe Properties, are called Panchymagogues. In general three things are to be con≈øidered in them; in compo≈øition two things are to be regarded, a proper Liquor whereof it is made, and ≈øuch things as are to be di≈ø≈øolved in it. The Liquor that is fit to di≈ø≈øolve your Medicine for a Purging Potion is to be con≈øidered, as to its quality and quantity: In re≈øpect of the quality, there is pre≈øcribed either a Decoction or Infu≈øion, or ≈øome other Liquor ≈øerving the intention of the Phy≈øician. A Decoction of Sena is generally u≈øed, or a Decoction of other Cathartics may be made, according to the diver≈øity of the Humours, ≈øufficient only for one Do≈øe; and if you di≈ø≈øolve nothing in it, the quantity mu≈øt be the larger. Things to be di≈ø≈øolved are con≈øidered either in quantity or quality. Manna and Ca≈ø≈øia are u≈øed to Purge Choler gently; Rhubarb for Fluxes; Syrups and Electuaries are al≈øo di≈ø≈øolved in it, Syrup of Ro≈øes ≈øolutive, or Diaprunum, or the like. As to the quantity, half an Ounce, or an Ounce of Syrup is u≈øually added, a Dram or two Drams of an
Electuary, an Ounce of Manna. A Purging Potion is very u≈øeful for tho≈øe that cannot take Pills or Bolus's.

An Emul≈øion is an altering Medicine u≈øed to a≈ø≈øwage Pain. In it are to be con≈øidered the Matter, the Liquor, and the things to be di≈ø≈øolved in it. The Matter in relation to its quality, are ≈øweet Almonds blanched, the four greater cold Seeds, or white Poppy Seeds, or the like; an Ounce, or an Ounce and an half, or two Ounces of the Matter are generally pre≈øcribed. The Liquor is either fair Water, or a Decoction of Barly, or the like. As to the quantity, a Pint, or thereabout, is pre≈øcribed; for it will not keep long. An Ounce, or an Ounce and an half of Syrup of Violets, or Maiden-hair, is u≈øually mixed with it; ≈øometimes to make it more plea≈øant, a little Ro≈øe-water is added to it. Three or four Ounces of it is a Do≈øe.

A Bolus is a form of Medicine, almo≈øt of the con≈øi≈øtence of Honey, or ≈øomewhat thicker. As to the quality of the Matter in general, it is compo≈øed of Purgers, both ≈øimple and compound. As to the quantity in general, a Bolus ought not to exceed ≈øix Drams; Ca≈ø≈øia, or the Pulp of Tamarinds is generally the Matter of it.

A Linctus is a Medicine of the thickne≈øs of Honey, compounded of pectoral Simples, and is u≈øed for Di≈øea≈øes of the Lungs and Brea≈øt: it is u≈øually made of Syrups, Oyl, and Sugar. As take of the Syrups of Jujubes, and Maiden-hair, each one Ounce and an half, of Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds fre≈øh drawn one Ounce, of Sugarcandy two Drams, mix them, by beating them well in a Gla≈øs Mortar till they are White.

A Linctus is commonly pre≈øcribed to be lickt with a Liquori≈øh Stick. Powders are al≈øo ≈øometimes u≈øed in a Linctus; as to their quantity, they are pre≈øcribed to an Ounce with four times the quantity of the Liquor.

Vomits are ≈øaid to be Medicines which evacuate Choler and Flegm, and ≈øometimes Poy≈øons from the Stomach and neighbouring Parts. Antimonial Medicines eject Choler, Mercurial Flegm; A≈øarabacca, and all things made of it evacuate Choler and Flegm.

list.head: Some Forms of Vomits.
list.item: Take of Oxymel of Squills one Ounce and an half, Wine of Squills two Ounces, mingle them, make a Vomit.
Take of the fre≈øh Leaves of A≈øarabacca, number ≈øix or eight, beat them, and pour upon them three Ounces of White Wine, pre≈øs out the Liquor, and let it be taken with Regimen.
Take of Salt of Vitriol one Scruple, two Scruples, or one Dram, let it be taken in a draught of Po≈ø≈øet Drink.
Take of the infu≈øion of Crocus Metallorum half an Ounce, one Ounce, or one Ounce and an half; take it in a Draught of Po≈ø≈øet Drink with Regimen.
Take of Sulphur of Antimony grains ≈øix or eight, Cream of Tartar one Scruple, mingle them, give it in the Pap of a roa≈øted Apple.
Take of Mercurius Vitae grains three or ≈øix, take it in the Pap of a roa≈øted Apple.

div.p: Chymical Vomits made of Vitriol, Antimony, and Mercury are mo≈øt e≈øteemed.

Salt of Vitriol is much valued, becau≈øe it ≈øeldom cau≈øes any di≈øturbance beyond the Stomach, whereas Stybiats ≈øometimes occa≈øion Convul≈øions of the Bowels, and Faintings, yet it works dully, and ≈øometimes not at all; wherefore upon taking of Salt of Vitriol, great quantities of Po≈ø≈øet-drink mu≈øt be taken, and it mu≈øt be forced up with a Feather. Pills are a ≈øolid form of Medicine, and round, made of Powders, and ≈øometimes Gums, Juices, tempered with ≈øome Clammy Liquor, chiefly prepared to Purge withall. The mo≈øt
u≈øual are, the Stomach Pill, Rudius's Pill, Agaric, Cochiae, Aloephangin. foetid. The Matter is generally Aloes, as the Ba≈øis; the Liquor is a Mucilage, or ≈øome proper Syrup. The Do≈øe of ≈øtrong Pills is a Scruple; of moderate, two Scruples, or a Dram; of the gentle one or two Drams.

The Liquor of a Purging Gli≈øter is the common Decoction. The Liquor of an altering Gli≈øter is made of mollifying things, heating or cooling, according to the intention. As to the quantity of the Liquor, it varies according to the Age of the Party very much; for three Ounces will ≈øerve for a Child of Four or Five Months old. A Pint is commonly pre≈øcribed for the Adult. Great Men will receive a Pint and an half; but it is to be noted, that for Women with Child, and tho≈øe that have a Drop≈øie, or are troubled with Wind; and for Old Folks, three quarters of a Pint will be ≈øufficient, when we would have the Gly≈øter long kept in the Body: The things to be di≈ø≈øolved are either Alterers or Purgers; the Alterers which are generally di≈ø≈øolved, are Honey, Sugar, and Oyl. Salt is ≈øometimes added, when we de≈øign to make the Gly≈øter more provocative. The Purgers are Electuaries, either Lenifying or Purging, according to the variety of the Humour to be Purged, and the Con≈øtitution of the Body.

A Medicinal Wine, is Wine impregnated with the Vertues of divers Simples infu≈øed in it to alter the Humours, or Purge: In the compo≈øition three things are to be ob≈øerved, the Wine, the Things to be infu≈øed in it, and the Things that are ≈øometimes di≈ø≈øolved in it. A Purging Medicinal Wine is impregnated with the Vertues of divers Purging Simples. As to the quality of the Wine, it is either new and unclean≈øed, or el≈øe Wine clean≈øed from the Lees; in relation to the quantity, that mu≈øt be limited with re≈øpect to the U≈øe and Do≈øe. But I u≈øually define the quantity of
Wine, and Things to be infu≈øed in it thus: A Purging Wine that is to be pre≈øcribed is to be u≈øed twelve days, either together, or every other day, wherein you mu≈øt be ≈øure to have twelve ≈øeveral Do≈øes of the Purgers with their Correctors, and if it be needful, ≈øit Alterers; then mu≈øt you compute the quantity of them all. For in≈øtance, ≈øuppo≈øe them eight Ounces: Now if you would have the Do≈øe of the Wine to be about an Ounce and an half, or two Ounces, pre≈øcribe it to three times their weight, and ≈øo for other quantities as you plea≈øe; by the ≈øame way, you may proceed as you ≈øee fit. But if the Wine be purely Purging, made of the gentler ≈øort of Cathartics, it is to be taken four, five, or ≈øix times, at due di≈øtances. The things to be infu≈øed, in re≈øpect of their quality, are either Purges only with their Correctors, or el≈øe with them are al≈øo infu≈øed divers Alterers dryed, as Woods, Roots, Barks, Leaves, Seeds, Flowers, Spices.

In relation to the quantity, the number of Do≈øes for which the Wine is Prepared, ≈øhall direct you. For in≈øtance, a Wine of Sena is de≈øired for twenty Do≈øes. Now the Do≈øe of Sena in infu≈øion is half an Ounce, or ≈øix Drams, therefore ten Ounces, or fifteen of it, is to be pre≈øcribed. If the Wine be prepared of many Purgers, both gentle and ≈øtrong, and al≈øo Alterers joined with them; this proportion is for the mo≈øt part to be generally ob≈øerved. Of the gentle ≈øort let there be one part, of the ≈øtronger ≈øort a quarter ≈øo much; of Correctors a quarter ≈øo much as of Purgers; Alterers ≈øhould be half ≈øo much as the Purgers. Things that are to be di≈ø≈øolved in re≈øpect of their quality, are either Sugar, or Spices. As to their quantity, for every Pint of Purging Wine, you may add three or four Ounces of Sugar, and two Drams of Cinnamon.
Medicinal Wines are u≈øually pre≈øcribed for long, and cold Di≈øea≈øes, e≈øpecially in the Winter-time.
Medicinal altering Wines are u≈øed with re≈øpect to certain parts, as Sage Wine for cold Affections of the Brain, Hy≈ø≈øop and Elecampane Wine for the Brea≈øt, Wormwood Wine for the Stomach.
Medicinal Wines are al≈øo pre≈øcribed again≈øt the Stone, to provoke Urine and the Cour≈øes. The compo≈øition is the ≈øame with that of the Purging Wine.

A Gargari≈øm is a liquid Medicine pre≈øcribed for Di≈øea≈øes of the Mouth, Gums and Throat. It is compounded of Waters, and proper things to be di≈ø≈øolved in it. As to the quantity, a Pint, or a Pint and an half of Water is pre≈øcribed. Of the things to be di≈ø≈øolved in it, namely Syrups, 3 or 4 Ounces; of Honey 1 Ounce and an half, or 2 Ounces; of Vinegar 2 or 3 Ounces.

A Pe≈ø≈øary is a Medicine to be put up a Womans Privities in many Di≈øea≈øes of the Womb. It is compo≈øed of an Ounce and an half, or two Ounces of ≈øome loo≈øening Opiat. Two are always pre≈øcribed, that when one is taken out, the other ≈øhould be put in: It is corporated with ≈øome Juice.
Note, that ≈øome Powders may be added to the Opiat, either ≈øharp hy≈øterical opening Powders to a Dram and an half, or two Drams, or el≈øe Powders of Purgers ≈øimple, or compound, to two Drams.

A Suppo≈øitory is a topical Medicine u≈øed to the Fundament, or Anus, three or four Inches in length, ≈ølender and round; it is either ≈øimple or compound. The ≈øimple is made either of the ≈øtalk or root of Beets, Colewort, or Mar≈øhmallows; the outward Peel being taken off, to which is added ≈øometimes Salt, (to augment the provocative Vertue) rub'd on the out≈øide, ≈ømoothen'd over with Oyl; al≈øo the ≈øtalk of a Leek anointed with Butter; or white Soap ≈øharpened like a Suppo≈øitory; al≈øo Honey alone boiled to a hard con≈øi≈øtence, for ≈øo it becomes more ≈øharp.

The Compound is made of Honey as the Ba≈øis, boiled till it will not ≈øtick to the Fingers, then adding Powders
to it near to this proportion: As to one Ounce you may add one Dram, or four Scruples of Powder at mo≈øt, according as the Powder is lighter in weight, or ≈øtronger in operation; which quantity will ≈øerve for two or three Suppo≈øitories.

A Catapla≈øm is a ≈øo≈øt Topick; it is compounded variou≈øly, either, which is mo≈øt u≈øual of the Mucilage of divers parts of Plants, to which are after added, either Oyls alone, or with Powders. Let there be of Mucilage ten Ounces, or a Pound; of Powders, one, two, or three Ounces; Oyl or things equivalent, three or four Ounces; or el≈øe you may expre≈øs only the quantity of the equivalent things, and ≈øet down of Oyl Q. S. ≈øo that the whole Catapla≈øm do not exceed one Pound and an half; it may be much le≈øs, according to the bigne≈øs of the part, and u≈øe. As to the Mucilage, it is made in re≈øpect of the quality of boiled Roots, as Mar≈øhmallows, Lillies, or the like. The Powders in relation to their quality are Flower of Barly, Beans, Lin≈øeed, Fenugreek Seed; or to di≈øcu≈øs, Orris, Cumin, Camomile Flowers, and the like; or ≈øometimes Fruits, ripe, or unripe, as Apples, Prunes, Quinces, and the like, roa≈øted under the Embers, or boiled in a fit Liquor, and brui≈øed, adding fit Powders in the quantity afore≈øaid; as in the Flux of the Belly, and Dy≈øentery, it is made of the Pulp of Quinces and a≈øtringent Powders; or ≈øometimes in Fluxes of the Belly, Vomiting, and to ≈øtrengthen the Stomach, a ≈ølice of Bread ≈øteeped in Wine, and toa≈øted hot, is pre≈øcribed, being ≈øprinkled with one or two Ounces of an a≈øtringent ≈øtrengthning Powder, to be applied to the Stomach.

A Catapla≈øm for Pain is made of Crums of White Bread ≈øteeped in half a Pint of Milk; to which is added two Yolks of Eggs, half an Ounce of Saffron, and q. s. of Oyl fit for the purpo≈øe. Catapla≈øms are applied chiefly to ea≈øe Pain, to ≈øoften hard Swellings, to
ripen Tumours, and to di≈ø≈øolve the Cau≈øe of Inflammations. They are u≈øually pre≈øcribed of a≈øtringent Things, to ≈øtop Fluxes, and are profitably made to provoke Urine; of Pellitory of the Wall, and Oyl of Scorpions, applied to the bottom of the Belly; for they relax, mollify, and empty powerfully.

A Pulti≈øs differs from a Catapla≈øm in nothing el≈øe, ≈øaving that that is prepared of the Mucilage of Things boiled to Pap, and this is u≈øually made of the flowery part of Things boiled to the con≈øi≈øtence of a Pulti≈øs. It is either compounded of the Flower of Pul≈øe, four Ounces being boiled in a convenient Liquor, to which afterwards are added Oyls, or three or four Ounces of Grea≈øe, or ≈øome other thing equivalent to Oyl, if the ca≈øe ≈øo requires, or of the Crums of White Bread to ea≈øe Pain, and ripen; or of a convenient Mucilage and Powders, and Oyls. But this is rather a Catapla≈øm.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. Of the Office of a Phy≈øician.
div.p:
THere is no part of a Phy≈øician's Office more illu≈øtrious than Con≈øultation; becau≈øe by it alone unlearned Phy≈øicians are di≈øtingui≈øhed from the learned; and there is nothing that brings greater advantage to the Sick; but Care mu≈øt be taken that Differences do not ari≈øe out of Hatred, or private Intere≈øt. We may indeed ≈øometimes oppo≈øe other Mens Opinions, if they ≈øeem not good, but re≈øpect mu≈øt be always had to the Laws of Rea≈øon and Experience, and we mu≈øt ≈øubmit always to the Judgment of the mo≈øt experienced, and to Plurality. The≈øe Con≈øultations mu≈øt be held apart from the Patients, to the end every Man may more freely di≈øcover his Fears or Hopes; for Fear is not ea≈øily removed out of the Patient's Head, when
he is once po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with it. Be≈øides, if any one of the Phy≈øicians have a Spark of Vain-glory in him, he will be apt to magnifie him≈øelf before the Patient.

A faithful and true Account of the Di≈øea≈øes, their Cau≈øes and Symptoms mu≈øt be required of the Patient; for Cel≈øus ≈øays, that many die thro' their own Fault, e≈øpecially Women, when their Mode≈øty will not allow them to reveal the ≈øecret Di≈øea≈øes of their Bodies.

We mu≈øt not utterly deny a Patient all Remedies, how de≈øperate ≈øoever his Ca≈øe is; for the Strength of Nature is admirable, and ≈øhe often rallies again≈øt the triumphant Enemy, and ≈øometimes in a fre≈øh Combate becomes victorious. Now, ≈øince it is ≈øo, and ≈øince oftentimes ≈øuch unexpected Events have convinced us, that as long as there is Life there may be Hopes, we ought to be doing ≈øomething: Hippocrates him≈øelf acknowledges that Predictions of Life and Death are not always certain.

Let the Phy≈øician be doubtful in his Progno≈øtic, unle≈øs there be mo≈øt certain, and infallible Signs of Death; Let him be moderate in his Promi≈øes, yet let him give always Hopes rather of Health, than foretel certain Death; for when the Patient is given over by the Phy≈øician, if he recover afterwards (as he often does, which occa≈øioned the Proverb, viz. that it is better to be condemned twice by the Phy≈øician, than once by the Judge) the Phy≈øician incurs Infamy.
In ≈øome Di≈øea≈øes, great regard mu≈øt be had to Mens way of living, otherwi≈øe they will be hardly cured; and ≈øo many good and admirable Cures have been performed.

Let neither the Phy≈øician, nor the Apothecary declare what their Medicines are, either to the Patient or to the By-≈øtanders; let them only ≈øignifie, that they intend to give a Purge, a Vomit, or a Gli≈øter, and conceal what the≈øe are made of, both becau≈øe otherwi≈øe they may be improperly taken, without the
Advice of a Phy≈øician, or becau≈øe when things are known, they are contemned.

Hippocrates bids us ob≈øerve all the Patient's Errors, whether about Meat or Drink, or about Medicines, or external things; for if through their own Faults they grow wor≈øe, the Blame is laid upon the Ph≈øician.
We mu≈øt not u≈øe Medicines, but upon urgent Nece≈ø≈øity; for ≈øometimes we mu≈øt re≈øt a while, and do nothing but order a good Diet.

It is not unbecoming a Phy≈øician, who is skill'd in the manual Operation, to breath a Vein, when there is no Surgeon to do it, or to ≈øet a Limb that is broken or out of joint; for a Surgeon's Work is one of the three Parts of Phy≈øick; nor is it di≈øgraceful to make up Medicines: And indeed it were well if Phy≈øicians applyed them≈øelves more to Pharmacy than they do.

Let the Phy≈øician never pre≈øcribe two Medicines at once, and leave the Patient to his Choice, becau≈øe then he is at a Lo≈øs, and can tru≈øt neither of them, but blames his Phy≈øician for Incon≈øtancy.

A Phy≈øician ought not always to contemn the Medicines of the common People. Let no Man, ≈øays Hippocrates, be a≈øhamed, if he be never ≈øo learned, to learn ≈øomething that conduces to the Perfection of his Art, tho from an old Woman.

A Phy≈øician mu≈øt not mix tho≈øe things which de≈øtroy one another by a manife≈øt Contrariety; for example, vitriolated things mu≈øt not be mixed with nitrous ones, nor aluminous things with Alcalies, and the like.

Some counterfeit Di≈øea≈øes, who≈øe Deceit it belongs to a prudent Phy≈øician to detect; now the Di≈øea≈øes that are counterfeited, are u≈øually Swooning, Apoplexy, Fits of the Mother. Some tye their Arms ≈øo ≈øtrait, that the Pul≈øe can ≈øcarce, if at all be felt; when they are called on aloud, they do not an≈øwer; if they
be prickt a little, or their Ears pull'd, or their Fingers bent, they bear it patiently. The Cheat is di≈øcovered by asking, whether any Want of Food has preceded, Lo≈øs of Blood, a Loo≈øne≈øs, Vomiting, or immoderate Sweating, or any Di≈øea≈øe; or whether he hath been in a hot Place, or where Coals have been kindled in a clo≈øe Room, or whether he hath been put in ≈øome great Pa≈ø≈øion. But if the extream Parts are cold, and if a cold Sweat bur≈øt out, e≈øpecially about the Head, Face, and Neck; if the Pul≈øe cannot be felt, or are creeping; if the Breathing be little and cold, if the Colour of the Face be gone, and if he void his Excrements, the≈øe ≈øignifie that the Di≈øea≈øes are not feigned: But if there be no ≈øuch Signs, and if the Cheater ≈øhuts his Eyes, and looks as if he were in a Swoon, the Phy≈øician mu≈øt mention ≈øome ≈øtrong Medicines, he mu≈øt order burning, bending of the Fingers, and pricking of the Body with Needles; for by this means the Cheat may be di≈øcovered. Some rai≈øe Bli≈øters, Swellings, and Ulcers, by wa≈øhing the Skin with the Juice of Spurge, or with a Decoction of Spani≈øh Flies, or Wa≈øps, in Water, or by applying ≈øcorching Fennel, or Turbith, or Powder of Rue: It is u≈øual with Beggars to move Compa≈ø≈øion, but the Cheat may be ea≈øily di≈øcovered, by applying Populeon Oyntment, or the like; becau≈øe Bli≈øters and Swellings occa≈øioned by ≈øuch Applications may be ea≈øily cured thereby. Some counterfeit Madne≈øs; but you may di≈øcover them by their Habit, and by the Ab≈øence of the Signs of Madne≈øs, or Melancholy. ∆≤li≈ø≈øes's feigned Madne≈øs was di≈øcovered by throwing his Son before the Plow; for he lifted the Plow over him. Some, with the Steem of Brim≈øtone, or with ≈øome ≈øuch thing, di≈øcolour the Face; Saffron or Rhubarb does the ≈øame. Tho≈øe that counterfeit Pains may be ea≈øily di≈øcovered, for they bear it better, and do not change Po≈øtures, as tho≈øe do that are in violent Pain. Be≈øides, they that are very
ill of a Di≈øea≈øe are willing to admit of any Remedy voluntarily, ≈øend for Phy≈øicians, and do whatever they pre≈øcribe. But if they be but a little ≈øick, or not at all, they refu≈øe ≈øuch Remedies. Sometimes it happens that a wounded Man, either out of Hatred to him that wounded him, or to get ≈øome Money out of him, feigns that ≈øome Limb is hurt: In this Ca≈øe you mu≈øt touch that Hand or Limb unawares.

When a Phy≈øician is fir≈øt called to a Patient, after he has put the Patient in Hopes of Recovery, let him order ≈øomething pre≈øently, that he may not be thought to practi≈øe Phy≈øick by Books, e≈øpecially when he is called after other Phy≈øicians; for then all expect ≈øomething more than others have done before; therefore when you are informed what they have done, begin ≈øome other Method, yet ≈øuch as you think is more effectual, le≈øt if you ≈øhould repeat the ≈øame things, they ≈øhould think you were called to no purpo≈øe. If the Di≈øea≈øe be ≈øuch as may be cured by Diet alone, yet you mu≈øt pre≈øcribe ≈øome Phy≈øick, which may do no Hurt, or ≈øomething like Diet, which may do Good, le≈øt they ≈øhould ≈øay you were ignorant, and affirm that Nature cured the Di≈øea≈øe. This mu≈øt be e≈øpecially done when the Patient never thinks him≈øelf ≈øafe or well, but when he is taking Phy≈øick; and if you do not trifle with him in this manner, he will find others that will tamper with him and ≈øpoil him.
A Phy≈øician ≈øhould never vi≈øit the ≈øick, unle≈øs he be ≈øent for, and his Vi≈øits ought not to be too frequent, when he is entertained.

There are ≈øome principal things, concerning which Patients ≈øhould be interrogated, fir≈øt, what it is that ails him, and how his Head and Stomach, and other principal Parts do; how many Days he has been ill; what made him ill, what Diet he kept; whether he be loo≈øe or co≈øtive; whether he u≈øed naturally to breed bad Humours; whether any natural Evacuation be
≈øtopt; whether he be u≈øed to labour, or a ≈øedentary Life.
Patients mu≈øt not always be ≈øeverely denied what Nature earne≈øtly craves for, for we ≈øee that ≈øeveral do not recover till their Appetites are gratified.
You mu≈øt vary the Cour≈øe of Diet and Medicines, according to the Con≈øtitutions, Climates, Situation of Countries.

There are many things in this Art, wherein for Urgency's Sake, it is a piece of Art to depart from Art; for tho there be many good Precepts and Rules, yet none are perpetual, and he that reckons any for perpetual and inviolable, may be a Methodi≈øt, but not at all rational; for a rational Phy≈øician proceeds not ≈øo much by Book as by Experience; for in Ca≈øes there is a wonderful Variety.

When the Phy≈øician judges ≈øome generous Remedy requi≈øite, and the Ratient or By-≈øtanders are again≈øt it, he ought to acquaint them with the pre≈øent Danger, the Mi≈øchief of deferring it, and the Damage that will follow; thus they that will not yield to Per≈øwa≈øions, will ≈øometimes obey for Fear of future Evil.

It is much better to be an empirical Phy≈øician, that is, one who practi≈øes according to Experience, than a theorical one, who practi≈øes according to his own Rea≈øonings and Figments; for Experience has long ≈øince informed all accurate Ob≈øervers of things, which happen in our Art, that Empiricks are more ≈øuccesful in their Practice than Theori≈øts, and ≈øuch as are Phy≈øicians from Books, or their own Speculations: The≈øe are ≈øo much more mi≈øerable in their Folly, becau≈øe they make others mi≈øerable with them≈øelves; but the World will be bubled with cramp Words, and great Brags.

It is unbecoming a Phy≈øician to harangue to the By≈øtanders; for it gives the Patient a Su≈øpicion that he
would cure indeed, but that he is not able, and therefore he would ≈øupply in Talk what he cannot perform by his Skill.

It is the Part of a Phy≈øician, not only to u≈øe Medicines, and to order the Meat and Drink, but al≈øo to take care of all things that mu≈øt be done or ≈øaid before the Patient, and of the Chamber, Hou≈øe and Bed, and of all external things, and to di≈øpo≈øe of them all, ≈øo as they may be mo≈øt for the Benefit of the Patient.

When the Nature of the Di≈øea≈øe is ob≈øcure, yet as for the Cure, an Indication is left us, to be taken from the Juvantia & Laedentia, by means whereof, trying the way by degrees, we may conduct the Patient, provided we make not too much Ha≈øte, than which nothing is more de≈øtructive. I am not a≈øhamed, ≈øays Sydenham, to confe≈øs, that when I was not ≈øatisfied what I ought to do, I provided be≈øt for my Patient and my ≈øelf by doing nothing; for while I waited for an Opportunity, the Di≈øea≈øe either went off of it ≈øelf, or put on ≈øuch a Type, as I knew well enough how to manage. And indeed, more ≈øhould be left to Nature than is now the Cu≈øtom to do; for he is much mi≈øtaken, who thinks Nature always needs the Help of Art; for if it were ≈øo, ≈øhe has not taken that Care of Human Kind, which the Con≈øervation of the Species requires, ≈øeeing there has been no Proportion between the Frequency of Di≈øea≈øes that invade Man, and their Faculties which Men have to drive them away, even in the≈øe Ages, when Phy≈øick flouri≈øhed mo≈øt, and when mo≈øt Men practi≈øed it.

It is found by Experience, that every ≈øeven or nine Years a Man undergoes ≈øome great Alteration; the≈øe are called Climacteric, becau≈øe they are Steps or Ladders, whereby we climb up to old Age: In the≈øe Years therefore no great Medicines mu≈øt be u≈øed, and becau≈øe then Nature u≈øes to do ≈øome great thing, the Phy≈øician mu≈øt be quiet.
Many Phy≈øicians avoid all Days of Oppo≈øitions and Conjunctions of the Moon, unnece≈ø≈øarily; for all the Phy≈øician has to do, is to ob≈øerve the Alterations of the Air.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. Of Animals that are of Medicinal ∆≤≈øe.
div.p: THE Lungs of a Lamb, as well as tho≈øe of a Fox, are commended for Con≈øumptions, and Di≈øea≈øes of the Lungs. The coagulated Milk of a Sheep or Goat is excellent for di≈ø≈øolving Womens coagulated Milk.
The Horns and Hoof of an Elk are in U≈øe, and both are accounted Specifics for an Epilep≈øie, Convul≈øions, Tremblings of the Limbs, Giddine≈øs, Palpitation of the Heart, and hy≈øteric Fits.

The Tooth of a Boar is reckoned a Specific in Pleuri≈øies and Quin≈øies; half a Dram or a Dram of it prepared, being given in a Decoction of the Flowers of red Poppies, or in a Decoction of Carduus Benedictus. Some give a Dram of the Ra≈øpings of it, mixed with Oyl of Almonds and Sugarcandy: But the Ra≈øpings of it mixed with a Decoction is be≈øt; for it yields a kind of a Gelly. The Stones are a Specific for Barrenne≈øs in Women, and an E≈ø≈øence is prepared of them, which is counted good for Impotents, and it is u≈øed al≈øo to promote and ≈øtimulate Venery. The Dung is reckoned an excellent Specific to ≈øtop Blood. The Urine is good for the Stone in the Kidneys and Bladder.

Of the Blood of an A≈øs is prepared an E≈ø≈øence, which is reckoned good for the Falling-≈øickne≈øs. The Filth of an A≈ø≈øes Ear promotes Sleep, being applied to the Temples, and is excellent in malignant Fevers,
but you mu≈øt not anoint the Temples with it too often, le≈øt it make the Patient ≈øleep too much. A≈ø≈øes Milk nouri≈øhes much, loo≈øens the Belly, and provokes Urine, and is much commended for a Con≈øumption, the Stone in the Bladder, and in the Kidneys; and is better in the≈øe Ca≈øes than any other ≈øort of Milk whatever, three Quarters of a Pint of it being drank five or ≈øix Mornings, ≈øweetned with an Ounce of Sugarcandy, and the Patient mu≈øt fa≈øt three Hours after; he mu≈øt al≈øo take the ≈øame Quantity three Hours before Supper: But in this Cour≈øe he mu≈øt ab≈øtain from all acid Meats. A≈ø≈øes Milk is al≈øo good for the Gout.

A≈ø≈øes Dung gathered in May, is good for bleeding at the No≈øe, or for Blood flowing from any other Part, a Dram being taken at a time. The Fume of the Dung is al≈øo good for bleeding at the No≈øe, and for too great a Flux of the Cour≈øes. Or, Take of Plantain Water one Ounce, of Syrup of Myrtles, and of the Juice of A≈ø≈øes Dung, each half a Dram; mix them: This Potion taken in the Morning, and continued for ≈øome Days, is an approved Remedy for all Fluxes of the Womb, whether white or red, ∆≤niver≈øals going before.

The Reins of an A≈øs powdered, and mixed with Honey, and drank in Beer, are an excellent Remedy for the Strangury. The hard Fle≈øh growing about the Knees of an A≈øs is reckoned as a great Secret for the making Hair to grow.

The Horns of a Bull ra≈øped is reckoned good for Impotents, e≈øpecially if it be ra≈øped off in the Time of Coition; ≈øo is al≈øo the Brain of a Sparrow killed in Coition. Bull's Gaul is the mo≈øt acrid and volatile of all the Gauls of Animals, and is reckoned very proper to take off Spots or Clouds from the Eye; the Tincture of it is reckoned an excellent Co≈ømetic, and the Gaul „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ d is of great U≈øe in Gli≈øters to provoke the Belly, a Dram being mixed with a Gli≈øter. A Pla≈øter
or Oyntment made of Aloes, Cow's Gaul, Myrrh, and Oyl of Coloquintida, and applied to the Navel, is much commended to expel Worms in grown People, and in Children. The Gaul of all Sorts of Animals is much commended for Di≈øea≈øes of the Ears, to quiet the Noi≈øe, to remove Deafne≈øs and Dullne≈øs of hearing, being put into the Ear with Cotton. The Spleen of a Cow is much commended for Di≈øea≈øes of the Spleen, viz. the Hardne≈øs, Inflation, Pain, and Swelling of it. It is al≈øo good for Ob≈øtructions of the Cour≈øes, and for the Cachexy of Virgins ari≈øing thence, for which it is much commended.

Cow's Marrow is frequently u≈øed for Di≈øea≈øes of the Nerves; Cow's Dung is frequently u≈øed for Burns, in the manner of a Catapla≈øm, and for Inflammations, and being applied to the Belly, it is an excellent Remedy for the Cholick, and to expel Wind. It is al≈øo applied to the Belly in Drop≈øies, to le≈ø≈øen the Swelling, and to di≈øcu≈øs the Water. It is al≈øo u≈øed for flegmatick Swellings of the Parts. It ≈øtops Inflammations, and prevents Gangrens. The Water of the Dung, called the Water of all the Flowers, is an excellent Co≈ømetic, and takes off Spots from the Face. It is al≈øo much commended for provoking Urine, and expelling Gravel. Some ordinary People pre≈øs out the Juice of the Dung, and drink it for the Cholick and Pleuri≈øie, and it is counted a pre≈øent Remedy.

There is often found in the Stomach of a Cow or Bull, a Stone, which is ≈øometimes pretty large, and ≈øometimes a Stone in the Gaul-bladder, the Powder whereof, e≈øpecially of that Stone in the Gaul-Bladder, is counted an excellent Remedy for the Jaundice, and to expel Gravel; it al≈øo expels Poi≈øons by Sweat, and drives away the Fits of the Falling-≈øickne≈øs. The Powder of the Stone is al≈øo an excellent Errhine, but it is be≈øt u≈øed by being mixed with the Juice of Beets, and applied to the No≈øtrils, for it pre≈øently cau≈øes ≈øneezing.

The Milk of a Cow, as all other Milk does, con≈øi≈øts of three Sub≈øtances, Whey, Butter, and Chee≈øe; it is an excellent Nouri≈øhment, and partakes much of the Nature of the Herb the Bea≈øts feed on; and ≈øo if they feed on Water-cre≈øs, Brook-lime, Scurvy-gra≈øs, Money-wort, and the like, the Milk will be good for the Scurvy; and if they eat Ground-Ivy, and the like, the Milk will be proper for a Con≈øumption, and Ulcers in the inner Parts.

In the U≈øe of Milk, you mu≈øt ob≈øerve to drink it warm from the Cow, for it is ≈øoon altered by the Air, and turns ≈øowre, and is very apt to contract Contagion, in a pe≈øtilential Time, and turns of a Sky Colour or livid.

Milk in general is proper to nouri≈øh the Parts; therefore it is very proper for ≈øuch as have a hectic Fever, or the like. It is al≈øo good to correct the Acrimony of the Humours, and is al≈øo an excellent Remedy for the Scurvy. It is al≈øo very proper for Di≈øea≈øes of the Urinary Pa≈ø≈øages, namely, bloody Urine, Heat of Urine, and the Strangury. It is al≈øo good for the Bloody Flux, e≈øpecially if Steel be often quenched in it. In this Ca≈øe it is to be taken by the Mouth, and to be injected in Form of a Gli≈øter. But in the U≈øe of it, acid things mu≈øt be avoided, and to hinder its Coagulation, it is convenient to mix a little Sugar with it; for Sugar powerfully hinders the Coagulation, and if a little of it be mixed with it, Butter or Chee≈øe can never be made.

But Milk is naught for ≈øuch as have continual or intermitting Fevers. It is al≈øo naught for tho≈øe that are troubled with Head-aches, Giddine≈øs, the Falling≈øickne≈øs, and the like: It is naught for Nau≈øeou≈øne≈øs, Vomiting, a Loo≈øene≈øs, and the Cholera Morbus. It mu≈øt not be u≈øed in Swellings of the Liver and Spleen, or in Ob≈øtructions of the Me≈øentery.
Outwardly u≈øed, it is an excellent Anodyne. It ea≈øes Pain. Flowers of Elder boyled with Milk is reckoned an excellent Medicine to take off Inflammations, and cures an Eri≈øypelas.

Whey moderately loo≈øens the Belly, cools and a≈ø≈øwages the Efferve≈øcence of the Blood, and is therefore proper in malignant and burning Fevers, either taken by it ≈øelf, or mixed with the Juice of Citron. And tho Milk be injurious to hypochondriac People, and to tho≈øe who≈øe Vi≈øcera are not firm, yet Whey is very proper for them, for it qualifies the Acid, and opens Ob≈øtructions of the Bowels. It provokes Urine, and is conveniently u≈øed in Summer Mornings to attemperate the Acrimony of the Blood and Diuretics; and things that purge and open may be mixed with it.
A Decoction of Fumitory being mixed with it, or Fumitory boyled with it, purifies the Blood, cures the Itch, a Heat of Urine, and ≈øpitting of Blood.
But Whey is not proper for old Men.
The Pizle of a Bull reduced to Powder, and a Dram of it being taken at a time, is good for a Di≈øentery, and a Pleuri≈øie; and this is one of Helmont's Antipleuretic Secrets.

A Toad is an Animal well known, upon the Account of the Antipathy that is betwixt it and the Spider, again≈øt which it defends its ≈øelf, by the U≈øe of Plantain. Crabs are very proper for tho≈øe that have a hectic ≈øever and are con≈øumptive, and for tho≈øe that have Ulcers in the Lungs and Reins; and indeed the whole Crab is vulnerary. q.p: Take of Frog-≈øpan Water, eight Ounces; of the Juice of River Crabs, two Ounces; of Saffron, one Ounce; of Opium corrected with Vinegar, half a Dram; of Camphor, one Scruple; mingle them for an Epithem. div.q:
Take two Drams of good Ambar-grea≈øe, ≈øo much Sugarcandy, half a Dram of Musk, and two Grains of Civet; beat them ≈ømall together, and put the Mixture into a Viol, pour upon it four Ounces of Wine well alcoholized, ≈øtop the Viol clo≈øe, and ≈øet it in Dige≈øtion in
Hor≈øe-Dung four Days; then taking it out, ≈øeparate that which is clear while it is warm; for it will congeal when cold. This E≈ø≈øence works more ≈øtrongly than Amber-grea≈øe in Sub≈øtance. The Do≈øe is from ≈øix to twelve Drops in ≈øome convenient Liquour.
div.p: Ambar-grea≈øe alone has ≈øcarce any Smell at all, but when its Parts are put in Motion by Fermentation, Sulphurs ri≈øe from it, which tickle the Sen≈øe of Smelling with a great deal of Plea≈øure. The Addition of Musk and Civet have a good Effect. As for the Sugarcandy, it ≈øerves only to ≈øeparate the re≈øt, that they may be the more ea≈øily powdered, and di≈ø≈øolved; for this Tincture is only a Di≈ø≈øolution of the≈øe Sulphureous Matters in Spirit of VVine.

Metallic Recrements are ≈øo called, becau≈øe they are not perfect Metals, but participate of the Nature and Matter of Metals, and are ≈øeparated by Fermentation in the Generation of Meals, from other perfect Metals.

Cobaltum is a Cau≈øtick, and is very volatile, and much mixed with a corro≈øive Ar≈øenick, and therefore is counted poy≈øonous. A Sky-colour is made of it. Some think a Medicine may be made of it for the Epilep≈øy; but the U≈øe of it is very dangerous, by rea≈øon of the Ar≈øenick.

Chalcitis, Mi≈øy, and Sory are Metallick Recrements, and belong to the Kinds of Vitriols, and may be properly called crude and impure Vitriol. Chalcitis is made of Sory, and Mi≈øy of Chalcitis. Mi≈øy is u≈øed for dying.

Cadmia Factitia is nothing el≈øe but the Soot of Bra≈øs, which ≈øticks to the Furnace in the Fu≈øion of the Metal. It is chiefly u≈øed in Surgery, for old and ill conditioned Ulcers; for being ≈øprinkled upon them, it drys much, and de≈øtroys the corrupt Ferment of Ulcers, and ≈øo it incarns and cicatrizes. Cadmia being prepared by Fire, and extingui≈øhed, is called prepared Tutty, which is very good for Di≈øea≈øes of the Eyes, the Powder
of it being blown into the Eyes, for Inflammations and Ulcers. An Oyntment is commonly made of it, and u≈øed for the Eyes: But it is very proper to mix with it a Grain or two of Camphor, or Saffron, or the like.

Litharge is nothing el≈øe but the Lead, whereby Gold, in Fu≈øion, is depurated, which ab≈øorbs all the vile Metals, when the Gold is in Fu≈øion. There are two Sorts of Litharge, viz. of Gold and of Silver. The Litharge of Gold is the mo≈øt pure.
Plumbago is the impure Mine of Lead.
Pompholix is the fine≈øt Sparkles which ≈øticks to the uppermo≈øt Part of the Furnace in the Fu≈øion of Bra≈øs.
Spodium is burnt Ivory.

Pompholix is much u≈øed in Surgery, and is much commended for Di≈øea≈øes of the Eyes. The Oyntment called Diapompholigos is much commended for the Itch, and Pu≈øtles in the Skin; and al≈øo for Inflammations in the Eyes.

Sperma Caeti is vulgarly reckoned among≈øt Bitumens, but it is certainly taken out of the Heads of Whales in Greenland. It is an excellent Remedy for di≈ø≈øolving coagulated Blood. It is u≈øed in Pleuri≈øies, Peripneumonia's, Brui≈øes, and the like, to take off Inflammations, and the like. It is al≈øo excellent for Inflammations and Swellings of the Papes, and for the Gripes in Children, and the Collick in grown People, being di≈ø≈øolved in ≈øome proper Water. It is al≈øo u≈øed for Di≈øea≈øes in the Brea≈øt, and for a ≈øuffocative Catarrh.

Petreolum is a Fat and bituminous Matter flowing by degrees from Rocks and Stones. Some think that Petreolum or Oyl of Peter is a Liquor drawn from Ambar, by the means of ≈øubterranean Fires, which make a De≈øtillation of it, and that Jet and Coals are the Remainders of it. This Opinion would have Probability enough in it; if the Places from whence this Sort of Drug comes, were not ≈øo far a≈øunder, the one
from the other; for Petreolum is not commonly found any where, but in Italy, Sicily, and Provence: It is excellent for Di≈øea≈øes of the Nerves, the Pal≈øy, and Convul≈øions, either alone or with Oyl of Ambar, and is excellent for cold Di≈øea≈øes of the Nerves. Ten or fifteen Drops of it being taken in Wine is a certain Cure for Ob≈øtructions of the Cour≈øes.

To conclude, Metals are counted ≈øeven, viz. Gold, Silver, Iron, Tin, Copper, Lead, and Quick≈øilver. This la≈øt is not malleable of it ≈øelf, as all the others are, but is ≈øo being mingled with others. And becau≈øe this is thought to be the Seed of Metals, it is numbred with the re≈øt. A≈øtrologers have conceited, that there was ≈øo great an Affinity and Corre≈øpondence between the ≈øeven Metals before named, and the ≈øeven Planets, that nothing happened to the one, but the other ≈øhared in it; and therefore they have given the≈øe ≈øeven Metals the Names of the ≈øeven Planets, each accordingly as they are governed, and ≈øo have called Gold the Sun, Silver the Moon, Iron, Mars, Quick≈øilver Mercury, Tin Jupiter, Copper Venus, and Lead Saturn. They have likewi≈øe fancied that each of the≈øe Planets has his Day apart to di≈øtribute liberally his In≈øluence on our Hemi≈øphere, and ≈øo they tell us, if we work upon Silver on Monday, Iron on Tue≈øday, and ≈øo of the re≈øt, we ≈øhall attain our End much better than on other Days.
As to Minerals, what≈øoever is found petrified in the Earth, or upon the Earth is called Mineral.

Petrification is made by a Coagulation of acid or ≈øalt Waters that are found in the Pores of the Earth. This Petrification differs according to the divers Di≈øpo≈øitions, or different Nature of the Earth, and according to the Time that Nature u≈øes in its Perfection.
