div.head: A Collection of Medicines, and the Virtues and ∆≤≈øes of them.
div.p: I Begin fir≈øt with ≈øimple Waters in U≈øe.
Sorrel Water cools and dries, and is u≈øed in alexipharmic Potions for a Vehicle.
Bettony Water heats, dries, attenuates, is diuretic and cephalic.
The Water of Holly Leaves heats, dries, clean≈øes, is diuretic and ≈øplenetic.
Carduus Water heats, dries, is ≈øudorific, and alexipharmic.
The Water of the le≈ø≈øer Centaury heats, dries, cures Fevers, and kills Worms.
The Water of the greater Celandine heats, dries, clean≈øes, clears the Eye when there is a Cataract.
Succory Water cools and dries, it is cephalic, cardiac, uterine, and ≈øtomachic.
The Water of Scurvy-gra≈øs heats and dries, is anti≈øcorbutic and ≈øplenetic
Eye-bright Water heats, dries, is a≈øtringent, and ≈øtops Fluxions on the Eyes.
Fennel Water heats, attenuates, di≈øcu≈ø≈øes, and is ≈øudorific, and clears the Sight
Bean-flower Water clean≈øes, provokes Urine, and beautifies the Face.
Strawberry Water clean≈øes the Face and Skin, and a≈ø≈øwages an Ery≈øipalas.
The Water of Lavender Flowers heats, dries, and is cephalic.
The Water of the Flowers of Lillies of the Vallies heats and dries, is cephalic, cures an Apoplexy, Epilep≈øy, and Giddine≈øs.
Ro≈øe Water cools and dries, is cardiac and cephalic.

Elder-flower Water mollifies re≈øolves, and is good for
an Ery≈øipelas, taken inwardly, or outwardly applyed.
Lime-flower Water cures the Falling-≈øickne≈øs, and expels Wind in Children, being ≈øweetned with Sugar.
The Water of Oak Leaves cools and dries, and cures the Bloody-flux and Hemorrhages.
Fumitory Water prepares Bile and Melancholy.
The Water of Gra≈øs is diuretic and lithontriptic, and ≈øtops a Flux of Blood.
Hy≈øop Water heats, dries, attenuates, and cuts gro≈øs Humours contained in the Lungs.
Lettice Water cools, moi≈øtens, and provokes Sleep.
Mallow-flower Water heats, moi≈øtens, mollifies, and is good for Di≈øea≈øes of the Lungs, Reins, and Bladder, and for Heat of Urine.
Balm Water heats, dries, is cardiac, and good again≈øt Melancholy.
Water of Honey heats, moi≈øtens, is diuretic, lithontriptic, breeds Hair, and cures a Suffu≈øion of the Eyes.
Mint Water heats, dries, is good for the Stomach and the Head.
Red Poppy Water cools, promotes Sleep, and is good for a Pleuri≈øy.
Par≈øly Water heats, dries, is diuretic, lithontriptic, and opens Ob≈øtructions.
Pur≈ølain Water cools, moi≈øtens, and takes away Heat of Urine.
Pennyroyal Water heats, dries, is hy≈øteric, and is good to force the Cour≈øes and Secundine.
Night≈øhade Water dries, cools, and cures an Ery≈øipelas, and Cancers of the Papes.
Frog-≈øpawn Water cools and dries, and cures Inflammations and Burns, and ≈øtops the Flux of the Hemorrhoids, and cures a red Face.

div.head: The Water of unripe Wallnuts, or the Am≈øterdam Alexipharmic.
div.p: TAke of unripe Wallnuts with their outward green Shells, gathered in May, and brui≈øed, two Pound; of the Herbs, Carduus Benedictus, Balm, Rue, Scabius, Scordium, each two Ounces; Cut them, and pour upon them of Wine Vinegar as much as will ri≈øe ≈øome Fingers above the Matter. Di≈øtil it in Gla≈øs as long as any Liquor will drop. Keep it in a Gla≈øs for U≈øe.
This is much commended by Practitioners. It attenuates, incides, penetrates, clean≈øes, re≈øi≈øts Putrefaction, is good in Malignant Fevers, and the Plague. The Do≈øe is half an Ounce, or an Ounce.

div.head: The Am≈øterdam Epileptick Water.
div.p: Take of the Roots of Male Peony dryed, half a Pound, of the Roots of Angelica and Fraxinella, of the Leaves of cretic Marjoram, Rue, and Sage, each one Ounce; of the Flowers of Male Peony, Bettony, Lilly of the Vallies, Lime-tree dryed, of the Seeds of oriental Bi≈øhops-weed, Nigella, each half an Ounce; of Peony two Ounces; of woody Ca≈ø≈øia, Cloves, the le≈ø≈øer Cardamoms, Nutmeg, each two Drams; powder them gro≈øsly, and pour upon them five Quarts of French Wine, or Rheni≈øh Wine, of common Water a Quart. Dige≈øt them four and twenty Hours, then di≈øtil them in Sand, and draw off about four Quarts. Keep it in a Gla≈øs well ≈øtopt.

This is excellent for many Di≈øea≈øes. It ≈øweetens the Ma≈øs of Blood, and cau≈øes Sweat, is good for all cold Di≈øea≈øes, and for ≈øuch as proceed from an acid
Ferment. It re≈øolves, attenuates, incides, clean≈øes, is ≈øtomachic, cephalic, diuretic, good for the Apoplexy, and the Falling-≈øickne≈øs. The Do≈øe is from two Drams to ≈øix in Balm Water.

div.head: The Antinephritic Water of Am≈øterdam.
div.p: Take of Hor≈øe-radi≈øh Root, four Ounces; of Liquori≈øh, the Roots of Re≈øtharrow, Par≈øly, and Burnet, each two Ounces; of nephritic Wood and Sa≈ø≈øafras, each three Ounces; of the Leaves of Ground Ivy, Bettony, Chervil, Strawberries, each two Handfuls; of the Seeds of Fennel and Nettles, and of the Berries of Winter Cherries, each two Ounces; of Juniper Berries one Ounce; cut and beat them, and infu≈øe them in a ≈øufficient Quantity of Ground-ivy and Wine, three Days and Nights; then di≈øtil them in a Cucurbit in Balneo Mariae to Siccity.
This opens, attenuates, re≈øolves, forces Urine and Sweat, and is a Specific for the Stone in the Reins and Bladder. The Do≈øe is from half an Ounce to one Ounce.

div.head: The Pal≈øy Water.
div.p:
Take of the Roots of Sar≈øa-parilla, of the Wood of Guiacum, each one Pound and an half, of Sa≈ø≈øafras four Ounces, of the Herbs Bettony, Mountain Calaminth, Germander, Ground Pine, Hy≈øop, Marjoram, Origanum, black Horehound, Primro≈øe, Penny-royal, Ro≈øemary, Sage, wild Thym, Thym, the Flowers of Marygolds, and Staechas, each one Handful, Juniper Berries one Ounce: Cut them and beat them, and infu≈øe them in a ≈øufficient Quantity of Spirit of Wine for three Days and Nights, then di≈øtil them in Balneo Mariae; to the di≈øtilled Water add of the Roots of bitter Co≈øtus, Pyrethrum, Ginger, the Seeds of white Mu≈øtard,
Cinnamon, Storax, Calamite, Ca≈øtor, each one Dram. Dige≈øt them ≈øome Days and Nights, then filtrate them through a Linnen Cloath, and keep the Liquor for U≈øe.
It heats, dries, attenuates, opens, re≈øolves, is ≈øtomachic, cephalic, and uterine, u≈øed inwardly or outwardly.

div.head: The Hy≈øteric Water.
div.p: Take of the Roots of Briony dryed, of ripe Elder Berries, dryed by a gentle Fire, and clean≈øed from the Stalks, each two Ounces, of the Leaves of Mugwort, Dittany, of Creet, Mother-wort, Nep, Ba≈øil, Pennyroyal, Rue, Savin dryed in the Shade, each half an Ounce, the yellow Peel of Oranges, one Ounce and an half; powder them and infu≈øe them for eight Days in three Quarts of Spirit of Wine, and one Quart of common Water; di≈øtil them in Balneo Mariae, and draw off four or five Pints, wherein infu≈øe of Myrrh and Ca≈øtor, each half an Ounce, of Engli≈øh Saffron three Drams; dige≈øt them for ≈øome Days, then ≈øtrain the Tincture through a Cloath, and keep it for U≈øe.
It heats and dries powerfully, penetrates, re≈øolves, opens Ob≈øtructions, forces Urine, Sweat, the Cour≈øes, and cures a great many cold Di≈øea≈øes. The Do≈øe is from two Drams to half an Ounce.

div.head: Treacle Water.
div.p:
Take of the yellow Bark of Citrons dryed, of the Roots of Butter-bur, Liquori≈øh, Burnet, Tormentil, each two Ounces; white Dittany, Gentian, Ma≈øterwort, Periwinkle, Zedoary, the Leaves of Carduus Benedictus, Rue, Scabius, Scordium dryed, each one Ounce; the Seeds of Sorrel and Carduus Benedictus, each half an Ounce; powder them all gro≈øsly, and infu≈øe
them in ≈øix Quarts of the be≈øt Spirit of Wine, and in three Pints of common Water: Dige≈øt them twenty four Hours, then di≈øtil them in Sand or Balneo Mariae, and draw off three Parts of four. Add to the Spirit drawn off, three Drams of Engli≈øh Saffron, three Ounces of Venice Treacle, and half an Ounce of Oyl of Sulphur by the Bell. Dige≈øt them for three Days and Nights, then ≈øtrain it through a Sive, and keep it in a Gla≈øs well ≈øtopt.
It heats, dries, evacuates by Urine and Sweat, it corrects acid Ferments that are too acrid, and re≈øtores a due Texture to the Ma≈øs of Blood. The Do≈øe is from two Drams to half an Ounce.

div.head: Compound Aqua Vitae.
div.p: Take of ≈øharp Cinnamon three Ounces, of all the Sanders ≈øix Drams, of the Roots of Avens, Galingal, Ginger, and the outward Bark of Oranges and Citrons dryed, each two Drams and an half, of Nutmeg, the le≈ø≈øer Cardamoms and Mace, each three Drams; of the Seeds of Ani≈øe, cretick Daucus, ≈øweet Fennel, and Ba≈øil, each one Dram and an half; of Gillyflowers, red Ro≈øes, and the Flowers of Ro≈øemary, each two Drams; make of all a gro≈øs Powder, and pour upon it of the be≈øt Spirit of VVine ≈øix Quarts, of common VVater one Quart, dige≈øt them a Night and a Day, and then di≈øtil them in Balneo Mariae, or in Sand, and draw off two Thirds of the Liquor: In the Spirit drawn off infu≈øe of the Powder Diamargarit frigid, and Diambra, each three Drams, of Amber-grea≈øe and Musk tied up in a Rag, each ten Grains; dige≈øt them three Nights and Days; to the ≈øtraining add of Julep of Ro≈øes half a Pint, mingle them, and keep it for U≈øe.
It heats, dries, is ≈øtomachic, cardiac, cephalic, and alexipharmic: It is good for all cold Di≈øea≈øes, and for the Pal≈øy, Apoplexy, and Epilep≈øy: The Do≈øe is half an Ounce.

div.head: Tincture of Cinnamon.
div.p: Take of ≈øharp Cinnamon gro≈øly powdered, two Ounces, Spirit of VVine rectified eight Ounces; put the Cinnamon into a long Viol, and afterwards pour upon it the Spirit of VVine; lute well to the Top of the Viol another Viol, and place it upon hot Sand for eight Days, then gently pour off the Tincture and keep it for U≈øe.
It heats, dries, is ≈øtomachic, uterine, cardiac, and cephalic: The Do≈øe is from two Drams to half an Ounce.

div.head: Tincture of Guiacum.
div.p: Take of the Shavings of Guiacum ≈øix Ounces, Spirit of VVine rectified, twelve Ounces, mingle them and dige≈øt them in a long Viol with another well luted to the Mouth of it for eight Days and Nights, then decant the Tincture, and ≈øtrain it gently through a linnen Cloath, and keep it for U≈øe.
It heats, dries, is ≈øtomachic, cures Catarrhs, and is of a plea≈øant Smell and Ta≈øte: The Do≈øe is from half an Ounce to one Ounce.

div.head: Tincture of Ca≈øtor.
div.p: Take of Ca≈øtor gro≈øly powdered, half an Ounce; put it into a long Viol, and pour upon it three Ounces of rectified Spirit of VVine; dige≈øt it eight Nights and Days, pour off the Tincture, and ≈øtrain it through a linnen Cloath, and keep it for U≈øe.
It heats, dries, is hy≈øteric, good for the Falling-≈øickne≈øs and the Pal≈øy: The Do≈øe is from ≈øix Drops to twenty.

div.head: Tincture of Saffron.
div.p: Take of Engli≈øh Saffron one Ounce, put it into a log Viol, and pour upon it ≈øix Ounces of Spirit of VVine; dige≈øt it for eight Days, then pour off the Tincture and keep it for U≈øe.
It heats, dries, is ≈øudorific, anodyne, ≈øtomachic, and forces the Cour≈øes: The Do≈øe is from ≈øix Drops to ten.

div.head: Elixir Proprietatis.
div.p: Take of Myrrh, Aloes, and Saffron, each half an Ounce, of Spirit of VVine rectified, ten Ounces, of Spirit of Sulphur by the Bell, half an Ounce; extract fir≈øt with the Spirit of VVine, a Tincture from the Saffron, by dige≈øting it ≈øix or eight Days; afterwards pour this Tincture with the Spirit of Sulphur upon the Myrrh and Aloes beat ≈ømall; dige≈øt them for a Month in a long Viol well ≈øtopt, and ≈øhake the Gla≈øs now and then, decant the black Tincture gently from the Faeces, and then either fling away the Faeces, or extract another Tincture from it, with Spirit of VVine as before: After the Elixir has ≈øtood without ≈øhaking a Night, decant it again, and afterwards let it ≈øtand a Night without ≈øhaking, and ≈øo decant it again till you find no Faeces at the Bottom, which you will find in the ≈øpace of few Days: This is commonly called Elixir, or Alexiterium Proprietatis.

This Tincture is hot and dry, ≈øtomachic, anodyne, uterine, alexipharmic, it loo≈øens the Belly, two Drams of it being taken at a time, and cures Tertian Agues, and is an univer≈øal Medicine; it agrees with all Ages and both Sexes: It alters, evacuates, and ≈øtrengthens; and, according to the Opinion of an excellent Phy≈øician, every Practitioner ought to have it
in Readine≈øs: The Do≈øe is from ≈øix Drops to twelve, unle≈øs you de≈øign to purge, then you mu≈øt give two Drams in VVine or Beer.

div.head: Tincture of Opium.
div.p: Take of crude Opium ≈øliced and toa≈øted on iron Plates, one Ounce, of the Spirit of wine Vinegar, ≈øix Ounces: Mix them in a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, and dige≈øt them three Days and Nights, then ≈øtrain the black Tincture through a linnen Cloath, and keep it for U≈øe.

It is hypnotic, anodyne, narcotic, and may be u≈øed in≈øtead of Laudanum Opiatum, in Potions, and other Liquors: Being applyed outwardly to the Temples with a Rag dipt in it, it ea≈øes Pain, and promotes Sweat, it al≈øo a≈ø≈øwages Pains of the Gout: The Do≈øe is two or three Drops.

div.head: Tincture of Steel.
div.p: Take of the Filings of Steel, one Ounce, of Rheni≈øh VVine ten Ounces; infu≈øe them in a clo≈øe Gla≈øs eight Nights and Days, then decant the red VVine and keep it for U≈øe.

It opens, clean≈øes, corrects a muriatick Salt, and the acid, when it is too acrid. It opens Ob≈øtructions, loo≈øens the Belly, and is good for a Cachexy: The Do≈øe is half an Ounce two or three times a Day. The ≈øame way is prepared Tincture of Strawberries, infu≈øed in rectified Spirit of VVine, new Strawberries being added till the Tincture is made. This Tincture is lithontriptic. The Tincture of Lacca is made the ≈øame way, which is hy≈øteric, anti≈øcorbutic, and hypochondriack; and ≈øo is the Tincture of Scordium made, which is alexipharmic.

div.head: Spirit of Vinegar.
div.p: Take of the ≈øharpe≈øt VVine Vinegar, four≈øcore Ounces; di≈øtil it in a low Gla≈øs Cucurbit, in Balneo Mariae, till that which remains in the Cucurbit is of a pitchy Con≈øi≈øtence. All the Liquour that comes forth is called di≈øtilled Vinegar, or Spirit of Vinegar.

It cools, dries, binds, re≈øtrains luxuriant Sulphur; but joined with Alcalies, it opens, clean≈øes, and forces Urine, and moves the Belly, as may be ≈øeen, when it is topulated with Crabs-eyes, Coral, or Steel. It al≈øo provokes Sweat, by rea≈øon of the Volatility, and different Parts whereof it con≈øi≈øts; namely, the ≈øubtle volatile Alcaly, which coagulates upon Lead, and ta≈øtes as ≈øweet as Sugar, but turns to an in≈øipid Fat upon Salt of Tartar, or fixed Nitre: The Do≈øe is from half an Ounce to an Ounce.

div.head: Ro≈øe Vinegar.
div.p: Take of red Ro≈øes, one Pound, of wine Vinegar, ≈øix Quarts; put them into a large Gla≈øs with a narrow Neck, ≈øtop it well, and tie it over with a Leather, and expo≈øe it to the Heat of the Sun for forty Days in the Summer; then pre≈øs out the Vinegar through a Cloath, and keep it for U≈øe; or if you plea≈øe, you may put in new Ro≈øes, and place it in the Sun again, as before.

It cools powerfully, dries and binds. It is cephalic and alexipharmic: The Do≈øe is half an Ounce. The ≈øame way are prepared the following Vinegars; Vinegar of Marygolds, which is cardiac and cephalic; Vinegar of Ro≈øemary Flowers, which is cephalic and cardiac; Vinegar of Lavender Flowers, which is cephalic; Vinegar of Elder Flowers, which is ≈øudorific and alexipharmic.

div.head: Treacle Vinegar.
div.p: Take of the Species of the Treacle VVater above de≈øcribed, except the Oyl of Sulphur by the Bell, the Saffron and the Treacle: Cut them, or beat them gro≈øly, and pour upon them fifteen Pints of VVine Vinegar; ≈øet them in the Sun for forty Days, or dige≈øt them eight Days in Balneo Mariae; then pre≈øs out the Vinegar through a Cloath, and keep it for U≈øe.

It is an excellent Pre≈øervative again≈øt the Plague: I took a Spoonful of this, ≈øays Marggrave, Morning, Noon, and Night, and nothing el≈øe, when the Plague raged violently at Leyden, in the Year 1664, and vi≈øited the People infected with the Plague every Day, and was pre≈øerved ≈øafe and ≈øound, when fifteen Phy≈øicians dyed of the Plague that Summer.

div.head: Vinegar of Squills.
div.p: Take of the Roots of Squills ≈øliced and hanged up by a Thred thru≈øt through them, forty Days, and dryed in the open Air, where the Sun or Rain does not come, one Pound; of VVine Vinegar four Quarts; put them into the Sun, as before, then ≈øtrain it. It attenuates, incides, and is thoracic: The Do≈øe is half an Ounce.

div.head: Praevotius his purging Vinegar.
div.p: Take of crude Tartar one Dram, or in≈øtead of it, of Cream of Tartar, half an Ounce, of the Leaves of Sena clean≈øed, three Drams, of Cinnamon and the Seeds of Ani≈øe, each half a Dram, of the ≈øharpe≈øt VVine Vinegar one Pint; infu≈øe them twenty four Hours, then ≈øtrain out the Vinegar, and keep it for U≈øe. It loo≈øens the Belly, attenuates, and incides, and is u≈øed in Sauces.

div.head: Simple Wormwood Wine.
div.p: Take of VVormwood dryed one Handful, of VVine fifty Quarts; put it into a Ve≈ø≈øel well ≈øtopt, and leave it in Infu≈øion till all the VVine is drunk. It attenuates, incides, is ≈øtomachic, and quickens the Appetite. The ≈øame way is prepar'd the le≈ø≈øer Centaury VVine, which is hepatic and a Febrifuge. And ≈øo is made the VVine of black Cherries, which is cardiac, and good for malignant Fevers. And ≈øo is made Ro≈ømary Flower Wine, which is cephalic and cardiac. So is made Eyebright Wine which is good for the Head and Eyes.

div.head: The common Decoction for a Gli≈øter.
div.p: Take of the Leaves of Mallows, Pellitory, Beet, Violets, Mercury, the Flowers of Camomile, each one Handful, the Seeds of Ani≈øe and ≈øweet Fennel, each two Drams; boyl them in a ≈øufficient Quantity of Water to a Pint. It mollifies the Faeces contained in the great Guts, and expels Wind, and is anodyne.

div.head: A ≈øharp Gli≈øter.
div.p: Take of the le≈ø≈øer Centaury, Hy≈ø≈øop, and Rue, each one Handful and an half, of the Seeds of Carawys, Fennel, and Cummin, each three Drams, of Agaric tyed up in a Rag, two Drams, of the Pulp of Coloquintida, one Dram: Boyl them in Fountain VVater to a Pint; to the ≈øtrained Liquor add of the Electuary of Hiera Picra one Ounce, mingle them, make a Gli≈øter. It powerfully attenuates, incides, cau≈øes a Revul≈øion, is good in ≈øleepy Di≈øea≈øes, and for other Di≈øea≈øes of the upper Parts.

div.head: The Carminative Decoction for a Gli≈øter.
div.p:
Take of the Seeds of Ani≈øe, Fennel, and Cummin, each half an Ounce, of Lawrel Berries brui≈øed, three
Drams, of the Flowers of Camomile and Dill, each half an Handful; boyl them in common VVater till half is con≈øumed. It incides, attenuates, and con≈øumes Wind ≈øticking in the Guts.

div.head: The Decoction of Brim≈øtone.
div.p: Take of crude Sulphur powdered, half a Pound, of Fountain Water five Quarts; boyl it till half is con≈øumed; keep the ≈øtrained Liquor for U≈øe. Being taken inwardly, it cools the Blood in Fevers; outwardly applyed, it cures the Itch, and Inflammations, and Redne≈øs in the Face.

div.head: Syrup of Vinegar.
div.p: Take of clarified Sugar, boyled to the Con≈øi≈øtence of Tablets, four Pound; pour upon it in an carthen Pot a ≈øufficient Quantity of White-wine vinegar, ≈øo as to make a Syrup without boyling, only ≈øtir it about till it comes to a Syrup. It cools, attenuates, incides, and quenches Thir≈øt.

div.head: Syrup of the Juice of Sorrel.
div.p: Take of clarified Sugar, boyled to the Con≈øi≈øtence of Tablets, four Pound; pour upon it in an earthen Ve≈ø≈øel, the Juice of Sorrel clarified by ≈øettling, and ≈øtrained, a ≈øufficient Quantity, ≈øo as that a Syrup may be made without boyling, only ≈øtir it about. It cools, thickens, is good for malignant Fevers, and the Plague.

div.head: Syrup of unripe Grapes.
div.p:
Take of clarified Sugar, boyled to the Con≈øi≈øtence of Tablets, four Pound; pour upon it in an earthen Pot, a ≈øufficient Quantity of the Juice of unripe Grapes, ≈øtir it
about, and make a Syrup without boyling. It cools, binds, ≈øtops vomiting and a Loo≈øne≈øs, and takes off Thir≈øt and Heat. The ≈øame way is made Syrup of Quinces, which binds and ≈øtrengthens the Stomach, and ≈øtops vomiting and a Loo≈øne≈øs, ≈øpitting of Blood, a Flux of the Hemorrhoids and Cour≈øes, the Bloodyflux, and the Coeliac Di≈øea≈øe. The ≈øame way is made Syrup of Pomgranates, which cools, moi≈øtens, re≈øi≈øts Putrefaction, and ≈øtops vomiting and Loo≈øne≈øs, and is cardiac. The ≈øame way is made Syrup of Lemons, which cools, incides, comforts the Heart, cures pe≈øtilential and continual Fevers, and the Heart-burning.

div.head: Syrup of Scurvygra≈øs.
div.p: Take of clarified Sugar, boyled to the Con≈øi≈øtence of Tablets, four Pound, of Scurvygra≈øs Water, a ≈øufficient Quantity, to make a Syrup without boyling. It heats, drys, qualifies an Acid, and is anti≈øcorbutic.

div.head: Julep of Ro≈øes.
div.p: Take of clarified Sugar, boyled to the Con≈øi≈øtence of Tablets, two Pound; pour upon it a ≈øufficient Quantity of Ro≈øe-water, to make a thin Syrup without boyling. It cools, dries, is cardiac, thoracic, and ≈øtomachic.

div.head: Syrup of Violets.
div.p: Take of Sugar, boyled to the Con≈øi≈øtence of Tablets, two Pound; pour upon it of the Infu≈øion of the fre≈øh Flowers of Violets, a ≈øufficient Quantity; make a Syrup without boyling. It cools moi≈øtens, corrects the Acrimony of Bile, and is thoracic and cardiac.

div.head: Compound Syrup of Wormwood.
div.p: Take of Roman Wormwood dryed, ≈øix Ounces, of red Ro≈øes two Ounces, of Indian Spiknard, three Drams; brui≈øe them, and infu≈øe them twenty four Hours in old odoriferous White-wine, and clarified Juice of Quinces, each three Pints, boyl them over a gentle Fire till half is con≈øumed, then ≈øtrain them; to the ≈øtrained Liquor clarified, add of clarified Honey, boyled to a Con≈øi≈øtence, and white Sugar, each one Pound; afterwards boyl them to the Con≈øi≈øtence of a Syrup. It heats moderately, binds, expels Wind, is ≈øtomachic, and forces Urine.

div.head: Fernelius's Syrup of Mar≈øh-mallows.
div.p: Take of the Roots of Mar≈øh-mallows two Ounces, red Vetches one Ounce, of the Roots of A≈øparagus, Liquori≈øh ra≈øped, Gra≈øs, Rai≈øins of the Sun ≈øtoned, each half an Ounce, of the Tops of Mar≈øh-mallows, of the Herbs Mallows, both the Maiden-hairs, Pellitory of the Wall, Burnet, and Plantain, each one Handful, of the four greater and le≈ø≈øer cold Seeds brui≈øed each three Drams; boyl them in a ≈øufficient Quantity of Water to the Con≈øumption of the third Part, ≈øtrain the Liquor out, and boyl it to a Syrup with four Pound of white Sugar. It is temperate, loo≈øens, mollifies, clean≈øes the Reins from Filth and Gravel, and takes off the Heat of Urine.

div.head: Fernelius's Syrup of Mugwort.
div.p:
Take of the Roots of Fennel, Elicampane, Orris, Lovage, Peony, and Madder, each half an Ounce, of the Herbs Mugwort two Handfuls, Bettony, Calaminth, Germander, Ground-pine, Hy≈øop, St. John's-wort,
Featherfew, Balm, Nep, Origanum, black Horehound, Pennyroyal, Savin, each one Handful, the Seeds of Ani≈øe, Daucus, Fennel, Nigella, Ba≈øl, Par≈øly, Rue, each three Drams: Beat them and cut them, and infu≈øe them twenty four Hours in a ≈øufficient Quantity of ≈ømall Hydromel; boyl them according to Art, and with five Pound of Sugar, boyl it to a Syrup, aromatize it with an Ounce of Cinnamon, and three Drams of Spiknard. It heats, opens, incides, moves the Cour≈øes, and is good for hy≈øteric Di≈øea≈øes.

div.head: Simple Syrup of the Juice of Bettony.
div.p: Take of the Juice of Bettony clarified three Pints, of white Sugar one Pound and an half; boyl them to the Con≈øi≈øtence of a Syrup. It heats, opens, clean≈øes, is cephalic and uterine, and gently moves the Cour≈øes. The ≈øame way is prepared the Syrup of Borrage, which moi≈øtens, and is good for Melancholy, Fainting, and Palpitation of the Heart. So is made Syrup of Carduus Benedictus, which heats, moves Sweat, is alexipharmic, good in a Pleuri≈øie, and to kill Worms. Simple Syrup of Succory is al≈øo made in the ≈øame way. It cools, opens, and is hepatic. So is al≈øo made Syrup of Scabius, which heats, clean≈øes Impo≈øthumes, is thoracic, and is good in a Pleuri≈øie, and for malignant Fevers.

div.head: Syrup of the Oak of Jeru≈øalem.
div.p: Take of the Herb called Oak of Jeru≈øalem, three Handfuls, of Hedg Mu≈øtard, Nettles, each two Handfuls, of red Colwort and Coltsfoot, each one Handful and an half: Boyl them in a ≈øufficient Quantity of Water; to the ≈øtrained Liquor add two Pound and an half of white Sugar; clarifie and boyl it to a Syrup. It heats, clean≈øes, and is thoracic.

div.head: Simple Bizantine Syrup.
div.p: Take of the Juice of Smallage and Garden Succory, each a Quart, of Buglo≈øs and Hops, each a Pint; boyl them till they are clear, and afterwards boyl them to a Syrup with three Pound of Sugar. It is temperate, it opens, incides, is good for the Jaundice, and to force the Cour≈øes.

div.head: Simple Syrup of Maiden-hair.
div.p: Take of fre≈øh Maiden-hair a little cut, five Ounces, of the Roots of Liquori≈øh ra≈øped two Ounces; infu≈øe them twenty four Hours in a ≈øufficient Quantity of hot Water, then boyl them according to Art; to five Pints of the clarified Liquor ≈øtrained, add four Pound of Sugar; boyl it to a Syrup. It is temperate, incides, attenuates, and opens.

div.head: Syrup of Cloves.
div.p: Take of the Water of aromatic Cloves, white like Milk, four Ounces; di≈ø≈øolve in it as much Sugar as will make it a Syrup without boyling. It heats, dries, attenuates, is cardiac, ≈øtomachic, uterine, and cephalic.

div.head: Syrup of Cinnamon.
div.p: Take of the be≈øt Cinnamon Water white like Milk a ≈øufficient Quantity; make a Syrup of it with a ≈øufficient Quantity of Sugar without Fire. It heats, dries, is cardiac, uterine, and cephalic.

div.head: Syrup of Coral.
div.p:
Take of red Coral powdered half an Ounce, of ≈øweet Spirit of Niter three Ounces; mingle them in a
long Viol, and dige≈øt them twenty four Hours in a hot Place, then filtrate through Paper, and make a Syrup of the ≈øtrained Liquor with a ≈øufficient Quantity of Sugar without Fire. It cools, dries, clean≈øes, opens, forces Urine, is good for hypochondriac Di≈øea≈øes, and ≈øtops violent Fluxes of the Belly.

div.head: Syrup of Succory with Rhubarb.
div.p: Take of the Roots of Smallage, A≈øparagus, Fennel, all fre≈øh, each two Ounces, of the Herbs Succory, Garden Endive, Dandelyon, each two Handfuls, of Fumitory, Liver-wort, Lettice, Hops, Sowthi≈øtle, each one Handful, Maiden-hair, old Barly, each one Ounce and an half, Winter Cherries, Liquori≈øh ra≈øped, each ≈øix Drams; boyl them in a ≈øufficientt Quantity of Water to the Con≈øumption of a third Part; then ≈øtrain it, and add four Pound of white Sugar, when it is clarified boyl it to a Syrup: In the mean while infu≈øe in a ≈øufficient Quantity of the Decoction above pre≈øcribed, of choice Rhubarb four Ounces, of Indian Spiknard two Drams; after a gentle boyling, ≈øtrain out the Liquor, and mingle it with the Syrup towards the End of boyling. It cools, opens, purges Choler, and agrees with every Age and both Sexes: The Do≈øe is one Ounce and an half, or more.

div.head: Syrup called Diacnicu.
div.p:
Take of the Roots of Angelica, Smallage, A≈øparagus, and Fennel, all fre≈øh, of Polypody of the Oak, each one Ounce and an Half, of the bark of Tamarisk, half an Ounce, of the Herbs Maiden-hair, Buglo≈øs, Germander, Ground-pine, Hy≈ø≈øop, Origanum, Scolopendrium, Thym, each half an Handful, Dodder, Winter Cherries, each half an Ounce, Rai≈øins of the Sun clean≈øed from the Stones two Ounces, of the Seeds
of Ba≈øtard Saffron brui≈øed four Ounces and an half, of the Seeds of Ani≈øe, Bi≈øhops-weed, Daucus, and Fennel, each one Ounce; boyl them in a ≈øufficient Quantity of Water to the Con≈øumption of a third Part; to the ≈øtrained Liquor add of white Sugar clarified two Pound; boyl it to the Con≈øi≈øtence of a Syrup; in the mean while take of the Leaves of Sena clean≈øed four Ounces, of choice Rhubarb, one Ounce and an half, of Agaric trochi≈øcated half an Ounce, of Ginger one Dram; infu≈øe them hot for a Night in a ≈øufficient Quantity of the Decoction pre≈øcribed; the next Day boyl them gently, afterwards ≈øtrain the Liquor out, and mix it with the Syrup towards the End of boyling. It purges gently Flegm and watery Humours by Stool, and it incides and clean≈øes; the Do≈øe is two Ounces.

div.head: Syrup of Fumitory.
div.p: Take of the Roots of Polypody of the Oak two Ounces, of the Herbs Roman Wormwood, Dodder, Endive, Scolopendrium, Hops, each one Handful, Dodder of Thym one Ounce and an half; boyl them in a ≈øufficient Quantity of Water till half is con≈øumed; to the ≈øtrained Liquor add of the Juice of Fumitory one Pint and an half, of the Juice of Borrage and Buglo≈øs, each half a Pint, of white Sugar four Pound; boyl them to a Syrup. It purges gently by Stool, and opens, and is good for Di≈øea≈øes of the Skin, and for Di≈øea≈øes proceeding from ≈øalt Humours.

div.head: Syrup of Liquori≈øh.
div.p:
Take of Liquori≈øh ra≈øped two Ounces, of the Herbs Coltsfoot four Handfuls, Maiden hair one Ounce, Hy≈ø≈øop half an Ounce; infu≈øe them twenty four Hours in a ≈øufficient quantity of Water, then boyl them to the Con≈øumption of half; to the ≈øtrained Liquor add of
the be≈øt Honey clarified, and of white Sugar, each one Pound; boyl them to a Syrup. It heats, moi≈øtens, incides, clean≈øes, is thoracic, helps Expectoration, and thickens the Humours flowing upon the Lungs.

div.head: Syrup of Hy≈ø≈øop.
div.p: Take of the Herbs Hy≈ø≈øop dried one Ounce and an half, of Maiden-hair ≈øix Drams, of the Roots of Smallage, Fennel, and Par≈øly, all fre≈øh, of Liquori≈øh ra≈øped, each ten Drams, of Jujubes and Sebe≈øtines, each thirty, of fat Figs, and fat Dates, each ten, of Rai≈øins of the Sun ≈øtoned one Ounce and an half, of clean≈øed Barly half an Ounce, of the Seeds of Quinces and Mallow each three Drams; boyl them in a ≈øufficient quantity of Water; to the ≈øtrained Liquor add of the white≈øt Sugar three Pound; clarifie it, and boyl it to a Syrup. It heats, attenuates, incides, clean≈øes the Reins and Bladder, is thoracic, good for an A≈øthma, a Cough, and to provoke the Cour≈øes.

div.head: Syrup of Jujubes.
div.p: Take of Jujubes, Number ≈øixty, of Barly clean≈øed, of Liquori≈øh ra≈øped, and of Maiden-hair, each one Ounce, of the Flowers of Violets, and of the Seeds of Mallows, each five Drams, of the Seeds of Quinces, Lettice, Melons, and white Poppies, each three Drams; boyl them in a ≈øufficient Quantity of Water to the Con≈øumption of half; to the ≈øtrained Liquor add two Pound of clarified Sugar; boyl it to a Syrup. It cools, thickens thin Humours, takes off Hoar≈øne≈øs and a Cough, cures a Pleuri≈øy, and helps Expectoration.

div.head: Syrup of Mint.
div.p:
Take of the Juice of Mint one Pint, of the Juices of Quinces, and of ≈øharp Pomgranats clarified, and of the
Infu≈øion of red Ro≈øes, each half a Pint, of white Sugar and clarified Honey, each one Pound and an half; boyl them to a Syrup according to Art, and at the End of boyling aromatize it with half an Ounce of the Powder Diarrhodon Abbatis tyed up in a Rag. It is temperate, a≈øtringent, ≈øtomachie, ≈øtops vomiting, the Hickops, and a Loo≈øne≈øs.

div.head: Syrup of Myrtles.
div.p: Take of Myrtle Berries two Ounces and an half, of unripe Medlars half a Pound, of the Seeds of Berberries, Sumach, Balau≈øtins, red Ro≈øes, white and red Sanders, each one Ounce and an half; brui≈øe and boyl them in a ≈øufficient Quantity of Water, to the Con≈øumption of a third Part; to the ≈øtrained Liquor add five Pound of clarified Sugar, boyl them again to a thicker Con≈øi≈øtence; toward the End add of the Juices of Quinces, and of acid Pomgranates clarified, each a Quart; make a Syrup according to Art. It cools, dries, is a≈øtringent and thoracic, it ≈øtops a Loo≈øne≈øs, a Flux of Blood, and ≈øtrengthens the Stomach.

div.head: Simple Syrup of Poppies.
div.p: Take of the Heads of white Poppies ripe and dried ten Ounces, boyl them in a ≈øufficient Quantity of Water till half is con≈øumed; add to the ≈øtrained Liquor two Pounds and an half of white Sugar, and boyl it to a Syrup. It cools, moi≈øtens, quali≈øies Choler, extingui≈øhes Thir≈øt, is thoracic and hypnotic. The ≈øame way is prepared the ≈øimple Syrup of Citron Bark, which heats, dries, is ≈øtomachic, cardiac, cephalic, and alexipharmic.

div.head: Syrup of red Poppies.
div.p:
Take of the fre≈øh Flowers of red Poppies three Pound, boyl them according to Art in a ≈øufficient Quantity of
Water; to the Liquor ≈øtrongly pre≈ø≈øed out add three Pound of white Sugar clarified, and boyl up your Syrup. It cools, is a≈øtringent and thickening, and is proper for burning Fevers, a Pleuri≈øy and Peripneumonia; it is al≈øo pectoral and hypnotic: The Do≈øe is one Ounce and an half.

div.head: Syrup of Pur≈ølain.
div.p: Take of the Juice of Pur≈ølain one Pint, of the Juices of Dai≈øies, Strawberries, Lettice, Plantain, the middle Hou≈øeleek, and Violets, all clarified, each two Ounces, of the Seeds of Quinces two Drams, of white Sugar two Pound; boyl them to a Syrup. It powerfully cools, ≈øoftens, thickens, and kills Worms.

div.head: Syrup of the five opening Roots.
div.p: Take of the Roots of Smallage, A≈øparagus, Fennel, Par≈øly, Kneeholm, all fre≈øh, each four Ounces; boyl them in a ≈øufficient Quantity of Water, to the ≈øtrained Liquor add four Pound of white Sugar, clarifie it and boyl it to a Syrup. It heats, dries, attenuates, cuts thick Humours, forces Urine, moves the Cour≈øes, expels Gravel, and is good for the Jaundice.

div.head: Syrup of dried Ro≈øes.
div.p: Take of red Ro≈øes dried one Pound, infu≈øe them twenty four Hours in a ≈øufficient quantity of warm Water; to the ≈øtrained Liquor add four Pound of white Sugar, and boyl it to a Syrup. It binds, ≈øtops Fluxes of the Belly and Womb, and vomiting, and clean≈øes Ulcers, and heals them.

div.head: Simple Syrup of Ro≈øes ≈øolutive.
div.p:
Take of the Infu≈øion of pale Ro≈øes, the fre≈øh Ro≈øes being put into it nine times, five Pints, of clarified Sugar
four Pound; boyl it to a Syrup. It purges Choler and watery Humours by Stool; the highe≈øt Do≈øe is three Ounces. Syrup of Gilly≈ølowers is made the ≈øame way. It heats, dries, is cardiac and alexipharmic.

div.head: Syrup of Ro≈øes ≈øolutive with Sena.
div.p: Take of the Leaves of Sena clean≈øed eight Ounces, of the Seeds of Ani≈øe and ≈øweet Fennel, each half an Ounce; infu≈øe them two Days in a ≈øufficient quantity of the Infu≈øion of pale Ro≈øes above de≈øcribed; to the ≈øtrained Liquor add two Pounds of white Sugar, and boyl it to a Syrup. It purges Choler, Melancholy, and ≈øerous Humours: The Do≈øe is two Ounces.

div.head: Syrup of Staechas.
div.p: Take of the Flowers of Staechas four Ounces, of the Herbs Bettony, Calaminth, Origanum, each one Ounce and an half, of Sage, and the Flowers of Ro≈ømary, each half an Ounce, of the Seeds of Fennel, Peony, and Rue, each three Drams; boyl them in a ≈øufficient quantity of Water till half is con≈øumed; to the ≈øtrained Liquor add of Sugar and the be≈øt Honey, each two Pound, clarifie the Liquor, and boyl it to a Syrup. It heats, attenuates, is cephalic, good for the Falling-≈øickne≈øs, Convul≈øions, trembling of the Members, and all cold Di≈øea≈øes.

div.head: The Syrup of Comfry of Fernelius.
div.p:
Take of the Roots and Tops of the greater Comfry, of all the Herb Dai≈øy, each three Parts, of the Herb Bettony, Burnet, Plantain, Knotgra≈øs, Scabius, Coltsfoot, and the Flowers of red Ro≈øes, each two Parts; brui≈øe them when they are green, and pre≈øs out the Juice, boyl it, and take off the Scum; to three Pints of it add two Pounds and an half of white Sugar, boyl
it to a Syrup. It is temperate, clean≈øes gently, is vulnerary, and good for Con≈øumptions.

div.head: Compound Syrup of Violets.
div.p: Take of the green Leaves of Violets five Handfuls, of the Seeds of Quinces and Mallows, each ≈øeven Drams, of Jujubes and Sebe≈øtins, each Number twenty; boyl them in a ≈øufficient quantity of Barly Water; to the ≈øtrained Liquor add one Pound and an half of white Sugar; boyl it to a Syrup. It cools, moi≈øtens, mollifies, is good for a Pleuri≈øy, a Cough, Heat of Urine, and nephritic Pains.

div.head: Honey of Mercury.
div.p: TAke of the Juice of Mercury clarified three Pints, of the be≈øt Honey clarified four Pound; boyl them over a gentle Fire to the Con≈øi≈øtence of a Syrup. It loo≈øens, clean≈øes, and is only u≈øed in Gli≈øters.

div.head: Honey of Ro≈ømary.
div.p: Take of the Tops of Ro≈ømary with the Flowers dried in the Shade one Pound, infu≈øe them a little in a ≈øufficient quantity of Water, then with three Pound of the be≈øt Honey clarified, boyl them over a gentle Fire, and while they are hot ≈øtrain them through a Cloath. It heats, dries, expels Wind, prepares Flegm, and is good for the Brain and Nerves. It is u≈øed in ≈øharp Gli≈øters. The ≈øame way is made Honey of Centaury, which clean≈øes and purges Choler. The ≈øame way is al≈øo made the ≈øimple Honey of Ro≈øes, which clean≈øes, ≈øtrengthens the Stomach, and ≈øtops hot Fluxions.

div.head: Solutive Honey of Ro≈øes.
div.p: Take of the Infu≈øion of pale Ro≈øes, fre≈øh Ro≈øes being put into it nine times, three Pints, of clarified Honey four Pound; boyl them to the Con≈øi≈øtence of a Syrup. It purges Choler and Serum: The Do≈øe is three Ounces.

div.head: Simple Oxymel.
div.p: Take of clarified Honey what quantity you plea≈øe, di≈ø≈øolve it over hot A≈øhes in an Earthen Pot, and add a ≈øufficient quantity of White-wine Vinegar; bring it to the Con≈øi≈øtence of a Syrup without boyling. It attenuates, cuts gro≈øs Humours, opens Ob≈øtructions, clean≈øes, expectorates, renders Re≈øpiration ea≈øie, and is in a manner temperate.

div.head: Oxymel of Squills.
div.p: Take the be≈øt Honey clarified, what Quantity you plea≈øe, di≈ø≈øolve it as was ≈øaid before, and add to it a ≈øufficient quantity of Squill Vinegar, and bring it to the Con≈øi≈øtence of a Syrup without boyling. It powerfully cuts gro≈øs Humours, and is good for the Falling-Sickne≈øs, Giddine≈øs, and an Hemicrania.

div.head: Diamoron of Nicholaus.
div.p: Take of the Juice of unripe Mulberries and Brambleberries, each one Pint and an half, of the be≈øt Honey clarified one Pound and an half, boyl them according to Art to a thick Syrup. It cools, repels, is a≈øtringent, good for Inflammations of the Throat and Almonds, the Quin≈øey, and Ulcers of the Mouth.

div.head: Rob of Acacia.
div.p: Take of the unripe Fruit of Bullace Tree, a ≈øufficient quantity, boyl them till they are ≈øoft, and pulp them through a Sive; to one Pound of Pulp add two Pound of fine Sugar, and boyl them to the Con≈øi≈øtence of a Rob. It cools, binds, and is good for the Bloody-flux and a Loo≈øen≈øs.

div.head: Rob of Berberries.
div.p: Take of the Juice of Berberries a quart, of white Sugar one Pound; boyl them to the Con≈øi≈øtence of a Rob. It cools, binds, qualifies Choler, is good for the Cholera Morbus, the Bloody-Flux, and a Loo≈øne≈øs.

div.head: Sapa, or ≈øimple Rob. It is called by the Greeks, Siraeum.
div.p: Take of Wine ju≈øt pre≈ø≈øed out of white generous ripe Grapes ≈øix quarts, boyl it over an open Fire to the Con≈øumption of two Thirds, namely, that two quarts may remain, of the Con≈øi≈øtence of Honey, then keep it for U≈øe. It binds, clean≈øes, dige≈øts, nouri≈øhes, is good for a Cough, and Di≈øea≈øes of the Mouth. Rob of acid Cherries is made the ≈øame way of the Juice pre≈ø≈øed out and thickened, namely, the Cherries are boyled by them≈øelves, and pulped through a Sive, and with, or without Sugar, are brought to a Thickne≈øs. It cools, dries, is cardiac, and alexipharmic.

The Rob of Dwarf Elder and Elder, purge Watry Humours, force Sweat, and is good for hydropick Per≈øons. The Rob of Quinces is a≈øtringent, ≈øtrengthens the Stomach, is good for the Cholera Morbus, and a Loo≈øne≈øs. Rob of the Juice of Ra≈øpherries cools and binds.

div.head: Of things candied.
div.p: THE way of candying is not always the ≈øame; for Roots, Barks, Stalks, hard Fruits mu≈øt be fir≈øt boyled to a Softne≈øs, and ≈øome mu≈øt be often infu≈øed for ≈øome Days, and afterwards boyled, and ≈øo candied with Water and Sugar, clarified with the White of an Egg, and boyled to the Con≈øi≈øtence of a Syrup; but Flowers and ≈øoft Fruits with clarified Sugar boyled with Water almo≈øt to the Con≈øi≈øtence of a Syrup; afterwards the Syrup being removed about half an Hour from the Fire, the Flowers and Fruits are put in, and afterwards it is boyled to the full Con≈øi≈øtence of a Syrup.

The candied Roots of Acorus heat, dry, and are ≈øtomachic. The candied Roots of Succory, cool, dry, and qualify Choler. The candied Roots of Elecampane, heat, dry, are thoracic, ≈øtomachic, and alexipharmic. Eryngo Roots candied, open, ≈øtimulate Venery, and provoke Urine, and purge the Reins and Bladder. The Roots of Satyrion candied, heat, moi≈øten, and provoke Venery. The Roots of Scorzonera candied, heat, and are alexipharmic, are good for Melancholy, the Falling-≈øickne≈øs, and Mother-fits The Roots of Comfry candied, ≈øtop bleeding, and heal Wounds. Ginger candied, heats, dries, is ≈øtomachic, and thoracic. The candied Orange Peel heats and dries, expels Wind, and is good for the Plague. The candied Bark of Citron is good for the ≈øame. Stalks of Lettice cool, moi≈øten, and quench Thir≈øt. Orange Flowers candied, and Citron Flowers candied, heat, dry, attenuate, are cardiac, cephalic, diaphoretic, and alexipharmic. The Fruit of the Berberry Tree cools and moi≈øtens; ≈øweet Cherries candied moi≈øten, are cephalic, and re≈øi≈øt Malignity. Myrobalans candied are ≈øtomachic, they qualifie Choler, Flegm, and Melancholy. Walnuts candied are ≈øtomachic,
force the Cour≈øes, expel Wind, and are good for Cholic Pains. Nutmegs candied, heat, dry, ≈øtop vomiting, and are ≈øtomachic. Currants candied, cool and moi≈øten. Quinces candied, cool, dry, are a≈øtringent and ≈øtomachic.

div.head: Purging Rai≈øins.
div.p: Take of the Leaves of Sena clean≈øed eight Ounces, of the Seeds of ≈øweet Fennel one Ounce; infu≈øe them a whole Night in a ≈øufficient Quantity of the Infu≈øion of pale Ro≈øes, fre≈øh Ro≈øes being put in nine times, in the Morning boyl them gently; to one Pint and an half of the ≈øtrained Liquor, add one Pound and an half of white Sugar clarified, Corinthian Rai≈øins clean≈øed one Pound; boyl them to a thick Syrup. They purge gently by Stool, and are u≈øed for tender People and Children. The Do≈øe is three Ounces.

div.head: Of Con≈øerves.
div.p:
COn≈øerves of the Flowers of Bettony heats, dries, is cephalic and ≈øtomachic. Con≈øerve of Borrage cures Melancholy and is Cardiac. Con≈øerve of Marygolds heats, dries, is cardiac, alexipharmic, and moves the Cour≈øes. Con≈øerve of Succory cools, dries, attenuates, and is hepatic. Con≈øerve of Eye-bright heats, dries, is cephalic, and good for the Eyes. Con≈øerve of Mallows is good for the Stone and Brea≈øt. Con≈øerve of Water Lillies cools, moi≈øtens, and di≈øpo≈øes to Sleep. Con≈øerve of Peony heats, dries, is cephalic, and good for the Falling-≈øickne≈øs. Con≈øerve of pale Ro≈øes purges Choler; the Do≈øe is five Ounces. Con≈øerve of red Ro≈øes dries, is a≈øtringent, cephalic, and cardiac. Con≈øerve of Ro≈øemary Flowers heats, dries, is cephalic and cardiac. Con≈øerve of Sage heats, dries, is cephalic and uterine. Con≈øerve of Comfry heats, dries, is thoracic and vulnerary. Con≈øerve
of Violets cools, moi≈øtens, is cardiac and thoracie. All the Con≈øerves above mentioned, mu≈øt be made of the Flowers of the Herbs. Con≈øerve of the Herb Wormwood heats, dries, attenuates, opens, is hepatic, ≈øtomachic, and ≈øplenetic. Con≈øerve of Fumitory is hot and dry, it opens Ob≈øtructions. Con≈øerve of Balm is hot, dry, cardiac, cephalic, and ≈øtomachic. Con≈øerve of Mint heats, dries, is a≈øtringent, cephalic, ≈øtomachic. Con≈øerve of Wood Sorrel cools, dries, is a≈øtringent, ≈øtomachic, and cephalic. Note, that tho≈øe things that are dry mu≈øt have three Pound of Sugar to every Pound of the Herb or Flower, and tho≈øe that are moi≈øt mu≈øt have two Pound of Sugar to every Pound of the Herb or Flower.

div.head: Pearled Sugar.
div.p: Take of the white≈øt Sugar one Pound, of the Water of pale Ro≈øes a ≈øufficient quantity; boyl it to the Con≈øi≈øtence of Tablets: Towards the End of boyling, mingle with it of prepared Pearl half an Ounce; form it into Tablets upon a Marble Stone. It cools, is a≈øtringent, cardiac, and cephalic.

div.head: Sugar of Mar≈øh-mallows.
div.p: Take of the Pulp of the Root of Mar≈øh-mallows three Pound, of the white≈øt Sugar ≈øinely powdered one Pound, with a ≈øufficient quantity of Ro≈øewater; make Tablets according to Art. It heats, moi≈øtens, and is thoracic.

div.head: Benedictum Laxativum.
div.p:
TAke of the Roots of Gummy Turbith, and of Spurge prepared, each ten Drams; of Hermodactiles, Scammony prepared, Flowers of red Ro≈øes,
each five Drams; of the Roots of Acorus, Galingal, Indian Spike, Ginger, Saffron, Mace, Cloves, long Pepper, the Seeds of Smallage, A≈øparagus, the le≈ø≈øer Cardamoms, Caraways, Fennel, Milium Solis, Kneeholm, Sal Gemmae, each one Dram; with thrice the quantity of the be≈øt Honey clarified; make an Electuary according to Art. It incides, attenuates, opens, purges Flegm, Choler, and Serum. The Do≈øe is from half an Ounce to ≈øix Drams.

div.head: Confectio Hamech.
div.p: Take of the Leaves of Sena clean≈øed, of the Roots of Polypody of the Oak, of choice Rhubarb, of white Agarick, of the Pulp of Coloquintida tyed up in a Rag, of the Flowers of Violets, of the Herbs Dodder of Thym, each two Ounces; of common Wormwood and Thym, each one Ounce; of the Seeds of Ani≈øe, Fennel, and of red Ro≈øes, each half an Ounce; infu≈øe them, and boyl them according to Art, in a ≈øufficient quantity of Whey; to the ≈øtrained Liquor add of the Juice of Fumitory clarified, and of Sugar, each one Pound and an half; boyl them to the Con≈øi≈øtence of Honey, and ≈øtrain them, and add of the Pulps of Ca≈ø≈øia, Prunes, Tamarinds, and Manna, each one Ounce and an half: When they are brought to a due Con≈øi≈øtence, ≈øprinkle into them, the Leaves of Sena clean≈øed, and choice Rhubarb, each one Ounce; of Scammony prepared, one Ounce and an half; of the Seeds of Fumitory, Ani≈øe, and Indian Spike, each three Drams; make an Electuary according to Art. It purges Melancholy, Choler, and ≈øalt Flegm, and is therefore good for the Itch, Madne≈øs, and a Cancer. The Do≈øe is from three Drams to ≈øix.

div.head: Diacarthamum.
div.p: Take of the Marrow of the Seeds of ba≈øtard Saffron, of Gummy Turbith, each one Ounce; of Hermodactiles, Scammony prepared, Liquori≈øh ra≈øped, each half an Ounce; of Ginger and Cinnamon, each two Drams; of choice Manna, and Honey of Ro≈øes, each one Ounce; of white Sugar di≈ø≈øolved in the Juice of Quinces one Pound; make an Electuary according to Art. It purges Flegm powerfully. The Do≈øe is from five Drams to an Ounce. Pills are frequently made of the Species of this Electuary, an Extract of them being made with Spirit of Wine rectified; but Scammony is added to the Extract. The Do≈øe is one Dram.

div.head: Caryo Co≈øtinum.
div.p: Take of bitter Co≈øtus, of the Seeds of Cummin, white Ginger, and Cloves, each one Dram; of Diagrydium and white Hermodactiles, the outward Bark being taken off, each two Drams; of clarified Honey, and odoriferous Wine, each three Ounces; make an Electuary according to Art. It purges ≈øerous Humours; but it is chiefly u≈øed for the Gout. The Do≈øe is from two Drams to half an Ounce.

div.head: Diacatholicon.
div.p:
Take of the Roots of Polypody of the Oak, four Ounces; of the Seeds of Fennel ≈øix Drams; boyl them according to Art in a ≈øufficient Quantity of Water: To the ≈øtrained Liquor add of white Sugar two Pound; boyl them to a Syrup, wherein di≈ø≈øolve of the Pulp of Ca≈ø≈øia, and of Tamarinds, each two Ounces; of the Leaves of Sena clean≈øed, two Ounces; of choice Rhubarb and Mechoacan, each one Ounce; of the Seeds of
Ani≈øe half an Ounce, of the four greater cold Seeds, of Liquori≈øh ra≈øped, and of the Flowers of Violets, each two Drams; make an Electuary according to Art. It purges all Humours. The Do≈øe is from half an Ounce to one Ounce.

div.head: Diaphenicon.
div.p: Take of the Pulp of Dates clean≈øed, and infu≈øed in Vinegar, and pulped through a Sive, and well evaporated, one Pound; of ≈øweet Almonds blanched, three Ounces; brui≈øe them, and mix them, and add to them two Pound of clarified Honey; let them boyl a little, and then ≈øprinkle in the following Powders, of Turbith finely powdered four Ounces, of Scammony prepared one Ounce and an half, Ginger, Galingal, Wood of Aloes, Cinnamon, Mace, the Leaves of Rue dryed, Pepper, the Seeds of Fennel and Daucus, each two Drams; make an Electuary according to Art. It purges Flegm and Choler. The Do≈øe is from half an Ounce to one Ounce.

div.head: The ≈øolutive Electuary of Prunes.
div.p: Take of the Pulp of Prunes that are acid and ≈øweet, thickened, one Pound; of the Pulp of Tamarinds and Ca≈ø≈øia di≈ø≈øolved in the Decoction of Prunes, each two Ounces; of clarified Sugar two Pound; boyl them to a Thickne≈øs, and then ≈øprinkle in the following Powders. Take of Scammony prepared two Ounces, of Rhubarb one Ounce, of Cinnamon half an Ounce, of the Flowers of Violets and red Ro≈øes, of the Seeds of Cucumber and Pur≈ølain, and of the Juice of Liquori≈øh, each two Drams, of yellow Sanders and Tragacanth, each one Dram; make an Electuary according to Art. It purges only Choler. The Do≈øe is from three Drams to ≈øix.

div.head: Hiera with Coloquintida.
div.p: Take of the Pulp of Coloquintida, Agarick, Germander, Horehound, Arabian Staechas, each ten Drams; Opopanax, Sagapenum, round Birthwort, the Seeds of Par≈øly and white Pepper, each five Drams; Cinnamon, Indian Spiknard, Polium, Saffron, Myrrh, each four Drams; of clari≈øied Honey three Pound; make an Electuary according to Art. It purges Flegm. The Do≈øe is from half an Ounce to ≈øix Drams.

div.head: Hiera Picra.
div.p: Take of lucid Soccotrine Aloes one Pound and an half; an Ounce of Cinnamon, Wood of Aloes, the Roots of A≈øarabacca, Indian Spicknard, Saffron, Ma≈øtich, each ≈øix Drams; of clarified Honey three times the Quantity, make an Electuary according to Art. It purges Choler and Flegm, incides, attenuates, and purges the remote Parts of the Body. An Ounce of it with a Scruple of Saffron was Haelideus's Experiment for an ob≈øtinate Ob≈øtruction of the Cour≈øes.

div.head: Lenitive Electuary.
div.p:
Take of Rai≈øins of the Sun ≈øtoned two Ounces; of the Herbs Mercury three Handfuls; of fre≈øh Maiden-Hair, of the Flowers of Violets, of clean≈øed Barly, each one Handful; of Liquori≈øh ra≈øped, of the Seeds of Fennel, each half an Ounce; of Jujubes, Sebe≈øtins, each Number twenty; of Prunes, Tamarinds, each one Ounce; of fre≈øh Roots of Polypody, of the Leaves of Sena clean≈øed, each two Ounces; boyl them according to Art in a ≈øufficient quantity of Water; to the ≈øtrained Liquor add of the Pulps of Ca≈ø≈øia, Tamarinds, and Prunes, each four Ounces, of white Sugar one
Pound, of the be≈øt Honey half a Pound, of the Leaves of Sena clean≈øed three Ounces and an half, of the Seeds of Ani≈øe three Drams; make an Electuary according to Art. It purges Flegm, Serum, Choler, Melancholy, and is good for the Di≈øea≈øes of the Brea≈øt, and a Pleuri≈øy. The Do≈øe is half an Ounce or an Ounce.

div.head: Electuary of the Juice of Ro≈øes.
div.p: Take of the Juice of fre≈øh pale Ro≈øes clarified, of white Sugar, each one Pound and an half; boyl them acccording to Art; towards the End, ≈øprinkle in of Scammony prepared one Ounce and an half; of all the Sanders, and Cinnamon well powdered, each two Drams; make an Electuary according to Art. It purges Choler and ≈øerous Humours. The Do≈øe is from half an Ounce to ≈øix Drams.

div.head: Venice Treacle.
div.p:
Take of the Troches of Squills ≈øix Ounces; of the Troches of Vipers, Magma Hedychroy, prepared Opium, long Pepper, each three Ounces; the Roots of Florentine Orris, of white and light Agarick, of Cinnamon, cretick Scordium, red Ro≈øes, the Seeds of Napi, Oyl of Nutmegs by Expre≈ø≈øion, the Juice of Liquori≈øh, each one Ounce and an half; of the Roots of ≈øweet Co≈øtus, five leaved Gra≈øs, Rhaponticum, or in≈øtead of it, Rhubarb, Indian Spiknard, Ginger, woody Ca≈ø≈øia, the Leaves of cretick Dittany, Mountain Calaminth, Horehound, Schaenanthum, Arabian Staechas, Engli≈øh Saffron, white and black Pepper, the Seeds of true Macedonian Par≈øly, Myrrh, Ma≈øculine Frankincen≈øe, Cyprian Turpentine, each ≈øix Drams; the Roots of Acorus, Gentian, Meum Athamanticum, Valerian, celtick Spike, the Leaves of Germander, Ground-pine, the Leaves of Malabathrum, Mountain Poly, fre≈øh Juniper Berries, the
Seeds of Bi≈øhop's-weed, Ani≈øe, the le≈ø≈øer Cardamoms, St. John's-wort, Sc≈øely, Thla≈øpi, the Cloves of Pliny; for Amomum, true bole Armenick, for Terra Lemnia, Chalcitis toa≈øted till it come to an A≈øh Colour, Gum arabick, Sagapenum, Storax Calamite, the Juice of Hypoci≈øtis, and of true Acacia, each half an Ounce; the Roots of ≈ømall Birthwort, the Flowers of the le≈ø≈øer Centaury, of the Seeds of cretick Daucus, of Opoponax, Galbanum; Ca≈øtor, Judaic Bitumen, each two Drams; a ≈øufficient quantity of generous Canary Wine to melt the Gums and Juices, of Narbon Honey thrice the quantity of all: Make an Opiate according to Art. It heats, dries, attenuates, kills Worms, expels Gravel; being taken in Par≈øly Water, it forces the Cour≈øes, helps Concoction in the Stomach, and is an excellent Alexipharmick; it's called the Mother of Medicines, as Mithridate is the Father. The Do≈øe is from half a Dram to three Drams. An Ounce of it is ≈øeldom given, except when Poy≈øon has been taken, and then it ought not to be given if the Patient be under ≈øeven Years of Age. The older this Medicine is, the better it is.

div.head: Mithridate.
div.p:
Take of Engli≈øh Saffron, Myrrh, male Frankincen≈øe, Ginger, white and light Agarick, Indian Spiknard, Cinnamon, the Seeds of Thla≈øpi, each ten Drams; of the Seeds of Se≈øely, of ≈øweet Co≈øtus, of the Leaves of Laurel, for Malabathrum, of Scaenanth, Arabian Staechas, long Pepper, true Storax Calamite, Galbanum, Opoponax, the Juice of Hypoci≈øtis, Cyprian Turpentine, Oyl of Nutmeg by Expre≈ø≈øion, for Opobal≈øamum, each eight Drams; of woody Ca≈ø≈øia, white Poly Mountain, cretick Scordium, white Pepper, Juniper Berries, the Seeds of cretick Daucus, Bdellium, Troches Cypheos, each ≈øeven Drams; the Roots of Gentian and of Celtick Spike, cretick Dittany, the Seeds of true Macedonian
Par≈øly, the le≈ø≈øer Cardamoms, Fennel, red Ro≈øes, Gumarabick, Opium prepared, each ≈øive Drams; the Roots of true Acorus, A≈øara Bacca, Valerian, the Seeds of Ani≈øe, Sagapenum, each three Drams; Meum Athamanticum, the Seeds of St. John's-wort, true Acacia, the Belly of a Schinck, each two Drams and an half; a ≈øufficient quantity of generous Canary Wine to melt the Gums and Juices, of Narbon Honey thrice the quantity of all: Make an Opiate according to Art. It heats, dries, forces the Cour≈øes, expels Gravel, forces Sweat, and is alexipharmic. The Do≈øe is from one Scruple to two Drams.

div.head: Fraca≈øtorius's Dia≈øcordium.
div.p: Take of the Leaves of Scordium dried, of red Ro≈øes, each one Ounce; of true Bole Armenick two Ounces; of the Roots of Bi≈øtort, Gentian, Tormentil, woody Ca≈ø≈øia, Cinnamon, Cretick Dittany, of the Seeds of Sorrel, of Storax Calamite, Galbanum, Gumarabick, each half an Ounce; of prepared Opium, Ginger, long Pepper, each two Drams; of clarified Honey three Pound; of generous Canary Wine a ≈øufficient quantity; make an Opiate according to Art. It moderately heats and dries, is a≈øtringent, ≈øtops vomiting, forces Sweat, and is good for the Plague, and big-bellied Women who cannot bear Treacle: It is al≈øo an excellent Remedy for Hickops. The Do≈øe is from one Dram to three.

div.head: Theriaca Diate≈ø≈øeron Me≈øues.
div.p:
Take of the Roots of round Birthwort, and of Gentian, Laurel Berries, and Myrrh, each two Ounces; clarified Honey two Pound; make an Electuary according to Art. It heats, dries, attenuates, is good for cold Di≈øea≈øes of the Head and Stomach, has an alexipharmic quality, and many prefer it before Venice Treacle.
The Do≈øe is from two Drams to half an Ounce.

div.head: Confection of Alkermes.
div.p: Take of the Syrup of the Grains of Kermes two Pound and an half, heat it, and add of Ambar-grea≈øe cut ≈ømall two Drams; ≈øprinkle the following Powders with liquid Ambar, of Wood of Aloes, and Cinnamon, each ≈øix Drams; of Lapis Lazuli prepared, of prepared Pearls, each two Drams; of Leaf Gold one Dram; make an Electuary according to Art. It heats, dries, is cardiac, good for Fainting, an Apoplexy, and Melancholy. It is an excellent A≈øtringent in a long and violent Loo≈øne≈øs. It is prepared with or without Musk. The Do≈øe is from half a Scruple to two Scruples.

div.head: Confection of Hiacinth.
div.p: Take of Hiathinths and red Coral, each half an Ounce; of true Bole Armenick one Ounce; of the Grains of Kermes, of the Roots of Tormentil and white Dittany, of the Seeds of Sorrel, Lemons, Pur≈ølain, of the Leaves of red Ro≈øes, all the Sanders, of the Shavings of Ivory, each four Scruples; of the Shavings of Harts-horn three Drams; of Saphyr, Smaragd, Topaz, Pearl, crude Silk, Gold, Silver in Leaves, each two Scruples, with a ≈øufficient quantity of Syrup of Lemons; make an Electuary according to Art. It cools, dries is a≈øtringent, ≈øudorific, cardiac, and expels Melancholy. The Do≈øe is from one Scruple to one Dram.

div.head: Philonium Me≈øue.
div.p:
Take of the Seeds of white Henbane, and white Pepper, each twenty Drams; prepared Opium ten Drams, Saffron five Drams; the Roots of Pyrethrum, and Indian Spiknard, and Ca≈øtor, each one Dram; of clarified
Honey, thrice the quantity of all; make an Electuary according to Art. It dries, is a≈øtringent, hypnotick, forces Urine, expels Gravel, being taken in Smallage Water; it al≈øo ≈øtops vomiting. The Do≈øe is from half a Scruple to half a Dram.

div.head: Nicholaus's quieting Opiate.
div.p: Take of the Flowers of red Ro≈øes and Violets, each three Drams; of the Seeds of white Henbane, Lettice, white Poppy, Flea-bane, Pur≈ølain, Scariola, of the Bark of the Root of Mandrake, of Opium prepared, Ginger, Nutmeg, Cinnamon, each one Dram and an half; of all the Sanders, of Spodium of Ivory burnt, of Tragacanth, each two Scruples, of clarified Honey, thrice the quantity of all; make an Opiate according to Art. It cools, is a≈øtringent, anodyne, and hypnotick. The Do≈øe is from one Scruple to a Dram.

div.head: Dia≈øena Montagnani.
div.p: TAke of the Leaves of Sena clean≈øed two Ounces; of Cream of Tartar half an Ounce; of the Seeds of ≈øweet Fennel two Drams, of Mace, Cinnamon, Sal Gemma, each one Dram; make a Powder. It heats, dries, incides, attenuates gro≈øs Humours, purges Melancholy, and is cephalic. The Do≈øe is from one Dram to one Dram and an half.

div.head: Diaturbith with Rhubarb.
div.p:
Take of Gummy Turbith, Hermodactiles, choice Rhubarb, each one Ounce; of prepared Scammony half an Ounce; of white and red Sanders, Ginger, Flowers
of Violets, each one Dram and an half; of Ma≈øtich, Seeds of Ani≈øe, Cinnamon, and Engli≈øh Saffron, each half a Dram; make a Powder. It purges Flegm and gro≈øs Humours with Choler. The Do≈øe is one Dram.

div.head: Galen's ≈øimple Hiera.
div.p: Take of lucid Soccotrine Aloes an hundred Drams; of Cinnamon, Wood of Aloes, the Roots of A≈øarabacca, and Indian Spiknard, Saffron, and Ma≈øtich, each ≈øix Drams; make a Powder. It purges only Choler: It heats, dries, is ≈øtomachic and cephalic. The Do≈øe is from one Dram to four Scruples.

div.head: Aromatic Ro≈øe Powder.
div.p: TAke of red Ro≈øes fifteen Drams, of Liquori≈øh ra≈øped ≈øeven Drams, of choice Cinnamon five Drams; of Wood of Aloes and yellow Sanders, each three Drams; of Gumarabic, Tragacanth, Mace, Cloves, each two Drams and an half; of Indian Spiknard, Nutmeg, the le≈ø≈øer Cardamoms, Galingal, each one Dram; make a Powder. It heats, dries, atenuates, is, ≈øtomachic, cardiac, and cephalic. The Do≈øe is one Dram.

div.head: Powder of Calaminth.
div.p: Take of the Herbs Mountain Calaminth, Origanum, Pennyroyal, the Seeds of Macedonian Par≈øly, Se≈øely, each two Drams, Smallage, Tops of Thym, each half an Ounce; black Pepper, Seeds of Lovage, each one Ounce; make a Powder. It heats, dries, attenuates, forces Urine, and the Cour≈øes, expels Wind, and is ≈øtomachic. The Do≈øe is one Dram.

div.head: Powder of Galingal.
div.p: Take of the Roots of Galingal, of Wood of Aloes, each ≈øix Drams; of the Roots of ≈øweet ≈ømelling Flag, Ginger, of Cinnamon, Mace, Cloves, white and long Pepper, the Seeds of Cummin, Lovage, the outward Barks of Oranges and Citrons dried, each one Dram and an half; the Herbs Calaminth, Mint dried, Indian Spike, the Seeds of Ani≈øe, Smallage, the le≈ø≈øer Cardomoms, Carawayes, Fennel, each one Dram; make a Powder. It heats, dries, cuts, and volatilizes gro≈øs Humours, expels Wind, ≈øweetens the Breath, is cephalic, cardiac, ≈øtomachic, alexipharmic. The Do≈øe is one Dram.

div.head: Simple Powder of Orris.
div.p: Take of the Roots of Florentine Orris half an Ounce; of white Sugarcandy, of the Powder Diatragacanth frigid, each two Drams; make a Powder. It heats, mollifies, attenuates, incides, and is good for a Cough. The Do≈øe is one Dram.

div.head: The greater Powder of Lacca.
div.p:
Take of prepared Lacca, Rhubarb, Scaenanth, each three Drams; of the Roots of round Birthwort, A≈øarabacca, Co≈øtus, Gentian, Madder, Indian Spiknard, woody Ca≈ø≈øia, Cinnamon, Saffron, of the Herbs Savin, Hy≈ø≈øop, of the thickened Juices of Wormwood, Water Agrimony, bitter Almonds, the Seeds of Bi≈øhopsweed, Ani≈øe, Smallage, Fennel, Bdellium, Ma≈øtich, Myrrh, each one Dram and an half; Pepper, Ginger, each one Dram; make a Powder. It heats, dries, incides, opens, is diuretic, and moves the Cour≈øes. It cures a Drop≈øy, drives out the Mea≈øles and Small-pox,
and is ≈øtomachic. The Do≈øe is half a Dram.

div.head: The Powder called Diamargarit frigid.
div.p: Take of ≈øplendid Pearls three Drams; of Wood of Aloes, all the Sanders, Cinnamon, of the four le≈ø≈øer cold Seeds, of white Poppy Seed, and of Myrtle Berries, of the Flowers of Buglo≈øs, Water Lillies, red Ro≈øes, Violets, of crude Harts-horn, of the Bone of a Stag's Heart, of the Shavings of Ivory, each one Dram, of white and red Coral, each half a Dram; make a Powder. It cools, is a≈øtringent, pectoral, cardiac, and good for malignant Di≈øea≈øes. The Do≈øe is one Dram.

div.head: The Powder called Diambra.
div.p: Take of the Roots of Roman Doronicum and Galingal, of Cinnamon, Cloves, Nutmeg, Mace, of the Leaves of Laurel, for Malabathrum, each three Drams; of Ginger one Dram and an half; of the Wood of Aloes, yellow Sanders, le≈ø≈øer Cardomoms, long Pepper, each two Drams; of Indian Spiknard and Ambar-grea≈øe, each one Dram; make a Powder. It heats, dries, is cardiac, alexipharmic, ≈øtomachic, and is good for old Men and Women. The Do≈øe is one Dram.

div.head: The Powder called Dianthus.
div.p: Take of the Flowers of Ro≈ømary one Ounce; of red Ro≈øes, Violets, of Liquori≈øh ra≈øped, each ≈øix Drams; of Galingal, Zedoary, Ginger, Wood of Aloes, Cinnamon, Cloves, Nutmegs, Indian Spike, the Seeds of Ani≈øe, Dill, the le≈ø≈øer Cardomoms, each four Scruples; make a Powder. It heats, dries, is cardiac, and expels Melancholy. The Do≈øe is one Dram.

div.head: The Powder called Diarrhodon Abbatis.
div.p: Take of red Ro≈øes one Ounce and an half; of white and red Sanders, each two Drams and an half; of Wood of Aloes, Gum Arabick, Tragacanth, Spodium of Ivory, each two Scruples; of the Roots of A≈øarabacca, Rhubarb, Indian Spike, Cinnamon, Saffron, Cloves, of the Fruit of Berberries, of the Seeds of Sorrel, Ani≈øe, the le≈ø≈øer Cardomoms, Endive, Lettice, Fennel, Ba≈øil, Pur≈ølain, Scariola, of the Juice of Liquori≈øh, of Ma≈øtich, each one Scruple, of crude Harts-horn, and white Pearls, each half a Scruple; make a Powder. It cools, dries, is a≈øtringent, cardiac, ≈øtomachic, and good for Con≈øumptions. The Do≈øe is one Ounce.

div.head: The Powder called Diatragacanth frigid.
div.p: Take of white Gum Tragacanth, half an Ounce; of Gum Arabick two Drams and an half; of fine Wheaten Flower one Dram; of Liquori≈øh ra≈øped, of the Seeds of Citruls, Cucmuber, Cucurbit, Melons, each half a Dram; of white Sugarcandy ≈øix Drams; make a Powder. We have pre≈øcribed but a ≈ømall Quantity of it, becau≈øe the Compo≈øition, by rea≈øon of the greater cold Seeds, will not keep above three Months, which is the rea≈øon al≈øo that we have omitted them in other Compo≈øitions. It cools, is a≈øtringent, good for Con≈øumptions and Coughs. The Do≈øe is one Dram.

div.head: The Powder of the three Sanders.
div.p:
Take of the three Sanders, red Ro≈øes, white Sugarcandy, of the Seeds of Lettice, Pur≈ølain, Scariola, each three Drams; of Rhubarb, Spodium of Ivory, Juice of Liquori≈øh, each two Drams and an half; of Gum Arabic, and Tragacanth, and of fine Wheaten Flower,

each one Dram and an half. It cools, binds, is ≈øtomachic, cardiac, and extingui≈øhes the Relicks of Fevers. The Do≈øe is one Dram.

div.head: Pulvis Liberans.
div.p: Take of true Bole Armenick, ≈øix Drams; of the Roots of Tormentil two Drams; of the Seeds of Sorrel, Carduus Benedictus, Citron, Coriander prepared, Endive, Rue, each one Dram and an half; of all the Sanders, of the Roots of white Dittany, each one Dram; of Roman Doronicum, Zedoary, Wood of Aloes, Wood of Ca≈ø≈øia, Cinnamon, the le≈ø≈øer Cardomoms, of Flowers of Buglo≈øs, Saffron, Mace, Water Lillies, Ro≈øes, Pearls, white and red Coral, Ambar, Hyacinth, Granate, the Ra≈øpings of Ivory and Hartshorn, of Spodium of Ivory, of crude Silk cut, each half a Dram; make a Powder. It binds, dries, is alexipharmic, is excellent for the Plague, it moves Sweat, and pre≈øerves from Putrefaction. The Do≈øe half a Dram to one Dram.

div.head: Nephritic Powder.
div.p: Take of true nephritic Wood, of Liquori≈øh ra≈øped, of Peach Kernels, each one Ounce; of the Seeds of Milium Solis, Saxifrage, each half an Ounce; of Smallage, Carawayes, Daucus, Fennel, Broom, the greater Bur, of Lovage, Macedonian Par≈øly, Mountain Siler, Roman Nettles, of the Roots of A≈øarabacca, and Ginger, each two Drams; of Indian Spike, Schaenanth, Ambar, Crabs-Eyes, each one Dram and an half; of Sal Prunella, Tartar vitriolated, each two Drams and an half; make a Powder. It heats, opens, attenuates, expels Gravel. The Do≈øe is one Dram.

div.head: A Powder for the Falling Sickne≈øs.
div.p: Take of the Roots of Male-peony, gathered at the beginning of Spring, at the decrea≈øe of the Moon, the Seeds of Male-peony, the Roots of white Dittany, and Mi≈øletoe of the Oak, the ≈øhavings of a Mans Scull, that died a violent Death, the ≈øhavings of Unicorns horn, Elks hoof, each one Ounce; Oriental Pearl, the Hyacinth ≈øtone, red Coral prepared, each half an Ounce; the Seeds of Cloveba≈øil, the Flowers of Limetree, Bettony, Lilly of the Vallies, each two Drams; Ambar-grea≈øe, half a Scruple; oriental Musk, ≈øix Grains; of Leaves of the pure≈øt Gold, number fifteen; make a Powder. This Powder is excellent for the Falling Sickne≈øs, the Apoplexy and Pal≈øy. The Do≈øe is from half a Scruple to half a Dram.

div.head: The Powder for the Bite of a mad Dog.
div.p: Take of the Leaves of Rue, Vervain, le≈ø≈øer Sage, Plantain, Polypody, common Wormwood, Mint, Mugwort, Balm, Bettony, St. John's-wort, the le≈ø≈øer Centaury, each equal parts. The≈øe Herbs mu≈øt be gathered when they are at their Perfection, that is about June; they mu≈øt be gathered when the Moon is Full, and the Weather fair. The Do≈øe of this Powder is half a Dram; it mu≈øt be mixed with half a Dram of Powder of Vipers, and taken in a ≈ømall Gla≈øs of White Wine in the Morning Fa≈øting, for nine days ≈øucce≈øively. It is al≈øo good to apply at the ≈øame time Par≈øly brui≈øed to the Part affected.

div.head: Powder of Vipers.
div.p:
Take as many Vipers flea'd as you plea≈øe; Cut off their Heads and Tails, and take out their Entrails,
but ≈øave the Heart and Liver, dry them in the ≈øhade, wa≈øh the Bodies, Hearts, and Livers in White-wine, and hang them up to dry in the ≈øhade; when they are quite dry, cut them very ≈ømall, beat them to Powder. It is very good for Scabs, Itches, and Lepro≈øies, and for a Con≈øumption; half a Dram, or a Dram of it may be taken in the Morning Fa≈øting; it may be taken for a good while together.

div.head: A Powder for a Dentifrice.
div.p: Take of the Roots of florentine Orris, Pumex-≈øtone, Harts-horn burnt, red Coral prepared, Cutlebone, Cream of Tartar, all finely Powdered, each one Ounce; of oriental Musk, and Civet, each half a Scruple; of the Oyls of Rhodium, Cloves, and Cinnamon, all by De≈øtillation, each two Drops; make a Powder. This does not only whiten and clean≈øe the Teeth, but fa≈øtens them, and keeps them from Rotting.

div.head: An other Powder for the ≈øame.
div.p: Take of fine Dragons Blood, and of Roman Allom burnt, both finely Powdered, each two Ounces; of oriental Musk, four Grains; mix them, make a Powder according to art; rub the Teeth with it gently, Morning and Evening.

div.head: An Oderiferous Powder for the Head.
div.p:
Take of the Roots of florentine Orris, eight Ounces; of yellow Sanders, four Ounces; of Lavender Flowers, red Ro≈øes, and Tops of Marjoram, each three Ounces; of Storax, and Benzion, each two Ounces; of ≈øweet Tachamahacca, and of the Flowers of Lillies of the Vallies, each one Ounce; of Cloves, Labdanum, true
Acorus, and round Cyperus, each one Dram; Powder them gros≈øly. The chief u≈øe of this Powder is for quilted Caps, to ≈øtrengthen the Brain. It may by al≈øo worn upon the Stomach, or Heart, or put among≈øt Cloaths, or Linnen for the ≈øaid purpo≈øe.

div.head: A Powder for the Worms.
div.p: Take of Worm≈øeed, of the Seeds of Citron, Broom, Pur≈ølain, Colworts, choice Rhubarb, Scordium, the le≈ø≈øer Centaury, Gentian, Harts-horn ra≈øped, each one Ounce; make a fine Powder. The Do≈øe is from half a Scruple to a Dram, according to the Age. When you u≈øe it, you mu≈øt add to it Mercurius Dulcis, and Scammony; the three la≈øt Dayes of the Moon are to be cho≈øen for the u≈øe of this Powder.

div.head: A Dige≈øtive Powder.
div.p: Take of the Powder Vipers, of the Seeds of ≈øweet Fennel, Ani≈øe and Coriander, each one Ounce; of Daucus and cretick Bi≈øhops-weed, each half an Ounce; of the outward Bark of dryed Citron, of ≈øharp Cinnamon, each three Drams; of Cloves and Mace, each one Dram; mix an equal Quantity of white Sugar with this Powder; half a Spoonful of it may be taken after Meals; it Cheri≈øhes the natural Heat, helps Concoction expels Wind, pre≈øerves and re≈øtores lo≈øt Appetite, corrects ill Fumes from the Stomach, and Sweetens the Breath.

div.head: A Powder again≈øt Mi≈øcarriage.
div.p:
Take of oriental Pearls prepared, of Unicorns Horn, and Ivory ra≈øped, of white Ambar, red Coral prepared, Ma≈øtich, Kermes Grains, red Sanders, Lemnian Earth, and Tormentil Roots, each half an
Ounce; of Mace one Dram; of Cloves one Scruple; make a Powder; mix with it an equal Quantity of white Sugar, and ≈øix Leaves of fine Gold; half a Scruple, or a Scruple of it may be taken Fa≈øting, in Syrup of Quinces, or in Broath; it al≈øo good for a Loo≈øne≈øs, the Bloody Flux, and a Weakne≈øs of the Stomach.

div.head: A Powder to ha≈øten Delivery.
div.p: Take the Te≈øticles of a Hor≈øe dryed in a Oven, according to Art, of ≈øharp Cinnamon, the Kernels of Dates, Borax, Saffron, the dryed Leaves of Savin, each two Drams; of Troches of Myrrh, one Dram; make a Powder.

div.head: An Hy≈øterick Powder.
div.p: Take of the Warts growing on Hor≈øes Legs, falling off, or being cut off in the Spring, one Ounce; of A≈ø≈øa-foetida, the Horns and Hoof of a Goat, each one Dram; make a Powder. This Powder mu≈øt be ca≈øt upon live Coals and the Fume mu≈øt be received upon the Parts a≈ø≈øected thro' a Tunnel.

div.head: A Powder for the bloodly Flux.
div.p: Take of Lemnian Earth, Bolearmenick, red Ro≈øes, Balau≈øtines, Roots of Tormentil, and Bi≈øtort, the Tears of Dragons blood, red Coral prepared, Blood≈øtone, each one Ounce; of the Seeds of Pur≈ølain, Plantain, and Flixweed, each half an Ounce; of Cloves and Mace, each two Drams; the Do≈øe is from one Scruple to a Dram: It may be given in Wine, or ≈øome a≈øtringent Water, or decoction; upon extraordinary occa≈øions, you may mix a grain of Laudanum.

div.head: A Powder again≈øt Hemorrhages.
div.p: Take of Blood-≈øtone, the Kernel of the Eagle-≈øtone, the Earth of Vitriol wa≈øht, remaining after di≈øtillation, Bolearmenick, Franckincen≈øe, Hor≈øetail, Knotgra≈øs, Lemnian Earth, burnt Harts-horn, Gyp≈øum, each equal Parts; make a Powder. It ≈øtops the Blood of a Womans Veins or Arterles being applyed with the White of an Egg, and bound upon the part affected; it ≈øtops Defluxions on the Eyes, being mixed with Vinegar, and applyed to the Eyes.

div.head: A ≈øneezing Powder.
div.p: Take of the dryed Leaves of Marjoram, Sage, Bettony, of the Flowers of Lillies of the Vallies, each one Ounce; of the Roots of Florentine Orris, of white Hellebore, Pyrethrum, the Seeds of Roman Nigella, each two Drams; of the Tops of Pennyroyal, and creeping Thym, each one Dram; make a Powder. It is good for Apoplexies, the Falling ≈øickne≈øs, Lethargies, and other Di≈øea≈øes of the Brain proceeding from a Cold. In extarordinary Lethargies, Drow≈øine≈øs, and ≈øleepy Di≈øea≈øes, two Drams of Euphorbium may be added to the Compo≈øition of this Powder; but not unle≈øs there be very great nece≈ø≈øity.

div.head: Agarick Trochi≈øcated.
div.p: TAke of white and light Agarick, three Ounces, with a ≈øufficient quantity of Canary Wine, wherein two Drams of Ginger hath bin infu≈øed; make Troches: They purge Flegm. The Do≈øe is one Dram.

div.head: White Troches of Rha≈øis.
div.p: Take of Ceru≈øs wa≈øhed in Ro≈øe water, ten Drams; of fine wheaten flower, four Drams; of Gum Arabick, and Tragacanth, each two Drams; of Camphor half a Dram; with the white of an Egg, make Troches. If you would have Opium in it, you mu≈øt add a Dram. It dryes, binds, repels, thickens, a≈ø≈øwages the acrimony of the Humours, and is u≈øed outwardly for Inflammations of the Eyes.

div.head: Troches of Alhandal.
div.p: Take of the white and light pulp of Coloquintida, purged from the Seeds, cut ≈ømall, and powdered, with a ≈øufficient quantity of Oyl of Ro≈øes, ten Ounces; of Gum Arabick, Tragacanth, Bdellium, each ≈øix Drams; Powder them all, and with part of the Gum Tragacanth, make ≈øuch a quantity of Mucilage in a ≈øufficient quantity of Ro≈øe water, as will make up the other Powders into a Pa≈øt, whereof make Troches to be dryed in the ≈øhade. They purge powerfully, and are good for the Collick, Apoplexy, A≈øthma, and Gout. The Do≈øe is one Scruple.

div.head: Troches of Winter Cherries.
div.p:
Take of Winter Cherries, three Drams, of true Bolearmenick, one Ounce; of the Gums Arabick, and Tragacanth, of Dragons blood in tear's, of Frankincen≈øe, fine wheaten Flower, juice of Liquori≈øh, bitter Almonds, Pine kernels, the Seeds of white Poppies, each ≈øix Drams; of the Seeds of Citruls, Gourds, Melons, each three Drams and an half; of the Seeds of Smallage, and Henbane, of Ambar, and prepared Opium, each two Drams; with the juice of Winter
Cherries, make Troches. They cool, mollifie, heal Wounds, are anodyne, good for Heat of Urine, and for Ulcers of the Kidneys, and provoke Urine, and have often done a great deal of good in de≈øperate ca≈øes. The Do≈øe is from one Dram to two Drams.

div.head: White pectoral Troches.
div.p: Take of the white≈øt Sugar one Pound, of white Sugarcandy, and penidiate Sugar, each four Ounces; of the Roots of Orris, two Ounces; of fine wheaten Flower one Ounce and an half; with the mucilage of white Tragacanth, extracted in Ro≈øe water, make ≈ømall Troches. They molli≈øie, thicken, clean≈øe, are good for a Cough, and a roughne≈øs of the Mouth. One Dram of them is to be held in the Mouth, till it di≈ø≈øolves.

div.head: Troches of Cappers.
div.p: Take of the Bark of the Root of Cappers, of Gum Ammoniacum, of the Seeds of the Cha≈øt Tree, each ≈øix Drams; of the Seeds of Water-cre≈ø≈øes, and Nigella, of the Leaves of Calaminth and Rue, of the Roots of Acorus, and round Birthwort, of bitter Almonds, of the juice of water Agrimony thickned, each two Drams; of the Roots of round Cyperus, of the Leaves of Scolopendrium, each one Dram. Make Troches with the fore≈øaid Ammoniacum di≈ø≈øolved in Vinegar. They heat, dry, ≈øoften, open, and are good for ob≈øtructions of the Spleen. The Do≈øe is from one Dram to half an Ounce.

div.head: Trochi≈øci Cypheos for Mithridate.
div.p:
Take of the Pulp of white and fat Currants, Cyprian Turpentine, each three Ounces; of Myrrh,
and Schenanth, each one Ounce and an half; of Cinnamon, half an Ounce; of the Roots of true Acorus, round Cyperus, Indian Spicknard, woody Ca≈ø≈øia, Juniper Berries, Bdellium, each three Drams; of Wood of Aloes, two Drams and an half; of Saffron, one Dram; of the be≈øt Honey clarified, of Canary Wine, each a ≈øufficient quantity to make Troches. They heat, dry, attenuate, heal, are Sudorifick, Cardiack, Alexipharmick. The Do≈øe is one Dram.

div.head: Trochi≈øci Hedychroi for Treacle.
div.p: Take of yellow Sanders, of the herbs Marjoram, Syriack Marum, of the Roots of A≈øarabacca, each two Drams; Acorus, ≈øweet Co≈øtus, Pontick Phu, Wood of Aloes, Cinnamon, Schenanth, Oyl of Nutmegs, each three Drams; Wood of Ca≈ø≈øia, Indian Spicknard, Laurel Leaves, Saffron, Myrrh, each ≈øix Drams; Gillyflowers of Pliny, one Ounce and an half; Ma≈øtich, one Dram, Canary Wine, a ≈øufficient quantity, to make Troches; dry them in the ≈øhade, and Oyl them over with the Oyl above mentioned. They heat, dry, open, are Diaphoretick, Sudorifick, and Alexipharmick. The Do≈øe is from half a Dram to three Drams.

div.head: Trochi≈øci Aliptae Mo≈øchatae.
div.p: Take of pure Labdanum, three Ounces, of Storax Calamite one Ounce and an half; of red Storax, one Ounce; of Wood of Aloes, two Drams; of Ambar, one Dram; of Camphor, half a Dram, of Musk, half a Scruple; with a ≈øufficient quantity of Ro≈øe water, make Troches. They are hot and dry, they attenuate, incide, are good for an A≈øthma, and for the vomiting up Milk. They ≈øtrengthen, and are u≈øed for Fames. The Do≈øe is from one Scruple to half a Dram.

div.head: Trochi≈øci Galliae Mo≈øchatae.
div.p: Take of Wood of Aloes, five Drams; of Ambar, three Drams; of Musk, one Dram; of the Mucilage of Tragacanth extracted with Ro≈øe water, a ≈øufficient quantity; make Troches. They heat, dry, attenuate, comfort the Heart, Brain, and Stomach, and yield a ≈øweet Smell, and are u≈øed for Fumes.

div.head: Troches of Myrrh.
div.p: Take of choice Myrrh, three Drams; of Lupins clean≈øed, five Drams; of the Roots of Madder, of the Leaves of Hor≈øe-mint, Penny-royal, Rue, of the Seeds of Cummin, A≈ø≈øafoetida, Sagapenum, Opoponax, each two Drams; with Syrup of Juice of Mugwort, make Troches. They heat, dry, open, incide, expell the Cour≈øes, and Secundine. The Do≈øe is from two Drams to three.

div.head: Troches of Rhubarb.
div.p: Take of choice Rhubarb, ten Drams; of the Juice of Water Agrimony thickened, half an Ounce; of the Leaves of red Ro≈øes, three Drams; of the Roots of A≈øarabacca, Madder, Indian Spicknard, of the Leaves of Wormwood, of the Seeds of Ani≈øe, and Smallage; each one Dram; of bitter Almonds half an Ounce; with the juice of Roman Wormwood, make Troches.
