They heat, dry, attenuate, open, purge gently, are good for a Drop≈øy, Cachexy, and Jaundice. The Do≈øe is from one Dram to three.

div.head: Renodaeus's Troches for a Gonorrhea.
div.p:
Take of the Seeds of the Cha≈øt Tree, of Ro≈øes,
Balau≈øtines. each half a Dram; of the Shavings of Ivory, and Ambar, each one Dram and an half; of Bolearmenick wa≈øht in Knot-gra≈øs Water, two Drams; of the Seeds of Plantain, four Scruples; of Sa≈ø≈øafras, two Scruples; with the Mucilage of the Seeds of Quinces extracted in the Water of Water-lillies; make Troches. It cools, dries, and is a≈øtringent. The Do≈øe is from one Dram to two Drams.

div.head: Troches of Squills for Treacle.
div.p: Take a fre≈øh clear Squill, the outward Bark, and woody Root being taken out: Cover it with Wheaten Pa≈øt, and roa≈øt it under the A≈øhes, or bake it in an Oven, till the Parts grow cru≈øty, and afterwards with a pointed ≈ømall Stick, pierce thro' the body of the Squill; then ≈øeparate the Cru≈øt from it; take of the ≈øoft and fine Marrow of the Squill, one Pound; of the Flower of Lupins, eight Ounces; mix them, and make Pa≈øte of them, and dry them in the ≈øhade. It dries, incides, is thoracick, and alexipharmick. The Do≈øe is from one Dram to two.

div.head: Troches of ≈øealed Earth.
div.p:
Take of ≈øealed Earth, or in ≈øtead of it, true Bolearmenick, half an Ounce; of true Acacia, Hypoci≈øtis, Dragons Blood in Tears, Gum Arabick toa≈øted, fine Flower toa≈øted, Blood-≈øtone, red Coral, Ambar, Spodium of Ivory, Balau≈øtins, red Ro≈øes, Seeds of red Ro≈øes, Seeds of Pur≈ølain toa≈øted, Cyperus Nuts, Harts-horn burnt, ma≈øculine Frankincen≈øe, Saffron, prepared Opium, each two Drams; the Seeds of black Poppies, Pearls, Gum Tragacanth, each one Dram and an half; with the Juice of Plantain, make Troches. They cool, dry, are a≈øtringent, good for ≈øpitting of Blood, all Hemorrhagies, and great fluxes of the
Cour≈øes. The Do≈øe is half a Dram with the Juice of Plantain.

div.head: Troches of Vipers for Treacle.
div.p: The be≈øt Vipers are to be had at Venice, or Padua. The Troches are prepared of the fle≈øh of Vipers, and Bread twice baked, both brui≈øed in a Mortar, and made into Troches. But how the Vipers are taken, how they are killed, and how the Troches are made, you may ≈øee in Hoffman. They are alexipharmick; they cure the Bites of Vipers, the Lepro≈øy, and other Di≈øea≈øes of the Skin; but they are rarely in u≈øe alone.

div.head: Pills Aloephangin.
div.p: TAke of the Roots of Acorus, A≈øarabacca, Indian Spicknard, Wood of Aloes, and yellow Sanders, Cinnamon, Mace, and Nutmegs, Cloves, Juniper berries, Cubebs, the le≈ø≈øer Cardomoms, Schaenanth, each half an Ounce; red Ro≈øes, Wormwood, each two Drams; of the≈øe extract a Tincture, with Spirit of Wine, in a Gla≈øs well ≈øtopt, wherein di≈ø≈øolve of clear pure Aloes, one Pound; then gently evaporate over hot A≈øhes the Spirit of Wine, and bring it to the con≈øi≈øtence of Pills; towards the end add, of Myrrh, and Ma≈øtich powdered, each half an Ounce; of Saffron, two Drams; make a Ma≈øs: They heat, dry violently, attenuate, incide, purge Choler, and Flegm; are cephalick, and peculiarly proper for old Men. They are al≈øo good for the Colick, and Wind. The Do≈øe is from one Dram to two Drams.

div.head: Pills of Agarick.
div.p:
Take of Agarick trochi≈øcated, three Drams; of
Gummy Turbith, five Drams; of the Powder of Galen's ≈øimple Hiera half an Ounce; of the Troches of Alhandal, of Myrrh, each two Drams; of Ma≈øtich, the Roots of Florentine Orris, the Leaves of Horehound, each one Dram; with Canary Wine make a Ma≈øs. They heat, dry, purge Flegm, are good for the Head, the Brea≈øt, the Cough, A≈øthma, a Coma, Catarrh, and Giddine≈øs. The Do≈øe is from half a Dram to four Scruples.

div.head: The Golden Pill.
div.p: Take of clear Aloes, Scammony prepared, each five Drams; of red Ro≈øes, and the Seeds of Smallage, each two Drams and an half; of the Seeds of Ani≈øe, and Fennel, each one Dram and an half; of Saffron, Ma≈øtich, the Troches of Alhandal, each one Dram; with Honey of Ro≈øes make a Ma≈øs. They purge Choler, and Flegm; they attenuate, incide, heat, and dry. The Do≈øe is from one Dram to four Scruples.

div.head: Pill Coch
div.p: Take of the Powder of Galen's ≈øimple Hiera, ten Drams; of Troches of Alhandal, three Drams and an half; of Scammony prepared, two Drams and an half; of Gummy Turbith, and the Flowers of Staechas, each five Drams; with Syrup of Staechas make a Ma≈øs. They heat, dry, purge ≈øtrongly Flegm and Choler. They are commonly counted cephalick. The Do≈øe is from two Scruples to four.

div.head: Pill of Hound≈øtongue with Ca≈øtor.
div.p: Take of the Roots of Hound≈øtongue dryed, of the Seeds of white Henbane, of Opium prepared, each half an Ounce; of Myrrh ≈øix Drams; of male Frankincen≈øe, five Drams; of Saffron, Ca≈øtor, and Storax Calamite, each two Drams; with Ro≈øe-water make a Ma≈øs. They cool, dry, bind, thicken, are anodyne, and narcotick. The Do≈øe is five Grains.

div.head: The true Catholick extract.
div.p: Take of the Pulp of Coloquintida, ≈øix Drams; of white Agarick, black Hellebore, Jalap, and Turbith each four Ounces; Powder them all gros≈øly, or cut and brui≈øe them, and make a Tincture in ≈øix Quarts of rectified Spirit of Wine. Dige≈øt them fourteen nights and days, and ≈øhake the Gla≈øs ≈øometimes; gently pour off the Tincture, and ≈øtrain it, thro' a linnen Rag. To the ≈øtrained Liquor add of fountain Water a Quart, and the whole Liquor will turn Milky, which di≈øtill in a Bath till only a Quart be left behind: Take the Gla≈øs out of the Bath, whil≈øt it is warm, and pour out the re≈øidue of the Water, with the Re≈øine into a new glazed Pan, and evaporate over a gentle fire to the con≈øi≈øtence of Honey: Afterwards add of clear Aloes powdered, eight Ounces; of Scammony ≈øulphurated, four Ounces; of Spirit of Wine rectified, four Ounces; mingle them, and evaporate them over a gentle fire to the con≈øi≈øtence of an extract fit to make Pills. It is a true catholick Purge. It purges Choler, Flegm, Melancholy, Serum, without any gripes. The Do≈øe is from fifteen Grains to a Scruple.

div.head: The greater Faetid Pill
div.p: Take of Troches of Alhandal, clear Aloes, Ammoniacum, Opoponax, Sagapenum, Myrrh, Dodder of Thym, the Seeds of Rue, each five Drams; of prepared Scammony, three Drams; of the Roots of Gummy Turbith, four Drams; of the le≈ø≈øer Spurge, and Hermodactiles, each two Drams; of Ginger one Dram and an half; of Indian Spicknard, Saffron, Ca≈øtor, each one Dram; of Euphorbium powdered, two Scruples; with the Juice of the Leaves of Leeks make a Ma≈øs. They heat, dry, open, purge Flegm and Choler, force the Cour≈øes, purge the mo≈øt remote parts of the Body, and are good for the Colick, Itch, and all cutaneous Di≈øea≈øes. The Do≈øe is from two Scruples to a Dram.

div.head: Bontius's hydropick Pill.
div.p: Take of the be≈øt Aloes, two Drams and an half; Gum Gotte di≈ø≈øolved in Malago Wine, one Dram and an half; Diagrydium prepared the ≈øame way, one Dram; Gum Ammoniacum, one Dram and an half; Tartar vitriolated, half a Dram; with a ≈øufficient quantity of Syrup of Ro≈øes ≈øolutive, make a Ma≈øs. They purge Serum plentifully, and open, and re≈øolve. The Do≈øe is one Scruple.

div.head: Pills of Hiera with Agarick.
div.p: Take of the Powder of Galen's ≈øimple Hiera, of Troches of Agarick, each half an Ounce; of clear Aloes, one Ounce; with Honey of Ro≈øes make a Ma≈øs. They purge Flegm, and Choler. The Do≈øe is from one Dram to one Dram and an half.

div.head: The Iliack Pill.
div.p: Take of Coloquintida, Sagapenum, each ≈øix Drams; Diagrydium, two Drams; with Wine make a Ma≈øs for Pills. They purge Flegm, Choler, are good for the Cholic, Iliack Pa≈ø≈øion, and an Hemicrany. The Do≈øe is half a Dram.

div.head: The Pill of the Lapis Lazuli.
div.p: Take of the Lapis Lazuli powdered, and often wa≈øht, ≈øix Drams; of Dodder of Thym, of the Roots of black Hellebore, of Agarick trochi≈øcated, each one Ounce; of Scammony prepared, of Sal Gemma, each two Drams and an half; of Cloves, and the Seeds of Ani≈øe, each half an Ounce; of the Powder of Galen's ≈øimple Hiera, fifteen Drams; with the Juice of Fumitory make a Ma≈øs. The≈øe Pills purge Melancholy, Flegm, and Choler; and heat, dry, and open; are good for a Cancer, a Quartan Ague, and Ob≈øtructions of the Bowels. The Do≈øe is from one Dram to one Dram and an half.

div.head: Laudanum Opiatum.
div.p:
Take of the Tincture of Opium prepared, of Opium
≈øliced and toa≈øted, and powdered, and infu≈øed in Spirit of Vinegar, a ≈øufficient Quantity; evaporate it gently in a Gla≈øs to the Con≈øi≈øtence of Honey. Take of this Extract one Ounce, of Engli≈øh Saffron powdered, one Dram; of Ca≈øtor powdered half a Dram: Mingle them, and gently evaporate them to the Con≈øi≈øtence of Pills. This is one of the chief In≈øtruments of Phy≈øick, whereby the Phy≈øician may do great things, and gain him≈øelf a great Reputation, if he knows how to u≈øe them rightly. They ea≈øe the greate≈øt Pains, and procure Sleep, and qualifie ≈øharp Humours, ≈øtrengthen the Parts, move Sweat, ≈øtop vomiting, Bloody-flux, and often expel the Gravel from the Kidnies. A ≈øtrong Man may take a Pill weighing three Grains.

div.head: The Ma≈øtich Pill.
div.p: Take of Ma≈øtich half an Ounce; of Agarick trochi≈øcated, three Drams; of fine Aloes, ten Drams, with the Juice of Wormwood make a Ma≈øs. They purge gently Flegm and Choler, and they are ≈øtomachick. The Do≈øe is one or two Drams.

div.head: Pills of Nitre.
div.p: Take of Salt of Nitre purified, of Euphorbium powdered, each one Dram; of Scammony prepared, of Troches of Alhandal, the Roots of black Hellebore, the be≈øt Aloes, Myrrh, Gum Arabick, each two Drams; with the Juice of Cabbage and Honey boyled, make a Ma≈øs. They heat, dry, purge Flegm and Choler from the remote Parts of the Body. They are good for the French-pox, the Pal≈øy, Giddine≈øs, and Falling-≈øickne≈øs. The Do≈øe is half a Dram.

div.head: Common Pe≈øtilential Pills.
div.p:
Take of the be≈øt Aloes, two Ounces; Myrrh, one Ounce; Saffron, half an Ounce; with Canary Wine make a Ma≈øs. It purges Choler, pre≈øerves from the
Plague and Putrefaction; is cardiac and alexipharmic: The Do≈øe is from one Dram to two Drams.

div.head: Pilulae ≈øine quibus.
div.p: Take of fine Aloes, fourteen Drams; of prepared Scammony, ≈øix Drams; of Agarick trochi≈øcated, Rhubarb, the Leaves of Sena clean≈øed, each half an Ounce; of yellow Myrobalans, two Drams; of the Herb Wormwood, of the Flowers of Violets, red Ro≈øes, Dodder, Ma≈øtich, Sal Gemma, each one Dram; with the Juice of Fennel, and Eye-bright make a Ma≈øs. They purge Choler, Flegm, and Melancholy, and are cephalic. The Do≈øe is from one Dram to one Dram and an half.

div.head: Bontius's Pill of Tartar.
div.p: Take of Aloes Soccotrine, two Drams; of Gum Ammoniacum di≈ø≈øolved in Vinegar, ≈øtrained, and thickned again, one Ounce and an half; Tartar vitriolated, one Scruple and an half; make a Ma≈øs. It attenuates, opens Ob≈øtructions, and purges gently. The Do≈øe is from two Scruples to one Dram.

div.head: Quercetan's Pill of Ammoniacum.
div.p: Take of the Extract of Soccotrine Aloes prepared with the Juice of Ro≈øes, four Ounces; of pure Gum Ammoniacum, ≈øix Drams; of choice Myrrh, half an Ounce; of the Powder of the three Sanders, of choice Ma≈øtich, each one Dram and an half; of Saffron, of the Salts of A≈øh and Wormwood, each two Scruples: Powder the Myrrh, the Ma≈øtich, and Saffron apart; make a fine Powder of them: Afterwards ≈øoften the Gum Ammoniac with a little Vinegar of Squills, in a Bra≈øs Mortar moderately heated, and then add to it the Extract of Aloes, and afterwards all the re≈øt of the Ingredients. They open Ob≈øtructions of the Liver and Spleen, and Me≈øentery, and cure long Agues. They cure Cachexies, and purge the Womb, and force the Cour≈øes. The Do≈øe is from one Scruple to a Dram.

div.head: Hy≈øterick Pills.
div.p: Take of Faecula of Briony, choice Myrrh, Vitriol of Steel, Salt of Mugwort, each two Drams; of choice Ca≈øtor, Rue, Camphor, each two Scruples; of the ≈øoft Extract of Aloes, made with the Juice of Mugwort, ten Drams. Beat the Ca≈øtor with the Rue and Myrrh; the Camphor mu≈øt be mingled with them, being powdered with a Drop or two of Spirit of Wine; then add the re≈øt of the Ingredients. The≈øe Pills ≈øuppre≈øs Vapours, and open Ob≈øtructions of the Cour≈øes. The Do≈øe is half a Dram.

div.head: Me≈øenterick Pills.
div.p: Take of the Extract of Aloes, made in the Juice of Fumitory, of choice Gum Ammoniacum, each one Ounce; of opening Saffron of Mars, and of Diagrydium, each half an Ounce; of choice Myrrh, Saffron, and Salt of Tamarisk, each two Drams; of Riverius's Salt of Steel, two Scruples: Make a Ma≈øs for Pills. The≈øe Pills open Ob≈øtructions of the Me≈øentery. They cure Cachexies, Drop≈øies, and open Ob≈øtructions of the Womb. The Do≈øe is from one Scruple to one Dram.

div.head: The Mercury Pill.
div.p: Take of choice Rhubarb, of the Troches of Alhandal, Diagrydium, Murcurius Dulcis, each one Ounce; of Venice Turpentine, diluted with Oyl of Turpentine, a ≈øufficient Quantity; make a Ma≈øs for Pills. The≈øe Pills are chiefly u≈øed for the Cure of Venereal Di≈øea≈øes. They draw the virulent Humours from all Parts of the Body, and evacuate them by Stool: But ≈øometimes they cau≈øe a Salivation in weak Per≈øons. The Do≈øe is from one Scruple to two.

div.head: Pills to ≈øtop a Gonorrhea.
div.p:
Take of the Roots of Bi≈øtort, Tormentil, Water Lilly, Ivy Berries, Seeds of Lettice, Rue, Cha≈øt-Tree, Ambar, Goats Blood, Ma≈øtich, Olibanum, Dragons Blood in Tears, Nutmegs, each half an Ounce. You
mu≈øt beat together in a Bra≈øs Mortar all the Ingredients, ≈øave the Ma≈øtich, which mu≈øt be beat by it ≈øelf; then heat the Mortar, and incorporate them with Venice Turpentine. The≈øe Pills are taken Morning and Evening for many Days fa≈øting. The Do≈øe is from half a Dram to a Dram.

div.head: Pills for a virulent Gonorrhea.
div.p: Take of diaphoretick Antimony, newly prepared, of native Cinnabar, and Cinnabar of Antimony, ≈øealed Earth, Florentine Orris, Liquori≈øh, white Ambar, Crabs-eyes prepared, each half an Ounce; of choice Myrrh, Olibanum, Ma≈øtich, and Saffron, each two Drams. You mu≈øt chu≈øe the fine≈øt Mineral Cinnabar, and that which is mo≈øt weighty. Grind the Ambar and Crabs-eyes upon a Porphyry Stone; Powder apart the Myrrh, Ma≈øtich, Olibanum, Saffron, Cinnabar Mineral, Cinnabar of Antimony, and diaphoretick Antimony: Beat together in a Bra≈øs Mortar the Roots of Orris and Liquori≈øh; and having ≈øifted, and well mingled them, heat the Pe≈øtle and Mortar moderately hot, and incorporate all the Ingredients with Turpentine. Note, the≈øe Pills, nor any other a≈øtringent Medicines can be ≈øafely u≈øed, before the Body hath been ≈øufficiently purged. Afterwards they may be taken Morning and Evening, for many Weeks. The Do≈øe is half a Dram.

div.head: Pills of boyled Turpentine.
div.p:
Take of Venice Turpentine, boyled till it is hard in Radi≈øh Water, or in the Water of Winter Cherries, four Ounces; of Liquori≈øh clean≈øed, and finely powdered, one Ounce; boyl the Turpentine over a ≈øoft Fire, in the di≈øtilled Water of Radi≈øhes, or Winter Cherries, or in any other Plant that forces Urine, till it be ≈øo hard, that you may make it into Pills. Then pour away all the Water from the Turpentine, and before it is cold, incorporate with it the Liquori≈øh finely powdered. The≈øe Pills force Urine when it has
been ≈øtopt by Flegm, and Gravel, or by the French Di≈øea≈øe. They are al≈øo good at the Beginning of a Gonorrhea, to make it run. One Dram or two of it may be taken ≈øeveral Days together.

div.head: The Pill for the Cholick.
div.p: Take of choice Aloes, diluted, and thickened in the Juice of pale Ro≈øes, three Ounces; of choice Agarick, one Ounce and an half; of Extract of Rhubarb, one Ounce; of the Liver of a Wolf prepared, ≈øix Drams; of the Tops of Wormwood, half an Ounce; of the Powder called Diarrhodon Abbatis, Salt of Wormwood, and Nutmegs, each one Dram and an half. Note, the Liver of the Wolf mu≈øt be taken from a Wolf newly killed; having taken out the Gall, wa≈øh the Liver in White Wine; put it into a glazed earthen Pot, the Cover being well luted, and ≈øet it into an Oven after the Bread is drawn; let it continue there for ≈øome Hours; then uncover the Pot, and turn the Liver; cover it again, and lute it as before, and place it in the Oven after the Bread is drawn, and let it ≈øtand as long as at fir≈øt, and ≈øo do till the Liver be quite dry. Beat in a Bra≈øs Mortar the Wormwood with the Agarick and Nutmegs, and the Wolf's Liver, and having ≈øifted the Powder, heat the Mortar and the Pe≈øtle, and melt in it by degrees the Extract of Aloes and Rhubarb, and incorporate them afterwards with as much Syrup of Succory, as will make the whole Ma≈øs of a good Sub≈øi≈øtence. The≈øe Pills gently purge Choler, and ≈øerous Humours, and cure the Cholick; one of them being taken every other Day, till the Patient is well. The≈øe Pills keep the Body open, and evacuate gently and in≈øen≈øibly the ill Humours. A Dram of them may be taken at a time, when you de≈øign to purge ≈øtrongly.

div.head: Poterius's Catholick Pill.
div.p:
Take of Soccotrine Aloes, half an Ounce; of choice Myrrh, two Drams; of choice Ma≈øtich, one Dram;
of Saffron half a Dram; of white Flowers of Antimony, one Dram. Powder all the Ingredients apart, ≈øift them thro' a fine Sieve, and incorporate them with Syrup of Ro≈øes ≈øolutive. They are commended for the Cholick, Giddine≈øs, and Falling-≈øickne≈øs. The Do≈øe is from fifteen Grains to twenty four.

div.head: Oyl of Sweet Almonds.
div.p: TAke what Quantity you plea≈øe of Sweet Almonds dried, beat them ≈ømall, and put them into a cour≈øe Canva≈øe Bag; pre≈øs out the Oyl in a Pre≈øs without Fire. It is temperate, mollifies, is anodyne, and nouri≈øhes con≈øumptive People. The Do≈øe is from half an Ounce to an Ounce. The following Oyls are made in the ≈øame manner. Oyl of bitter Almonds, which heats, dries, incides, clean≈øes, mollifies, is diuretic, and kills Worms.

The Oyl of the Seeds of Lettice is made the ≈øame way, which cools, and cures a Gonorrhea. Oyl of the Seeds of Henbane promotes Sleep, the Temples being anointed with it, ≈øtops a Gonorrhea, and the Cour≈øes, the Loins being anointed with it. It ea≈øes the Pain of the Ear being dropt into it, and the Pain of the Teeth, the Tooth being ≈øtopt with Lint dipt in it. It cools, and dries. True Oyl of Laurel, which is brought from the Fortunate I≈ølands, heats, dries, di≈ø≈øipates, and mollifies. Oyl of Mace heats, dries, is nephritic, and good for the Cholick. Oyl of Walnuts, heats, dries, di≈øcu≈ø≈øes, cures the Cholick, the Itch, and is good for the Gout. Oyl of Eggs, heats, moi≈øtens, is anodyne, and vulnerary. Oyl of ripe Olives, heats, moi≈øtens, clean≈øes, moves vomiting, is vulnerary, and anodyne. Oyl of unripe Olives, called Omphacine, cools, dries, and is a≈øtringent. Palm Oyl is brought from the Indies; it cools, and ≈øerves in≈øtead
of Oyl of Ro≈øes. Oyl of the Seeds of Rocket, heats, dries, provokes Venery. Oyl of Flax, is temperate, mollifies, and ripens. Oyl of Nigella, heats, dries, opens, is diuretick, and uterine. Oyl of Poppies, cools, moi≈øtens, promotes Sleep, is anodyne, and narcotick.

div.head: Oyls prepared by Infu≈øion and Decoction.
Oyl of Wormwood.
div.p: TAke of the Tops of Wormwood cut, and brui≈øed, four Ounces; Omphacine Oyl, three Pints; infu≈øe them fifteen Days in a Gla≈øs, in the Sun, or in ≈øome hot Place, repeating thrice the Infu≈øion of Wormwood; and to the la≈øt Infu≈øion add of the Juice of Wormwood, four Ounces. Boyl them to the Con≈øumption of the Juice. It heats, dries, kills Worms, and is ≈øtomachic.

div.head: Oyl of the Leaves and Flowers of Dill.
div.p:
It heats, moi≈øtens, mollifies, and re≈øolves. Oyl of the fre≈øh Flowers of Camomile, heats moderately, and is anodyne; it is called by Surgeons the Holy, or Ble≈ø≈øed Oyl. Oyl of Quinces cools, binds, ≈øtops vomiting, and a Loo≈øne≈øs, and the Bloody-≈ølux. Oyl of the Tops and Flowers of St. John's-wort, heats, dries, attenuates, is anodyne, vulnerary, and is good for Burns. Oyl of Ja≈ømine mollifies, dige≈øts, is good for a Scirrhus, a Pleuri≈øy, an A≈øthma, and a cold Catarrh, being outwardly u≈øed. Oyl of the Flowers of Wall-flower heats, dries, attenuates, dige≈øts, is anodyne; kills Worms, and moves the Cour≈øes. Oyl of the Flowers of Lilly of the Vallies, heats, dries, mollifies, is anodyne. Oyl of Marjoram heats, dries, attenuates, moves the Cour≈øes, and is cephalic. Oyl of cri≈øped Mint heats, dries, ≈øtrengthens, and ≈øtops vomiting; ≈øo does Oyl of Nep: Oyl of the white Flowers of Water-Lillies cools, moi≈øtens is anodyne.
Oyl of Ro≈øes compleat, made of Ro≈øes full blown, and ripe Oyl, cools, binds, repels, ≈øtrengthens, and is anodyne. Oyl of Ro≈øes omphacine is made of red Ro≈øes not full blown, and omphacine Oyl; it cools powerfully, binds and ≈øtrengthens, and is anodyne. Oyl of Rue heats, dries, and is good for the Cholick. Simple Oyl of Scorpions mixed with Oyl of bitter Almonds expels the Stone of the Bladder and Reins, the Loins, Pubes, and Peritonaeum, being anointed with it. It is al≈øo good for venemous Bites. Oyl of the Leaves, and Berries of Night-≈øhade mixed with the Oyl of Ro≈øes Omphacine, cools, moi≈øtens, binds. Oyl of the Leaves of ≈øweet Trefoil, mollifies, ripens, is vulnerary, and cures a Rupture. Oyl of the Flowers of Violets made with Omphacine Oyl, cools, moi≈øtens, mollifies, and is thoracick. Oyl of Mullein heats, dries, mollifies, is thoracick, good for the Gout, and the Piles. I ≈øay nothing of the Compo≈øition of the≈øe Oyls, becau≈øe it is well known.

div.head: Oyl of Cappers.
div.p: Take of the Bark of Roots of Cappers, one Ounce; of the Bark of Tamarisk, of the Roots of Cyperus, of the Seeds of Agnus ca≈øtus, of the Leaves of Scolopendrium, or of Ceterach, each two Drams; of Rue, one Dram; of Wine Vinegar, and the be≈øt Wine, each two Ounces; of ripe Oyl one Pint. Boyl them in a double Ve≈ø≈øel to the con≈øumption of the Oyl and Vinegar; ≈øtrain them. It attenuates, opens, and mollifies a Scirrhus.

div.head: Oyl of Ca≈øtor.
div.p:
Take of Ca≈øtor, Storax, Calamite, Galbanum, Opoponax, Euphorbium, Woody Ca≈ø≈øia, the Roots of Co≈øtus, of Cyperus, of Pellitory of Spain, and of Indian Spicknard, of the Leaves of Savin, of Saffron, Schaenanth, Cubebs, black and long Pepper, each two Drams; of Oyl, three Pints; of odoriferous Wine, a Quart; powder tho≈øe things that ought to be powdered,
and infu≈øe them all in Wine for a natural day; boyl them with Oyl in a double Ve≈ø≈øel to the con≈øumption of the Wine; then ≈øtrain it out. It heats, clean≈øes, attenuats, moves the Cour≈øes, and the Belly, is good for the Spine of the Back, and for the Nerves, being u≈øed outwardly and inwardly. The Do≈øe is one Dram.

div.head: Oyl of Saffron for the Pla≈øter of Frogs.
div.p: Take of Engli≈øh Saffron, Cardamoms, the Roots of Acorus, each one Ounce; Myrrh, half an Ounce; infu≈øe them in Vinegar for ≈øix days. Then add of Oyl of Olives, one Pint and an half: Boyl them with a gentle fire till all the Vinegar is con≈øumed; then ≈øtrain them. It heats, attenuates, mollifies.

div.head: Oyl of Euphorbium.
div.p: Take of Euphorbium, half an Ounce; of the Oyl of Wall-flowers, and odoriferous Wine, each five Ounces; boyl them to the con≈øumption of the Wine. It heats, dries, di≈øcu≈ø≈øes, attracts, is good for the Noi≈øe of the Ears, and cures Baldne≈øs.

div.head: Oyl of Orris.
div.p: Take of the fre≈øh Roots of Orris brui≈øed, half a Pound; of the fre≈øh Flowers of sky-coloured Orris, one Pound; of the Decoction, or Juice of other Roots of Orris, one Pint; of Oyl of Olives, three Pints and an half; boyl them in a double Ve≈ø≈øel to the con≈øumption of the Liquor; ≈øtrain them. It heats, attenuates, mollifies, cures Convul≈øions, Noi≈øe of the Ears, Ob≈øtructions of the Lungs. It cures Di≈øea≈øes occa≈øioned by the eating of Mu≈øhroms, Hemlock, and Coriander.

div.head: Simple Oyl of Earth-worms.
div.p: Take of Earth-worms wa≈øhed in good White Wine, half a Pound; of Oyl of Olives, two Pound; of White VVine, four Ounces; boyl them to the con≈øumption of the VVine; ≈øtrain them out. It heats, moi≈øtens, is anodyne.

div.head: Oyl of Ma≈øtich.
div.p: Take of choice Ma≈øtich, three Ounces; of Oyl of Ro≈øes, one Pint; of odoriferous VVine, two Ounces; boyl them to the con≈øumption of the VVine in a double Ve≈ø≈øel; ≈øtrain them out. It heats moderatly, is a≈øtringent, ≈øtrengthens, clean≈øes the Face, and is ≈øtomachick.

div.head: Oyl of the Mucilages.
div.p: Take of the fre≈øh Roots of Mar≈øh-mallows cut, four Ounces; of fre≈øh Squills brui≈øed, four Ounces; of the Seeds of Fenugreek, and Flax whole, each one Ounce and an half; infu≈øe them in a ≈øufficient quantity of VVater; then boyl the VVater gently, till it becomes thick, and Mucilaginous. Then add of the Oyls of Dill, Camomile, and white Lillies, each ≈øixteen Ounces; boyl them together to the con≈øumption of the watry humidity; ≈øtir it about now and then to keep it from burning. It heats, moi≈øtens, di≈ø≈øipats, opens, and is anodyne.

div.head: Oyl of Myrtles.
div.p: Take of the Berries of Myrtles dryed and brui≈øed, half a Pound; of Omphacine Oyl, one Pint and an half; of rough red VVine, four Ounces; infu≈øe them, and afterwards boyl them to the con≈øumption of the VVine; then ≈øtrain them out. It cools, dries, con≈øolidats, is thoracick, nervine, and being u≈øed with Labdanum, after the manner of an Oyntment, it hinders the Falling of the Hairs.

div.head: Nard Oyl.
div.p:
Take of Spicknard, three Ounces; of the Leaves of Marjoram, two Ounces; of VVood of Aloes, and of Leaves of Laurel, of the Roots of ≈øweet ≈ømelling Flag, of Cyperus, and Elecampane, Cardamoms, Mace, Schaenanth, each one Ounce and an half; of VVhite Wine, and common VVat, each fourteen Ounces; of Oyl of Olives, four Pints and an half; boyl them in
a double Ve≈ø≈øel, then ≈øtrain them out. It heats, dries, and is anodyne.

div.head: Oyl of Foxes.
div.p: Take a Fox flea'd, and his Bowels taken out, and his Bones broken, and the Fle≈øh cut ≈ømall; boyl all in a ≈øufficient quantity of Sea water, or Salt water till half is con≈øumed; add of old Oyl, two Quarts; of the Herbs Dill, Origanum, Thym, each half a Pound; boyl them again, till the Fle≈øh falls from the Bones, and till the Water is con≈øumed; ≈øtrain them out. It heats, di≈ø≈øipates powerfully, is good for the Nerves, and Gout.

div.head: Apopleptick Bal≈øom.
div.p:
TAke of Oyl of Nutmegs by expre≈ø≈øion, one Ounce; of Ro≈øin of Storax, two Drams; of Indian Bal≈øom, and Ambar-grea≈øe, each one Dram and an half; of true Civet, four Scruples; of oriental Musk, one Dram; of Oyl of Ambar rectified, half a Dram; of di≈øtilled Oyl of Cinnamon, one Scruple; of the di≈øtilled Oyls of Lavender, Marjoram, Rue, Cloves, each fifteen Grains; of the di≈øtilled Oyls of Citron, Oranges, Rhodium wood, each half a Scruple; of Agate, ≈øix Grains. Powder the Musk and Ambar-grea≈øe in a bra≈øs Mortar; mix with them a drop of ≈øome of the di≈øtilled Oyls; melt the Oyl of Nutmegs in a Spoon over a gentle fire; and when it is melted, and is half cold, incorporate with it the Storax, the Indian Bal≈øom, the Musk, and Ambar-grea≈øe; then add the Civet, and the di≈øtilled Oyls; mix them well, and make a Bal≈øom. This is a great remedy for Apoplexies, and all Di≈øea≈øes of the Brain, and is much commended for its plea≈øant Smell, and is a great pre≈øervative again≈øt ill Smells, and a pe≈øtilential Air; for Di≈øea≈øes of the Brain; the Temples and Sutures of the Head may be
anointed with it, or it may be put into the Ears with Cotton.

div.head: Hypnotick Bal≈øom.
div.p: Take of Oyl of Nutmegs by expre≈ø≈øion, and of Populeon Oyntment, each one Ounce; of Deers Marrow, Oyl of Ro≈øes and Water Lillies, each three Drams; Oyl of Henbane-≈øeed by expre≈ø≈øion, Oyl of white Poppies, extract of Opium and Saffron, each two Drams; of Ambar grea≈øe, Musk, Civet, and di≈øtilled Oyl of Rhodium, each eight Grains; moi≈øten the extracts of Opium and Saffron with a little Spirit of Wine; then incorporate them by degrees over a gentle fire with the Oyl of Nutmegs, Deers Marrow, and Populeon Oyntment; then add the Oyls; and la≈øtly the Ambar-grea≈øe powdered, and incorporated with the Civet. This Bal≈øom provokes Sleep gently, and ea≈øes pains of the Head occa≈øioned by continued Fevers. You may put a ≈ømall quantity of it up the No≈øtrils, and into the Ears; or you may anoint the Temples, Wri≈øts, and Soles of the Feet with it.

div.head: Stomachick Bal≈øom.
div.p: Take of Oyl of Nutmegs by Expre≈ø≈øion, two Ounces; of the Oyls of Wormwood, Ma≈øtich, Nard, and white Wax, each ≈øix Drams; of the Oyls by Di≈øtillation of Wormwood, cri≈øped Mint, Cinnamon, Cloves, Thym, and Mace, each one Dram: Melt the white Wax, and the Oyl of Nutmegs over a gentle Fire, when they are melted take them from the Fire, and incorporate the Oyls. This Bal≈øom fortifies and heats the Stomach, ≈øtops vomiting, quickens the Appetite, helps Dige≈øtion, ea≈øes the Pain of the Stomach, the Cholic, the Gripes, and the Bloody-flux. It is al≈øo very good for Di≈øea≈øes of the Brain, and Nerves, the Parts being anointed with it.

div.head: ∆≤terine Bal≈øom.
div.p:
Take of Goats Suet, of the Tears of Galbanum and A≈ø≈øa-foetida, of the Fat contained in the Ca≈øtors Cy≈øtis,
one Dram and an half; of the di≈øtilled Oyls of Ambar, Jet, Rue, and Savin, each two Drams. Incorporate the Fat of the Ca≈øtor, and the di≈øtilled Oyls, with the re≈øt of the Ingredients, excepting the Goats Tallow, which you mu≈øt fir≈øt melt, and when it is half cold again, mix it with the re≈øt. It a≈ø≈øwages Pains of the Womb, and cures the Vapours, being applyed hot to the Pit of the Navel, and covered with a Walnut Shell. A little of it may be taken up the No≈øtrils, and the Out-≈øide of the Throat may be anointed with it. It is al≈øo good to provoke the Cour≈øes.

div.head: A Bal≈øom to make the breeding of the Teeth ea≈øie.
div.p: Take of fre≈øh May Butter, three Ounces; of Hen and Ducks Fat, each two Drams; of the Juice of River-Crabs, drawn out with the Water of Blewbottle Flowers, of the Mucilage of the Roots of Mar≈øh-Mallows, each two Ounces. Beat two or three River Crabs in a Marble Mortar, with a wooden Pe≈øtle, moi≈øten them with a little Water of Blewbottles; pre≈øs out two Ounces of the Juice, add to it two Ounces of the Mucilage of Mar≈øh-mallows, the May Butter, the Hens and Ducks Fat; put them into a glazed Earthen Pot, and boyl them over a gentle Fire, till half the Moi≈øture is con≈øumed; then ≈øtrain them, and add Sugarcandy finely powdered, four Ounces; the Yolk of one Egg, Musk, and Ambar-grea≈øe, each ≈øix Grains: Mix them, and make a Bal≈øom. It ≈øoftens the Gums, they being anointed with it, and if Children ≈øhould ≈øwallow it, it would do them no harm.

div.head: An excellent Bal≈øom for the Hands.
div.p:
Take of Venice Soap, moi≈øtened with the Juice of Lemons, half a Pound; white Virgin Honey, two Drams; Talk of Venice, Sugarcandy, the Roots of Orris finely powdered, each half an Ounce; Salt of Tartar, Borax, Sperma Caeti, each two Drams; Indian Bal≈øom, one Dram; Oyls of Rhodium Wood, Cinnamon, and Cloves, each half a Scruple; oriental Musk
and Ambar-grea≈øe, each twelve Grains. Cut the Soap ≈ømall, and put it into a glazed earthen Pan, and di≈ø≈øolve it upon a gentle Fire, in two Ounces of Lemon Juice, then add the Honey, the Sperma Caeti, and the Bal≈øom: Take the Pot from the Fire, and incorporate by degrees the Powders, and la≈øtly the Musk, Ambargrea≈øe, and di≈øtilled Oyls: The Talk is ea≈øily powdered, being fir≈øt laid before a quick Fire for a Quarter of an Hour, and then beaten in a Mortar heated with a hot Pe≈øtle, and then ≈øifted. This Bal≈øom whitens, clean≈øes, and ≈ømoothens the Skin beyond any Pa≈øte or Pomatum that can be prepared, the Hands being rubbed with it.

div.head: Fernelius's a≈øtringent Oyntment.
div.p: TAke of Oyl of Ro≈øes, often wa≈øhed with Allom Water, one Pound and an half; of white Wax, four Ounces; of Acacia, Myrtle Berries, Balau≈øtins, the Barks of Acorns and Pomgranates, of unripe Galls, Sumach, Ma≈øtich, each one Ounce. Powder them all, and infu≈øe them four Days in the Juices of Medlars and Sloes; then dry them over a gentle Fire, and with Oyl, and a ≈øufficient Quantity of Wax, make an Oyntment according to Art. It dries cools, is powerfully A≈øtringent, defends the Parts from Fluxions, contracts the Brea≈øts, and takes off the Wrinkles from the Belly after Child-bearing.

div.head: The Aegyptiack Oyntment.
div.p: Take of Verdegrea≈øe, five Ounces; of crude Allom, one Ounce; of the be≈øt Honey, fourteen Ounces; of ≈øtrong Vinegar, ≈øeven Ounces: Boyl them according to Art, to the Con≈øi≈øtence of an Oyntment. It eats down proud and dead Fle≈øh, and is good for Fi≈øtula's, and old Ulcers.

div.head: ∆≤nguentum Agrippae.
div.p: Take of the fre≈øh Roots of Briony, two Pound; wild Cucumber, one Pound; Squills, half a Pound; Orris, three Ounces; of the Roots of Wakerobin, Dwarf Elder, Fern, each two Ounces; of white Wax, fifteen Ounces; of Oyl, two Quarts: Make an Oyntment. It heats, dries, being applyed to the Belly, it purges by Stool. It is good for the Drop≈øy, and Di≈øea≈øes of the Spleen, the Belly being anointed with it.

div.head: The white Oyntment with Camphor.
div.p: Take of Oyl of Ro≈øes, one Pint; of white Wax, three Ounces; of Ceru≈øs, ≈øix Ounces; of Camphor rubbed with Oyl of Ro≈øes, two Drams: Make an Oyntment. It cools, dries, cures the Itch, Burns, Pu≈øtles, Ulcers, and other Vices of the Skin.

div.head: Simple Oyntment of Mar≈øh-Mallows.
div.p: Take of the Oyl of the Mucilages, one Quart; of yellow Wax, half a Pound; of Ro≈øin, three Ounces; of Turpentine, one Ounce and an half: Make an Oyntment. It heats, moi≈øtens, mollifies, is good for the Pain of the Side, the Pain of the Bladder, the Brea≈øt, and the like.

div.head: Compound Oyntment of Mar≈øh-Mallows.
div.p: Take of the Oyl of the Mucilages, one Quart; of yellow Wax, half a Pound; of Ro≈øin and Colophony, each three Ounces; of the Gums of Galbanum, and Ivy, and Turpentine, each one Ounce: Make an Oyntment according to Art. It heats, moi≈øtens, mollifies, dige≈øts, and cures the hardne≈øs of the Nerves.

div.head: The Apo≈øtles Oyntment.
div.p:
Take of Ammoniacum, Ro≈øin, Turpentine, yellow Wax, each fourteen Drams; of Lytharge of Gold, nine Drams; of long Birthwort, Bdellium, Male Frankincen≈øe, each ≈øix Drams; of Galbanum, Opoponax, Myrrh, each half an Ounce; of Verdegrea≈øe, two Drams; of common Oyl, one Quart; of Vinegar
a ≈øufficient Quantity: Make an Oyntment according to Art. It heats, dries, clean≈øes, takes off dead Fle≈øh, is good for Fi≈øtula's, Ulcers, and Wounds.

div.head: ∆≤nguentum Arthanitae.
div.p: Take of the Juice of the Roots of Sow-bread, or for want of it, of the Decoction of one Pound of the Roots dried, and cut into Slices, of the Juice of wild Cucumber, of Butter, each half a Pound; of Oyl of Orris, one Pound; of the Roots of Polypody of the Oak, three Ounces; of the Pulp of Coloquintida, one Ounce and an half; of Euphorbium, two Drams: Brui≈øe tho≈øe things that are to be brui≈øed, and infu≈øe all for ≈øome Days; afterwards boyl them gently to the Con≈øumption of the Juices. In the ≈øtrained Liquor di≈ø≈øolve two Ounces and an half of yellow Wax. While the≈øe are warm, mingle with them three Drams of Sagapenum di≈ø≈øolved in Vinegar. Boyl and ≈øtrain, and evaporate it again to the Con≈øi≈øtence of an Oyntment; of Bulls Gall evaporated to the Con≈øi≈øtence of Honey, half an Ounce; and la≈øt of all, the following things finely powdered. Take of Scammony, Coloquintida, white Turbith, Aloes, Mezereon Berries, each two Drams and an half; of Euphorbium, Myrrh, the Flowers of Camomile, long Pepper, Ginger, each one Dram; Sal Gemma, two Drams: Make an Oyntment. It purges by Stool, if the Hypoga≈øter is anointed with it: But if the Stomach be anointed with it, it occa≈øions vomiting. It purges Water in the Drop≈øy, kills and carries off Worms, and heats, and dries much.

div.head: The Golden Oyntment.
div.p: Take of common Oyl, a Quart; of yellow Sanders, ≈øix Ounces; of Turpentine, two Ounces; of Ro≈øine of the Pine, and Colophony, each one Ounce and an half; of Ma≈øtich, and Frankincen≈øe, each one Ounce; of Saffron one Dram: Make an Oyntment according to Art. It heats, mollifies, clean≈øes, ripens, and is anodyne.

div.head: Oyntment called Ba≈øilicon.
div.p: Take of yellow Wax, black Pitch, and Ro≈øine, each half a Pound; of common Oyl, a Quart: Make an Oyntment according to Art. It heats, dries, heals Wounds, and incarns Ulcers, and is anodyne.

div.head: Oyntment of Lime.
div.p: Take of Quick Lime, wa≈øht according to Art, and dryed, two Ounces; of Ceru≈øs, two Ounces and an half; of Litharge of Gold and Silver, each three Ounces; of Tutty, two Drams; Oyl of Ro≈øes, a Quart; of Calves Suet, eight Ounces; of the Juices of Lettice, Plantain, and Night≈øhade, each four Ounces; of Oyntment of Ro≈øes, two Ounces and an half; with a ≈øufficient Quantity of white Wax make an Oyntment. It cools, dries, and cures Burns.

div.head: ∆≤nguentum Diapompholigos.
div.p: Take of Oyl of Night≈øhade, ≈øixteen Ounces; of white Wax, five Ounces; of Ceru≈øs wa≈øht, two Ounces; of Pompholix prepared, of Lead burnt and wa≈øht, of Frankincen≈øe, each one Ounce: Make an Oyntment according to Art. It cools, dries, is good for Ulcers, is anodyne, and breeds Fle≈øh, tames a cancerous Malignity, and cures Ulcers of the Legs.

div.head: Oyntment of Elecampane, with or without Mercury.
div.p: Take of the Roots of Elecampane, boyled in Vinegar, beat, and moderately dried, one Pound; of old Hogs-lard ≈øalted, eight Ounces; of old Oyl, four Ounces; of Quick≈øilver, new Wax, Turpentine wa≈øht, each two Ounces; of common Salt, one Ounce: Make an Oyntment according to Art. It mollifies, heats, cures Venereal Nodes, the Itch, and Lice.

div.head: ∆≤nguentum Martiatum.
div.p:
Take of the Herbs Wormwood, Southernwood, Ba≈øile, Calaminth, the le≈ø≈øer Centaury, Germander, Garden Co≈øtus, Marjoram, Water Mint, Cow≈ølip, Savin, Sage, the le≈ø≈øer Hou≈øleek, each one Ounce and an half; Laurel Leaves, Ro≈ømary, Rue, each three
Ounces; of the Seeds of Cummin, Fenugreek, the greater Nettle, each half an Ounce; of Bears Fat, Deers Marrow, liquid Storax, each three Ounces; of Butter, one Pound; of Oyl of Nutmegs by Expre≈ø≈øion, one Ounce; of Oyl of Olives, two Quarts; of yellow Wax, one Pound; of good Wine, a ≈øufficient Quantity. The Herbs having been infu≈øed eight Days in Wine, make an Oyntment according to Art. It heats, mollifies, is good for cold Di≈øea≈øes of the Nerves, for trembling, a Pal≈øy, the Gout, and ≈øwelling of the Spleen.

div.head: Nerve Oyntment.
div.p: Take of Oyntment of Mar≈øh-Mallows, four Ounces; of the Fat of Ducks, Gee≈øe, Dogs, Cats, each two Ounces; of the Oyls of Dill, Camomile, Laurel, Worms, Foxes, each one Ounce; of the Oyl of Euphorbium, Peter, Spike, Turpentine, each half an Ounce; of Spirit of Wine, one Ounce and an half; with a ≈øufficient Quantity of VVax: Make a ≈øoft Oyntment according to Art. It heats, moi≈øtens, mollifies, but is chiefly u≈øed for the Nerves.

div.head: An Oyntment for the Eyes.
div.p: Take of Lapis Calaminaris prepared, three Ounces; of prepared Tutty, one Ounce; of white Vitriol, and Camphor, each two Scruples; of Oyntment of Ro≈øes, one Pound: Make an Oyntment according to Art. It cools, dries, ≈øtops Fluxions upon the Eyes, is anodwne, takes off Redne≈øs of the Eyes, a little of it being applyed to the Corners of the Eyes, and to the Eyelids.

div.head: ∆≤nguentum nutritum.
div.p: Take of Litharge of Gold finely powdered, half a Pound; of Oyl of Ro≈øes, and Wine Vinegar, each a ≈øufficient Quantity, to make an Oyntment. It cools, dries, repels, breeds Fle≈øh, and cicatrizes Ulcers.

div.head: The pectoral Oyntment.
div.p: Take of fre≈øh Butter, ≈øix Ounces; of Oyl of Sweet Almonds, four Ounces; of the Oyls of Camomile, and Violets, each three Ounces; of Ducks and Hens Fat, each two Ounces; of Roots of Orris, one Ounce; of white Wax, three Ounces: Make an Oyntment according to Art. It attenuates, dige≈øts, helps Expectoration, is anodyne, and ea≈øes the Pain of the Brea≈øts and Sides.

div.head: Pomatum Oyntment.
div.p: Take of fre≈øh Hogs-lard, cleared from the Skin, and wa≈øht in White-wine, of Sheeps Suet wa≈øht in White-wine, each one Pound; ≈øixteen Apples called Pomwaters, clean≈øed and boyled in Ro≈øe Water, Rhodium Wood, Sa≈ø≈øafras, the Roots of Florentine Orris, each ≈øix Drams; of Benzoin, and Storax Calamite, each half an Ounce: Make an Oyntment. It heats, moi≈øtens, mollifies, and is good for Chaps in the Lips.

div.head: Populeon Oyntment.
div.p: Take of fre≈øh Buds of the Poplar, three Pound; of fre≈øh Hogs-lard un≈øalted, ≈øix Pound; the Buds of the Poplar mu≈øt be brui≈øed, and infu≈øed in the Lard till the following Herbs are gathered. Take of the Herbs Burdock, Henbane, Lettice, Mandrakes, black Poppies, the greater and le≈ø≈øer Hou≈øleek, Night≈øhade, Violets, Navelwort, or Pur≈ølain, the tender Tops of Brambles, each two Handfuls. Brui≈øe them all, and boyl them with the Lard and Poplar Buds, till the Moi≈øture is con≈øumed, and make an Oyntment according to Art. It cools, mollifies, is anodyne, di≈øpo≈øes to Sleep, the Wri≈øts, Forehead, and Temples being anointed with it.

div.head: The Potable Oyntment.
div.p:
Take of fre≈øh Butter without Salt, one Pound; of the Roots of Madder, the greater Comfry, and Tormentil, each half an Ounce; of Ca≈øtor, Dragons-Blood, Crabs-eyes, each two Drams; of red Wine
half a Pint. Boyl them to the Con≈øumption of the Wine, and make an Oyntment according to Art. It attenuates, opens, di≈ø≈øolves coagulated Blood, and is good for Brui≈øes. The Do≈øe is half an Ounce.

div.head: Galen's cooling Oyntment.
div.p: Take of Omphacine Oyl of Ro≈øes, four Ounces; of white Wax, one Ounce: Di≈ø≈øolve the Wax in the Oyl, and wa≈øh it often with Water, and ≈øhake it well. La≈øtly, wa≈øh it with Ro≈øe Water, and add a little Vinegar to it, and ≈øo make an Oyntment according to Art. It cool, moi≈øtens, and is anodyne.

div.head: Oyntment of Ro≈øes.
div.p: Take of fre≈øh Hogs Lard, cleared from the Skin, two Pound; of fre≈øh pale Ro≈øes, a ≈øufficient Quantity: Mix them, and ≈øet them in the Sun for ≈øome Days, then let them ferment, and ≈øtrain them out; to the ≈øtrained Liquor add the ≈øame Quantity of Ro≈øes; ≈øet them in the Sun again; boyl them, and ≈øtrain them as before; repeat the Ro≈øes till the Lard has a plea≈øant Smell, and keep it for an Oyntment. It cools, mollifies, cures an Herpes, and Inflammations.

div.head: The Mundificative Oyntment of Smallage.
div.p:
Take of the Leaves of Smallage, three Handfuls; of Ground Ivy, the greater Wormwood, the le≈ø≈øer Centaury, Germander, Sage, St. John's-wort, Plantain, Milfoil, Perwinkle, the greater and middle Comfry, Bettony, Woodbine, Vervain, Speedwel, yellow Ladies Bed-≈øtraw, Knot-gra≈øs, Adders Tongue, Burnet, each two Handfuls; of common Oyl, four Quarts; of white Pitch, Rams Suet, yellow Wax, and Turpentine, each two Pound: Gather the Herbs, if it may be, all on the ≈øame Day, when they are in their full Vertue, and brui≈øe them in a Marble Mortar: Melt the Wax, Pitch, and Suet in a Copper Pan tinn'd within, over a gentle Fire in the Oyl; put in the brui≈øed Herbs, and boyl them together gently, ≈øtirring the Ingredients from time to time with a
wooden Spatula; and when the Moi≈øture is almo≈øt all con≈øumed, ≈øtrain, and ≈øtrongly pre≈øs out the whole. When the ≈øtraining is cold, and ≈øeparated from the Faeces and Moi≈øture, take of choice Myrrh powdered, and of Succotrine Aloes, each four Ounces; of round Birthwort, and the Roots of Florentine Orris, each two Ounces; incorporate all the≈øe finely powdered with the whole, and the Oyntment is made. This Oyntment is proper to clean≈øe all ≈øorts of Ulcers and Wounds, and di≈ø≈øipate excrementitious Sero≈øities, and to prevent them from breeding. It is al≈øo e≈øteemed good again≈øt the biting of mad Dogs.

div.head: Pla≈øter of Bettony.
div.p: TAke of the Juice of Bettony, Smallage and Plantain, each one Pint; of Wax, Gum Elemy, Ro≈øine of the Pine, and Turpentine, each half a Pound; make a Pla≈øter according to art. It heats a little, and clean≈øes a little, and breeds fle≈øh. Fore≈øtus commends it for Wounds of the Head.

div.head: Pla≈øter of Ceru≈øs.
div.p: Take of Ceru≈øs wa≈øht ≈øome time with Rain-water, and dryed again and powdered, of Oyl of Olives, each half a Pound; of yellow Wax, two Ounces; boyl it according to art, and make a Pla≈øter. It cools, dries, is good for Burns, and Inflammations, for Vices of the Skin, and ≈øuperficial Ulcers.

div.head: The Pla≈øter called Diachalcitis, or Diapalma.
div.p:
Take of old Oyl, Litharge of Gold, each three Pound; old Hogs Lard cleared from the Skins, two Pound; Chalcitis burnt, or of white Vitriol, four Ounces; ≈øtir them in boyling with the green Branches of the Palm-tree, or of the Oak, or Willow, or Medlar-tree, and make a Pla≈øter according to art. It dries, binds, and clean≈øes, is good for pe≈øtilential Tumours,
bloody Wounds, and to clean≈øe all manner of Ulcers, brui≈øes black and blew, and is indeed a Pla≈øter of great u≈øe.

div.head: Simple Diachylon.
div.p: Take of the Oyl of the Mucilages, three Pints; of Litharge of Gold, one Pound and an half; make a Pla≈øter according to art. It cools, moi≈øtens, mollifies, ripens, re≈øolves, di≈ø≈øipates, and is proper for Swellings of the Spleen, Stomach, and the like.

div.head: Diachylon with Gums.
div.p: Take of Oyl of the Mucilages, eight Pints; of Litharge of Gold, four Pound; of VVax and Turpentine, each half a Pound; of Ammoniacum, Galbanum, Opoponax, Sagapenum, each four Ounces; make a Pla≈øter according to art. It mollifies much, ripens, dige≈øts, heats moderately, and is good for old Swellings.

div.head: The Pla≈øter called The Grace of God; with, and without Verdegrea≈øe.
div.p: Take of new VVax, Ro≈øine, Goats Suet, each four Ounces; of Turpentine, two Ounces; Verdegrea≈øe, Ma≈øtich, Olibanum, each three Drams; make a Pla≈øter according to art. It heats, dries, clean≈øes Ulcers and VVounds, and makes them heal.

div.head: The Pla≈øter called Gry≈øeum, or of Lapis Calaminaris.
div.p: Take of Lapis Calaminaris prepared, one Ounce; of Litharge, two Ounces; of Ceru≈øs, and Tutty, each half an Ounce; of Turpentine, one Ounce; of Frankincen≈øe, five Drams; of Ma≈øtich, three Drams; of Myrrh, two Drams; of Ca≈øtor, one Dram and an half; of Goats Suet, one Ounce; make a Pla≈øter according to art. It cools, dries, incarns, and cicatrizes.

div.head: Pla≈øter of Melilot.
div.p:
Take of the Tops of Melilot, ≈øix Ounces; of the Leaves of VVormwood, Marjoram, of the Flowers of Camomile, of the Seeds of Fenugreek, of Laurel Berries,
and the Roots of Mar≈øh-mallows, each three Drams; of the Roots of Cyperus, Orris, and Indian Spicknard, of woody Ca≈ø≈øia, the Seeds of Bi≈øhops-weed, Smallage, and the le≈ø≈øer Cardomoms, each two Drams and an half; of Ammoniacum, ten Drams; of Bdellium and Storax Calamite, each five Drams; of Turpentine, one Dram and an half; dryed Figs, number twelve; Ro≈øine, Goats Suet, each four Ounces; of yellow VVax, eight Ounces; of Oyl of Spike two Ounces; of Oyl of Marjoram, a ≈øufficient quantity. Make a Pla≈øter according to art. It heats, mollifies, ripens, re≈øolves Hardne≈øs, it loo≈øens, and is very anodyne.

div.head: Pla≈øter of Red Lead.
div.p: Take of red Lead, one Pound; common Oyl, a Quart; boyl them according to art, and add to them of Wax, one Pound and an half; of Turpentine, four Ounces; of burnt Lead prepared, two Ounces; make a Pla≈øter according to art. It cools and dries Wounds, and old Ulcers, and heals them.

div.head: Pla≈øter of the Mucilages.
div.p: Take of Oyl of the Mucilages, ≈øix Ounces; of Ammoniacum, Galbanum, Opoponax, Sagapenum, each half an Ounce; of Saffron, two Drams; of yellow Wax, twenty Ounces; of Turpentine, two Ounces; make a Pla≈øter according to art. It heats, attenuates, mollifies, ≈øuppurates, draws, clean≈øes, takes off an E≈øchar in Burns, and is good for Swellings.

div.head: Pla≈øter called Oxycroceum.
div.p: Take of yellow Wax, Colophony, Ship Pitch, each ≈øix Ounces; Engli≈øh Saffron, two Ounces; Ammoniacum, Galbanum, Ma≈øtich, Myrrh, Turpentine, Frankincen≈øe, each two Ounces; of Vinegar a ≈øufficient quantity to di≈ø≈øolve the Gums; make a Pla≈øter according to art. It heats, dries, mollifies, di≈øcu≈ø≈øes Tumours, is anodyne, good for broken Bones, and the I≈øchidiack pain.

div.head: Pla≈øter of Frogs, with, or without Mercury.
div.p: Take of the Oyls of Camomile, Dill, Lillies, Spike, each four Ounces; of Saffron, two Ounces; of Hogs Lard, two Pound; of Calves fat, one Pound; of true Oyl of Laurel, eight Ounces; of male Frankincen≈øe, two Ounces and an half; Euphorbium, ten Drams; live Frogs wa≈øht in Wine, number twelve; Earthworms wa≈øht in Wine, ≈øeven Ounces; the Leaves of Feverfew, the Flowers of Schaenanth, and Staechas, each four handfulls; the Juice of the Roots of Dwarf Elder, and Elecampane, of clear Turpentine, each four Ounces; of liquid Storax, three Ounces; of Litharge of Gold, two Pound; of quick-≈øilver extingui≈øhed in Turpentine, eight Ounces; of good Wine, two Quarts; of white Wax, a ≈øufficient quantity; make a Pla≈øter according to art. It heats, mollifies powerfully, takes off the pain of the Limbs, in the French Di≈øea≈øe; is excellent for an humoural Rupture of the Scrotum, e≈øpecially if ≈øome Sulphur powdered be added to it.

div.head: Fernelius's Pla≈øter for Ruptures.
div.p:
Take of true Acacia, long and round Birth-wort, Balau≈øtins, Cups of Acorns, Beans, unripe Galls, Malicorium, Myrtles, Cypre≈øs Nuts, the Seeds of Plantain, each half an Ounce. Powder them all, and moi≈øten them with Ro≈øe Vinegar, and let them ≈øtand for two Days; then dry them; then take of the Roots of Comfry, Fern, O≈ømund Royal, of the herb Hor≈øtail, each one Ounce; of Aloes, Ma≈øtich, Mummy, Myrrh, Frankincen≈øe, each two Ounces; of Bolearmenick wa≈øht in Vinegar, of the Lapis Calaminaris prepared, of Litharge of Gold, and Dragons Blood, each three Ounces; of Ship Pitch, two Pound; of Turpentine a ≈øufficient quantity; powder them all, and with the fore≈øaid Powder mix them with the Pitch melted, and incorporate them exactly with the Turpentine, and ≈øo make a Pla≈øter according to art. It binds violently,
dries, ≈øtops Fluxions, is good for Ruptures, broken Bones, and to ≈øtrengthen the parts.

div.head: Paracel≈øus's Stiptick Pla≈øter.
div.p: Take of Ammoniacum, Bdellium, each two Ounces; of Galbanum, Myrrh, Olibanum, Opoponax, the Roots of long and round Birth-wort, and of white Dittany, the Load-≈øtone prepared, each one Ounce; Oyl of St. John's-wort, a Quart; true Oyl of Laurel, two Ounces; Litharge of Gold, one Pound and an half; yellow Wax, half a Pound; Turpentine, four Ounces. Make a Pla≈øter according to art. It heats, dries, clean≈øes moderately, and draws.

div.head: The Cerate of Sanders.
div.p: Take of red Sanders, ten Drams; of the white and yellow Earth, each ≈øix Drams; of red Ro≈øes, twelve Drams; of Bolearmenick, ≈øeven Drams; of Spodium of Ivory, four Drams; of Camphor, two Drams; of Omphacine Oyl of Ro≈øes, nine Drams; of white Wax, a ≈øufficient quantity to make a Cerate. It cools, dries, ≈øtrengthens, and is very good for Inflammations.

div.head: Galen's Stomach Cerate.
div.p: Take of Ma≈øtich, and red Ro≈øes, each twenty Drams; of the Leaves of Wormwood, fifteen Drams; of Indian Spicknard, ten Drams; of Omphacine Oyl of Ro≈øes, one Pint; with a ≈øufficient quantity of Wax make a Cerate. It cools, dries, binds, ≈øtops Vomiting, and ≈øtrengthens the Stomach.

div.head: A Sparadrap.
div.p:
Take of Omphacine Oyl of Ro≈øes, half a Pint; of Rams Suet, four Ounces; white Wax, ten Ounces; of Litharge and red Lead, each three Ounces; of Bolearmenick, Ma≈øtich, burnt Lead prepared, of Frankincen≈øe, and Tutty, each one Ounce and an half; of Camphor, half an Ounce; Boy I the Litharge and red Lead together with the Oyl of Ro≈øes, and the Suet (a ≈øufficient quantity of Water being added at fir≈øt) to a due con≈øi≈øtence; than pour on the Wax melted; and
la≈øtly mingle the Powders, and make a Pla≈øter according to art; and while it is hot dip in a Linnen Cloath, and lay it upon a Plate moi≈øtened with Oyl of Ro≈øes. It dries, binds, ≈øtrengthens, breeds Fle≈øh, and heals.

div.head: Pla≈øter of Sulphur.
div.p: Take of Ship Pitch, Ro≈øine and yellow Wax, each twelve Ounces; of Sulphur finely powdered, and of Oyl of Camomile, each four Ounces; of Turpentine, Orris Powdered, and Cummin, each one Ounce and an half; make a Pla≈øter according to art. It heats, powerfully, dries, attenuates mollifies, di≈øcu≈ø≈øes, re≈øolves, draws, and is good for hard Tumours.

div.head: Pla≈øter of Tabacco.
div.p: Take of Rams Suet, white Pitch, and Ro≈øine, each one Pound and an half; yellow Wax, one Pound; fre≈øh Tabacco brui≈øed, three Pound; brui≈øe the Tabacco leaves in a marble Mortar with a wooden Pe≈øtle, and having boyled them with the Rams Suet, Pitch, and Ro≈øine over a gentle Fire in a copper Pan tinned, ≈øtirring them from time to time, till the Moi≈øture of the Tabacco be almo≈øt con≈øumed, ≈øtrain and ≈øtrongly pre≈øs forth the Compo≈øition; then let it cool, and having thrown away the Faeces remaining at the bottom, take of pure Gum Ammoniacum, and of Venice Turpentine, each eight Ounces; melt the Gum Ammoniac in a bra≈øs Mortar heated, and incorporate with it the Turpentine, and mix them with the other ingredients off from the Fire; and when the Ma≈øs is almo≈øt cold, make it up into Rolls This Pla≈øter is commended to mollifie hard internal Tumours, particularly tho≈øe of the Liver and Spleen, tho' they ≈øhould prove ≈øchirrhous.

div.head: Angelus Sala's Magnetick Pla≈øter.
div.p:
Take of Sagapenum, Ammoniacum, Galbanum, each three Ounces; of yellow Wax, and Turpentine, each four Ounces and an half; of ar≈øenical Magnet, three Ounces; of the Earth of Vitriol wa≈øht, one Ounce;
of Oyl of Ambar, half an Ounce: After you have di≈ø≈øolved the Gums in twenty Ounces of Vinegar of Squills over a moderate Fire, pa≈øs them thro' a ≈øtrong Cloath, and boyl them to the ordinary con≈øi≈øtence of Pla≈øters; melt the Wax in a copper Pan with the Oyl of Ambar, and having taken them off the Fire, incorporate with them the Turpentine, Earth of Vitriol, and ar≈øenical Magnet finely powdered, together with the Gums thickened, and the Pla≈øter is made. The ar≈øenical Magnet is made in the following manner. Take of Hungarian Antimony, yellow Sulphur, and cri≈øtaline Ar≈øenick, each two Ounces; powder two Ounces of pure Antimony, as much yellow Sulphur, and as much cri≈øtaline Ar≈øenick, and having mingled them together, put them over a Sand Bath moderately hot; keep the Cucurbit there, till the Ingredients are altogether di≈ø≈øolved, which you ≈øhall know by putting into the ≈øub≈øtances a ≈ømall Iron Rod; for then they will ≈øtick to the Rod like Turpentine: Then let the Matter cool; break the Cucurbit, and keep the Ma≈øs to be powdered, when there is occa≈øion. The Author of this Pla≈øter cries it up highly, and affirms, that being applyed upon Bubo's, and pe≈øtilential Carbuncles, it ripens them quickly, opens them, and draws at the ≈øame time the Venom from the Center to the Circumference. It al≈øo perfectly cures the Kings Evil, drawing the ≈øcrophulous Matter from the remote parts of the Body, and pefectly cures in five or ≈øix Weeks.

div.head: A Pla≈øter for I≈ø≈øues.
div.p: Take of Oyl of Ro≈øes, and Ro≈øe-water, each a Quart; of Venice Ceru≈øs, and Litharge of Gold prepared, each eight Ounces; boyl them according to art to a Pla≈øter; then add of white Wax, ≈øix Ounces; melt the white Wax cut into pieces, and incorporate it exactly with the re≈øt. This Pla≈øter has no ill Smell, and does not ≈øtick very clo≈øe.

div.head: The Marrow of Chymi≈øtry.
div.p: CHymi≈øtry, which comes from the Hebrew Word Chema, ≈øignifying an hot Star, is a contemplative and active Art: It examines all natural things; it teaches how to ≈øeparate the different Sub≈øtances, which are found in mixt Bodies. Tubal Cain, the eighth Man from Adam, was well skilled in Metallick Operations; and Mo≈øes calcined the Golden Calf of the Children of I≈ørael, and reduced it to a Powder. It is called the Hermetic Art, from the ancient Aegyptian Hermes, who was well skilled in Chymi≈øtty, and was one of the fir≈øt Inventors of it.

As to the Principles of Chymi≈øtry, they are five; Water, Spirit, Oyl, Salt, and Earth; two are pa≈ø≈øive, viz. Water and Earth; the re≈øt are active. But to pa≈øs by the≈øe things, we will treat only of ≈øuch Medicines as are mo≈øt u≈øed, and approved in Phy≈øick. Fir≈øt, we will ≈øet down tho≈øe Medicines that are made of Vitriol.

To make the Oyl and Spirit of Vitriol, the Vitriol is calcined till it is yellow, that the accidental Humidity may fly away, and then it is di≈øtilled in a Gla≈øs Retort, in the highe≈øt Degree of Fire for ≈øixty Hours, whereby the Spirit comes forth. At the Bottom remains a very acid corro≈øive Spirit, which ≈øome call fal≈øly, the Oyl. This Di≈øtillation may be perfomed in a le≈øs Time, and to more Advantage, with a large Receiver that has a large Mouth, for ≈øo the Spirit will have a freer Pa≈ø≈øage. The honourable Mr. Boyl makes his Ens Veneris with Colcothar of Vitriol, fir≈øt edulcorated with Rain Water, and afterwards ≈øublimed with a double Quantity of Sal Armoniac. This is a noble Medicine for the Rickets. The ≈øame Colcothar edulcorated, and reduced to a Catapla≈øm with the
White of an Egg, often cures Cancers of the Brea≈øts not ulcerated. Pour, Drop by Drop, the corro≈øive Spirit into Rain Water impregnated with Vitriol, and evaporate it half away, and you'll ≈øee Streaks like Hairs; pour the ani≈øated Bal≈øom of Sulphur into the ≈øaid Water, and you will find a red Ma≈øs like Soap. If you take Vitriol of Steel, with a double Quantity of Sal Armoniack, and proceed in the ≈øame Method, you'll have a Sublimate in Ta≈øte and Smell like Ens Veneris. The Styptic Water is a Solution of Vitriol and other Ingredients.

Take of Colcothar of red Vitriol, that remains in the Retort, after the Spirit is drawn out, burnt Allom and Sugarcandy, each half a Dram; the Urine of a young Per≈øon, and Ro≈øe Water, each half an Ounce; Plantain Water, two Ounces; ≈øtir them all together a good while in a Mortar, then pour the Mixture into a Viol, and when you u≈øe it, ≈øeparate it by Inclination. This ≈øtyptick Liquor ≈øtops Arterial Blood without Excoriation. Apply a Rag dipt in it, and hold it a while to the Part.

Some di≈øtil Vitriol of Mars for a Spirit, and count it a great Secret: But it is nothing el≈øe but Spirit of Vitriol regenerated. Tartar vitriolated is vulgarly made by dropping Spirit of Vitriol upon Oyl of Tartar per Deliquium, till it is perfectly ≈øaturated, and afterwards they dry it, then they di≈ø≈øolve it in Rain Water, filtrate and evaporate it, and again gently dry it for U≈øe: But the following way of preparing it is much better.

Take green Vitriol, di≈ø≈øolve it in Rain Water, afterwards dige≈øt, and filtrate, then by hot Iron Plates, wholly ≈øeparate the Particles of Copper from it, then filtrate it again, and drop upon it a ≈øufficient Quantity of Spirit of Sal Armoniac, or Harts-horn; dige≈øt and filtrate it, and repeat the Operation till no Filth remains at the Bottom, then evaporate it till it
is dry, keep it for U≈øe. The Do≈øe is one Scruple.

Of Roman Vitriol calcined, and Niter, each one Pound; of common Salt, two Pound; and of Quick Lime, half a Pound, is made Aqua Fortis, by Di≈øtillation. The common way of making Aqua Fortis, is with Colcothar of Vitriol, and Niter; but I ≈øuppo≈øe this is Spirit of Niter; therefore take Vitriol calcined till it is yellow, and of Niter, each equal Parts; put them both into a Gla≈øs Retort, and having luted on the Receiver, keep up a ≈øtrong Fire, as long as any Vapours appear in the Receiver. If you add Sal Armoniac, the Aqua Fortis will become Aqua Regia, which is much u≈øed about Metals. Take the Caput Mortuum of Aqua Fortis, and with Rain Water extract a Salt; filtrate, and cri≈øtalize it, then grind it upon a Stone, and afterwards put the Salt into a Retort, and pour upon it the fore≈øaid Aqua Fortis; di≈øtil, and cohobate it till the whole comes over into the Receiver, and you'll have a Noctiluca like Fire. The ≈øame way is made the ≈øhining Salt, wherewith the Beard being moi≈øtened, appears in the Dark like Fire, by the Addition of a fine Spirit, which few know, made of one Part of Niter, and three Parts of Engli≈øh Bole, which you mu≈øt afterwards rectifie, and keep for U≈øe. The Salt extracted by the Rain Water from the Caput Mortuum, is nothing el≈øe but Niter, tho' ≈øome think it is an Alcali: So thought Dr. Mayow, who affirms, in his Treati≈øe of Niter, that the Caput Mortuum of di≈øtilled Niter, is very like an Alcali Salt.

Among all the Salts, I think common Salt is the mo≈øt excellent; this is peculiar in it, viz. that it crackles and makes a Noi≈øe when we endeavour to free it from its accidental Moi≈øture. It is di≈øtilled in the ≈øame manner as Niter. At the End of Di≈øtillation white Flowers are di≈øtilled in the Neck of the Retort.

Take of the rectified Spirit of Salt, what Quantity you plea≈øe; with Quick Lime dry it to a Powder, melt it in a Crucible, and when it is cold, powder it, and mix it with a fourth Part of Quick-Lime, and di≈øtil it in a Retort; the Spirit that comes off, will ≈ømoak continually, and white Vapours will exhale, that ≈ømell and ra≈øte plea≈øantly. This Spirit being taken in Broath, is good for nephritick Pains, the Drop≈øy, and to open Ob≈øtructions, and very friendly to the Bowels, and ferments. Vinegar being di≈øtilled, commonly the Flegm comes fir≈øt, and then the acid Spirit: But the rea≈øon is becau≈øe ≈øome evaporate fir≈øt the half, or three Parts of it, and then di≈øtil the Re≈øidue: But if a ≈øufficient quantity of Vinegar were di≈øtilled without previous Coction and Evaporation; they would find that a fine Spirit would a≈øcend before the Flegm.

Put ≈øix Quarts of ≈øtrong Vinegar into an Earthen Pan, evaporate in a Bath about a Quart, which is the flegmatic Part, and pour that which remains into a Gla≈øs, or Earthen Cucurbit, and di≈øtil it in a ≈øtrong Sand Heat, until there remains nothing at Bottom, but a Sub≈øtance like Honey. This is the common way of di≈øtilling Vinegar. Its principal U≈øe is to di≈ø≈øolve, or precipitate Bodies. It is ≈øometimes mixed in Cordial Potions, to re≈øi≈øt Putrefaction. The Do≈øe is half a Spoonful. It is mixed with Water, and this Oxycrate is u≈øed inwardly to ≈øtop Bleeding, and is outwardly applyed to cure Inflammations.
Sulphur burnt under a Bell yields a very acid and corro≈øive Spirit.

div.head: VVillis's Tincture of Sulphur is made in the following manner.
div.p: Take of Sulphur, one Ounce; of Salt of Tartar, three Ounces; of Canary Wine, a Quart; make a Tincture according to Art. Of this Tincture is made the Syrup ≈øo famous over all England.

div.head: Bal≈øom of Sulphur is made in the following manner.
div.p: Put into a ≈ømall Matra≈øs, an Ounce and an half of Flowers of Sulphur, and pour upon it eight Ounces of Oyl of Turpentine; place your Matra≈øs in Sand, and give it a dige≈øting Fire two Hours; afterwards increa≈øe it a little for four Hours, and the Oyl will take a red Colour. Let the Ve≈ø≈øel cool, then ≈øeparate the clear Bal≈øom from the Sulphur that could not di≈ø≈øolve. This Bal≈øom is excellent for Ulcers of the Lungs and Brea≈øt. The Do≈øe is from one Drop to ≈øix in ≈øome proper Liquor. You may reduce this Bal≈øom to the Con≈øi≈øtence of an Oyntment, by evaporating ≈øome Part of it, and it is u≈øed to clean≈øe Wounds and Ulcers.
If you would make Ani≈øeed Bal≈øom of Sulphar, you mu≈øt u≈øe the Oyl drawn from Ani≈øeeds in≈øtead of it, and proceed as before. It is more agreeable than the former, and has le≈øs Acrimony.
From Tartar and Salt of Niter, is di≈øtilled a plea≈øant Spirit; which, when rectified according to the common way, is good for Ob≈øtructions, and Gravel.

div.head: The Tincture of Salt of Tartar, which is really nothing el≈øe than alcalizat Particles joined with Spirit of Wine, is made in the following manner.
div.p: Take of Salt of Tartar fu≈øed in a Crucible, and powdered in a hot Mortar, what quantity you plea≈øe; put it into a large Viol, afterwards pour upon it a ≈øufficient quantity of rectified Spirit of Tartar hot, and mix them well; then pour upon them Spirit of Wine, and ≈øhake them again, and you'll pre≈øently have a red Tincture impregnated with Salt of Tartar, which is of a plea≈øant Ta≈øte, Smell, and Colour. This Tincture excellently di≈ø≈øolves all di≈øtilled Oyls, and al≈øo Bal≈øom of Gilead, which cannot be di≈ø≈øolved by Spirit of Wine, or any other Men≈øtruum, and ≈øo it becomes an excellent Diuretick, Aperitive, Ab≈øter≈øive, and ≈øtomachic Medicine, good for an A≈øthma, Con≈øumption and Drop≈øy.

div.head: Spirit of Tartar is made in the following manner.
div.p: Fill two Thirds of a Retort with Tartar grofly powdered; place your Retort in a reverberatory Furnace, and fit it to a large capacious Receiver, and begin the Di≈øtillation with a very ≈ømall Fire, for three Hours, to warm the Retort, and to drive out the Flegm Drop by Drop. Throw away this in≈øipid Water, and refitting the Receiver, lute clo≈øely the Joints; increa≈øe the Fire by little and little, and you'll ≈øee Spirits fill the Receiver with Clouds. Continue it, that the Oyl may likewi≈øe come forth; then, when there will come no more, let the Ve≈ø≈øels cool, and unlute them. Pour that which is in the Receiver into a Tunnel lined with brown Paper, that the Spirit may filtrate, and ≈øeparate from the thick black Oyl that remains in the Filter: Keep this Oyl in a Viol. It is good to ≈ømell to in hy≈øteric Fits, it is al≈øo good for paralytic Parts, and cold Pains, but its Smell is very nau≈øeous. Pour the Spirit into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, and rectifie it by di≈øtilling it in Sand. It is good for the Pal≈øy, A≈øthma, and Scurvy, it works by Urine and Sweat; it is al≈øo u≈øed for hy≈øteric Di≈øea≈øes, and the Falling Sickne≈øs. The Do≈øe is from one Dram to three, in ≈øome proper Liquor.

div.head: Fixed Salt of Tartar is made in the following manner.
div.p: Break the Retort, which ≈øerved you for Di≈øtillation of Tartar, and take out the black Ma≈øs you find in it; calcine it until it becomes white, then put it into a a great deal of hot Water, and make a Lee, filtrate it, and pour it into a Ga≈øs, or Earthen Ve≈ø≈øel; evaporate in a Sand Heat all the Water, and there will remain a white Salt, which is called Salt of Tartar. It is aperitive, and is u≈øed to draw forth the Tincture of Vegetables, and to open Ob≈øtructions.

div.head: Oyl of Tartar per Deliquium is made in the following manner.
div.p:
Take of Salt of Tartar, what quantity you plea≈øe;
powder it, and tye it up in in a Rag, and hang it in a cold and moi≈øt Place; put a Gla≈øs under it to receive the Liquor, which you mu≈øt filtrate till it is clear. It cools, clean≈øes, loo≈øens, and is good for the Itch, and to clean≈øe the Skin; it cures Ulcers in the Head, and Venereal Pu≈øtles.
The way of making Salt of Tartar with Niter is not good, for all the Tartar does not fly away.

div.head: Tincture of Coral made after the be≈øt manner.
div.p: Take Coral gro≈øly powdered, di≈øtil it in a Retort with a violent Fire for forty Hours. In the Receiver you'll find a red and unctuous Liquor, tho' in a ≈ømall quantity. Bring it to the Con≈øi≈øtence of Honey, and then with Spirit of Wine, draw a red Tincture. As to the other Preparations of this Tincture, there is no depending on them, becau≈øe the Men≈øtruum is apt to grow red of it ≈øelf, or by the long Dige≈øtion, or by the Addition of Salts.

div.head: Magi≈øtery of Coral is made in the following manner.
div.p: Take what quantity you plea≈øe of the Impregnation of Coral, either red or white, made with di≈øtilled Vinegar. Pour it into a Viol, or Matra≈øs, and drop into it the Liquor of the Salt of Tartar, made by Deliquium; a Curd will appear, which will precipitate to the Bottom, in a very white Powder. Decant the clear Liquor, and wa≈øh the Powder five or ≈øix times with Water; dry it, it is that which is called the Magi≈øtery of Coral. It chears, and fortifies the Heart, re≈øi≈øts Poy≈øon, ≈øtops the Bloody-flux, and all other Hemorrhagies. The Do≈øe is from ten to thirty Grains.

div.head: Salt of Coral.
div.p:
Take what quantity you plea≈øe of the Di≈ø≈øolution of Coral made by di≈øtilled Vinegar; pour it into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, or Earthen Pan, and evaporate in Sand all the Moi≈øture: There will remain at Bottom a Salt of
Coral. Keep it in a Viol well ≈øtopt. It has the ≈øame Virtues with the Magi≈øtery.
Of all imperfect Metals, except Lead, a Tincture may be drawn.

Take Regulus of Antimony, Iron, Copper, Tin, in a due Proportion; fu≈øe, and powder them, and fire them with a ≈øufficient quantity of Niter. Increa≈øe the Fire, and keep them in Fu≈øion till the Ma≈øs is betwixt a sky and green Colour, then draw a Tincture with Spirit of VVine according to Art. This is an excellent Medicine for Chronical Di≈øea≈øes, and Ob≈øtructions. Poterius's famous Powder is made of Niter, Antimony, and Tin. If you mix with it Ro≈øine of Gujacum, you will have an excellent ≈øudorific Medicine, and which I have much experienced, ≈øays Viganus. If the Flowers of Antimony are reverberated with a violent Fire, till they are very red, you may draw a red Tincture from them with rectified Spirit of VVine.

Tincture of Antimony is made with Salt of Tartar, and Regulus of Antimony, by calcining with Fu≈øion of the Fire for three Days, in a Gla≈øs Furnace. At length you'll find a red Ma≈øs, wherewith a very red Tincture may be made with rectified Spirit of VVine. I do not think, ≈øays Viganus, that any of the Salt of Tartar remains in the Tincture, by rea≈øon of the violent Calcination; and we find by Experience, that if the red Powder be expo≈øed to the Air, it does not lo≈øe its Redne≈øs.

div.head: Mercurius Dulcis.
div.p:
Powder ≈øixteen Ounces of corro≈øive Sublimate in a Gla≈øs Mortar; mix with it by degrees twelve Ounces of Mercury revived from Cinnabar; ≈øtir this Mixture with a wooden Pe≈øtle, till all the Quick≈øilver becomes imperceptible; then put this gray Powder into ≈øeveral Viols, two Thirds whereof mu≈øt remain empty; ≈øet them in a Sand Furnace, with a little Fire at fir≈øt, then increa≈øe it to the third Degree; continue it in
this Condition till your Sublimate is made, which u≈øually happens in four or five Hours. Break your Viols, and fling away a little light Earth that is found at the Bottom. Separate al≈øo that which ≈øticks to the Neck of the Viols, but gather up carefully all that is in the Middle, which is very white, and having powdered it, ≈øublime it again in Viols, as before; ≈øeparate once more the Matter in the middle, and ≈øublime it in other Viols as before. La≈øtly, ≈øeparate the Earthy Matter at the Bottom, and the fuliginous that lies in the Neck of the Viols, and keep the Sublimate that is in the middle, for it is ≈øufficiently ≈øweetened. Mercurius Dulcis is u≈øed for all Venereal Di≈øea≈øes. It opens Ob≈øtructions, and kills Worms. The Do≈øe is from ≈øix Grains to half a Dram.

div.head: White Precipitate.
div.p: Di≈ø≈øolve eight Ounces of Mercury, revived from Cinnabar, in ten Ounces of Spirit of Niter; after it is di≈ø≈øolved, pour upon it Salt Water filtrated, made of five Ounces of Sea Salt, in a quart of Water; add a quarter of an Ounce of volatile Spirit of Sal Armoniac, and a white Powder will precipitate; when it is ≈øettled, pour off the Water, and wa≈øh it well with Fountain Water, and dry it in the Shade. It is u≈øed to rai≈øe a Salivation. The Do≈øe is from four to fifteen Grains. It cures Tetters, and the Itch, a Dram, or two Drams of it being mixed with one Ounce of Pomatum.

div.head: Red Precipitate.
div.p:
Di≈ø≈øolve four Ounces of Mercury revived from Cinnabar in five Ounces of Spirit of Niter; pour the Di≈ø≈øolution into a ≈øhortnecked Viol, and evaporate with a gentle Heat all the Moi≈øture; then quicken the Fire by degrees, and rai≈øe to the third Degree, and continue it ≈øo, till all the Matter is turned red; then take it off the Fire, and break the Viol when it is cool, and take out the Precipitate. It takes down proud Fle≈øh, and
lays open Chancres, being mixed with burnt Allom, Aegyptiacum, and Ba≈øilicon.

div.head: Turbith Mineral.
div.p: Di≈ø≈øolve two Ounces of Quick≈øilver revived from Cinnabar, with eight Ounces of Oyl of Vitriol, in a Gla≈øs Retort; then ≈øet the Retort in Sand, and make a Fire underneath, and di≈øtil the Humidity. Make the Fire ≈øtrong enough towards the End, to force out ≈øome of the la≈øt Spirits; then break your Retort, and powder the white Ma≈øs in a Gla≈øs Mortar; pour warm Water upon it, and the Matter will pre≈øently turn to a yellow Powder, which you mu≈øt ≈øweeten by wa≈øhing it often, then dry it in the Shade. It purges ≈øtrongly, both by Vomit and Stool, and is u≈øed for the French Pox. The Do≈øe is from two Grains to ≈øix in Pills.

div.head: Opening Saffron of Mars.
div.p: Wa≈øh well ≈øeveral Iron Plates, and expo≈øe them to the Dew for a great while; when they are ru≈øty, you mu≈øt gather up the Ru≈øt, and then put the Plates again in the Dew, and gather the Ru≈øt as before; and ≈øo do till you have got enough. This is really the be≈øt Saffron of Mars. It cures the Drop≈øy, Green-≈øickne≈øs, Ob≈øtructions of the Liver, Pancreas, Spleen, and Me≈øentery. The Do≈øe is from two Grains to two Scruples.

div.head: A≈øtringent Saffron of Mars.
div.p:
VVa≈øh what quantity you plea≈øe of the following aperitive Saffron of Mars, five or ≈øix times with ≈øtrong Vinegar, leaving it to ≈øteep an Hour at a time, then calcine it in a Pot in a great Fire five or ≈øix Hours; after that let it cool, and keep it for U≈øe. For this opening Saffron of Mars, take of Filings of Steel, and Sulphur powdered, each equal Quantities. Mix them together, and make them into a Pa≈øte with Water; put this Pa≈øte into an Earthen Pan, and leave it to ferment four or five Hours; after which put the Pan over a good Fire, and ≈øtir the Matter with an Iron
Spatula, which will flame; and when the Sulphur is burnt, it will appear black; but continuing a good ≈øtrong Fire, and ≈øtirring it about two Hours, it will be of a very red Colour, and then it is made. The binding Saffron of Mars ≈øtops a Loo≈øne≈øs, and immoderate Fluxes of Hemorrhoids and Cour≈øes. The Do≈øe is from fifteen Grains to a Dram.

div.head: Salt of Mars.
div.p: Take of Spirit of Wine and Oyl of Vitriol, each equal Parts; put them in a clean Frying-pan, and ≈øet it in the Sun for ≈øome time, then in the Shade without ≈øtirring; it will turn to a Salt; dry it, and keep it in a Viol well ≈øtopt. It is good for Ob≈øtructions. The Do≈øe is from ≈øix to twelve Grains in ≈øome proper Liquor.

div.head: Tincture of Steel.
div.p: Powder and mix well together, twelve Ounces of Ru≈øt of Iron, and two Pound of white Tartar of Mount-pelier, then boyl them in a great Iron Pot, with fifteen Pints of Rain Water, twelve Hours; ≈øtir the Matter with an Iron Slice often, and pour in more boyling Water, according as it con≈øumes; afterwards leave it a while to ≈øettle, and you'll have a black Liquor; filtrate, and evaporate it in an Earthen Pan, over a Sand Fire, till a Skin ri≈øes upon it. It opens Ob≈øtructions, is good for Cachexies, Drop≈øies, and Ob≈øtructions of the Cour≈øes. The Do≈øe is from a Dram to half an Ounce in a proper Liquor.

div.head: Volatile Spirit of Sal Armoniac.
div.p:
Powder a-part eight Ounces of Sal Armoniac, and a Pound and an half of quick Lime; mix them in a Mortar, and pour upon them four Ounces of Water, and put it pre≈øently into a Retort, half whereof mu≈øt remain empty; ≈øet your Retort in a Sand Furnace, and fit to it a great Receiver, and lute the Junctures exactly. Begin the Di≈øtillation without Fire for a quarter of an Hour, afterwards increa≈øe by little and little to the
≈øecond Degree, continue it till nothing more comes forth; take off your Receiver, and pour out the Spirit immediately into a Viol, turning away your Head, as much as may be, to avoid a very ≈øubtle Vapour that continually ari≈øes from it. Stop the Bottle clo≈øe with Wax to keep in the Spirit. You'll have of it five Ounces and ≈øix Drams. It is good for Ob≈øtructions, malignant Fevers, Falling-≈øickne≈øs, the Pal≈øy, Plague, Small-pox, and the like. It works by Per≈øpiration, or by Urine. The Do≈øe is from ≈øix to twenty Drops in ≈øome proper Liquor.

div.head: Ro≈øine of Jalap.
div.p: Powder gro≈øly a Pound of good Jalap, and put it into a large Bolt-head, and pour upon it as much rectified Spirit of Wine, as will ri≈øe three Fingers above the Matter; ≈øtop the Bolt-head with another, who≈øe Neck enters into it, and luting the Junctures with a wet Bladder, dige≈øt it three Days in a Sand Heat; the Spirit of Wine will receive a red Tincture. Decant it, and then pour more upon the Jalap; proceed as before, and mixing your Di≈ø≈øolutions, filtrate them through brown Paper. Put that which you have filtrated into a Gla≈øs Cucmbit, and di≈øtil in a vaporous Bath, two Thirds of the Spirit of Wine, which may ≈øerve another time for the ≈øame Operation. Pour that which remains at the Bottom of the Cucurbit, into a large Earthen Pan filled with Water, and it will turn to a Milk, which you mu≈øt leave a Day to ≈øettle; and then ≈øeparate the Water by Inclination, you will find the Ro≈øine at Bottom like Turpentine; wa≈øh it ≈øeveral times with Water, and dry it in the Sun; it will grow hard like common Ro≈øine; powder it fine, and it will become white: Keep it in a Viol. It purges Serum, and is good for Drop≈øies. The Do≈øe is from four to twelve Grains.

div.head: Extract of Rhubarb.
div.p: Brui≈øe, or cut very ≈ømall a Pound of good Rhubarb, and put it into a gla≈øs Cucurbit; pour upon it two Quarts of Succory or Endive Water; then having placed the Cucurbit in a Bath of Sand, and kept a very moderate Fire under the Bath, ≈øtrain out the Tincture, and put the Sediment again into the Cucurbit, and pour upon it a Quart of Succory Water. Renew the Maceration in the ≈øame Bath, and with the ≈øame heat for ≈øix hours; then having ≈øtrained, and pre≈ø≈øed out the ≈øub≈øtances, and returned the Sediment again into the Cucurbit, pour upon it a Pint of good Spirit of Wine, and having carefully luted it, put it into the ≈øame Bath, and renew the Maceration for ≈øix hours; ≈øtrain the whole, and pre≈øs it out very hard; then having mixed this Tincture with the former, and pa≈ø≈øed the whole Mixture thro' a Sheet of Cappaper, pour the filtred Liquor into a glazed Pipkin, and evaporate the ≈øuperfluous Moi≈øture over a very gentle Fire, which mu≈øt be continued till the principal ≈øub≈øtance of the Rhubarb remains at the Bottom of the Pipkin, about as thick as the Con≈øi≈øtence of an Extract.

div.head: Extract of Coloquintida.
div.p:
