Having clean≈øed the Coloquintida from all its Seeds, and cut the Pulp very ≈ømall, put a Pound thereof into an indifferent large Cucurbit, and place it upon Sand, and put to the Coloquintida three Quarts of white Wine; put on the head of the Cucurbit, and lute it well, and fit on a Receiver; kindle a gentle Fire under the Furnace, and keep it ≈øo twelve hours; then unlute the Ve≈ø≈øels, and ≈øtrain out the Infu≈øion, and ≈øet it apart; put the Sediment into the Cucurbit again, and pour upon it a Pint of good Spirit of Wine, and all the Wine which was di≈øtilled into the Receiver; then ≈øtop up the Cucurbit, and lute it well, and infu≈øe the whole for twelve hours in a Bath like the
former, but with a little more heat; pre≈øs out the Tincture, and mix it with the former, and filter both thro' a Sheet of Cap-paper; put it again into a Cucurbit, fit on a Receiver, and draw off in Sand with a moderate Fire the Spirit of Wine, which will ≈øerve another time for the like Tinctures; then unlute the Ve≈ø≈øels, and pour all the Liquor that remains in the Cucurbit into a glazed Pipkin, and evaporate the ≈øuperfluous Moi≈øture lei≈øurely in Sand, till it come to the Con≈øi≈øtence of a Rob; When it is cold, keep it in a Pot for u≈øe, or you may continue the Evaporation, and reduce this Rob to a real Extract of Coloquintida. It is chiefly u≈øed to purge watry Humours from the remote parts of the Body, and is al≈øo very good for a Drop≈øy. It may be given with Extract of Rhubarb, or alone in Pills, from two or three Grains to eight or ten.

div.head: Oyl of Cinnamon.
div.p:
Brui≈øe four Pounds of good Cinnamon, infu≈øe in it ≈øix Quarts of hot Water, and dige≈øt it in an earthen Ve≈ø≈øel clo≈øe ≈øtopt two days; pour the Infu≈øion into a large Copper Limbeck, and lute a Receiver clo≈øe to it: Di≈øtill with a pretty good Fire three or four Pints of the Liquor; then unlute the Limbeck, and pour into it the di≈øtilled Water; you'll find at bottom a little Oyl, which you mu≈øt pour into a Viol, and ≈øtop it clo≈øe; di≈øtill the Liquor as before; then returning the Water into the Limbeck, take the Oyl you find at bottom of the Receiver, and mix it with the fir≈øt; repeat this Cohobation, until there ri≈øes no more Oyl; then take away the Fire, and di≈øtil the Water that remains in the Receiver, the ≈øame way that Spirit of Wine is rectified, and you'l have an excellent Spirituous Cinnamon Water. The Oyl of Cinnamon ≈øtrengthens the Stomach, and is indeed an excellent Corroborative. After this manner almo≈øt all the Oyls of odoriferous Vegetables may be drawn, as Box,
Ro≈øes, Ro≈ømary, Lavender, Juniper, Cloves, and Ani≈øeeds.

div.head: Di≈øtillation of an odoriferous Plant, ≈øuch as Balm, its Extract, and fixt Salt.
div.p: Take a good quantity of Balm newly gathered, when it is in its Vigour; beat it well in a Mortar, and put it into a large earthen Pot; make a ≈øtrong Decoction of other Balm, and pour into the Pot enough of it, to ≈øweat it ≈øufficiently; cover the Pot, and leave it two days in Dige≈øtion; then put the Matter into a large copper Limbeck, and ≈øet on a Receiver; make a Fire of the ≈øecond Degree under it, and di≈øtil about half the Water; then let the Ve≈ø≈øels cool, and unlute them; you'l find in the Receiver a very good Balm water. Let it ≈øtand open in the Sun five or ≈øix days; then ≈øtop it, and keep it for u≈øe.

Pre≈øs thro' a Linnen Cloath, that which remains in the Body, and let the Expre≈ø≈øion ≈øettle; filter and evaporate the Water with a gentle heat in an earthen Ve≈ø≈øel, till there remains an Extract of the con≈øi≈øtence of Honey.

Dry the re≈øidence that remains after expre≈ø≈øion, and burn it with ≈øtore of other Balm likewi≈øe dryed; you may obtain an Alkali Salt from the A≈øhes by a Lee in Water, which being filtred, evaporate it in a Gla≈øs, or earthen Ve≈ø≈øel in Sand, there will remain a Salt, which you may make white by calcining it in a Crucible in a ≈øtrong Fire.
The Water, Extract, and Salt of all odoriferous Plants, ≈øuch as Sage, Marjoram, Thym, Mint, Hy≈ø≈øop, and the like may be drawn after the ≈øame manner.

div.head: The Di≈øtillation of a Plant, that is not oderi≈øerous, ≈øuch as Carduus benedictus, and its e≈ø≈øential Salt.
div.p:
Take a good Quantity of Carduus Benedictus, when it is in its prime; pound it in a Mortar, and fill with it two thirds of a Limbeck; draw by expre≈ø≈øion a ≈øufficient
quantity of the Juice of other Carduus, and pour it into the Limbeck, that the Herbs ≈øwiming in the Juice may not ≈øtick to the Bottom, during the di≈øtillation: Di≈øtil with a Fire of the ≈øecond Degree, about half as much VVater, as you u≈øed Juice.

Pre≈øs thro' a Linnen Cloath that which remains in the Limbeck; let the Juice ≈øettle, and after it is filtred, evaporate with a ≈ømall Fire about two thirds of the Liquor in an earthen, or gla≈øs Ve≈ø≈øel; ≈øet this Ve≈ø≈øel in a cool place, and leave it there eight or ten days, there will ≈øhout out Cri≈øtals round about the Ve≈ø≈øel; Separate them, and keep them in a Viol well ≈øtopt, the≈øe Cri≈øtals are called the e≈ø≈øential Salt. The extract of Carduus may be al≈øo made as the Extract of Balm was. Succory, Fumitory, Sorel, Scabius, Cre≈ø≈øes, and all other Plants, that are not odoriferous, which yield good ≈øtore of Juice, mu≈øt be di≈øtilled like Carduus Benedictus; and this method may ≈øerve to draw the e≈ø≈øential Salt out of any Plant what≈øoever.

div.head: Spirit of Wine Tartarized.
div.p: Fill a large Bolt-head with a long Neck half full of Brandy, and fitting a Head and Receiver, lute clo≈øe the Junctures; ≈øet your Bolt-head upon a Pot half filled with Water, to di≈øtil in a vaporous Bath: The Spirit will ≈øeparate from the Flegm, and ri≈øe pure; continue the Fire till nothing more di≈øtils, ≈øo you'l have a pure Spirit of Wine at the fir≈øt di≈øtillation. Put a Pound of Salt of Tartar into a long Gla≈øs Body; pour upon it two Quarts of Spirit of Wine prepared, as above; place your Ve≈ø≈øel in Sand, and cover it with a Head, to which fit a Receiver; lute well the Junctures with a wet Bladder, and give it a gradual Fire, which continue until three parts of the Spirit of Wine are ri≈øen; then remove the Fire, and keep this Spirit in a Viol well ≈øtopt.

div.head: Queen of Hungary's Water.
div.p:
Gather Ro≈ømary Flowers, when they are at their
be≈øt, and fill a Gla≈øs Cucurbit half full with them; pour on them a ≈øufficient quantity of Spirit of Wine, to infu≈øe them; ≈øet the Cucurbit in a Bath, and joyning its Head and Receiver, lute clo≈øe the Junctures, and give it a dige≈øtive Fire for three days; then unlute them, and pour into the Cucurbit that which has bin di≈øtilled; refit your Limbeck, and increa≈øe the Fire ≈øtrong enough to make the Liquor di≈øtil drop by drop, and when you have drawn about two thirds of it, put out the Fire; let the Ve≈ø≈øels cool, and unlute them. Keep the Water in a Viol well ≈øtopt.

div.head: Laudanum.
div.p: Cut into ≈ølices four Ounces of good Opium, and put it into a Bolt-head; pour upon it a Quart of Rain Water well filtred; ≈øtop the Bolt-head, and ≈øetting it in the Sand, increa≈øe your Fire by degrees, to make the Liquor boyl for two hours, ≈øtrain it warm, and pour it into a Bottle. Take the Opium, which remains undi≈ø≈øolved in the Rain Water, dry it in an earthen Pan over a ≈ømall Fire, and putting it into a Matra≈øs, pour upon it Spirit of Wine to the height of four Fingers; ≈øtop the Marra≈øs, and dige≈øt the Matter twelve hours in hot A≈øhes; afterwards ≈øtrain the Liquor, and there will remain a glutinous Earth, which is to be flung away. Evaporate both the≈øe Di≈ø≈øolutions of Opium ≈øeparatly in Gla≈øs Ve≈ø≈øels in a Sand Heat, to the Con≈øi≈øtence of Honey; then mix them, and evaporate to the Con≈øi≈øtence of a ≈øolid Extract.

div.head: Extract of Aloes.
div.p: Di≈ø≈øolve in a ≈øufficient quantity of Juice of Ro≈øes, eight Ounces of Soccatrine Aloes; after the di≈ø≈øolution is ≈øettled five or ≈øix hours, decant it, and when you have filtred it, evaporate the Liquor gently, till it comes to the Con≈øi≈øtence of an Extract.

div.head: Di≈øtillation of Tabacco.
div.p:
Put into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit eight Ounces of good Tabacco
cut ≈ømall; pour upon it about an equal weight of Flegm of Vitriol; cover the Cucurbit with its Head, and dige≈øt the Matter in Sand for a day; fit to it a Receiver, and di≈øtil about five Ounces of Liquor with a ≈ømall Fire; keep it in a Viol. It is a ≈øtrong Vomit. The Do≈øe is from two Drams to ≈øix in ≈øome proper Liquor. It is likewi≈øe good for Tetters, and the Itch, the parts being gently rubbed with it. Put that which remains in the Cucurbit-into an earthen Retort; place it in a Furnace, and fit to it a great Receiver, and luting clo≈øe the Junctures, begin with a ≈ømall Fire to rai≈øe all the Flegm; increa≈øe the Fire by little and little, and the Spirits will come forth with a black Oyl; continue the Fire till there comes no more. Let the Ve≈ø≈øels cool, and unlute them. Pour that which you find in the Receiver into a Tunnel lined with brown Paper; the watry part will pa≈øs thro', while the black and foetid Oyl remains in the Filter. Keep it in a Viol. A Dram of it may be mixed with two Ounces of Hogs Grea≈øe; it is a good remedy for the Itch and Tetters. This Oyl is very de≈øtructive to ≈øeveral Animals, e≈øpecially to Cats; for if a ≈ømall Drop of it be dropt upon the Tongue, it occa≈øions deadly Convul≈øions, and the Creature peri≈øhes, if Spirit of Sal Armoniac be not pre≈øently applyed to the No≈øtrils. Of the Juice of Tabacco the Italians make an Oyntment, which they count very good for ≈øordid Ulcers. The Spaniards are much delighted with Tabacco of their own growth, which is very ≈øweet, and be≈øt to make ≈øneezing Powder. The Portugue≈øe mo≈øt e≈øteem Bra≈øil Tabacco, which is very ≈øtrong, and very narcotic. The People of China and Japan have Tabacco, but they u≈øe it ≈øparingly, as do the Turks and Per≈øians. The Engli≈øh and Dutch e≈øteem Virginia Tabacco, which they ≈øometimes mix with Ma≈øtich, Ambar, Harts-horn, Lavender, Bettony, Sage, according to their Con≈øtitution.

div.head: Di≈øtillation of Turpentine.
div.p: Take three Pounds of good Turpentine, and pour it into a Retort large enough to remain half empty; add to it an handful of Stupe, to prevent the thicker parts of the Turpentine from ri≈øing, when the Liquor di≈øtils; you mu≈øt clean≈øe the in≈øide of the Neck of the Retort, and place it in a Furnace to di≈øtil in an open Fire; fit to it a Receiver, and luting the Joynts, begin the di≈øtillation with a very ≈ømall Fire, only to warm the Retort, and to drive out a volatile Spirit; after which increa≈øe the Fire by degrees; there will come forth fir≈øt a clear Oyl, then a yellow Oyl, and at la≈øt a red Oyl; Take care to ≈øeparate the≈øe Liquors, as they do di≈øtil, and when you ≈øee the red Oyl begin to come thick, take away the Fire, and when the Ve≈ø≈øels are cold, unlute them; keep all the≈øe Liquors ≈øeparately in Viols. The volatile Spirit is an excellent Aperitive. It is given from four to twelve Drops in ≈øome proper Liquor, to expel Gravel, and for nephritic Pains. The fir≈øt Oyl ≈øerves for the ≈øame u≈øes, as the Spirit. The ≈øecond and third ≈øerve as a Bal≈øom to heal Wounds, to a≈ø≈øwage Swellings, and to fortify the Nerves.

div.head: Oyl of Camphor.
div.p: Put into a Matra≈øs three or four Ounces of good Camphor gro≈øly beaten, and pour upon it twice as much Spirit of Niter; ≈øtop your Ve≈ø≈øel clo≈øe, and ≈øet it over a Pot half full of Water a little heated; ≈øtir it now and then to help forward the Di≈ø≈øolution, which will be fini≈øhed in three Hours, and then you'll find the Camphor turned into a clear Oyl, which ≈øwims above the Spirit; ≈øeparate it, and keep it in a Viol well ≈øtopt. It is u≈øed for the Caries of Bones, and to touch Nerves that are uncovered.

div.head: Oyl of Myrrh per Deliquium.
div.p:
Boyl Eggs until they are hard; then cutting them in two, ≈øeparate the Yolk, and fill the White with
Myrrh powdered; ≈øet them on little Sticks placed conveniently in an Earthen Pan, in ≈øome moi≈øt place, and there will di≈øtil a Liquor to the Bottom of the Ve≈ø≈øel, which you mu≈øt keep for U≈øe. It clears the Face from Spots.

div.head: Di≈øtillation of Vipers.
div.p: Put ≈øix Dozen of Vipers dryed in the Shade into a coated Gla≈øs Retort; ≈øet it in a reverberatory Furnace; fit to it a large Receiver, and lute the Joints clo≈øe; then begin the Di≈øtillation with a ≈ømall Fire to warm the Retort gently, and to drive out a flegmatic Water Drop by Drop; when this Water cea≈øes to drop, increa≈øe the Fire a little, and Spirits will come forth, which will fill the Receiver with white Clouds, and at la≈øt a black Oyl will di≈øtil, and a little volatile Salt will ≈øtick to the Sides of the Receiver; continue the Fire till there comes no more; then let the Ve≈ø≈øels cool, and unlute them; ≈øhake about the Receiver a little, that the volatile Salt may fall from the Sides, and pour it all into a Bolt-head, fit to it, with a Head, and a ≈ømall Receiver, and lute the Joints with a wet Bladder. You mu≈øt place your Ve≈ø≈øel in Sand, and with a gentle Fire under it, the volatile Salt will ≈øublime, and ≈øtick to the Head, and uppermo≈øt Part of the Bolt-head. Separate it, and keep it in a Viol well ≈øtopt.

It is an excellent Medicine, good for malignant Fevers, Agues, Pox, Apoplexy, Falling-Sickne≈øs, Pal≈øy, Hy≈øterick Di≈øea≈øes, and the Bitings of all venomous Bea≈øts. The Do≈øe is from ≈øix to ≈øixteen Grains in ≈øome proper Liquor. That which remains in the Bolt-head mu≈øt be turned into a Tunnel lined with brown Paper; the Spirit and Flegm will pa≈øs through, but the ≈øtinking Oyl will remain behind; with this Oyl Paralytick Parts may be anointed. The Spirit and Flegm mixed confu≈øedly, mu≈øt be put into an Alembick, and di≈øtilled in a vaporous Bath, till half the Liquor comes off, and you'll have a Spirit, that
mu≈øt be kept well ≈øtopt. It is much of the ≈øame Virtue with the Salt. The Do≈øe is from ten to thirty Drops. The volatile Salt of Harts-horn may be drawn the ≈øame way, and al≈øo the Spirit.

div.head: Di≈øtillation of ∆≤rine.
div.p: Take of ≈øound Young Mens Urine, newly rendred, twelve Quarts; evaporate it in an Earthen Cucurbit, in a Sand Heat to the Con≈øi≈øtence of Honey; put on an Head and Receiver, and lute the Joints clo≈øe; make a ≈ømall Fire, to draw off what remains of the Flegm; then increa≈øe it by degrees, and the Spirit will ri≈øe with a little Oyl, and afterwards the volatile Salt, which will ≈øtick to the Head; keep up the Fire, till there comes no more; then unlute the Ve≈ø≈øels, and ≈øeparate the volatile Salt, and put it into a Bolt-head, and pour upon it the Spirit that is in the Receiver; then put a Blind-head to the Bolt-head, and lute the Joints with a wet Bladder; then ≈øet the Bolt-head on Sand, and ≈øublime with a ≈ømall Fire all the volatile Salt, and keep it in a Viol well ≈øtopt. It operates by Urine and Sweat, is good for Agues, and malignant Fevers, and opens Ob≈øtructions. The Do≈øe is from five to fifteen Grains in ≈øome proper Liquor. That which remains in the Bolt-head mu≈øt be filtred; the Spirit will pa≈øs through the Filter, but the ≈øtinking Oyl will be kept behind.
The Spirit may be di≈øtilled in a Sand Heat, to ≈øeparate it from a thick Matter, which remains at Bottom. It has the ≈øame Virtues as the Salt. It is given from eight to twenty Drops.

div.head: Di≈øtillation of Honey.
div.p:
Put four Pound of good Honey into a large Earthen Body, and di≈øtil the Water in a moderate Sand Heat, until acid Drops begin to come; then put out the Fire, and keep the Water for U≈øe. It makes the Hair grow, the Roots of the Hairs being moi≈øtened with a Spunge dipt in it, Put what remains in the Body
into a Gla≈øs-coated Retort, whereof two Thirds mu≈øt remain empty; ≈øet the Retort in a reverberatory Furnace; then put on a large Receiver, and lute the Joints; then begin the Di≈øtillation with a gentle Fire for three Hours, to warm the Retort; then increa≈øe it by degrees, and the Spirits will ri≈øe with a little black Oyl, and fill the Receiver with Clouds; continue the Fire till it will di≈øtil no longer; then unlute the Ve≈ø≈øels, and ≈øeparate the Spirit from the black Oyl in a Tunnel lined with brown Paper. This Spirit opens Ob≈øtructions, and may be dropt into Juleps to make them plea≈øantly acid.

div.head: Crocus Metallorum.
div.p: Take of Antimony and Niter, each one Pound; powder them, and mix them well together; put this Mixture into an Iron Mortar, and cover it with a Tile; but leave an open place, to put in and take out a live Coal; when the Coal is put to it, the Matter will flame, and cau≈øe a great Detonation, which being over, and the Mortar grown cold, ≈øtrike again≈øt the Bottom, that the Matter may fall down; then ≈øeparate the Dro≈øs from the ≈øhining part with an Hammer. This is called Liver of Antimony, which being wa≈øht ≈øeveral times, with warm Water, is called Crocus Metallorum. The Do≈øe of it is from two to eight Grains.

div.head: Gla≈øs of Antimony.
div.p:
Take of Antimony powdered, one Pound; calcine it in a ≈ømall Fire in an unglazed earthen Pot. Stir the Matter continually with an Iron Spatula, until Vapours ri≈øe no longer: But if, notwith≈øtanding your ≈øtirring, the Powder ≈øhould chance to run into Lumps, as it often does, put it into a Mortar, and powder it, and calcine it again, and when it will fume no more, and is of a gray Colour, put it into a Crucible, cover it with a Tile, and ≈øet it in a Wind Furnace, and make a very ≈øtrong Coal Fire to melt the Matter. Uncover
the Crucible about an Hour afterwards, and put the End of an Iron Rod into it, to ≈øee whether the Matter that ≈øticks to it is become diaphanous; if ≈øo, pour it upon a Marble Stone well warmed, and it will congeal, and you'll have the Gla≈øs of Antimony. Cool it, and keep it for U≈øe. It is a violent Vomit. The Do≈øe is from two to ≈øix Grains.

div.head: Di≈øtillation of Guiacum.
div.p: Fill a large Retort three quarters full with Guiacum ra≈øped; place it in a reverberatory Furnace, and put on a large Receiver; begin the Di≈øtillation with a Fire of the fir≈øt Degree, to warm the Retort gently, and to di≈øtil the Water, which they call Flegm; continue it in this condition, until there come no more Drops, which is a Sign that all the Flegm is di≈øtilled. Throw away that which you find in the Receiver, and fitting it again to the Neck of the Retort, lute well the Junctures. You mu≈øt afterwards encrea≈øe the Fire by degrees, and the Spirits, and Oyl will come forth in white Clouds; continue the Fire until there comes no more; let the Ve≈ø≈øels cool, and unlute them; pour that which is in the Receiver into a Tunnel lined with brown Paper, ≈øet upon a Bottle, and the Spirit will pa≈øs through, and leave the black Oyl in the Tunnel; pour it into a Viol, and keep it for U≈øe; it is an excellent Remedy for Rottenne≈øs of Bones, for the Tooth-ach, and to clean≈øe old Ulcers. It may be rectified, as Oyl of Ambar is, and may be u≈øed inwardly in the Epile≈øy, Pal≈øy, and to expel the Secundine. The Do≈øe is from two Drops to ≈øix.

div.head: Cornachine Powder.
div.p: Take of Antimonium Diaphoreticum, Diagrydium, and Cream of Tartar, each equal Parts. The Do≈øe is from twenty to forty five Grains.

div.head: Sweet Spirit of Niter.
div.p:
Put eight Ounces of good Spirit of Niter, and ≈øo much Spirit of Wine alcoholized into a large Bolthead;
≈øet it upon Straw in a Chimney, and the Liquor will grow hot, without Fire under it; and half an Hour, or an Hour afterwards, it will boyl very much; have a care of the red Vapours that come out apace, at the Neck of the Bolt-head; and when the Ebullition is over, you'll find the Liquor clear at the Bottom, and to have lo≈øt half what it was. Put it into a Viol, and keep it for U≈øe. Sweet Spirit of Niter is good for the Wind-Cholick, and nephritick Pains, for Hy≈øterick Di≈øea≈øes, and all Ob≈øtructions. The Do≈øe is from four to eight Drops in ≈øome proper Liquor.

div.head: Sweet Spirit of Salt.
div.p: Take of Spirit of Salt, and Spirit of Wine, each equal Parts; mix them, and ≈øet them in Dige≈øtion for two or three Days in a double Ve≈ø≈øel, in a gentle Sand Heat. It is good to expel Gravel. The Do≈øe is from four to twelve Drops, in ≈øome convenient Liquor.

div.head: Sal Prunellae.
div.p: Take of purified Salt-peter, two Pounds; put it into a Crucible, and ≈øet the Crucible in a Furnace among burning Coals; when the Niter is melted, throw into it one Ounce of Flowers of Sulphur, a Spoonful at a time, the Matter will pre≈øently flame, and the more volatile Parts of the Salt-peter will fly away. When the Flame is over, the Matter will remain in a very clear Fu≈øion. Take the Crucible out with a Pair of Tongs, and pour the Matter into a clean Bra≈øs Ba≈øon, a little warmed; ≈øhake about the Ba≈øon to ≈øpread the Matter while it is cooling. Sal Prunellae is cooling, and dinretick, is good for Fevers, Quin≈øeys, and the running of the Reins, and for all Di≈øea≈øes that are occa≈øioned by Heat, and Ob≈øtructions. The Do≈øe is from half a Dram to a Dram in ≈øome proper Liquor.

div.head: Tincture of Ambar.
div.p:
Make a fine Powder of ≈øix Ounces of yellow Ambar, put it into a Bolt-head, and pour upon it rectified Spirit
of Wine, to the Height of four Fingers; put another Bolt-head into this, and ≈øo make a double Ve≈ø≈øel; lute the Joints well with a wet Bladder, and dige≈øt it five or ≈øix Days in hot Sand, till you have a good Tincture; then pour off the Tincture, and put more Spirit of Wine to the Matter; dige≈øt as before, and mix it with the other Tincture; filtrate them, and di≈øtill them in a Limbeck, and draw off with a ≈ømall Fire half the Spirit Wine, and keep the Tincture in a Viol well ≈øtopt. It is good for hy≈øteric Di≈øea≈øes, the Pal≈øy, Falling-≈øickne≈øs, and Apoplexy. The Do≈øe is from ten Drops to a Dram in ≈øome proper Liquor.

div.head: De≈øtillation of Ambar.
div.p:
Powder Ambar gro≈øly, and fill with it two Thirds of a coated Gla≈øs Retort; ≈øet it in a Furnace on two Iron Bars, and put on a large Receiver; lute the Joints clo≈øe, and with a ≈ømall Fire warm the Retort, and drive out the Flegm; then increa≈øe the Fire by little and little, and there will di≈øtil a Spirit, and an Oyl; continue the Fire, until there comes no more; then let the Ve≈ø≈øels cool, and unlute them; pour a Pint of warm Water into the Receiver to di≈ø≈øolve ≈øome volatile Salt that ≈øticks to the Sides; pour all the Liquor into a Gla≈øs Limbeck; put on a Receiver, and lute the Joynts clo≈øe; heat the Ve≈ø≈øels with a ≈ømall Fire; afterwards increa≈øe it a little, and the Spirit and Water will ri≈øe, and with them a little white Oyl; continue the Fire until no more ri≈øes, and the thick Oyl remains at the Bottom, without boyling; ≈øeparate the white Oyl that ≈øwims upon the Flegm and Spirit, and keep it in a Viol well ≈øtopt. It is u≈øed inwardly for the Falling-≈øickne≈øs, Pal≈øy, Apoplexy, and hy≈øteric Di≈øea≈øes. The Do≈øe is from one Drop to three in ≈øome proper Liquor. To ≈øeparate the Water and Spirit, you mu≈øt pour them both into a Gla≈øs Di≈øh, and evaporate over a very ≈ømall Fire, two Thirds of it; that which remains is Spirit of Ambar;
keep it in a Viol well ≈øtopt. It is good for the Scurvy, Jaundice, ≈øtoppage of the Urine, and for Ulcers in the Neck of the Bladder. The Do≈øe is from twelve to twenty four Drops in ≈øome proper Liquor. The black Oyl mu≈øt be kept for external U≈øes.

div.head: Volatile Salt of Ambar.
div.p: Powder two Pounds of Ambar, put it into a large Earthen Cucurbit, whereof three Parts mu≈øt be empty; place it in Sand, put on the Head, and a ≈ømall Receiver, and lute the Junctures clo≈øe; keep a ≈ømall Fire under, for about an Hour; then when the Cucurbit is grown hot, increa≈øe the Fire lei≈øurely to the third Degree, and there will drop fir≈øt a Flegm and Spirit, afterwards the volatile Salt ri≈øes, and ≈øticks to the Head in Cri≈øtals, then there di≈øtils an Oyl, fir≈øt white, then red; when the Vapours cea≈øe, put out the Fire, and when the Ve≈ø≈øels are cold unlute them; bru≈øh the volatile Salt together with a Feather, and put it into a large Viol, whereof three Parts mu≈øt be empty; place the Viol in Sand, and ≈øtop it only with Paper, and with a little Fire ≈øublime the pure Salt in fair Cry≈øtals to the Top of the Viol; take the Viol from the Fire, when you perceive the Oyl ri≈øe; break the Viol, and put the Salt into another Viol well ≈øtopt. This Salt is good for the Jaundice, Difficulty of Urine, Ulcers in the Bladder, the Scurvy, and hy≈øteric Fits, and is excellent for all Ob≈øtructions. The Do≈øe is from eight to ≈øixteen Grains in ≈øome proper Liquor.

div.head: Cinnabar of Antimony.
div.p:
Take the Caput Mortuum of Antimony, remaining after the Di≈øtillation of the Butter; put it into a ≈ømall Gla≈øs Retort well coated, and place it in a reverberatory Furnace; the Flame mu≈øt not touch the Neck of the Retort; continue the Fire an Hour and an half, and all the Caput Morttum will be ≈øublimed in the Neck of the Retort into the Sub≈øtance of Cinnabar; break the Retort, and ≈øeparate the ≈ømall Faeces. Powder
the Cinnabar, and ≈øublime it again in a new Retort. It is an excellent Medicine both in young and old, and without doubt like an Alcali. It attemperates the Acrimony of the Humours. The Do≈øe is two Grains.

div.head: Bezoardicum Minerale.
div.p: Melt in hot A≈øhes two Ounces of the Butter of Antimony, put it into a Bolt-head, drop upon it good Spirit of Niter, till the Matter is quite di≈ø≈øolevd; while it is di≈ø≈øolving, Vapours will ri≈øe from it, which you mu≈øt carefully avoid, and therefore it is be≈øt to place it in a Chimney. Pour the Solution into an Earthen Pan, and evaporate it over a gentle Sand Fire, till it is dry; a white Ma≈øs will remain, which you mu≈øt let cool; then pour upon it two Ounces of Spirit of Niter; ≈øet the Ve≈ø≈øel again in Sand, and evaporate as before; pour again two Ounces of Spirit of Niter, and after the Moi≈øture is evaporated, increa≈øe the Fire a little, and caldine the Matter half an Hour; then put out the Fire, and you'll have a white Powder. Keep it in a Viol well ≈øtopt. It forces Sweat. The Do≈øe is from ≈øix to twenty Grains in ≈øome proper Liquor.

div.head: Butter of Antimony.
div.p:
Take of Regulus of Antimony powdered, ≈øix Ounces; of ≈øublimate Corro≈øive powdered, one Pound; mix them, and put them into a Gla≈øs Retort, half whereof mu≈øt remain empty; place your Retort in Sand, put on a Receiver, and lute the Joints; then kindle a ≈ømall Fire, and there will drop a clear Oyl; after that increa≈øe the Fire a little, and white thick Liquor like Butter will come forth, which you mu≈øt melt with live Coals, placed near the Neck of the Retort, that it may run into the Receiver. Continue Fire until you ≈øee a red Vapour come forth; then take away the Receiver, and place another in its Room filled with Water; increa≈øe the Fire by Degrees, and
when the Retort is red hot, the Mercury will run into the Water. Dry it and keep it for U≈øe as other Mercury. Butter of Antimony clean≈øes Ulcers, and eats down proud Fle≈øh.

div.head: Common Regulus of Antimony.
div.p: Take of Antimony ≈øixteen Ounces, of crude Tartar, twelve Ounces; of purified Niter, ≈øix Ounces; powder them, and mix them well together; then make a large Crucible red hot, throw in a Spoonful of the Mixture, and cover it with a Tile, till the Noi≈øe is over, and ≈øo do by Spoonfuls, one after another, until all the Matter is ca≈øt in; then make a great Fire about it, and when the Matter has been a while in Fu≈øion, pour it into a Mortar grea≈øed with Suet, and heated; then ≈øtrike the Sides of the Mortar with a Pair of Tongs, to make the Regulus fall to the Bottom. When it is cold, ≈øeparate the Dro≈øs that remains in the Top with an Hammer; powder it, and melt it in another Crucible; then throw into it a little Niter, and it will flame a little; then pour out the Matter into the Mortar well clean≈øed and grea≈øed, and let it cool.

div.head: Diaphoretic Antimony.
div.p:
Take of Antimony, one Part; of purified Niter, three Parts; mix them well together, and ca≈øt a Spoonful of this Mixture into a red hot Crucible, in the Fire; you'll hear a Noi≈øe, and when the Detonation is over, throw in another Spoonful, and ≈øo do, till all the Powder is in the Crucible; keep a great Fire about it two Hours; then ca≈øt the white Matter into an Earthen Pan, filled almo≈øt with clear Water, and leave it ≈øteeping warm ten or twelve Hours, that the fixed Salt-peter may di≈ø≈øolve in it; ≈øeparate the Liquor by Inclination, wa≈øh the white Powder that remains at the Bottom five or ≈øix times with warm Waand dry it. It is ≈øudorifick, good for malignant Fevers, and other malignant Di≈øea≈øes. The Do≈øe is
from ≈øix Grains to thirty in ≈øome proper Liquor.

div.head: Oyl of the Barks of Oranges and Citrons.
div.p: Take of the fre≈øh Barks of Oranges or Citrons, what Quantity you plea≈øe; infu≈øe them till they putrify; then di≈øtil them in a ≈øufficient Quantity of Water. This Oyl heats, dries, is diaphoretick, kills Worms, and is alexipharmic.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: EXcellent purging Pills, prepared by the Author, are to be ≈øold by Mr. Henry Bonwick at the Red Lion in St. Paul's Church-yard: They cure the Scurvy, the mo≈øt reigning Di≈øea≈øes of this Kingdom; they purge the Head, Brea≈øt, Stomach, and Reins, and clean≈øe the Blood, and are a very proper Purge for tho≈øe that cannot confine them≈øelves when they want purging, but are forced to go abroad about their Bu≈øine≈øs. The Price of each Box is one Shilling ≈øix Pence, with Directions for U≈øe.

div.head: Books printed for Henry Bonwicke at the Red Lion in St. Paul's Church-yard.
div.p: COllections of Acute Di≈øea≈øes, in five Parts: 1. Of the Small-Pox and Mea≈øles; 2. Of the Plague and Pe≈øtilential Fevers: 3. Of continual Fevers: 4.
